4.8.1 Does 16:8 constitute the end of the gospel?. 200

5 Notes. 202

 

 

 

1           Prologue: Good News of Gods Return to his People (1:115)

1)      Indicates the content of the Gospel: Jesus Christ, the Son of God.

a)      Son of God is Marks primary Christological identity for Jesus (DJG 2d ed).

b)      Appears in the beginning, middle, and end.

2)      1:113 is the ἀρχή of the good news about him.

3)      Functions as the lens for reading the story of Jesus in the rest of Mark. Provides key for understanding this by strong presence of christological material.

a)      1:1

b)      1:23

c)      1:78

d)      1:911

e)      1:1213

4)      The appeal to 2 prophetic texts establishes the essential outline and themes of Marks gospel (1:1-3). It also grounds the Gospel in Israels prophetic hopes and prepares us for John (the messenger whom these prophets spoke (4-8) and then Jesus, the Lord, whose coming the prophets foretold and for whose coming JB was to prepare (9-15) (NIVSB).

1.1         Heading (1:1) [1]

1)      Function of 1:1

a)      Introduction and theme verse for the entire book.

i)       This book is the beginning of the good news about Jesus

b)      *Introduction for the prologue (1:18; Stein || 1:113; Cranfield, Lane || 1:115; Guelich, France.[1]

i)       This (i.e., the immediately following story) is how the good news of Jesus begins. The rest of the book fills out the content of the gospel.

2)      Ἀρχὴ:

a)      ἀρχή: temporal beginning of the description of a series of events || first things, elementary principles, or rudimentary elements.

3)      Gospel of Jesus Christ (τοῦ εὐαγγελίου Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ):

a)      the following account is presented as a gospel and the subject is Jesus Christ, the Son of God

b)      Gospel

i)       Greco-Roman Context

(1)   We think of the birthday inscription in honor of Caesar Augustus. For example, see the recent and very helpful M. E. Boring, K. Berger, and C. Colpe, Hellenistic Commentary to the New Testament (Nashville: Abingdon, 1995). The relevant part of the Priene Inscription is cited along with Mark 1:1 on p. 169.[2] See also P. Oxy. 1021 in honor of Nero.

(2)   Inscription from Priene (9 BCE). It celebrates the benefactions of Augustus, whom providence has sent as a savior and who brought peace and an end to war.

(a)   since Providence, which has ordered all things and is deeply interested in our life, has set in most perfect order by giving us Augustus, whom she filled with virtue that he might benefit humankind, sending him as savior (σωτήρ), both for us and for our descendants, that he might end war and arrange all things, and since the Caesar through his appearance (ἐπιφανεῖν) has exceeded the hopes of all former good messages (εὐαγγέλια), surpassing not only the benefactors who came before him, but also leaving no hope that anyone in the future would surpass him, and since for the world the birthday of the god was the beginning of his good messages (ἦρξεν δὲ τῷ κόσμῳ τῶν δι αὐτὸν (sc. τόν Σεβαστὸν) εὐαγγελίων ἡ γενέθλιος ἡμέρα τοῦ θεοῦ) [may it therefore be decided that (OGIS 458)[3].

(3)   Comparison with Mark

(a)   Mark (εὐαγγέλιον) || Priene (εὐαγγέλια)

(b)   Mark (ἀρχή) || Priene (ἄρχω)

(c)   Good news is brought by a divine agent: Mark (Jesus the anointed one, the Son of God; Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ [υἱοῦ θεοῦ]) || Priene (Augustus, savior, benefactor, θεός.). Moreover, in many papyri, Augustus is referred to as υἱὸς θεοῦ. Moreover, the appearance of ἐπιφανεῖν emphasizes the divine appearance of Augustus.

(4)   See also Ferguson, Backgrounds, 46.

(5)   Juxtaposition of these 2 images sovereignty of God || sovereignty of Rome; kingdom of God || kingdom of Rome; authentic peace comes not through the subjugation of people (or the pax Romana) but through their release by God, and through the restoration of Gods people

ii)     *Gospel (εὐαγγέλιον) and the verbal preach the good news (εὐαγγελίζομαι) denote the fulfillment of OT promises in a re-creation of a fallen world and the redemption of the people of God from judgment and death, the inbreaking of Gods kingdom

(1)   *Isaianc good news: coming of God (40:9); saving reign of God in peace and justice (52:6), work of God on behalf of the outcasts (61:12). The good news of God concerns his salvation, i.e. well-being in the truest and fullest sense for humanity.

(2)   The presence of the OT citation that gospel should be understood in the OT background, and that this OT gospel has found its fulfillment in Jesus.

iii)   Here, it is the good news about Jesus Christ, his life, ministry, death, and resurrection. The statement as it is written primary horizon is Israels narrative and Isaiahs prophetic hopes of restoration.

c)      Ἰησοῦ Χριστοῦ (Jesus the Messiah; NIV)

i)       *objective genitive (Guelich, Stein) || subjective genitive (1:1415; Cranfield) || both.

ii)     Χριστοῦ:

(1)   *Focuses on Jesus role as the Messiah, the vice-regent in Gods kingdom || name, rather than a title (Stein).

4)      [υἱοῦ θεοῦ]: key Christological title in Mark.

a)      Synonymous with Χριστός (2 Sam 7:14; Ps 2:7).

b)      Against an OT background, the title is not so much a claim to deity as one that points to a true humanity and the authentic people of God (Carson-Moo)

i)       Describes Israel, then of David (2 Sam 7), and righteous individuals (Sir 4:10)

ii)     In Mark, it indicates Jesus unique relationship to God the Father (esp. 1:11; 9:7).

c)      Divine Sonship. Its use in the title developed understanding within the later church (France).

5)      Jesus Christ, Son of God

a)      Rhoads, Mark as Story, 50, suggests that theres a progressive confirmation of this in the gospel. Jesus is affirmed as the Christ by Peter mid-way through the book, and Jesus is confirmed as Son of God by the centurion at the end of the book.

1.2         Prologue (1:213) [13, 16, 18, 20]

1)      Some put the prologue at 1:1415 with matching references to gospel in 1:1, 1415.

2)      Spirit:

a)      Outpouring of the Spirit eschatological age.

b)      Here, Spirit is tied to the ministry of Jesus. OT expectation that the Spirit will reside on the Servant of God (Isa 42:1). So, references to Spirit show messianic significance of Jesus as one who is empowered by the Spirit and who dispenses the Spirit, a role that is reserved only for Yahweh.

3)      Desert

a)      *Place of hope and new beginning (Jer 2:23; Hos 2:1415). In Isa 40:35, the voice in the wilderness which introduces visions of restoration is followed by New Exodus, a new beginning in the wilderness (Isa 41:1819; 43:1921; 44:34).

i)       JBs ministry in the wilderness probably arose from his desire to fulfill Isa 40:3. In the same way, the location of the Qumran community in the wilderness was also to fulfill Isa 40:3.

ii)     Some connect JB with the Qumran community, but we dont really know.

b)      Place of divine succor and comfort

c)      Place of testing

4)      The presence of Spirit and desert in 1:213 sets the stage for the rest of the gospel, giving a view of the behinds-the-scenes, a larger than life dimension filled with cosmic conflict (1:1213). In 1:14, we come down to earth and see normal inhabitants of Galilee who are bewildered. But Mark doesnt want us to forget the truths laid out here (Hooker).

1.2.1        The forerunner: John the Baptist Prepares the Way (1:28) [13, 16]

1)      Emphasis

a)      John the Baptist: The opening verse may be paraphrased: The beginning of the gospel of Jesus Christ was the appearance in the wilderness of John the Baptist (Achtemeier, ABD). one cannot understand the significance of Jesus Christ apart from John the Baptist.

i)       JB is the precursor of Jesus in his preaching of repentance (1:4 || 1:15) and also in his final fate.

ii)     Marks narrative focuses primarily on Jesus. When it does not, it focuses on John the Baptist.

iii)   Failure to understand JBs ministry by the chief priests and scribes lead also to failure to understand Jesus ministry (11:2732).

b)      *Jesus: Stein argues that the emphasis should not be on John the Baptist but on Jesus and how the ministry of John the Baptist sheds light on Jesus.

i)       Fulfillment of scripture new covenant (14:24) is not a rejection old but the culmination of the old.

ii)     Baptism of the Holy Spirit Jesus comes with the power and prerogative of God, ushering in the new eschatological age.

c)      *Isaiah: Green interpreting Guelich, France note that 1:1 is better translated as The beginning of the gospel concerning Jesus Messiah, Son of God, as written by the prophet Isaiah. The beginning of the good news does not lie with the advent of Jesus but with Isaiah. Marks story of the significance of Jesus ministry has its roots in the promise of liberation of Israel from the bondage of exile as related by Isaiah.[4] Thus, it is not that Mark or some part of Marks opening chapter is the beginning of the good news. Rather, it is Isaiah.

 

1)      Isaianic Quote: Jesus is Isaiahs Promised Lord (1:23)

a)      These verses locate Jesus mission and message in the context of Isaiahs great hopes of a new exodus from exile. (NIVSB).

i)       Jesus story fulfills Isas prophecy that God would rescue his people and restore Jerusalem to a light to the nations (NIVSB).

b)      Quote is a combination of Mal 3:1 (elements drawn from Exod 23:20) and Isa 40:3.

i)       Attribution to Isa

(1)   Mark used a now-lost testimonium.

(2)   *Because it is more well-known and is the most important source.

(a)   Isa is the most influential OT prophetic work in the NT and in Mark (NIVSB).

(3)   *Similar to 2 but using his sandwich structure, Mal/Exod reference modifies the Isaianic material that frames it.

c)      It is written: OT citation to confirm a statement; intensive perfect shows its abiding value.

d)      I send: shows divine initiative

e)      messenger: Jesus || *John the Baptist.

i)       John is the culmination of prophetic heralds sent by God (Osborne).

ii)     One rabbinic school understood prophecy to have ceased with Malachi. So, the presentation of John as a prophet is a daring claim the beginning of the end (France).

f)       Lord God, but allows Christian reader to equate Lord = Jesus.

i)       Mark replaced τοῦ θεοῦ ἡμῶν (Isa 40:3 LXX) in εὐθείας ποιεῖτε τὰς τρίβους τοῦ θεοῦ ἡμῶν with αὐτοῦ, shifting focus to of the Lord and thereby helping the assimilation of Lord = Jesus.

g)      OT context:

i)       New Exodus:

(1)   Book of Isaiah is typically divided into 3 sections with Isa 4055 dealing with the end of the Babylonian exile, typically understood as the New Exodus.

(2)   Isa 40:35 evoke the exodus. These verses call for the preparation of the way for Yahwehs return to deliver his people so that all flesh may know his glory. The preparation of the way for Yahwehs arrival naturally implies the same for his redeemed peoples return to Zion.

(3)   Isa 4055 draws extensively from Israels first exodus. But the original exodus pattern is transformed into a grander new exodus: deliverance of the exiles from the power of Babylon and its idols, Yahwehs leading of and provision for his blind people along the way, and his arrival and enthronement in a gloriously restored Zion. But Isa. 40:3 is key: without Yahwehs presence (cf. Isa. 40:5, 9, 10, 11) there can be no salvation. It is his advent as a mighty warrior that is the sine qua non of Israels deliverance (40:1012; 51:911; 52:1012) (CNTUOT).

(4)   But these great hopes did not come to fruition. Consequently, the New Exodus was delayed until finally effected in the future messianic servant of Jesus.

ii)     Isa

(1)   The messenger encouraged exiled Israel to believe the announcement of Gods coming in a powerful new exodus to redeem and lead them to a restored Jeruslaem. However, when they were back in their homeland, Israels continued disobedience meant God had not returned to dwell with them (NIVSB).

iii)   Mal

(1)   Malachi declared that God would send his messenger (i.e. Elijah) to purify the priesthood (Mal 3:3) in preparation for the returning Lord and his great judgment against the wicked (Mal 3:5; 4:5). If Israel failed to respond, then when the Lord came suddenly to his temple (Mal 3:1), he would curse the land (Mal 4:6) (NIVSB).

iv)   Significance in Mark

(1)   JB is the messenger; Jesus is the long-awaited presence of God himself that has come to save his people. Israel must repent and believe. If they and their priesthood fail to respond to the proclamation of Jesus messenger, the coming of the Lord to his temple will instead mean devastation (ch. 13) (NIVSB).

v)      Other contours of Isaianic hope

(1)   Coming of JB in the wilderness (Mark 1:911 || Isa 42:1; 61:1)

(2)   Jesus in the wilderness (Mark 1:1213 || Isa 40; 65)

(3)   Jesus proclamation of the gospel of God (Mark 1:1415 || Isa 40:9; 52:7; 61:12)

h)      Function:

i)       Role of JB

(1)   All 4 Gospels emphasize JBs role in preparing for Jesus.

(2)   Describes the ministry of John the Baptist; he is Malachis prophesied Elijah, whose task is to prepare Israel for Gods return to Jerusalem and his temple. Thus, Israel must listen to him if they are to avoid the curse that Yahwehs coming might bring.

ii)     Christological: Jesus is Isaiahs promised Lord. He is God. See Marks modification of Isa 40:3 above. The Isaianic references indicate Jesus identity and mission.

(1)   He has come to effect Isaiahs long-awaited new exodus, he is not only Israels Davidic and Isaianic servant Messiah who embodies all that Israel was called to be (1:1011) but also as Marks opening sentence implies in some mysterious way the very presence of God himself (1:23) (CNTUOT).

(2)   Just as Yahweh promised to deliver Israel from the strong man Babylon (Isa 49:2425), to lead his blind people (Isa 42:16) back to Jerusalem, so also will Jesus deliver Israel from the strong man Beelzebul, lead the blind followers (e.g. Bartimaeus) back to Jerusalem (CNTUOT).

(3)   Demonstrates that Jesus ministry is the fulfillment of Gods divine plan of redemption, and that Jesus is coming as the Lord.

(a)   If so, emphasis is on See, I am sending my messenger ahead of you, who will prepare your way; 3 the voice of one crying out in the wilderness: Prepare the way of the Lord, make his paths straight.

(b)   The way of the Lord is a people made ready by John for Yahwehs intervention by means of the mightier one.

(4)   The good news of Jesus (1:14) is the Isaianic gospel of the inbreaking of Gods kingdom.

iii)   Warning (function of Mal 3:1):

(1)   Mal addresses disappointment of the apparent failure of Isaiahs new exodus or the promised prosperity of Haggai. Malachi defends Yahwehs integrity, declaring that the present misfortune is the result of the faithlessness of the priesthood and people. Malachi affirms the certainty of Yahwehs coming. Nevertheless, the presence of a corrupt priesthood will only result in judgment. So, Yahweh mercifully sends his messenger Elijah to purify Israel before Yahweh comes.

(2)   There is thus an underlying judgment motif which is finally realized in the cursing of Israel and the prediction of the destruction of the temple.

iv)   Ecclesiological: Hearing John and following Jesus are the marks of true Israel. To refuse to do so is to reject the possibility of living with Yahweh in the restored Zion.

2)      Ministry of John the Baptist: John is Malachis Promised Elijah (1:48) [13, 16]

a)      John: Means the Lord is gracious. Johns call to repentance is Gods gracious preparation for his coming (NIVSB).

b)      Not John the Baptist (as a title) but John the baptizer or the baptizing one (substantival participle βαπτίζων). Only Mark uses John the baptizer, though he also uses John the Baptist.

c)      wilderness:

i)       Place where Israel first became Gods people (Exod 19) and where God would purify them (Ezek 20:3538). Against the backdrop of Isa 40:3, Johns location underlines the significance of his mission in preparation for Gods new exodus (NIVSB).

d)      Baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins.

i)       Qumran: daily ritual washings

ii)     Normative Judaism: single initiatory proselyte baptism for Gentiles

iii)   John: single initiatory baptism, signaling a new commitment.

(1)   For Jews: remnant theology. To be a Jew is not enough; one must be baptized for the repentance of sins to be part of the people of God.

(a)   Baptism was an initiatory rite for Gentiles John perhaps saying that the self-satisfied Jews were no better than the Gentiles.

(2)   μετανοίας: cause || producer || purpose || source baptism arising out of repentance || descriptive repentance baptism (Wallace, Stein).

(a)   This repentance baptism is not so much because it is commanded by God. Rather, it is because he is coming and brings with him the kingdom of God that one should repent. Thus, it is preparatory for the christological and eschatological events that are going to take place, in preparation for the Stronger one (Stein).

(b)   Outward sign of heartfelt repentance toward God in preparation for his coming. Israels prophets had consistently called Israel to repentance in order that they might know Gods gracious forgiveness and be reconciled to him (NIVSB).

(3)   Uniqueness: Not that it was administered by John or that it was a once-for-all or that it accompanied repentance, but that it resulted in forgiveness of sins.

(a)   Not ex opere operato. It is repentance, rather than baptism, that leads to forgiveness. Josephus, Ant. 18.117, notes that baptism is not meaningful unless it was preceded by a commitment to ἀρετή, in the form of δικαιοσύνη towards one another and εὐσέβεια towards God.

(4)   εἰς ἄφεσιν ἁμαρτιῶν:

(a)   The goal of this repentance-baptism was for the forgiveness of sins that was yet to come, and which was to accompany the baptism of the Spirit by the Greater One (Guelich).

e)      whole all: Hyperbole emphasizing Johns impact but also emphasizing the spiritual hunger of the people (NIVSB).

f)       Went out:

i)       From Judea/Jerusalem to ἔρημος: Repudiation of Jerusalem, which according to nationalist ideology was considered the hub of the world to which all the nations would come.

ii)     Its been nearly 4 centuries since they truly saw a prophet. Thus, the people were excited (NIVSB).

g)      confessing their sin: Biblical prereq for national reconciliation, it indicates the centrality and genuiness of their repentance. Johns ministry is presented as inaugurating the fulfillment of Isaiahs new exodus, which Jesus himself would complete through his baptism in the Spirit and his death as the suffering servant (NIVSB).

h)      They were baptized by him: Jewish proselyte baptism was typically self-administered (Stein). Thus, here, it highlights Johns prophetic role and the distinctiveness of his baptism.

i)       His appearance: Reinforce prophetic image, esp. in the mold of Elijah (2 Kgs 1:8).

j)       His diet: Typical food found in the wilderness, again John ministered in the wilderness, in fulfillment of Isa 40:3.

i)       JBs rough attire and clean desert food (Lev 11:2122) mark him as one living apart from an impure and self-indulgent Israel (NIVSB).

k)      Johns preaching (1:78) [16]. Gives reason for the repentance baptism for the forgiveness of sins.

i)       Emphasis of preaching: ἔρχεται, emphasized by placement at the beginning: He is coming. Therefore, repent and be baptized.

ii)     ἰσχυρότερος:

(1)   Historically, how did John understand this: God || eschatological prophet of Deut 18:15 || *Messiah || Son of Man || unknown prophet.

(2)   In the context of Isa, this echoes the prophets promise that the mighty God, who was more powerful than Israels oppresors, would come to judge his foes and restore Zion. Israels deliverance is at hand. (NIVSB)

(3)   He is greater because of his greater divine authority as seen in his exorcism, healings, and miracles, and the role he would play in the redemption of the world (Stein).

(4)   OT passages do not anticipate a human figure; coming of Jesus is the coming of God. Again, showing that υἱὸς θεοῦ is more than a synonym for Messiah (France).

(a)   If JB did not anticipate that the stronger one was God, why did he consider himself to be the one calling in the wilderness (John 1:23), a passage which anticipates not a human figure but the coming of God himself? (Lau) ???. Unless, the understanding of this passage at that time was to the coming of the Messiah.

iii)   after me:

(1)   ὀπίσω μου is a t.t. for discipleship, // to ἀκολουθέω. Some speculate that Jesus is a disciple of John. If so, then the disciple is now greater than his master.

(2)   *temporal: Jesus comes after Johns time.

iv)   untie: Most lowly task, too low for disciples and even for Hebrew slaves. John is not even worthy to be Jesus slave.

(1)   Suggests that Jesus is more than a mere mortal.

v)      baptize with the HS:

(1)   Q: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire.

(a)   Jesus is more than a mere mortal, since, in Johns Bible, only God is the one who would pour forth the Spirit.

(2)   The difference between the baptism of John and Jesus (or the baptism that he institutes for the church) is not the form of baptism (immersion) or medium of baptism (water), but the benefits associated with it.

(a)   Both baptism of John and the early church associated baptism with repentance and the forgiveness of sins. But Jesus ushered in the arrival of the new age.

(3)   eschatological pouring out of the Spirit, the mediation of Gods presence, and a sign of the Last Days.

(4)   The bestowal of the Spirit expressed metaphorically as a baptism signified Gods eschatological act of salvation promised long ago by the prophets. Therefore, the Baptist was declaring the dawn of a new day of salvation, not simply a new baptism. (Guelich)

(5)   In the OT, bestowal of the Spirit is the prerogative of God. Here, Mark shows that Jesus will come with the power and prerogative of God.

(6)   In Isa 63:11, God sends his Holy Spirit among Israel as they pass through the sea. The prophets also declared that God would pour forth his Spirit on the people in the last days. The combination of wilderness, passing through water (in the exodus), and the promised Spirit suggests that Johns baptism is a reenactment of the exodus, particularly described in Isa 63:11, in anticipation of Gods pouring out of the promised last-day Spirit on his redeemed Israel. (NIVSB)

1.2.2        Baptism of Jesus (1:911) [18]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christological:

i)       Events confirm that Jesus is the Son of God

(1)   Heavens torn apart; Spirit descends upon Jesus; voice from heaven.

b)      Eschatological

i)       Coming of the long-awaited Spirit

ii)     Return of the prophetic voice in John the Baptist, the returning Elijah.

iii)   Dawn of the messianic age

c)      Relationship: Christological developments usher in the eschatological.

2)      Function

a)      The language recalls what God says to his anointed one (i.e. the king) in Ps 2:7 and to his servant on whom he puts his Spirit so that he can bring justice to the world (Isa 42:14). Function of the baptism then is to initiate Jesus into the office of Gods coming king.

 

1)      Jesus came from Nazareth of Galilee

a)      Possibly in contrast to those who came from Judea/Jerusalem. Animosity between Galilee and Jerusalem in NT

i)       Northern and Southern Israel were divided after Solomon.

ii)     Galilee surrounded by Gentile communities on East, North, and West. Moreover, bisected by the Via Maris with its multitude of travelers; so southern Jews viewed Galilee with suspicion. Galileans were at best tolerated by people in Jerusalem.

iii)   See France, Matthew, 57. He notes some differences may be oversimplified as follows:

(1)   Racially: Area of N. Kingdom had a more mixed population. Here, some conservative Jewish cities (Nazareth, Capernaum) were in close proximity to large pagan cities such as Tiberias or Sepphoris.

(2)   Geographically: Separated from Judea by Samaria; and from Perea (in the S.E.) by the Decapolis.

(3)   Politically: Politically separated after Herod the Great died.

(a)   Herod Antipas: Galilee and Perea

(b)   Archelaus: Judea until AD 6; then procurators.

(4)   Economically: Galilee offered better agricultural and fishing resources than the mountainous Judea. The wealth of some Galileans was envied by Judeans.

(5)   Culturally: Judeans despise Galileans as their country cousins, lacking Jewish sophistication and surrounded by Hellenistic centers.

(6)   Linguistically: Galileans spoke a distinct form of Aramaic that was looked down upon by Judeans. See Matt 26:73 For your accent betrays you.

(7)   Religiously: To Judeans, Galileans were lax in their observation of proper ritual, arising primarily from their distance from the temple and religious leadership in Jerusalem.

b)      Nazareth: insignificant village even by Galilean standards. See Nathanaels (a Galilean) remark in John 1:46 (Nazareth! Can anything good come from there?). Thus, improbable candidate for the ἰσχυρότερος.

2)      was baptized

a)      Savior identified with those he came to save.

b)      Matthews fulfill all righteousness πληρῶσαι πᾶσαν δικαιοσύνην.

i)       Matts addition is an attempt to explain Marks difficulty.

ii)     πληρόω:

(1)   bring to completion: to complete all that God has set out for him to do (Osborne).

(2)   prophetic fulfillment: Jesus prophetically fulfills the righteousness that is found in Isa 53:11 (PNTC).

iii)   *δικαιοσύνη not in the moral sense, but as the obedience of both John and Jesus (for us) to the will of God in salvation history.

(1)   δικαιοσύνη in Matt is conduct which God expects of his people obedience to Gods will. Jesus therefore obeys his fathers will (i.e. he fulfills all righteousness) by signaling his determination to take on the role of the suffering servant and the role of the obedient son (confirmed by Gods response, Thou art my son in whom I am well pleased).

(2)   By baptism and the giving of the Spirit, John and Jesus together show their obedience to Gods will to inaugurate the fulfillment of Gods salvation plan.

iv)   2 significance

(1)   Salvation-historical: Jesus needs to be baptized so that the savior can identify with those he came to save (numbered with the transgressors; Isa 53:12) in preparing for the saving activity of God (Hagner).

(2)   Jesus obeys his Fathers will by assuming the role of the righteous Suffering Servant (Isa 53:11).

3)      Heavens opened: indicate a vision.

a)      *σχίζω occurs 2x in Mark, here and in the tearing of the temple (15:38).

i)       Both are divine eschatological intervention: beginning of Jesus public ministry (baptism) and end of Jesus public ministry, results of his death (tearing of the veil).

ii)     Both are tied to key moments of revelation: Both moments reveal Jesus identity as the Son of God. Here, it is Gods voice. In Mark 15:39, the next verse immediately after the tearing of the veil, the centurion remarks, Truly, this man was the Son of God.

(1)   The impact of this as the revelation of Jesus identity as the Son of God is further strengthened if the title in 1:1 is not authentic.

(2)   But 15:39 centers on the tearing of the veil which does not appears as a revelatory moment.

b)      *Possible allusion to Isa 64:1 Oh, that you would rend the heavens and come down (Watts).

i)       Isa 5566 is typically understood in a postexilic context where Isaiah laments and petitions over Israels condition in the aftermath of a meager return (CNTUOT).

ii)     In Isas last prayer (63:7-64:12), Isa recalls Yahwehs mighty deeds of the exodus, pleads with Yahweh to break his silence to again split the heavens and come down. If allusion is true, then Isaiahs final lament has been answered. God has come down to deliver his people. In some strange way, Jesus is not merely Yahwehs agent but God himself.

4)      Spirit descended like a dove:

a)      *Fulfills expectation that the Messiah will be given Gods spirit (Isa 11:2; 42:1; 61:1; 63:11), the anointing of Gods chosen servants for a particular task. The one who is to baptize with the HS is now shown to be able to do so.

b)      Like a dove: *adjectivally (cf. Luke 3:22 bodily form as a dove) || adverbially.

i)       Symbolism is unclear.

c)      Did Jesus have the Spirit before his baptism? No.

i)       The baptism suggests that from this point on, Jesus does what he does and says what he says under the guidance and power of the Spirit (Mark 1:12; cf. 3:29).

5)      The voice of God

a)      *Juxtaposes Ps 2:7 (coronation of the Messiah who would rule the nations; Ps 2 is a messianic Psalm) and Isa 42:1 (servant of God as one whom he delights who will bring salvation to Israel and be a light to the nations).

i)       Two contrasting ideas (Messiah & Servant) are brought together, bringing together divine sonship and suffering servant. Divine sonship is defined in terms of obedience, which is defined in terms of the Suffering Servant.

(1)   {Note that the OT does not consider Messiah as Son of God}

b)      Greek (my Son, the beloved one ὁ υἱός μου ὁ ἀγαπητός). Son unique sonship; beloved only (as in 12:6 where the beloved son must be an only son since he is the heir; Stein); relationship similar to the Johannine μονογενής.

c)      Matt: This is my beloved son with him I am well pleased someone else heard it. Perhaps it was Matts rewording to show that the heavenly voice spoke not only for Jesus benefit but also for the crowd (and for those who later read about the story), i.e., Matt turns it into a public proclamation. Perhaps, it was for John to confirm the decision to baptize Jesus. Regardless, the change can be understood as ipsissima vox.

i)       The Gospel of the Ebionites have the heavenly voice speak 2x (once as in Matt, once as in Mark). But this is unnecessary.

6)      No hint that Jesus became or was adopted as Gods son at his baptism. Rather, the baptism is the launch of his public ministry, for which he as the Son of God, is well prepared.

7)      Function of Ps 2 and Isa 42

a)      Christology:

i)       Messiah: Jesus is Davids messianic heir who will prevail over his enemies (Ps 2); he is also Yahwehs Spirit-anointed servant who will deliver servant Israels blind and deaf captives.

ii)     Suffering servant: In Isa 42, Israels enigmatic servant is both individual and corporate, in that he was also understood to be faithful Israel. The servant reflects what Israel was meant to be as well as characteristics of the nations representative deliverer through whom the ideal will be attained (CNTUOT). So Jesus Son of God designation, his passing through the water (baptism), and his 40 day sojourn identify him with Israels past. As Yahwehs Davidic messianic servant deliverer, he is also the true and faithful Israel.

b)      Opposition: Both Ps 2 and Isa 42 note the presence of opposition. For e.g., the rebellious nations of Ps 2 are represented in Mark by the demons. At the same time, the DSS and Psalms of Solomon understand opposition to Messianic rule to come from apostate Israel. This is echoed in Mark in Israels leadership, especially the Jerusalem authorities.

1.2.3        Temptation: Context of Jesus Mission (1:1213) [20]

1)      Emphasis (Stein)

a)      Example for Christians undergoing persecution. But there is no warrant for this as no harm comes to Jesus.

b)      Contrasts Jesus victory in overcoming temptation vis--vis Israels failure. But there is no explicit comparison here.

c)      Apocalyptic restoration of the pre-fall paradisal bliss through Jesus undoing of Adams failure. But there is no explicit pointer to an Adam-Christ typology.

d)      Once for all defeat of Satan. But there is no clear statement to this effect in Mark.

e)      *Christological: Shows Jesus victory over Satan. He goes into the wilderness, the place of wild beasts and the realm of Satan. He (the one who is Strongerthe Son of God) is ministered by the lesser (angels). Here, with 1:111, we have Jesus, the Son of God, announced by John the Baptist (1:28), anointed by the Spirit (1:10), acknowledged by the voice from heaven (1:11), and approved by testing in the wilderness (1:1213) [Stein].

 

1)      Spirit: Shows Jesus is led by the Spirit after he is anointed by the Spirit.

2)      Shows the context of Jesus mission. Focus is not on the temptation but on the repeated phrase τὴν ἔρημον (2x).

a)      Wilderness: away from human contact, displays the primary figures (dramatis personae) of the coming conflictnot about human supporters or opponents, but of a supernatural conflict (France).

3)      Wild animals: *part of the opposing force that is allied with Satan (France, Stein) || symbol of Edenic harmony (Guelich, Bauckham).

4)      Adam-Christ typology: absent (Stein) || present (Guelich, Marcus).

5)      Q (Keener, Messianic Expectations)

a)      Satan may not be challenging the fact of Jesus sonship, but the nature. Since you are Gods son, you must fit into various worldly expectations for power. But Jesus resists culturally-defined models of power and refuse to accommodate to the expectations of his contemporaries.

b)      Stone to bread.

i)       Magicians were known for trying to transform one substance to another.

ii)     Jesus: Appeals to a biblical model where God himself provided for his son Israel in the wilderness.

c)      Protection of angels

i)       Abuse of privilege.

ii)     Jesus: Do not presume on your relationship with the Father. He alludes to Israels dissastisfaction with Gods provision in the wilderness. Jesus recognizes that his mission will include suffering.

d)      Worship Satan in exchange for the kingdoms of the world

i)       Worship of power. Satan invites Jesus to rule the world without the cross, so long as Jesus first worships Satan.

ii)     Jesus: One must worship God alone.

6)      Redaction

a)      Matt

i)       Satan temps Jesus with kingdoms of the world because it contrasts with Jesus preaching on the kingdom of heaven.

(1)   But note that Luke also has this.

b)      Luke

i)       Luke concludes the temptation account with Jesus at the pinacle of the temple (4:9 ) because it is the thematic epicenter of Luke-Acts

2           Act 1: Galilee (1:148:21)

2.1         Introduction: Essential message of Jesus (1:1415) [30, 32]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Eschatological:

i)       Close of the old covenant, and the ushering in of the new covenant and the kingdom of God.

b)      Christological

i)       Jesus, the Son of God, ushers in the kingdom of God.

2)      Message of Jesus:

a)      Time is fulfilled; kingdom of God has arrived; this arrival is good news; the proper response to this good news is repentance and faith.

b)      This passage sums up the message of Jesus. Mark nowhere else tells us what Jesus spoke to the public when he took the initiative in public discourse. Elsewhere, Jesus usually responds to various situations or is a collection of stories that communicate the kingdom to the people (Marshall, NT Theology).

c)      Why does Mark give us so little info about Jesus message? Perhaps, he considered it more important to talk about the role and identity of Jesus.

 

1)      After: both temporal and eschatological (John belongs to the old era; 2:21). If eschatological, then John closes the old covenant era and the ministry of Jesus ushers in the new covenant and kingdom of God.

2)      John was arrested (παραδοθῆναι): divine passive; possible allusion to the same fate that awaits Jesus. The fates of John and Jesus are tied in 9:1213.

3)      Gospel of God (1:14) || Gospel of Jesus Christ (1:1)

a)      story of Jesus is at a significant level the story of Gods project.

b)      Gospel of God: The author of the gospel is God. The good news is Gods divine plan of the coming kingdom, and it is now being put into effect.

4)      Message

a)      Continuity with John the Baptist

i)       Jesus preaching of repentance in light of the coming of the kingdom of God (1:15) || Johns preaching of repentance in light of the Coming One who brings in the kingdom (1:4). Note that this message of repentance is also preached by the disciples (6:12). (Only occurrence of μετανόεω/μετάνοια are found in these 3 verses)

b)      Gods part

i)       Time is fulfilled: Not χρόνος (chronological time), but καιρός (decisive moment). Decisive moment in salvation history with the fulfillment of the prophetic hope of messianic deliverance.

(1)   Prophets typically announced what God would do in the future. Jesus announcement is primarily of fulfillment.

ii)     Kingdom of God is at hand:

(1)   2 main options: imminent, going to come soon || realized in the person of Jesus (France, Edwards).

(a)   *But France thinks that this question is misplaced. Rather, he notes that to declare that Gods kingship has come near is to say that God is now fulfilling his agelong purpose, rather than to point to a specific time or event which can be defined as either already present or still future, but not both. Again, Gods kingship is both eternal and eschatological, both fulfilled and awaited, both present and imminent.

(2)   Referent:

(a)   Davidic like kingdom that is established in Jerusalem (political)

(b)   spiritual rule of God that is established in the human heart (non-eschatological)

(i)     Liberal theology: fatherhood of God, brotherhood of man, infinite value of the human soul.

(c)   end of history soon occurring and the final judgment to take place (consistent eschatological)

(d)   promised rule of God now having arrived in its entirety (realized eschatology)

(e)   *reign of God now beginning (OT promises are fulfilled, promised Spirit is again active) but the final consummation is still in the future (already but not yet)

(i)     Better to understand the kingdom of God dynamically as a reign rather than as a realm.

(3)   Kingdom and household language is also used of Satan. Since the world is the realm of Satan, the arrival of the kingdom of God invasion and the recovery of territory and people from the enemies kingdom.

c)      Mans part

i)       Repent and believe:

(1)   The announcement of the arrival of the kingdom of God is not a threat but of good news. The proper response is repentance and faith, believing in the good news from God about Jesus Christ, believing that God is acting in what Jesus says and does.

5)      Chronology

a)      In Mark, ministry of John and Jesus do not overlap. But in John 3:224:2, there existed a period of overlap. Reminder that Mark did not write his gospel in order (Papias), and it does not provide a chronological log of Jesus activities.

2.2         Call of the disciples: Formation of the Jesus circle (1:1620) [34]

1)      Theology

a)      Discipleship

i)       If Stein is right that each of the 3 sections begins with a summary statement followed by teachings concerning discipleship (1:1620; 3:1319; 6:713), this passage teaches us about what it means to follow Jesus: repentance and faith (1:15).

ii)     Negative response: (Repentance) Leaving everything behind that might come between us and God.

iii)   Positive response: (Faith) Following Jesus and becoming fishers of men.

b)      Christological

i)       Call for total obedience in discipleship Jesus identity as the Son of God. He is able to make such outrageous claims because he gives more than what he asks. He is the one who gives his life as a ransom for many (10:45).

ii)     Shows the authority of Jesus: He calls and they immediately leave everything and follow him. {Historically, from the Gospel of John, it may not be as dramatic as presented here; but, Mark clearly portrays Jesus as an authoritative leader who calls and people respond; Lau}

 

1)      The kingdom of God comes to a group of socially unimportant people in a remote province of Galilee. Highlights the truth of the parable of the mustard seed.

2)      Jesus base is situated in Capernaum: Focus of the provinces life with (1) its flourishing fish industry and its (2) location on the active trade route to the tetrachy of Philip.

3)      αὐτοὺς ἐν τῷ πλοίῳ καταρτίζοντας τὰ δίκτυα: Odd construction. He saw James and John and them mending their nets. Its as though αὐτούς was added to provide a grammatical subject for καταρτίζοντας. Some render this as an adverbial clause and do not translate the αὐτούς. See reference in Stein.

4)      Follow me (ὀπίσω μου). Here, its followed by ἀκολουθέω and clearly indicates a disciples position in relation to his teacher. See also 1:7.

a)      Relationship between Jesus and disciples is probably not that of a rabbi and his students, but more of a charismatic leader similar to Elijahs call of Elisha. Rabbis did not call their students; they came to him (Hengel, France). Moreover, rabbinic students listened and learned from their rabbis; here, Jesus disciples follow him, spend time with him (3:14), and participate in his mission. Stressing that the initiative lies with Jesus sovereign authority with which Jesus calls the disciples.

i)       Other areas where Jesus differed from rabbis:

(1)   A rabbi typically would have 1 pupil; Jesus called 12.

(2)   Jesus spoke on his own authority, using I say to you or prefixing them with Amen.

b)      Radical discipleship in leaving their occupation (1:18) and family (1:20). But note other references later where they still have access to a boat (3:9; 4:1, 35; 5:21; 6:32, 45, 54; 8:13).

i)       And immediately they left their nets:

(1)   Although εὐθύς can sometimes be a simple connective without significant temporal dimension (1:10), it probably has a full temporal significance here, suggesting the importance of entering the kingdom, that the kingdom is more important than life itself (cf. 8:36).

ii)     This scene is more understandable historically if Peter and Andrew had known Jesus earlier (as in John 1:3542). But Marks portrayal highlights the radical demands of discipleship.

5)      Fishers of men: Fishing imagery is typically of judgment in OT. Here, it is to rescue people from rather than catch them for judgment.

6)      Hired hands: James and John were from a family who could hire workers.

7)      Escalating response: Peter and Andrew leave their nets (possessions, career); James and John not only leave their nets and boat (possessions, career), but also their father (family).

2.3         Jesus healing ministry in Capernaum and Galilee (1:2145): 4 or 5 healing narratives

1)      If we take this as a collection of 4 healing narratives, then its possible to include 2:112 which forms a bridge as healing #5 and controversy #1.

2)      Grouped as 1:2139 (Preaching and healing: General impression) or 1:2145 (Jesus healing ministry in Capernaum and Galilee).

3)      Commonly understood as a typical day in Capernaum showing main features of Jesus ministry: exorcism, healing, and proclamation. But 1:3234 and 1:3538 actually occur on the following day. Moreover, 1:39 and 1:40-45 have no temporal connection with what has proceeded.

2.3.1        Healing #1: Exorcism: Power encounter in the synagogue (1:2128) [3536]

1)      Theology

a)      Christological: Who is Jesus? The Holy One of God.

i)       Christ as an authoritative teacher

(1)   For Mark, Jesus healing, casting out of demons, and preaching are all tied to his teaching ministry.

(a)   Structure

(i)     Summary statement of Jesus teaching (1:21-22) 21 Καὶ εἰσπορεύονται εἰς Καφαρναούμ καὶ εὐθὺς τοῖς σάββασιν εἰσελθὼν εἰς τὴν συναγωγὴν ἐδίδασκεν. 22 καὶ ἐξεπλήσσοντο ἐπὶ τῇ διδαχῇ αὐτοῦ ἦν γὰρ διδάσκων αὐτοὺς ὡς ἐξουσίαν ἔχων καὶ οὐχ ὡς οἱ γραμματεῖς.

1.      Exorcism

(ii)  Comment about Jesus authoritative teaching (1:27) 27 καὶ ἐθαμβήθησαν ἅπαντες ὥστε συζητεῖν πρὸς ἑαυτοὺς λέγοντας τί ἐστιν τοῦτο; διδαχὴ καινὴ κατʼ ἐξουσίαν καὶ τοῖς πνεύμασι τοῖς ἀκαθάρτοις ἐπιτάσσει, καὶ ὑπακούουσιν αὐτῷ.

(b)   Function: This pericope is linked back to Jesus teaching in 1:1415. There, Jesus teaches about the coming kingdom. Here, he manifests the kingdoms arrival in his exorcism.

(2)   Even though Mark lacks most of the teaching material of Jesus in Matt-Luke, it emphasizes Jesus teaching ministry (cf. 2:13; 4:1, 2, 6:2, 6, 34; 8:31; 9:31; 10:1; 11:17, 18; 12:14, 35, 38; 14:49). Reasons:

(a)   *The lack of other teaching/preaching material perhaps shows that Jesus announcement of the arrival of the kingdom of God is the primary message of Jesus. All the miracles then validate this central teaching. (Lau). But do note that there are 2 major teaching sections in Mark (chs. 4, 13). Mark 4 (parables of the kingdom) can be easily tied to 1:15. How about Mark 13? Not sure yet.

(b)   No clear theory for this emphasis (Stein).

ii)     Authority in general (Jesus as an authoritative figure):

(1)   ἐξουσία (1:22, 27); teaching congregation amazed at his ἐξουσία; exorcism visible display of ἐξουσία over demons.

(2)   Other areas of Jesus authority: healing ministry, raising the dead, control of nature, ability to forgive sins (2:10), cleanse the temple (11:2833), give authority to his disciples to cast out demons (3:15; 6:7). Do not just look at occurrences where ἐξουσία occurs.

(3)   ἐπιτιμάω (1:25): Again shows Jesus authority.

iii)   Amazement at Jesus teaching, healings, exorcisms, passion predictions or divine epiphanies.

(1)   astonished (ἐκπλήσσομαι): 1:22; 6:2; 7:37; 10:26; 11:18

(2)   amazed (θαμβέομαι): 1:27; 10:24, 32

(3)   marveled (θαυμάζω): 5:20; 15:5, 44

(4)   feared (φοβέομαι): 4:41; 5:15, 33; 6:50; 9:6, 32; 10:32; 11:18; 16:8

(5)   amazed (ἐξίστημι): 2:12; 5:42; 6:51

(6)   amazement (ἔκστασις): 5:42; 16:8

(7)   Presents Jesus ministry with a miraculous tinge refutes opinion that Mark combats a divine man (θεῖος ἀνήρ) theology.

iv)   Climax: Demons pronouncement, You are the Holy One of God!

b)      Eschatological: Manifestation of the arrival of the kingdom in casting out demons.

 

1)      καὶ εὐθύς: Loose connection lacking distinct chronological meaning (Stein).

2)      Teaching:

a)      Probably no difference between teaching (διδάσκω) and preaching (κηρύσσω) given their interchangeable usage in 6:12 and 6:30. (The teaching here in 1:2122, 27 is linked to Jesus preaching in 1:1415, as his teaching & exorcism here is a manifestation of his preaching of the arrival of the kingdom of God.)

b)      In Matt and Luke, only outsiders (including Judas) address teacher as διδάσκαλε (or ῥαββί). In Mark, it is appropriate for disciples to use it (e.g. Mark 4:38), in Mark, teaching is an important part of Jesus mission.

c)      Astonished (ἐξεπλήσσοντο): Recognition of something out of the ordinary.

d)      Authority: Contrasted with the scribes. Scribes taught by referring to past authority while Jesus teaching was predicated not only on his own authority (Truly, truly, I say ) but also his authority over demons.

i)       Scribes:

(1)   Formerly a secular position. In NT, they were the recognized theological authorities in Jesus day, interpreting biblical texts and serving as guardians of the traditions. They are primarily associated with the Pharisees.

3)      Exorcism:

a)      Background:

i)       Other Greco-Roman sources show interest in exorcism, but very few narratives available.

ii)     In OT, there is no clear example of exorcism. The nearest analogy is the case of David playing the lyre for Saul. Nevertheless, the evil spirit returned after David left Saul. This was not the triumph over evil spirits that we find in the NT.

(1)   Its no wonder then that people would be amazed at the exorcism.

b)      What to us and to you: Means We have nothing in common and Leave us alone

c)      I know who you are:

i)       Commonly believed that exorcists gained power by possessing the demons name. So, the demon here tries to gain control of Jesus by stating his name. But, theres no adversative here (But I know who you are) to show that this is a defensive move on the part of the demons.

ii)     *Interpret this in light of editorial comment of 1:34 (they knew him) demons are reliable spokesperson for Jesus identity, and helps to answer the question, Who is Jesus of Nazareth?

(1)   Demons knowledge of Jesus identity contrasts with the disciples finite knowledge and hard hearts.

d)      Holy One of God:

i)       Used for people who were in a special relationship with God (Elisha, 2 Kgs 4:9; Aaron, Ps 106:16). Here, probably synonymous with Son of God (cf. Luke 1:35; see also the // account where Luke juxtaposes Holy One of God [4:34] and Son of God [4:41]).

ii)     Holy links Jesus with the Holy Spirit whose presence is a mark of the Messiah.

e)      Be silent: Jesus subjugates demons and brings them under his control.

i)       Might indicate secrecy motif || silencing demon is part of the exorcism (France).

f)       Reaction: Beginning of Jesus popularity.

2.3.2        Healing #2: Peters Mother-in-Law: Single healing (1:2931) [37]

 

1)      Continues to show Jesus ἐξουσία over human afflictions. But Jesus is no travelling healer; he responds to different needs as he meets them.

2)      She served them: proof of the healing, she recovered completely.

3)      Sermon outline for Mark 1:2939 by Osborne: Power for ministry is in (1) Jesus; (2) prayer; and (3) willingness to move out to meet the needs of others.

2.3.3        Healing #3: Various diseases; sick healed at evening: general healing ministry (1:3234) [38]

1)      Christology

a)      Jesus authority and power to heal reveal who he is. He has authority over demonic forces (1:2128), physical illness (1:2931), and his great power is emphasized (1:32-34). From 4Q521 (and also Luke 4:1819), God, through the Messiah, will heal the sick, give sight to the blind, raise the dead, free the prisoners, and proclaim good news to the poor.

2)      Secret

a)      Mark notes that demons knew who Jesus is. Thus, they are reliable spokesperson affirming that Jesus is the Holy One of God (1:24), the Son of God (3:11), the Son of the Most high God (5:7). Possible growing intensity.

i)       These affirmations, coupled with divine declarations at the baptism, transfiguration, and Jesus own confession (14:6162; 15:2, 26, 32), support Marks claim that Jesus is the Son of God.

b)      But despite these commands, Jesus greatness cannot be hidden.

 

1)      That evening, at sunset

a)      Dual statements when one would suffice. Other dual temporal statements in 1:35; 2:20; 4:35; 10:30; 13;24; 14:12, 43; 15:42; 16:2.

b)      They bring the sick only at the end of Sabbath, following rabbinic rules on healing.

2)      Mark differentiates between illness and demon possession. Refutes the claim that people in the first century believed all illness were spiritual in nature.

3)      Note the extensive popularity

a)      Brought all; the whole city; healed many.

b)      ἔφερον: continuous nature this is just 1 example of the many Jesus healed.

4)      He would not permit the demons to speak, because they knew him

a)      Introduce the secrecy motif more clearly than 1:25.

2.3.4        Beginning of itinerant preaching ministry: mission expands beyond Capernaum (1:3539) [3940]

1)      Christology

a)      Emphasize Jesus greatness. He cannot be hidden even when he wanted to be alone.

i)       Confirms Marks assertion that Jesus is the Son of God.

ii)     Can be tied to secrecy motif (Lau).

2)      Failure of the disciples

a)      Introduces difference between Jesus program and the disciples expectation. Disciples want to take advantage of the natural human policy, capitalizing on Jesus popularity; Jesus is guided by the impulse of the Father.

3)      Prayer: (Devotional)

a)      In Mark, Jesus prays only 3 times: Here, after feeding of the 5,000; Gethsemane.

b)      Each is at a critical point in his ministry || *Stein, however, argues that in contrast to Luke, Mark does not have Jesus pray at major events in his life. The prayer in Gethsemane is traditional.

c)      Prayer this practice is his source of direction from God and the power to accomplish it.

 

1)      πρωῒ ἔννυχα λίαν: early in the morning, dark[5] exceedingly; temporal duplication.

2)      Everyone is looking for you

a)      In 1:45, 6:3133, this popularity leads to Jesus withdrawal into the wilderness. Jesus is tempted by the public clamor and withdraws from it (Osborne).

3)      Let us go: His primary mission is not to be a wonder worker but to proclaim the kingdom of God.

4)      That is why I came out (ἐξῆλθον):

a)      Significance: Jesus as the divine envoy from God. Perhaps, a hint of the coming into the world of the pre-existent Son of God as in John. Note that Luke 4:43 uses ἀπεστάλην (ἀποστέλλω is commonly used in FG to refer to God sending the Son).

b)      No significance: While ἦλθεν may have Christological significance (2:17; 10:45), here the use of ἐξῆλθον suggests no christological significance (Stein).

5)      1:39

a)      Summary of 1:1438.

b)      Casting out demons again emphasizes arrival of the kingdom of God and the overthrow of the demonic kingdom.

2.3.5        Healing #4: Leprosy: Law of uncleanness (1:4045) [42]

1)      Christology:

a)      Affirms identity Jesus

i)       If baptism designates Jesus as Gods son, this healing demonstrates it. Jesus does what only God can do.

(1)   Moses cries out to God to heal Miriam (Num 12:13)

(2)   Elijah only instructs Naaman, but Jesus touches.

(3)   Priests only pronounce the cure, but Jesus commands the cure.

(4)   In all of this, Jesus shows himself to be greater than Moses, Elijah, or the priesthood.

ii)     Healing of leprosy, like raising the dead, is tied to the coming of Gods kingdom (Matt 11:5; Luke 7:22). Affirms Jesus message that Gods kingdom has come (1:1415) in him.

iii)   In some rabbinic writings, leprosy was Gods way of exiling the wicked, and some considered it a precursor to national exile, such that purification was necessary for restoration. Mark presents Jesus as not only purifying the unclean within Israel but also unclean Israel itself (CNTUOT). Thus, its removal was necessary to Israels restoration from exile.

iv)   Affirms greatness of Jesus: The leper cannot remain silent about Jesus.

2)      Law: Jesus complies with the law.

 

1)      Leprosy: used for a wide range of disease but includes true leprosy (Hansens disease).

a)      Socially, a leper = corpse (Josephus, A.J. 3.11.3 264).

b)      Curing leprosy is likened to a miracle equal to raising the dead (2 Kgs 5:7; b. Sanh 47a).

2)      If you will, you can make me clean: lepers faith. Request for healing rather than ritual pronouncement, which only a priest can do (Osborne).

a)      Jesus reputation has reached even a man that is cut off from society. Emphasize Jesus greatness.

3)      TC in 1:41: σπλαγχνισθεὶς (NA27,28) or ὀργισθείς (D).

a)      NIV84: filled with compassion.

i)       Most manuscripts. Change to ὀργισθείς could be prompted by 1:43 (καὶ ἐμβριμησάμενος αὐτῷ εὐθὺς ἐξέβαλεν αὐτὸν).

b)      NIV: Jesus was indignant.

i)       Easier to explain why a scribe would change ὀργισθείς to σπλαγχνισθεὶς.

ii)     If authentic, its anger at the ravages of the disease, or anger at the doubt in the mans question, If you are willing.

4)      Touched him: Instead of being defiled, Jesus cleanses the man.

5)      Sternly charged him (ἐμβριμησάμενος ἐξέβαλεν):

a)      Strong warning given in light of 1:45; this increased publicity of misdirected popular enthusiasm hindered Jesus mission.

b)      Surprising (can mean enraged). Probably, the suffering caused by the disease, both socially and physically, led Jesus to anger and compassion of the presence of pain and suffering in this world. Anger was not directed at the man, implied by the previous moved by compassion (France).

c)      Secrecy motif. Pre-Markan (Stein, Risnen).

6)      Spread the news: Shows that Jesus glory cannot be contained. When one is touched by Jesus, it is impossible to keep quiet (1:45; 5:20; 7:24, 36).

a)      Hooker (1991:67): The command for silence functions in precisely the opposite way to what one expects: it serves as a means of revelation to the hearers/readers of the gospel.

2.4         Conflict narratives (2:13:6)

1)      Theology

a)      Conflict:

i)       Opponents: γραμματεῖς (2:6), Φαρισαῖοι (2:24); οἱ γραμματεῖς τῶν Φαρισαίων (2:16), and οἱ Φαρισαῖοι μετὰ τῶν Ἡρῳδαινῶν (3:6).

(1)   All 4 gospels present the Pharisees as the core constituent of the opposition, although the Sadduccean priests and elders took the initiative in the final elimination.

ii)     5 episodes that contrast with the growing popularity of Mark 1. Increasing intensity: 2:6 (mental) 2:18, 24 (directed towards disciples) 3:2 (pre-mediated and directed at Jesus) 3:6 (plot to kill Jesus).

iii)   Prepare readers for Jesus passion prediction and death.

iv)   Centers on authority: Is Jesus authorized by God for the ministry he is performing?

b)      Christology

i)       These conflict stories demonstrate Jesus authority and the refusal of the religious authorities to acknowledge it.

ii)     In 1:2145, Jesus is affirmed as the Son of God through miracles. Here, is it by his actions and sayings.

(1)   High point in each account is a Christological statement that answers the question Why (2:7, 16, 18, 24)

(a)   2:10 Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins

(b)   2:17 I came not to call the righteous but sinners

(c)   2:1920 The days will come when the bridegroom is taken away from them

(d)   2:2728 The Son of Man is lord even of the Sabbath

(e)   3:4 Is it lawful on the Sabbath to do good or to do harm, to save life or to kill? (But this is not really Christological? But it shows his authority to interpret what can and cannot be done on the Sabbath).

iii)   Jesus greatness and divine nature emphasized in this pericope by (1) great crowds; (2) heals a paralytic; (3) all were amazed; (4) no one has ever witnessed before what Jesus did no one has done what Jesus could do; (5) reads the hearts of men as God does; (6) exercises divine prerogative in forgiving sins.

c)      Structure

i)       5 stories are framed by 2 healing stories (2:1-12; 3:16) with 3 pronouncement stories in the middle. But this is not exactly clear since 2:112 can also be a pronouncement story.

2)      Notice the questions asked in 2:7, 16, 18, 24.

2.4.1        Healing #5 (Paralytic); Conflict # 1 (Healing and forgiveness) (2:112) [43]

1)      Christology:

a)      Jesus greatness: Big crowds so that theres no place not even around the door.

b)      Divine authority to forgive sins.

i)       Jesus is earlier presented as an authoritative figure, but here, he is one that has authority that equals God.

ii)     No evidence that any man, whether prophet, priest, king, or Messiah had authority to forgive sins (Stein, Hooker). This was a prerogative that only belonged to God.

iii)   Jesus not only has, but he will also exercise Gods authority upon the earth.

c)      New exodus: Jesus is the one who inaugurates Israels eschatological return from exile:

i)       Sins are forgiven (Isa 43:25) and the lame walk (35:6), both indicative of the new exodus.

d)      Ecclesiology, Jesus as the new center of Israel: Priests can only recognize the cleansing of a leper, and the scribes can debate only forgiveness while Jesus actually heals and forgives. Thus, Jesus is the new center around which Israel and its relationship to God is reconfigured. Israels response to him is therefore becoming increasingly important (CNTUOT).

 

1)      In 1:22, Mark contrasts Jesus authority with that of the scribes. There, his teaching authority was supported by his authority over demons. Here, his authority to forgive sins is supported by an actual healing. The scribes face a serious challenge and we see the beginning of their opposition.

2)      Opening (2:12)

a)      Capernaum is his base.

b)      Preach the word: preach the Christian message. In the setting of Jesus, it would probably refer to 1:1415. In Marks day, it would have been understood as the Gospel.

3)      Setting (2:34)

a)      Houses: Excavated houses show rooms that were small, rarely reaching more than 5 meters across. Most houses were single-storey. The roof was typically used for working or sleeping. It was constructed of beams that were thatched with rush and daubed with mud.

i)       Unroofed the roof digging out:

(1)   Dual expression. Matt does not mention it; Luke uses let him down through the tiles (κεράμων) Explanations for Luke.

(a)   Luke contextualizes for building environment of Gentiles in the northern Mediterranean area.

(b)   Luke may be describing the removed lumps of clay with a word that also indicated their function. κέραμος can mean clay as in 2 Sam 17:28; Shepherd of Hermas 4.1.6 2. Some also suggest that tile roofs were used in Palestine (Bock).

(2)   Jesus takes this as an act of faith.

b)      Pallet κράβαττος: slang for a poor persons bed or mattress.

4)      Declaration (2:5):

a)      Faith: Rudimentary faith that Jesus as Gods anointed is able to heal.

b)      Your sins are forgiven: Not a divine passive (ἀφίενται; PPI). Jesus is not stating a fact, i.e. Your sins have been forgiven by God || God has forgiven your sins. Rather, he is doing the actual forgiving.

5)      Reaction of the leaders (2:67)

a)      It is blasphemy:

i)       In OT, only God could forgive sins.

(1)   Gods very identity is the forgiveness of sins. Gods self identification tied to the forgiveness of sins is only found in Exod 34:67 (first exodus); Isa 43:25 (new exodus). Given Mark 1:23, Isa 43:25 is probably in view.

ii)     Mishnah defines blasphemy narrowly as pronouncing the divine name. But in pre-70, the term was probably used more broadly: any claim to do what God could only do, infringing on his divine prerogative. See John 10:33 because you being a man are making yourself God.

iii)   Blasphemy is a capital offence (Lev 24:1016)

iv)   Jesus is blaspheming here not because he is claiming to be God or pronouncing the sacred name of God, but because he acts like God, exercising a prerogative that only God has.

6)      Pronouncement: Authority (ἐξουσία) to forgive (2:911):

a)      Which is easier to say

i)       *Claim to forgive sins

(1)   Note that it is which is easier to say not which is easier to do.

(2)   Goes from more difficult to easier. If the more difficult (healing a lame person) can be done, this guarantees that the easier (claim to forgive sins) claim is also true.

ii)     Neither is easier, since both cannot be done by men, but is a prerogative of God alone.

b)      You may know: Markan editorial comment for the readers || to the paralytic || *to the scribes.

c)      the Son of Man

i)       Background

(1)   Aramaic circumlocution for I (Vermes; Bauckham)

(2)   *Derives from Dan 7:1314

(a)   But in Dan 7, one like the Son of Man comes to judge sins. Here, Jesus forgives sins, only something that Yahweh can do. There is thus an escalation of the messianic understanding of Dan 7, surpassing that found in 1 Enoch and 4 Ezra

(b)   There was an implied messianism in this term, which was picked up in 1 Enoch and 4 Ezra.

(c)   Dan 7 has no article before Son of Man. The presence of an article in Mark may mean that Son of Man, i.e. the Danielic Son of Man.

(d)   The theological crux of the Son of Man language is Jesus authority. If so, then Jesus does not only have impressive authority, but has an authority that equals God. An authority which was formerly a heavenly prerogative can now be exercised on earth (ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς) because of the Son of Man (who in Dan 7:1314 was given sovereign authority and power over earth).

(3)   Why did Jesus use this term? Although the term had implicit messianic overtones, it was ambiguous and not as explicit as Messiah or Son of David.

7)      Result (2:12)

a)      Note that theres no order to secrecy.

b)      They were all amazed and they glorified God. Opposite reaction to the scribes who accused Jesus of blasphemy.

i)       Shows Jesus greatness.

c)      They have already seen Jesus do similar things (note the ἔφερον in 1:32; same as 2:3). But now it is elevated to the authority to forgive sins.

2.4.2        Conflict # 2: Call of Levi: Disreputable company (2:1317) [44]

1)      Location: Probably Capernaum given by the sea and presence of the τελώνιον (tax office), since Capernaum functioned as a border town between the tetrachies of Philip and Antipas. The location would be a toll station on the Great Trunk Road (mistakenly called the Via Maris)trade route from Damascus to Caesarea through Capernaum. See Moody map 090 for Great Trunk Road.

2)      τελώνης: does not collect direct taxes (poll tax [income and property taxes]) but indirect taxes, customs charged on goods in transit. Levi/Matthew was probably working for a chief tax collector (such as Zaccheus).

a)      Associating with a τελώνης is a provocative action: incur disapproval of the religious authorities and the wrath of patriotic sensibilities of the people.

b)      Sharing a table table fellowship and a symbol of identification. Jesus association with sinners shows (1) hostility and exclusivism of the scribes; (2) inclusive nature of the kingdom of God. The meal symbolizes messianic banquet.

3)      Function:

a)      Christology:

i)       Shows Jesus ability to offer forgiveness of sins towards sinners.

b)      Ecclesiology:

i)       Salvation is offered to the outcast.

ii)     If Jesus is to be the new center of Israel, and if Jesus is reconstituting what Israel is supposed to be, then it shows that the kingdom of God is offered to sinners. Moreover, the conflict and opposition against Jesus by the scribes of the Pharisees shows that they are not part of this Israel that Jesus is forming.

 

1)      Levi:

a)      Is this Levi the same as Matthew, one of the disciples mentioned in 3:18? Probably, since the // account in Matt 9:913 gives Matthew sitting at the tax office. Moreover, list of disciples in Matt 10:3 specifically states Matt the tax collector.

i)       Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 110, argues that Mark did not know that Levi = Matthew. The author of the Gospel of Matt took over Marks call of Levi and changed the name to Matt because he wanted to narrate the call of Matt. He then goes on to show the implication that Gospel of Matt was not written by Matthew. But this is surely circular reasoning.

b)      Levi is here described as the Son of Alphaeus. In Mark 3:18, the apostle James is also called the Son of Alphaeus. So, its possible that Levi may have been the brother of James.

2)      Follow me (Ἀκολούθει μοι) and he followed (ἠκολούθησεν) him: ἀκολουθέω is now a t.t. for discipleship.

3)      Reclining at the table (NASB) κατάκειμαι (2:15) and καταλίνομαι may suggest more of a Symposium than a Jewish meal where people sat. The Symposium, despite its Hellenistic origin, was widely followed in Palestine for more formal or festive meals. This more luxurious meal may messianic banquet.

4)      Accusation (2:16)

a)      Scribes of the Pharisees: Within the Pharisaic sect, there were scribes whose very purpose is to ensure correct observance of the law. Scribes were probably associated with various sects and associations within 1st century Judaism.

b)      Why is he eating : This is not an innocent question, but a hostile question. Eating fellowship, accepting them as friends and brothers. Thus, Jesus eating with tax collectors and sinners he is offering them entrance into the kingdom (cf. story of Zacchaeus; Luke 19:5, 7).

5)      Jesus reply (2:17): Focus on the priority of need.

a)      Those who are well have no need of a physician, but those who are sick.

i)       Note the common metaphor of moral failure/sin and physical illness.

ii)     Need for a doctor to meet his patients; a healer must get his hands dirty (France).

b)      Righteous:

i)       Does not mean that righteous people didnt need forgiveness since the Son of Man gave his life as a ransom for many. Its probably irony to the scribes self-righteousness, i.e. those who think themselves righteous.

c)      Called to what? Probably tied to Jesus κήρυγμα in 1:1415 (Repent and believe the good news). Jesus mission, like Johns, is to call people to repentance and the forgiveness of sins. Notice the τελῶναι καὶ ἁμαρτωλοί (2:15) links with the preceding ἐξουσία ἀφιέναι ἁμαρτίας (2:10). Luke 5:32 makes the connection explicit I have come to call sinners to repentance.

2.4.3        Conflict # 3: Question about fasting: Old and new in religious observance (2:1822) [45]

1)      Christology

a)      Coming of Jesus Christ is an eschatological event that inaugurates the new age, dividing history into BC (before Christ) and AD (anno Dominiin the year of the Lord).

i)       The new age is incompatible with the old age (Judaism).

b)      Alludes to the death of Jesus death is not a tragedy nor did it catch Jesus by surprise.

 

1)      Conflict over fasting (2:1820)

a)      Objection: the disciples were failing to conform to the religious observances of certain Jewish groups.

i)       This was not a required OT act of fasting. OT required only 1 day of fastingDay of Atonement. It was more of an individual choice than a set pattern. Basic meaningrepentance and humility before God.

ii)     Pharisees fast 2x a week (Mon, Thu). See Luke 18:12.

iii)   Criticism directed at the disciples is fundamentally directed at Jesus because it is assumed that the disciples behavior reflected the masters teaching.

b)      Jesus reply assumes that his disciples will fast when he is taken away, but now is not the time to do so.

i)       Focus is on the bridegroom.

(1)   OT typically portrays Yahweh as the bridegroom of Israel, and the marriage as the eschatological relationship with his redeemed, the coming age of salvation (Isa 61:10; 62:45; Hos 2:1420; Ezek 16:7ff).

(2)   In the NT, bridegroom used for Christs relationship to the church.

ii)     Stress the joy of the new age.

iii)   They will fast when the bridegroom is taken away Jesus violent death (ἀπαρθῇ suggests external intervention rather than natural causes).

2)      2 parables supporting the new economy (2:21-22). Shows foolishness of containing the new within the structures of the old.

a)      1st parable: New cloth shrinks when washed and will tear the old garment with which it is placed.

b)      2nd parable: New wine which ferments and expands will burst old wineskins which have become brittle with frequent use.

c)      New cloth and new wine = Jesus teaching; old garment and skins = existing religious traditions and norms of Judaism. The newness of Jesus message of the kingdom of God is incompatible with the existing forms of religion (fasting of the disciples of John and the Pharisees). This is already indicated by the growing opposition against Jesus ministry. Mark also alluded to this by having Jesus ministry (the new) begin only after John (the old) was arrested.

i)       This principle can be applied broadly to Christian traditions within the context of first century Judaism.

ii)     Pauline terminology: The old has passed away; behold, the new has come (2 Cor 5:17); new creation; the new man.

(1)   Newness is tied to Jesus: the new commandment | the new covenant | new exodus (Isa 43:19; See, I am doing a new thing! Now it springs up; do you not perceive it? I am making a way in the wilderness and streams in the wasteland.)

iii)   Example:

(1)   John 9, Jesus healing a man born blind. The Pharisees did not have the categories to understand what Jesus was doing. The blind man who did not have such categories was able to perceive that Jesus had done a miracle.

d)      Ties back to Jesus preaching ἤγγικεν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ (1:15). It is because the kingdom has come that one cannot put new wine into old wineskins.

2.4.4        Conflict # 45: Lord of the Sabbath (2:233:6) [46-47]

1)      History of Interpretation

a)      Some argue that this was added to provide justification for the Sabbath practice of the early church. More likely is the notion that the Sabbath practice of the early church derived from the life of Jesus (his teachings and actions concerning the Sabbath) and in his resurrection on the first day of the week.

2)      Sabbath:

a)      4th commandment of the Decalogue. Shows Jews to be the people of God. Pious Jews were willing to die rather than fight in self-defense against Antiochus Epiphanes (until they realized it was not pragmatic). In general, only a life threatening situation superseded the requirement of the Sabbath.

b)      The Essenes would not assist one out of the pit or help an animal give birth on the Sabbath (CD 10:1411:18).

c)      The Book of Jubilees (written around the same period) still advocates death penalty for those who break the Sabbath (Jub 50:8, 13; cf. Exod 31:1415).[6]

3)      What was work?

a)      Halakhic law,[7] codified in the Mishnah, and realized in the 39 prohibited acts clarified the meaning of work (m. Sabb. 7:2). Intentional breaking of the Sabbath was still a capital offence.

b)      There was room for debate concerning the Sabbath halakhah. But Jesus did not debate, he simply ignored the issue. Jesus did not specifically reject the Sabbath law. The issue was the understanding of what was permissible and what was not. By his assertions, he instituted his own authority and overturned the authority of halakhic law.

4)      Jesus and the Law (See Law in DJG).

a)      Did Jesus abrogate the Sabbath?

i)       No clear evidence.

(1)   The OT prohibits work on the Sabbath but gives few details about what constitutes work. The scribal traditions tried to fill in this void. Jesus and his disciples clearly violated these scribal traditions in plucking grain and healing people whose lives were not in danger. But it is difficult to say whether these actions are clear violations of the Mosaic Law. The most that can be said is that Jesus initiative in healing on the Sabbath stretches the Sabbath commandment. But we have no evidence that Jesus himself ever violated, or approved of his disciples violating, the written Sabbath commandment.

(2)   Jesus humanitarian ministry is not intended to abrogate but to define the Sabbath. Just as the father works on the Sabbath (John 5:1718), so he is able to do so. He claims an authority over the Sabbath, including the right to interpret, transform or abrogate the Sabbath. But Jesus never actually uses this authority to abrogate the Sabbath.

b)      Sabbath and the love hermeneutic

i)       In Matt, it adds that the disciples were hungry. But the emphasis here is not so much that human need takes precedence over obedience to the Law. Rather, by comparing his disciples with Davids followers, Jesus is comparing himself to David. If Davids followers were justified in doing what was unlawful, so much more the disciples in their service of someone greater than David are justified. The christological focus is emphasized when Matt immediately makes a comparison between Jesus and the temple (Matt 12:56).

ii)     In Mark, there is a strong humanitarian statement: the Sabbath was made for man (i.e. for mans benefit), not man for the Sabbath. This does not mean that one can break the Sabbath because of human needs, but that the Sabbath must be understood within this framework. The Sabbath is truly obeyed only when human need is factored into ones decision making process. So, rather than being a violation of the Law, Jesus Sabbath-day healing of a woman is a true fulfillment of the law (it was necessary [ἔδει] that she be healed on the Sabbath; Luke 13:16).

iii)   For Jesus, the 2 basic commandments (love for God and for others) must always be considered in interpreting the meaning of the Law.

2.4.4.1       Conflict #4: Plucking grain: Sabbath conflict (2:2328) [46]

1)      Christology: Shows Jesus divine authority.

a)      Authority of Jesus greater than that of Israels greatest king, David. In other gospels, Jesus is portrayed as greater than Abraham (John 8:53), Jacob (John 4:12), Jonah and Solomon (Matt 12:3841), the temple (Matt 12:6).

b)      Since Sabbath was made for man (i.e. for his benefit), and since Jesus as the Son of Man is lord over humanity, Jesus is also lord over the Sabbath.

i)       Previously, Mark has shown Jesus divine authority to forgive sins, to offer tax collectors and sinners entrance into the kingdom of God, and to turn fasting into feasting. Here, Jesus is viewed on par as God, who is understood in the OT to be Lord of the Sabbath (although that is not a title applied to God) because he instituted the Sabbath.

ii)     If you interpret that what the disciples were doing is against the Law (harvesting on the Sabbath), then this story allegiance to Jesus takes precedence over following the Law.

c)      Marks Jesus does not debate what constitutes work or Sabbath. Rather, the fundamental issue is the relationship between Torah and the Son of Man. If regulations to protect the holy could be set aside for David, how much more so for those with Daniels messianic Son of Man, who has supreme authority over the Sabbath. The primary issue here is not Sabbath, but Christology.

 

1)      Dispute (2:2326)

a)      making way: odd expression, possible allusion to Marks new exodus motif in 1:23 (CNTUOT).

b)      2 possible objections

i)       *Plucking the heads of grain on the Sabbath constituted work, which was not permitted (Exod 34:21; Jub 2.2930). The charge of breaking the OT law was more severe than the previous charge of following the traditions (voluntary fasting).

(1)   But does plucking grain constitute the harvesting in Exod 34:21? Its debatable.

ii)     Exceeding the permitted travel length on the Sabbath.

c)      Christs response from 1 Sam 21:16. Appeal to Scripture for a precedent.

i)       Logic of Jesus argument.

(1)   The Law allows for exceptions as in the case of David and in the present. Certain basic needs trump the ritual keeping of the law. 1 Sam is not a Sabbath violation, but the principle is the same. Davids need for food took precedence over the argument that sacred food was reserved for priests.

(a)   But the text does not indicate that the disciples were hungry (but see // in Matt 12:1); he does not argue that what David did was lawful (on the contrary, he notes which is not lawful for any but the priests to eat); he does not attack a misunderstanding of the law concerning the Sabbath.

(2)   *Defense focuses on Jesus authority.

(a)   Logic is not whether the action is legitimate. But whether Jesus as Lord of the Sabbath has authority to override conventional interpretations of the Sabbath.

(b)   *The logic of Jesus argument is not that since David did this, everyone else can also do it. Rather, the precedent of what David did because he was David (how much more a fortiori) someone greater than David will be able to do it too. Logic of the argument a personal authority at least as great as David. This logic is also seen in Matt where we have something greater than the temple someone greater than David should be read here too.

(c)   Fits with Marks emphasis so far where Jesus has authority to forgive sins, eat with tax collectors and sinners, and his presence turns fasting into feasting.

ii)     Mention of Davids companions Jesus companions are covered by his authority.

iii)   1 Sam 21 has Ahimelech as the priest. His son Abiathar became high priest throughout Davids reign.

(1)   Translation
