(a)   NIV: In the days of Abiathar the High Priest in the lifetime of Abiathar [who later became well known as the High Priest]

(b)   *RSV, NRSV, NET: when Abiathar was high priest. << Most natural way of reading.

(2)   Resolution

(a)   The error was noticed early. See textual variants.[8]

(b)   Many scholars have hypothesized that one of the three individuals who would have been involved in the transmission of the statement (Jesus who uttered it originally, Mark who wrote it down in the Gospel, or Peter who served as Marks source) was either wrong about Abiathar or intentionally loose with the biblical data in order to make a point. (cf NET notes)

(c)   Difficult grammar:[9] Marks reference of ἐπί + genitive (Abaiathar) is

(i)     to call attention to the section in the scroll where the incident occurs. See also 12:26 in the passage concerning the Bush (Lane).

(ii)  to indicate a wide time frame, i.e. in the days of Abiathar the high priest.

(d)   *The event was associated with the high priesthood of Abiathar (Edwards), probably because Abiathar figures prominently in the David story.

(i)     History may at times replace the lesser known with the greater.

1.      For e.g. Nebuchadnezzar replaces Nabondius as the father of Belshazzar (Dan 5:2, 11, 18) (Marcus, Mark, 241; Collins, Mark, 203 n130). But this may be because father need not mean father but ancestor.

(ii)  Ahimelechs son, Abiathar, became high priest during Davids reign. Marks purpose is to connect this event with the Jerusalem temple (rather than the sanctuary at Nob) (Gundry).

(iii)                        *If the point is to establish an authoritative precedent, then the mention of Abiathar rather than Ahimelech is significant. Abiathar went on to become chief priest of David underscoring Gods affirmation of Ahimelechs decision, his presence with David, and his abandonment of Davids opponent Saul. Similarly, those who oppose Jesus and his disciples are like those who oppose David (CNTUOT).

2)      Pronouncement: Twofold conclusion (2:2728)

a)      Sabbath was made for man:

i)       The purpose of the Sabbath was for mans benefit. But the purpose of this statement is not to give a humanitarian understanding of the Sabbath. Rather, the purpose (ὥστε) of 2:27 is to demonstrate the authority of Jesus in 2:28.

ii)     Moo, however, in the DJG article above argues that the focus is humanitarian.

b)      Son of Man is Lord of Sabbath: Audacious claim.

i)       Shows Jesus eschatological authority and his authority over the law. Jesus is the final interpretation of Torah. In the OT, God is Lord of the Sabbath because he instituted it (Gen 2:3; Exod 20:811; 31:1217; Lev 23:3). Since Sabbath is made for man, Jesus as Lord of humanity (in virtue of being the Son of Man) is also Lord of the Sabbath.

ii)     If the Sabbath was created for humanity, in this case Israel, then how much more (ὥστε) is Daniels messianic Son of Man its Lord who is none other than true-humanity Israels cloud-borne representative and now on earth (2:1) and with Gods authority effecting Israels new-exodus deliverance in his own holy war (CNTUOT).

(1)   The reference to Jesus holy war alludes to Davids secret mission from the king (i.e. supposedly God; 1 Sam 21:2).

2.4.4.2       Conflict #5: Man with the withered hand: Healing and opposition intensified (3:16) [47]

1)      Christology

a)      Authority of Jesus

i)       The issue of this passage is not so much on the legal issue of whether it is lawful to heal on the Sabbath. Rather, it centers on the authority of Jesus. As Lord of the Sabbath, Jesus has the authority to redefine what is appropriate to do on the Sabbath.

ii)     Authority of Jesus also seen in how he silences his opponents.

 

1)      Stress is not on the miracle but on the confrontation as the story begins with a miracle and ends with a confrontation.

2)      Setting (3:12)

a)      2nd Sabbath incident is not connected with the first (Luke 6:11 on another Sabbath), but the narrative sequence (as in Matt and he went on from there, and entered their synagogue) assumes that Jesus returns from the cornfields and perhaps the same Pharisees watching (3:1) him.

3)      Confrontation (3:34)

a)      Matthew (12:1112) adds the metaphor of the lost sheep, arguing from the rabbinic principle that since relief of animal suffering is permissible (to some extent) on the Sabbath, how much more human suffering. Matt also stresses the humanitarian aspect of the Sabbath in the previous account by noting that the disciples were hungry (only in Matt; Matt 12:1).

b)      Jesus question (Is it lawful ) is a technical question on halakhah, rabbinic book of rules for daily living (Osborne).

i)       Jesus probably understood from Mic 6:8 that practicing justice and lovingkindness mandated one to heal on the Sabbath. Therefore, knowing what is right to do and not doing it would be sinning (cf. Jas 4:7).

ii)     Pharisees, following oral tradition, would agree that when life is in danger, you can heal the Sabbath.[10] But that is not the case here.

iii)   Antithetical parallelism do good save life || do evil kill. Understood in several ways:

(1)   *Contrast between Jesus noble motivation and his enemies wicked motivation

(a)   Do good = healing a man; Save life = assume a man without an arm is as good as dead [Both involve Jesus ministry of healing, casting out demons, and preaching the kingdom of God]|| Do evil = Spy on him and accuse him; Kill = penalty for profaning the Sabbath (Collins) [Both refer to his opponents hindering Jesus healing ministry and plotting to kill him]

(b)   Bring wholeness from the curse || Hinder Jesus ministry and kill him (3:6)

(c)   Their criticism of saving a life on the Sabbath and their intent to kill him makes them hypocritical.

(2)   Edwards:

(a)   Do good or to do evil refers to healing the handicapped man. Human need poses a moral imperative to do good.

(b)   Save a life or to kill refers to Jesus, to the observers response to Jesus.

(3)   Do evil kill on the Sabbath alludes to 1 Macc 2:2941 where they would defend themselves if attacked on the Sabbath. Thus, it was acceptable for them to do evil and kill on the Sabbath in such instances.

(a)   Their criticism of Jesus desire to save lives while permitting doing evil and killing shows their hypocrisy.

(4)   *Allusion to Deut 30:15 LXX See, I have given before you today life and death, good and evil. The summons here is a call to obey. Obedience life; apostasy death.

(a)   The high point in the first exodus was Yahwehs self-revelation (Deut 30:1114). For Mark, Gods presence and his Torah are now embodied in Jesus, since in this new exodus, he does that to which the Torah could only point and which only Yahweh himself could do (cleansing leprosy, forgiving sins, expelling demons). Whereas sin is a transgression of Gods will as expressed in the Torah, now it is to reject Jesus, in whom Gods will is fully expressed (CNTUOT).

c)      Silence

i)       Historical in that they did not want to debate Jesus. To answer yes (It is lawful on the Sabbath to do good ) would undermine their whole approach to the Sabbath; to answer no (It is not lawful on the Sabbath to do good ) might not win the favor of the synagogue congregation (France).

ii)     Theological: σιωπάω also occurs in 4:39 (stilling of the storm). So, both here and there, the silencing emphasizes Jesus authority. See also 1:25 with the silencing (φιμόω) of the demon. This is debated because σιωπάω is not always used to denote Jesus authority (9:34; 10:38; 14:61).

4)      Miracle (3:56)

a)      Action

i)       Heart: seat of mental discernment and spiritual insight (France).

ii)     Note Marks description of Jesus emotion (anger & grief)more vivid description. Matt and Luke omit it.

b)      Reaction: Prior conflict narratives now culminate in the plot to kill him.

i)       Herodians: supporters and adherents of Herod Antipas.

ii)     Combination of political (Herodians) and religious (Pharisees) elements should not be surprising since there was not much division between politics and religion in those days.

iii)   Here is probably an agreement to silence Jesus when the time is right. Fleshes out 2:20 (removal of the bridegroom) and contrasts those who rejoice with the bridegroom and those who are determined to destroy the bridegroom (France).

5)      3:6 not only concludes the story of the healing in the synagogue, but also shows the cumulative effectiveness of Jesus radical teaching in the 2 Sabbath pericopes and his overall ministry in this section of Mark.

2.5         Jesus heals multitudes by the sea: Wide recognition of Jesus authority to heal; Summary of Jesus ministry (3:712) [48]

1)      Summary statement of Jesus ministry.

2)      Christology

a)      Who is this Jesus?

i)       The demons know Jesus true identity. This summarizes what preceded (1:1, 11, 24) and prepares for the identification of him as Son of the Most High God by Legion (5:7). Mark reveals further who Jesus is by his miracles which become more miraculous: nature (4:3541), incurable disease and death (5:2143).

3)      Secret

a)      Historically: Avoidance of open proclamation of messianic titles made sense politically lest one fans into flames revolutionary zeal.

b)      Theologically:

i)       Demonstrates Christs greatness. Despite commands for silence, Jesus greatness cannot be hidden. In so doing, the secret confirms Jesus identity as the Son of God.

ii)     Demonstrates Jesus did not die for his political activity.

 

1)      Withdrawal to the sea. Function:

a)      Reminds us that Jesus is still popular, despite the opposition.

b)      Show the different range of impressions regarding Jesus, anticipating Mark 4 (parable of the seeds).

c)      Provides context for selection of 12.

2)      Jesus popularity with the crowds

a)      great multitude (3:7, 8); crowd (3:9); crush him (3:9); many (3:10); large geographical area (Judea, Jerusalem, Idumea, beyond Jordan, Tyre, Sidon).

i)       Greater than John the Baptist because geographical spread is wider.

b)      Reason for popularityJesus miraculous deeds (ἀκούοντες ὅσα ἐποίει; 3:8).

3)      Have a boat (πλοιάριον)[11] ready:

a)      Supposedly theirs. The abandonment of their occupation has not left them without access to a boat. The frequent mention of the group travelling by boat also suggests this point (France). Other explanation: they relied on their old connections to borrow boats (Lau).

4)      He healed many many in Semitic context means all (Stein). Matt has he healed them all.

5)      Demons

a)      Demons recognize Jesus and pay homage (προσπίπτω) to him. Their declaration ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ is more christologically loaded than ὁ ἅγιος τοῦ θεοῦ. This truth, the highest Christological confession in Mark, is already articulated at the beginning, by God at Jesus baptism (1:11), by God at his transfiguration (9:7), but remains hidden until it surfaces at the trial (14:61-62), and is perceived by the centurion at the crucifixion (15:39).

b)      Demons naming of Jesus.

i)       Probably not seen as a means to control Jesus, but a reluctant confession of who Jesus is.

ii)     Demoniac in the synagogue: Holy One of God (1:27) here, Son of God Gerasene demoniac: Son of the Most High God (5:7) << Notice the progression.

iii)   Iterative imperfect: ἐθεώρουν, προσέπιπτον, ἔκραζον happen often shows great authority of Jesus.

c)      Purpose of silence:

i)       μὴ αὐτὸν φανερὸν ποιήσωσιν suggests that what the demons say is true.

ii)     Full revelation can only come after the crucifixion and resurrection.

2.6         Varying responses to Jesus: Supporters and Opponents (3:1335) [49, 11618, 121]

1)      Shows the wide spectrum of response to Jesus (France).

a)      Supporters (insiders): the 12 (3:1319)

b)      Opponents (outsiders) 1: Jesus family (3:2021)

c)      Opponents (outsiders) 2: scribes from Jerusalem (3:2230)

d)      Concluding tableau: insiders and outsiders (3:3135).

2)      Intercalation (3:2035). Compares and contrasts the two level of opposition with their // charge of madness and demon possession.

a)      Jesus family sets out to take control of him (3:2021)

i)       Delegation of scribes from Jerusalem (3:2230)

b)      Jesus family arrives but do not achieve their purpose (3:31-35)

3)      Another chiasm around the scribes capital charge of collusion with Beelzebul

a)      The crowds come to Jesus (3:20)

i)       Jesus family thinks that he is beside himself (3:21)

(1)   The scribes accusation (3:22)

(a)   Jesus response (3:2329)

(2)   The scribes accusation restated (3:30)

ii)     Jesus family comes to take charge (3:3133)

b)      The crowds sit around Jesus as his new family (3:3435)

4)      Focus on peoples position as either insiders or outsiders, a feature that is further stressed in 4:1011.

a)      Insiders:

i)       He chose 12 that they might be with him (ἵνα ὦσιν μετ αὐτοῦ; 3:14); he goes into a house (εἰς οἶκον; 3:20) presumably with them, and the crowds sit around him (ἐκάθητο περὶ αὐτὸν; 3:32); (τοὺς περὶ αὐτὸν κύκλῳ καθημένους; 3:34).

b)      Outsiders:

i)       His family went out (ἐξῆλθον) to seize him (3:21);[12] they are standing outside the house (ἔξω στήκοντες; 3:31).

2.6.1        Supporters: The 12 (3:1319) [49]

1)      Function:

a)      Defines what it means to be a follower of Jesus: To be with Jesus and to carry on his mission.

b)      Explains how the group obtained their authority from Jesus.

c)      Christological: Shows authority of Jesus.

i)       Like God in the OT, he calls people for service; like God, he also renames people

ii)     By appointing the 12, Jesus shows he is the one that brings about the fulfillment and restoration of Israel.

d)      Jesus death is not accidental: Rather, Jesus knowingly chose someone who was going to betray him.

2)      The 3 lists

a)      Matt 10:24; Mark 3:1619; Luke 6:1316.

 

1)      The call (3:1314a).

a)      Significance of mountains:

i)       The ascent up the mountain may recall Moses ascent of Sinai (Marcus).[13]

ii)     Mountains nearness to God, place of divine-human communication and encounter. Atop mountains, Jesus prays (6:46), is transfigured (9:28), foretells the future (13:35).

iii)   *Just as God establishes Israel from atop a mountain (Exod 1924), so Jesus atop a mountain establishes an end-time people of God (Kingsbusy, Conflict, 93).

b)      He called those whom he desired: Discipleship is not a choice, but a call (cf. John 15:16). Jesus calling contrasts with the rabbis: (1) Rabbis did not call disciples but were chosen by the disciples who saw them as guides to be followers of Torah; (2) Jesus call disciples to follow him, not the Torah.

c)      In Mark, οἱ μαθηταί refers to the 12. In John, it refers to a larger group of people. How about Matt and Luke?

2)      Purpose (3:14b15)

a)      1st: To be with him (ἵνα ὦσιν μετ αὐτοῦ), to be his constant companions in contrast to the crowds who come and go, to be one with him. This then forms the basis for the other 2 (to preach and to have authority).

i)       They are to be with him so that they can learn from him and witness his actions, thus enabling them to be his apostles and witnesses.

ii)     In Acts 1:21, companionship with Jesus throughout his ministry is the prerequisite for the replacement apostle.

b)      2nd: To preach (κηρύσσω).

i)       Prior to this, Jesus preaches (κηρύσσω) the kingdom of God. After this point, κηρύσσω is no longer used of Jesus, but of other people.

ii)     Note that preaching and exercising authority are both extensions of Jesus own mission.

c)      3rd: To have authority (ἐξουσία) to cast out demons. Note that authority is hitherto used exclusively of Jesus (1;22, 27; 2:10).

i)       With exorcism, the disciples share in the supernatural conflict.

3)      The lists of names (3:1619a)

a)      See chart in Luke Intro.docx

b)      Mark places Simon, James, and John (the inner circle) first || Matt and Luke place (Simon & Andrew), (James & John) together, in the order in which they were called (Mark 1:1619).

c)      Luke & Mark appear to give the name Peter to Simon during the appointment of the 12. Matt puts it at Caesarea Philippi (although he uses the name earlier). John places it at the initial encounter of Simon Peter with Jesus in John 1:42.

d)      Sons of Thunder: Could mean that they are hasty and violent (see Luke 9:54).

e)      Thaddeus (Mark, Matt) = Judas the son of James (Luke)

i)       Does not any unreliability nor does it show that the importance of the 12 diminishes in significance such that even their names could not be recalled by the time of Matt & Luke.

ii)     Possible explanations.

(1)   Thaddaues was a member of the 12 who dropped out and was replaced by Judas, the son of James.

(2)   *Same person. Thaddeus is a Greek name; Judas is a Semitic name. Palestinian Jews sometimes bore both Semitic and Greek names.[14] E.g. Saul-Paul, John-Mark.

f)       Simon the Cananaean (Mark, Matt) = Simon the Zealot (Luke)

i)       ὁ Καναναῖος = Aramaic for enthusiast, patriot. Luke then translates the Aramaic meaning into Greek. Textus Receptus has Κανανίτης (Cananite, man from Cana).

ii)     ζηλωτής:

(1)   *religious (see also Acts 21:20; 22:3; Gal 1:14). Not a political party since the use of Zealots to refer to a party does not appear in our sources until after 66 CE.

(2)   political party.

(a)   Simon is one who is zealous for the law and would use violence to punish flagrant violation of the law. Such violence was directed against fellow Jews rather than Romans.

(b)   The extent of the Zealots movement in Jesus day is not clear, but they clearly gained in prominence during the Jewish revolt. Readers of Mark would probably have read it along political lines. The presence of a tax collector and a Zealot together then is remarkable, and is possible only because of the transforming power of the Spirit.

g)      Judas: Identified as who also betrayed him. Foreshadows and points to death of Jesus.

i)       Whenever Judas is mentioned by name, theres always a commentary attached that emphasizes his treachery. For e.g. 14:10 Judas Iscariot, who was 1 of the 12, went to the chief priests; 14:43 while he was still speaking, Judas came, 1 of the 12, and with him a crowd with swords and clubs.

ii)     Judas is placed last in all 3 lists (Mark, Matt, Luke) a retrospective view of the 12 from the perspective after Jesus death.

4)      Implication:

a)      Eyewitnesses.

i)       In Mark-Luke, 7 are never mentioned again; in Matt, 6 are never mentioned again. Nevertheless, they are not left as an amorphous group, but are probably named here to indicate their importance as those responsible for the overall shape of the story of Jesus and much of its content.

b)      12 represent 12 tribes of Israel

i)       Rejection of Israel and formation of the new Israel.

ii)     Eschatological restoration of national Israel since Israel at that time constituted only 2 and a half tribes (Benjamin, Judah, and half of Levi).

(1)   Restoration of Israel. Qumran was ruled by a council of 12, signifying the renewed Israel (Osborne).

iii)   Both are probably correct. Jesus is restoring Israel, but not according to its national and political hopes, but of a body comprising Jews and Gentiles.

iv)   Jesus is bringing in the kingdom of God to Israel

v)      Ideal constitution of the 12 and the Jewish hopes for the restoration of all 12 tribes in the messianic age. Jesus appointment of the 12 in his ministry the messianic restoration of Israel has already begun in nucleus.

c)      The 12 is the necessary beginning point of the church. Thats why Judas had to be replaced. The choosing of the 12 Gods work of reconstituting the true Israel is continuing.

2.6.2        Opponents 1: Jesus Family (3:2021) [116]

1)      Theology of 3:2035

a)      Christology

i)       Greatness of Jesus Christ: The one stronger than John the Baptist is also stronger than the supposed strong man (prince of demons, Satan), and is able to plunder his house.

(1)   The ἱσχυρός lemma only appears in 1:7 (ἔρχεται ὁ ἰσχυρότερός μου ὀπίσω μου) and 3:27 (τὴν οἰκίαν τοῦ ἰσχυροῦ).

ii)     Jesus is the one who brings about the turn in salvation history.

(1)   The point: Satans kingdoms has an end (τέλος ἔχει; 3:26), and Gods kingdom is being established.

iii)   Presence of scribes from Jerusalem foreshadows Jesus death.

b)      Discipleship

i)       Obedience to the will of God must be placed above family ties. Exemplified earlier in James and John leaving their family to follow Jesus (1:20).

 

1)      In the Synopsis, Sermon on the Mount and Sermon on the Plain is inserted here.

2)      Probably οἱ παρ αὐτοῦ = Jesus family.

3)      This verse indicates that Jesus family went out to take Jesus under their control. Perhaps he was causing an embarrassment to the family honor. This is difficult, giving rise to TC: οἱ γραμματεῖς καὶ οἱ λοιποί replaces the ambiguous οἱ παρ αὐτοῦ. They are probably a more acceptable source for the statement that He is out of his mind (3:21).

4)      Fulfillment of Ps 69:8 I have become a stranger to my kindred, an alien to my mothers children (Collins in France).

5)      Note the 3:2021 only occurs in Mark, shows Marks intentional intercalation. His family considered him insane, while the authorities considered him demon-possessed.

a)      Osborne claims that insanity and demon possession were linked in the ancient world. France, however, says that there is little evidence for this claim.

6)      Parallel structure in 3:21 & 3:30

a)      Family: ἔλεγον γὰρ ὅτι ἐξέστη (3:21).[15]

b)      Scribes: ὅτι ἔλεγον, Πνεῦμα ἀκάθαρτον ἔχει (3:30) [But ὅτι is used differently]

2.6.3        Opponents 2: Scribes from Jerusalem {Beelzebub controversy} (3:2230) [117118]

1)      In Mark, theres no indication that this scene happens chronologically from 3:2021. Probably, topically arranged.

2)      Up to now, Jesus only meets local Galilean opposition. Now, he has opposition from Jerusalem. In 7:1, well see once again Pharisees and some of the scribes who had come from Jerusalem.

a)      People in positions of national authority are beginning to form an unfavorable impression of Jesus.

3)      Charge (3:22)

a)      Charge #1: He is possessed by Beelzebul. Only in Mark.

b)      Charge #2 : He casts out demons by the prince of demons = Beelzebul (cf. Matt 12:24; Luke 11:15).

c)      From 3:23-26, Beelzebul = Satan, but we dont know what is its lexical meaning. Possibly a corruption of Baalzebul (Baal of the height). Later manuscripts have Baalzebub (Baal the fly).

i)       BDAG: orig. a Philistine deity; the name זְבוּב בַּעַל means Baal (lord) of flies.. Whether זְבוּל בַּעַל (=lord of filth?) represents an intentional change or merely careless pronunciation cannot be determined w. certainty

4)      Jesus answer (3:2329).

a)      Jesus responds to their accusation in parables (ἐν παραβολαῖς). Outside Mark 4, Mark uses παραβολή almost always in the context of controversy with the scribes.

i)       Pragmatically, this is prudent rather than using direct speech which may be dangerous. Theologically, it points to Mark 4 and the distinction between insiders and outsiders. There, insiders are revealed secrets but outsiders are given only parables. Here, these scribes would be the extreme example of outsiders (France).

b)      Jesus responds in reverse order.

i)       Answer to second charge: He casts out demons by the prince of demons (3:2327)

(1)   Jesus considers all demonic power to be under Satan (a major difference with demonology of Judaism), and he understands his exorcism not as a battle with a particular demon but with Satan himself.

(2)   2 parables of a divided kingdom (3:24-25). A kingdom must be united or an enemy will exploit its internal strife to its detriment. What is happening in Jesus exorcisms was not the self-destruction of the kingdom of Satan from within, but the overpowering of Satan externally by one who is greater.

(a)   Is Jesus argument valid for all exorcisms? No. I would think in general, pagan exorcists work by using more powerful spirits to subdue weaker spirits. But ultimately, the one who is freed of the weaker spirit is now enslaved to the more powerful spirit. In this way, the kingdom of Satan remains entrenched. Jesus, however, was not talking about individual skirmishes, but about the larger battle ultimately between 2 kingdoms: the kingdom of darkness and the kingdom of light (Lau).

(3)   Applied to Satan (3:26).

(a)   Implication: Negatively, Satans kingdom is not facing internal strife.

(4)   Conclusion (3:27)

(a)   Another parable, this time positively to show that Satans kingdom is facing an external enemy, i.e. in Jesus himself, the strong one. The point: Satans kingdoms has an end (τέλος ἔχει; 3:26), and Gods kingdom is being established. The focus is on the eschatological development in salvation history rather than on individual exorcism of demons.

(b)   Some would say that the binding of Satan in 3:27 occurs during the temptation narrative. The earlier occurrence of Satan is 1:12. This may then reinterpret Jesus temptation as an occasion when Jesus bound the strong one. But theres no explicit link. Emphasis here lies not in when Satan is bound, but that he is bound by the Stronger One.

(c)   Binding theme in Scripture (Osborne)

(i)     Satan and his minions are first bound at the fall of angels from heaven (1 Pet 3:19; Jude 6).

(ii)  Bound in this sphere once for all at the first advent. Nevertheless, he is still god of this world (2 Cor 4:4). We participate in his binding when we follow Jesus in our lives.

(iii)                        Final binding occurs first in the bottomless pit and then in the lake of fire (Rev 20).

(5)   OT Context: Possible allusion to Isa 49:24

(a)   Can plunder be taken from warriors, or captives be rescued from the fierce? But this is what the LORD says: Yes, captives will be taken from warriors, and plunder retrieved from the fierce; I will contend with those who contend with you, and your children I will save (Isa 49:2425).

(b)   Isa 49:24 shows that Yahweh, being especially present in his servant, will restore Israel from the nations and their idols (49:25).

(c)   In Isa 4055, Israel is in bondage to the nations and especially their idols. In the intertestamental period, the belief emerged that behind the idols stood the demons. The binding of demons is thus a common theme in Jewish eschatological traditions.

(d)   In Mark, Jesus is the Yahweh-Warrior who have rent the heavens and come down to effect the long awaited new-exodus deliverance of his people from bondage. In keeping with the intertestamental focus, the enemy is now no longer Babylon or Rome and their idols, but the demons. This is therefore no common exorcist. Jesus must be identified with the inbreaking and the powerful kingly rule of Isaiahs Yahweh-Warrior himself and his true-Israel servant (CNTUOT).

ii)     Answer to first charge: He is demon possessed (3:2830) [118]

(1)   Amen saying. Does not occur in Jewish literature. Echoes OT formula, As I live, says the Lord. It is divine self-authentication and guarantees the veracity of what is being said.

(2)   sons of men = humanity in general

(3)   Sin and blasphemies

(a)   Its not that these sins are not serious. They will have eternal consequences if they are not repented and forgiven. Nevertheless, they will be forgiven in the normal way of forgiveness when people repent and seek forgiveness.

(b)   Sins || blasphemies: horizontal sins against humanity (horizontal) || vertical sins against God (Stein). {why cant blasphemies be horizontal too}

(4)   Blasphemy in the technical rabbinic sense (as in uttering the name of Yahweh) was a capital offense. But what is blasphemy against the Holy Spirit (εἰς τὸ πνεῦμα τὸ ἅγιον)? Blasphemy can in general be understood as slanderous speech.

(a)   Never has forgiveness ultimate fate. Paraphrase guilty of a sin with eternal consequences (France).

(i)     Text does not say whether this eternal guilt is revocable or whether theres a clause unless he repents. Not as harsh as Heb 6:46; 10:2627 (France). But some may say that its similar to Heb 6, 10.

(b)   Essence:

(i)     Whatever may be the case with other slanderous speech, there is one sort which is not forgivable, that against the Holy Spirit (France). Here, slanderous speech against the Holy Spirit is attributing the source of Christs exorcism not with the Spirit but with Satan. The juxtaposition of Holy Spirit and unclean spirit rejection of the truth and the rule of God from a hard heart. Blasphemy against the Holy Spirit is willful disobedience and rejection of God.

1.      Jesus is the one who will baptize with the Holy Spirit (1:8), who is given the Holy Spirit (1:10), who is led by the Spirit (1:12), and who brings in the kingdom of God (1:15) and ushers in the period of the Spirit. Blasphemy against the Spirit (attributing the source of Christs exorcism to demons) is the denial of evidence that the kingdom of God has arrived. (Lau).

(ii)  The emphasis here is not on a particular set of words but about a pattern of life. If one adopts a position like that of the Pharisee, when, not by way of misunderstanding but through hostility to what is good, that person calls good evil, and, on the other hand, makes evil good, then that person has put himself in a state that prevents forgiveness They called good evil. People in such a situation cannot repent and seek forgiveness: they lack a sense of sin; they reject Gods competence to declare what is right. It is this continuing attitude that is the ultimate sin (Morris, Matt).

(c)   Pastoral:

(i)     Most wonder if they have committed the unforgivable sin. But this is here probably a warning against deliberate rejection of Gods purposes, resisting the work of the Spirit in the human heart. Without the work of the Spirit, repentance is impossible.

(ii)  This sin can be discerned only with 20/20 hindsight. Many whom we might have imagined this sin later comes Christians.

(iii)                        Concern about whether one has committed the unpardonable sin is probably an indication that one has not.

(5)   OT context (Isa 63:10)

(a)   Yet they rebelled and grieved his Holy Spirit. So he turned and became their enemy and he himself fought against them (Isa 63:10).

(b)   Isa 63:10, just as in the first exodus, the second exodus will be met with faithlessness. In grieving his Holy Spirit, Yahweh turns and becomes their enemy, and subsequently hardens their hearts (63:17) just as he had down to Pharaoh.

(c)   In Mark: As in Isaiah, the new descent of the Spirit was greeted in precisely the same way as the old. But since this is Gods final, eschatological, deed of salvation, those who utterly reject it can find no salvation (CNTUOT).

(6)   Matthew (whoever says a word against the Son of man will be forgiven; but whoever speaks against the Holy Spirit will not be forgiven )

(a)   If Son of Man = Jesus = Son of God, why is it OK to blaspheme against Son of Man but not the Holy Spirit?

(i)     *Emphasis is not on the possibility of forgiveness when one blasphemes against the Son of Man (saying that he has an unclean spirit), but the comparison highlights the impossibility of forgiveness when one blasphemes against the Spirit, attributing the work of God to Satan and failing to acknowledge the arrival of the kingdom of God. For such, there is no forgiveness.

(ii)  *Within the context of the larger narrative

1.      Rejection of the truth of the gospel || Rejection of the same truth in full awareness that is exactly what one is doingthoughtfully, willfully, and self-consciously rejecting the work of the Spirit. The distinction between Son of Man and the Holy Spirit is incidental (Carson).

(iii)                        *The term Son of Man is an ambiguous term in which the truth of Jesus is not fully revealed. In this situation, it would be possible to speak against him without realizing that one is directly opposing the saving purposes of God (France, Matt). And there is no reason why someone who sins in this way should not later seek forgiveness. But to blaspheme against the Spirit is to call good evil and a complete perversion of values (Morris, Matt)

(iv) To speak a word against the Son of Man may refer to rejecting Jesus without truly sensing the Spirits power in him (NIVZSB).

2.6.4        Concluding Tableau: Insiders and Outsiders (3:3135) [121]

1)      Intercalation

a)      Family hears about Jesus not being able to eat (3:20-21) || scribal accusation that Jesus has the devil (3:2330) || Jesus family outside calling for Jesus (3:3135)

i)       Compares 2 cases of repudiation of Jesus: family and official level. They are those who should know him best (his family) and those who ought to know the most about the God from whom Jesus was sent (religious authorities).

(1)   This is further made explicit in 6:4 A prophet is not without honor, except in his own country, and among his own kin, and in his own house.

(2)   Repudiation points again to the inevitability of Jesus death.

ii)     Material in the middle aids the interpretation of the other. Scribes make a false judgment on Jesus. In the context, we are not to interpret the desire of his family as innocuous. The bracketed tradition shows that the family shares in the negative viewpoint of the scribes towards Jesus. They are not to be accorded incipient belief or sympathy toward what Jesus does or teaches, as Luke possibly does in 8:1921 (desiring to see you vis--vis seek you in Mark). Here, Jesus physical family is contrasted with his true family.

2)      Contrast between insiders and outsiders.

a)      Insiders:

i)       The crowds sit around him (ἐκάθητο περὶ αὐτὸν; 3:32); (τοὺς περὶ αὐτὸν κύκλῳ καθημένους; 3:34).

b)      Outsiders:

i)       They are standing outside the house (ἔξω στήκοντες; 3:31); your mother and your brothers outside (ἡ μήτηρ σου καὶ οἱ ἀδελφοί σου ἔξω; 3:32).

3)      Jesus attitude: brusque, not welcoming them even after their journey. Here, its not that family relations are unimportant, but that there is a higher priority: obedience to his mission in proclaiming the kingdom of God.

a)      Radical discipleship:

i)       Ties between believers are stronger (eternal) than familial ties.

ii)     In certain situations, OT and rabbinic teaching teaches that service to God requires severance of familial relationship (Osborne).

4)      Brothers:

a)      *Younger brothers born to Joseph and Mary after Jesus birth (Helvidius)

b)      Sons of Joseph from an earlier marriage (Epiphanius)

c)      Cousins of Jesus (Jerome)

5)      Whoever does the will of God (τὸ θέλημα τοῦ θεοῦ)

a)      Pharisees thought that they were doing the will of God. The phrase does not occur again in Mark. But in the story so far, it probably relates to Jesus proclamation of the kingdom of God, and calls for repentance, commitment, and belief in the gospel.

b)      Sonship motif again. Just as Jesus, the Son of God, is obedient in doing the will of God, so also those who do the will of God will be the brother, sister, and mother of Jesus.

i)       What defines sonship (or familial relationships) is not DNA but obedience to the Father.

2.7         Explanatory discourse: The paradox of the Kingdom of God {Parables about the Kingdom} (4:134) [122130]

1)      Little teaching has been recorded so far.[16] This discourse is to explain the narrative which follows and precedes it.

a)      Answers the question How the message of the kingdom of God can meet with different response?

i)       Narrative so far has described the initial proclamation of the kingdom of God. The response is varied: enthusiasm and commitment by the disciples || plot by Pharisees and Herodians to destroy Jesus || skepticism of Jesus family || accusation of blasphemy by the scribes from Jerusalem || superficial enthusiasm by the surrounding crowds || amazement at Jesus teaching and power. This narrative explains how people can respond so differently, but it does not explain why people respond so differently. 4:134 explains how there are different responses to the gospel leading to the formation of insiders and outsiders, but it does not explain why some are inside and some are outside.

ii)     The outsiders, although they hear and see the works of the kingdom, they cannot understand what is taking place (4:12). The insiders, on the other hand, by their openness to instruction (and that is the key), are given insight and understanding.

b)      Marks readers, like the disciples of Jesus, have been given insight and understanding that the kingdom of God has indeed come with Jesus and that the words and deeds of Jesus are evidence of this. Consequently, having been given ears to hear, they should heed (4:3, 9, 23, 2425) and make sure that they are good soil, bearing fruit for the kingdom || Response is left to the discretion of the reader.

2)      Focus of this teaching is the kingdom of God, especially the τὸ μυστήριον τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ (4:11).

3)      Division between insiders and outsiders

a)      Depends on how each group hears the word.

i)       Fate of the 4 types of seeds depends on hearing the word.

ii)     4:23 εἴ τις ἔχει ὦτα ἀκούειν ἀκουέτω.

iii)   4:24 Βλέπετε τί ἀκούετε

4)      Here, Jesus tells 4 parables that describe the divisive impact and mysterious nature of the KOG. After this, he performs 4 parabolic deeds that reveal the true source of his authority and what he has come to do (NIVSB).

5)      Setting

a)      4:1 Jesus teaches by the sea 4:1012 suggests a change in scene (and when he was alone) 4:35 Jesus leaves the crowds and crosses to the other side of the sea.

b)      Probably not a chronological event in the life of Jesus but a collection of Jesus teaching. Confirmed by the statement in 4:3334 with many such parables he spoke the word to them (Stein).

6)      Include discussion on What is a parable? in Parable Notes.docx. (See below)

7)      Marshall, NTT, 90

a)      Teaching here is that those who respond to the gospel go on to advance in knowledge of the kingdom of God in a way that is not possible for those who remain outside. If the latter hear Jesus teaching and do not respond, his teaching only appears as riddles that they hear without understanding. It is a puzzle why some respond positively while others do not. Mark does not say that the former respond because God causes them to. But he is saying that persistent refusal to believe means that people are deprived of the opportunity to believe.

2.7.1        What is a parable? (From Parable Notes.docx)

2.7.1.1       Form

1)      παραβολή: Greek context: illustration, comparison, analogy usually in a story form to reveal a moral or spiritual truth.

a)      A narrative or saying of varying length, designed to illustrate a truth especially through comparison or simile (BDAG).

2)      OT mashal: The LXX translates mashal with παραβολή.

a)      More than an earthly story with a heavenly meaning.

b)      Proverb (Ezek 18:23; 1 Sam 24:13).

c)      Byword, satire, taunt, or word of derision (Isa 14:34; Hab 2:6).

d)      Riddle (Ps 78:2; Ezek 17:2; Ps 49:4; Prov 1:6)

e)      Story or allegory (Ezek 24:25; 2 Sam 12:14 [even though the term is not used there])

f)       Epigrams.

g)      The opposite of propositional speech.

3)      NT: παραβολή

a)      Proverb (Luke 4:23; Luke 6:39)

b)      Metaphor, figurative saying (Mark 7:1417; Luke 5:3638)

i)       Metaphor makes an implicit comparison

ii)     Simile makes an explicit comparison with terms such as like, as, as if, seems.

c)      Similitude is an expanded explicit comparison that is turned into a picture.

i)       Mark 4:3032. Compares kingdom of God to a mustard seed.

ii)     Matt 13:33. The kingdom of heaven is like yeast that a woman took and mixed in with 3 measures of flour until all of it was leavened.

d)      Story parable: when a similitude is expanded from a picture into a story.

i)       Parable of the great banquet (Luke 14:1620)

ii)     Parable of the 2 sons (Matt 21:2831)

iii)   Parable of the 12 virgins (Matt 25:113)

iv)   Parable of the lost son (Luke 15:1132)

e)      Example parable: Similar to a story parable. But while a story parable provides analogy between an earthly story and a heavenly truth, an example parable usually serves as a model for behavior with such commands as Go and do likewise (Luke 10:37).

i)       Parable of the rich fool (Luke 12:1621)

f)       Allegory: In contrast to a story parable or an example parable that has one main point of comparison, an allegory has several.

i)       Pilgrims Progress.

ii)     Parable of the tenants (Mark 12:111)

iii)   Parable of the weeds (Matt 13:2429; 3643)

iv)   Parable of the wedding banquet (Matt 22:114)

v)      Parable of the sower (Mark 4:39;1320)

4)      Stein: We define a parable as a figure of speech in which there is a brief or extended comparison.

2.7.1.2       Significance of a parable

1)      Meaning does not lie on the surface. Degree of communication depends to the extent to which the hearers share the background and values of the speaker, and what you get out of it depends in part on what you bring in. Moreover, the meaning does not lie so much in the cognitive; rather, the parable also includes a call to response with regard to ones attitude, will, and action. To understand a parable is to be challenged to change, and not to be enlightened only.

a)      Modern day illustration: Moule states that a parable is like a modern political cartoon. A good cartoon needs the viewer to work out its meaning, react to it critically, and then respond by either voting one way or another. The degree of communication depends on the viewers awareness of the events or issues. How much you get out of it depends on how much you bring into it.

 

2.7.2        Setting (4:12) [122]

1)      Boat: Recalls the boat that was prepared in 3:9. Presumably, Jesus and the 12 are in the boat.

2)      The superlative ὄχλος πλεῖστος and πᾶς ὁ ὄχλος Jesus great popularity.

3)      Sit: Normal position for teaching.

4)      ἐν παραβολαῖς: *by means of parables || enigmatically, in riddles.

2.7.3        Parable of the Sower (4:39) [122]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Emphasis on sower || *seeds || *soil

i)       Probably not sower given the lack of attention. Emphasis is on the seeds (Parable of the seeds; France) || the different soils (Parable of the soils; Osborne).

ii)     Emphasis on the seed: Seed represents the proclamation of the word and the coming kingdom of God. The 1st 3 soils explain why scribes, Pharisees, and Jesus family dont respond. Nevertheless, Marks readers should know that there is also the good soil that will bear fruit. Thus, Marks readers should continue proclaiming the good news.

iii)   *Emphasis on the soils: Exhortation to Marks readers to pay attention to the kind of soil they should be. This is primarily seen in the exhortation to hear (4:3, 9) and the interpretation of the different kinds of soils in 4:1320. This parable then // the summary of Jesus preaching in 1:15 Repent and believe in the gospel. To Marks readers, it would serve as an exhortation to recommit themselves and endeavor to be the good soil.

b)      Emphasis is on the contrast between ordinary beginnings and extraordinary results, not between the seed wasted and that which yielded grain. This latter interpretation is unlikely because seed is used in 4:4, 5, and 7, while seeds in 4:8 (Achtemeier, ABD).

i)       Function: Do not trust normal judgments based on what seem at first natural phenomena. The end will be quite extraordinary, and it will not be evident from the beginning. Do not judge Jesus on the basis of what appears to be normal judgments based on natural phenomena. To do that will be to miss his significance which will become evident at his resurrection and Parousia.

(1)   Within the context, those who have made such errors in judgment include the scribes and Jesus family, those who judge by normal human criteria. An ordinary person doing what Jesus did would be judged out of his mind by his family; and an ordinary person doing what Jesus did would stand under the judgment pronounced by the scribes. Those who judge Jesus on the basis of human judgment will miss his connection to Gods rule, and the inevitable greatness of the kingdom of God.

(2)   4:1420 emphasize the need to hold fast to what Jesus says, regardless of subsequent difficulties one may encounter. This turns on how one listens, and responds to Jesus, the point also of 4:10-12. Those who perceive Jesus by the usual criteria will fail. While they may see what he does, they do not really perceive its meaning.

(3)   4:2134 again contrast beginnings and endings. The sayings (2122, 2425, 23) concern appropriate activities and inappropriate activities) appropriate reaction is stressed.

 

1)      6 individual seeds:[17] 3 failed; 3 succeeded.

a)      Contrast between those that failed is seen in the tense.

i)       Failure: Note how they all fail progressively later in their growth stage:

(1)   1st seed never geminates:

(a)   ἦλθεν (AAI) τὰ πετεινὰ καὶ κατέφαγεν (AAI) αὐτό [4:4]

(2)   2nd seed germinates and dies shortly afterward:

(a)   ἐκαυματίσθη (API), διὰ τὸ μὴ ἔχειν ῥίζαν ἐξηράνθη (API) [4:6]

(3)   3rd seed germinates but does not bear fruit at harvest time

(a)   συνέπνιξαν (choked, AAI) αὐτό, καὶ καρπὸν οὐκ ἔδωκεν (AAI) [4:7]

ii)     Success

(1)   ἐδίδου (IAI) καρπὸν ἀναβαίνοντα (PAP) καὶ αὐξανόμενα (PMP), καὶ ἔφερεν (IAI) ἓν τριάκοντα καὶ ἓν ἑξήκοντα καὶ ἓν ἑκατόν [4:8]

(2)   Show continuous growth.

2)      Comparison with other gospels. Generally similar among all 3.

a)      Mark:

i)       Slight emphasis on listening. Listen! (4:3). Absent in Matt, Luke.

ii)     Vivid description of growth.

(1)   Mark (brought forth grain, growing, increasing, yielding 30x, 60x, 100x)

(2)   Matt (brought forth grain, 100x, 60x, 30x)

(3)   Luke (yielded 100x).

3)      He who has ears to hear, let him hear: Reader has responsibility to discern and apply the message.

a)      Hear the significance of the parable, and therefore sow liberally.

b)      Hear the significance of the parable, and make sure you hear the gospel message carefully (4:1320).

2.7.4        Purpose of Parables (4:1012) [123]

1)      See Why the parables notes in Parables Notes.docx

2)      Emphasis:

a)      Lack of understanding and rejection by outsiders was part of the divine plan. All of this is ultimately under the sovereign plan of God. Therefore Marks readers should take comfort in it. Thus, they should continue to sow the word, and heed the exhortation to hear (4:3, 9, 23) and be good soil, bearing fruit.

3)      Function of parables (Carson). Why did Jesus tell parables? [From Matt]

a)      In line with scripture, his message reveals things hidden in Scripture.

b)      In line with scripture, his message blinds, deafens, hardens.

4)      Issue (Stein)

a)      Insiders alone have been given the secret whereas those outside hear everything in parables. How then do you explain the following:

i)       Disciples at times do not understand (4:13; 6:5152; 7:1723; 8:1021; 9:3032) or need explanations (4:1320)

ii)     Sometimes, those outside understand Jesus teaching (12:112, esp. 12:12)

iii)   Sometimes, crowds are also given explanations (4:11)

iv)   It appears that Jesus intentionally taught in parables to keep outsiders from understanding in order that they might not repent and receive forgiveness? How do you reconcile this with John 3:16; 1 Tim 2:4; 2 Pet 3:9?

b)      What was given to the disciples was not only a cognitive perception of Jesus teaching but the conviction of its truthfulness.

5)      Intercalation: Purpose of parables sandwiched between the parable of the sower both throws light on each other. Present in all 3 gospels.

a)      Expand further on this.

 

 

 

2.7.4.1       Why the parables?(From Parable Notes.docx)

1)      Inadequate answers

a)      Illustration: No better illustration of Gods love than the parable of the prodigal son.

i)       Inadequate, because the parables are not always self-evident even to the disciples. Thus, while parables may at times reveal and illustrate, they are not always clear and they may indeed conceal.

2.7.4.1.1     Parables as a means of revelation
2.7.4.1.1.1     Mark

Mark 4:10 Καὶ ὅτε ἐγένετο κατὰ μόνας, ἠρώτων αὐτὸν οἱ περὶ αὐτὸν σὺν τοῖς δώδεκα τὰς παραβολάς. 11 καὶ ἔλεγεν αὐτοῖς, Ὑμῖν τὸ μυστήριον δέδοται τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ· ἐκείνοις δὲ τοῖς ἔξω ἐν παραβολαῖς τὰ πάντα γίνεται, 12 ἵνα βλέποντες βλέπωσιν καὶ μὴ ἴδωσιν, καὶ ἀκούοντες ἀκούωσιν καὶ μὴ συνιῶσιν, μήποτε ἐπιστρέψωσιν καὶ ἀφεθῇ αὐτοῖς.

 

1)      Explanation given only to insiders.

a)      when he was alone; those who were with him; 12

b)      Those who were with him (οἱ περὶ αὐτὸν): recall περὶ αὐτὸν ὄχλος (3:32, 34). There, the distinction between outsiders and insiders are those who do the will of God (3:35). Here, they are the ones to ask about the meaning of parables. To those that are interested and who have this curiosity, more would be given (4:25 For to those who have, more will be given). So the group περὶ αὐτόν is self-selected, not predestined (France).

c)      Ὑμῖν τὸ μυστήριον δέδοται τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ

i)       Mystery

(1)   τὸ μυστήριον is not a mystery which only the initiated are intended to understand, but denotes something that could not be known by men except by divine revelation. The mystery here is the secret that the kingdom of God has come in the person, words, and deeds of Jesus.[18] That is a secret because God has chosen to reveal himself indirectly and in a veiled way (Cranfield 153). It is therefore not marked by incomprehensibility but hiddenness.

(2)   From the Aramaic rāz (Dan 2:1819, 27, 30, 47). The interpretation of Nebuchadnezzars dream is a secret which is hidden from the wise men of Babylon but revealed to Daniel. It is something given rather than deciphered.

(3)   Matthew mysteries; Mark mystery, collective noun.

(4)   Mystery of the kingdom of God the message about Gods kingdom is so paradoxical or veiled that it will take divine revelation to understand it.

(5)   δέδοται knowledge of the mystery has already been given. They know that the kingdom of God has already come in Jesus.

ii)     Better to be translated as to you, it has been given to know the mystery since Matt 13:11, Luke 8:10 provides to know.

(1)   What does know mean?

(a)   Cognitive

(b)   *Not just cognitive but the conviction that it is true and valid. The disciples know that the kingdom of God has truly come and that Jesus healings and exorcisms are a manifestation of that reality (Stein).

(i)     Looking back at Mark 3:2228, everybody sees the healing of the demon possessed. Some see it as the arrival of the kingdom; the scribes see it as the manifestation of Satan.

(ii)  Tie this with the role of the Holy Spirit in exegesis. A non believing and a believing exegete may arrive at the same exegetical conclusions of a passage, but it is the believing exegete who realizes the validity and truth of what he is seeing. Example of the duck-rabbit illusion.

2)      Another example where a parable reveals the kingdom of God is seen in the parable of the vineyard tenant (12:112). There, the religious leaders clearly understood the parable and that the parable was spoken against them (12:12).

3)      In essence, parables do reveal. But at times, what they reveal is veiled truth.

2.7.4.1.2     Parable as a means of concealing: Use of Isa 6:910 in Mark 4:1012
2.7.4.1.2.1     Quote of Isa 6:910

2.7.4.1.2.1.1    Isa 6:910 context (CNTUOT)

9 And he said, Go, and say to this people: Hear and hear, but do not understand; see and see, but do not perceive. 10 Make the heart of this people fat, and their ears heavy, and shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their hearts, and turn and be healed. 11 Then I said, How long, O Lord? And he said: Until cities lie waste without inhabitant, and houses without men, and the land is utterly desolate, 12 and the LORD removes men far away, and the forsaken places are many in the midst of the land. 13 And though a tenth remain in it, it will be burned again, like a terebinth or an oak, whose stump remains standing when it is felled. The holy seed is its stump.

 

LXX 9 καὶ εἶπεν Πορεύθητι καὶ εἰπὸν τῷ λαῷ τούτῳ Ἀκοῇ ἀκούσετε καὶ οὐ μὴ συνῆτε καὶ βλέποντες βλέψετε καὶ οὐ μὴ ἴδητε, 10 ἐπαχύνθη γὰρ ἡ καρδία τοῦ λαοῦ τούτου, καὶ τοῖς ὠσὶν αὐτῶν βαρέως ἤκουσαν καὶ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς αὐτῶν ἐκάμμυσαν, μήποτε ἴδωσιν τοῖς ὀφθαλμοῖς καὶ τοῖς ὠσὶν ἀκούσωσιν καὶ τῇ καρδίᾳ συνῶσιν καὶ ἐπιστρέψωσιν καὶ ἰάσομαι αὐτούς.

 

1)      Isa 1 introduces the book of Isa and Isa 112. Here, Isa uses Deuteronomic language and describes God initiating legal proceedings against rebellious Israel who refuses to understand.

2)      Isa 25 continues the judgment motif.

a)      There are 2 themes:

i)       Emphasis on idolatry and illicit cultic practice.

ii)     Primary responsibility rests on the Jerusalem leadership who rejects Gods instruction.

b)      In the Song of the Vineyard (Isa 5), the people condemn themselves. In Isa 5:24, we have the peoples final repudiation of Yahwehs instruction.

3)      Isa 6 with the commissioning of Isa is the beginning of Yahwehs lex talionis. Israel rejects Yahwehs instruction and refuses to understand. Consequently, Yahweh as the supreme judge ratifies their choice, sentences them to a hardening of heart (like Pharaoh). Ultimately, they will continue to see but not understand, they will continue to hear but not comprehend until the cities lie desolate.

a)      Note Isa 6:9, Go tell this people rather than the more endearing phrase my people.

b)      God commands Isaiah to undertake this ministry in the full knowledge that the results will be negative; such preaching to these people evokes a negative response, and is in some sense the cause of the negative response.

c)      The peoples hardening toward Gods purposes is not merely a result of their own volition, but is brought about actively by the prophetic messenger (Koestenberger, John, CNTUOT).

d)      Isaiahs success is not dependent on a positive response on the part of the people, but by his faithfulness to his commission from God.

4)      In sum, Isa. 6:913 is Yahwehs judicial response, effected through the parabolic proclamation of his prophet, to an idolatrous Judah, whose protestations of faithfulness are belied by the leaders rejection of Yahwehs instruction (CNTUOT).

 

1)      Context of Isa 6:910 seems to favor the view that ἵνα suggests purpose, especially the statement Make the heart of this people calloused; make their ears dull and close their eyes.

a)      But, the omission of the phrase make the heart of this people calloused in Mark weakens the purpose nature of the Isa quite in Mark.

b)      The common interpretation of this passage in Jesus day saw this verse as a promise rather than a threat.

2.7.4.1.2.1.2    Isa 6:910 in Judaism

1)      General trend in LXX and Targum is not to soften the impact of the MT but to clarify the reason behind Yahwehs hardening of Judahs heart.

2)      In the DSS, the Qumran community consider themselves the holy seed. They are exhorted to hear so that their eyes being opened, they might walk perfectly in all of Gods paths.

3)      But the rabbinic writings focus not on the threat of hardening but the promise of forgiveness.

2.7.4.1.2.2     Use of Isa 6:910 in Mark

Mark 4:10 Καὶ ὅτε ἐγένετο κατὰ μόνας, ἠρώτων αὐτὸν οἱ περὶ αὐτὸν σὺν τοῖς δώδεκα τὰς παραβολάς. 11 καὶ ἔλεγεν αὐτοῖς, Ὑμῖν τὸ μυστήριον δέδοται τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ· ἐκείνοις δὲ τοῖς ἔξω ἐν παραβολαῖς τὰ πάντα γίνεται, 12 ἵνα βλέποντες βλέπωσιν καὶ μὴ ἴδωσιν, καὶ ἀκούοντες ἀκούωσιν καὶ μὴ συνιῶσιν, μήποτε ἐπιστρέψωσιν καὶ ἀφεθῇ αὐτοῖς.

 

1)      Similarities between Isa 6 and Mark

a)      Issue: Yahwehs kingship || Jesus ushering of the kingdom of God

b)      Rejection of Gods salvation by Judahs leadership || rejection by Israels religious leadership.

i)       What is the pattern of leaderships rejection of Jesus in Mark?

(1)   Conflict accounts in 2:13:6, culminating in the plot by the Pharisees and Herodians on the life of Jesus.

(2)   Jesus warning against blasphemy and the unpardonable sin (3:29) suggests that a line has been crossed; the religious authorities willfully make themselves enemies of God.

(3)   As in Isaiah, Jesus then responds in parables in 4:134 which confirm those on the outside in their rebellion.

(a)   In this way, Mark confirms the understanding of the MT as clarified in the LXX, the Targum: it is the prior stubborn rebellion of the nation that leads to its judgment.

2)      Differences between Isa and Mark

a)      In Isaiah, both the people and leaders have made their decision to reject Yahweh. In Mark, this is not so. Thus, Jesus concludes his parable by saying, Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear.

i)       For example, Jesus family keeps their concerns private and do not denounce him. They are not in the same degree as the scribes. Nevertheless, until they make a conscious choice for Jesus, they are still in the outside.

3)      Everything centers on hearing in faith and repentance. The parables are revelatory of the kingdom and of the hearers hearts.

a)      They are the judicial response from Jesus (the one who inaugurate Gods kingly reign) to stubborn and rebellious hearts. For those who refuse, Jesus parable in words and deeds only confirm their unbelief. Jesus proclamation and deed of the kingdom of God reveal as clearly as a lamp on a stand (4:2123).

b)      At the same time, they are also a warning to those who are less hostile, perhaps like Jesus family, but who are nevertheless still outside. If they do not respond to the good that he does and the life that he gives with repentance and faith, then even the little that they have will be taken away (4:2425).

4)      Application

a)      Importance of hearing rightly.

b)      Humility. In order to hear rightly, one must be self aware of our lack of illumination, and, like the disciples, ask him to explain the parables.

i)       This need for humility in order to obtain spiritual illumination or spiritual sight is seen in John 9, esp. 9:3941. Jesus said, For judgment I came into this world, that those who do not see may see, and those who see may become blind. When the Pharisees claim to see, Jesus remarks, If you were blind, you would have no guilt; but now that you say, We see, your guilt remains.

 

1)      ἐκείνοις δὲ τοῖς ἔξω ἐν παραβολαῖς τὰ πάντα γίνεται

a)      τὰ πάντα: Includes Jesus entire ministry, but focus is on his teaching about the kingdom of God.

b)      This does not mean that Jesus only uses parables in teaching outsiders, but that to outsiders, all things are obscure.

i)       But then, how do you explain 4:34? He did not speak to them without a parable (probably hyperbole). Jesus teaching was not limited to parables (1:15; 3:28; 6:1011; 8:3438; 9:3350; 10:1819, 2431, 4245; 12:1344; 13:537, This is hyperbole to emphasize the enigmatic nature of Jesus teaching (Stein).

c)      ἐν παραβολαῖς: note the plural.

i)       *This verse that parables are not given in order to help people understand. But in Mark 4, parables are employed to give understanding of Gods kingdom, not so much to obscure them. 4:1112 must be understood within the larger context that parables do convey truth rather than conceal it, albeit veiled truth.

d)      France notes that it is misleading to ask whether parables reveal or conceal. The intention of the sower is to produce results, but whether that is achieved depends on the soils. Similarly, parables will elicit different results. The focus is not on the intention of the teacher but on the receptivity of the hearers.

2)      ἵνα options

a)      purpose (in order that). The purpose of the parable is to conceal. Reason: to prevent those outside from understanding and as a result repenting and being forgiven.

i)       Refutation: But Jesus intentionally used certain parables to teach those outside (Luke 15:12 and subsequent parables). Moreover, at times, those outside understood the parables (Mark 12:12).

b)      result (so that)

c)      fulfillment (Lane)

d)      typological correspondence (France)

e)      causal

f)       *blurring of purpose and result (Moule, Idiom,143).

g)      *purpose, but rather than arguing from cause result (since God purposed that those outside would not repent and be forgiven, Jesus taught in parables), the argument moves from the result cause (since Jesus teaching resulted in those not understanding, this must be in Gods plan) [Stein]

3)      μήποτε

a)      *lest or in order that not take place

i)       Jesus taught in parables to prevent his hearers from turning and being forgiven.

b)      unless or if perhaps (Blomberg, Parables).

i)       Support: The Marcan form of Isa 6:910 differs from the MT and the LXX and follows the Targum. The Targum translates the μήποτε not as in order that not (i.e. lest), but as lest perhaps or unless. Rabbinic exegesis took the conclusion of Isa 6:10 as a promise that God would forgive Israel if she repented.

ii)     Bottom line: Jesus teaching in parables will result in a lack of understanding unless his hearers turn and are forgiven.

(1)   We have example of μήποτε interpreted this way in Luke 3:15; John 7:26; 2 Tim 2:5. But this is not the usual way of translating μήποτε.

4)      Marks phrase is rendered Jesus taught in parables with the purpose (in order) that those on the outside would hear and see and not understand with the purpose (lest) that they not turn and be forgiven. Jesus speaks in parables so that/in order that outsiders will not be able to understand.

a)      But some of Jesus parables were understood well (12:12). Here, the Pharisees understood (cognitively) that Jesus spoke the parable against them. But they did not understand the truth or validity of the parable. Therefore, they did not turn (ἐπιστρέψωσιν), but rather sought to arrest him. Rather, the parable only confirmed the hardness of their hearts.

5)      Other ways to get around the difficulty that are not convincing.

a)      Mark mistranslated the Aramaic that Jesus used. Instead of translating it as οἵ (who), Mark translated it as ἵνα (in order that).

i)       Translation: To you has been given the secret of the kingdom of God, but for those outside who see but do not perceive and hear but do not understand, everything appears as mashalim (riddles or parables).

ii)     Refutation: Speculative; what we only have is Mark.

b)      Mark 4:1012 is a Marcan creation that cannot be traced back to Jesus.

i)       Refutation: Mark 4:1012 differs from MT and LXX, but is traced back to the Targum Palestinian-Aramaic environment for its origin.

c)      Little difference between purpose and result.

i)       Translation: Since Jesus teaching in parables resulted in his listeners not understanding and repenting, this must ultimately be due to the purpose of God.

d)      Interpret ἵνα as ἵνα πληρωθῇ.

i)       Translation: To you . but for those outside everything is in parables in order that [what the Scriptures have said may thus be fulfilled and] they may indeed see but not perceive, and may indeed hear but not understand, unless they should turn [in faith to God] and [then they will] be forgiven.

6)      Bottom line: Jesus did, at least at times, use the parables for purposes of concealing as well as revealing.

a)      But though the interpretation and precise meaning is withheld, the outsiders still perceive the gist (cf. Mark 12:12) (Caragounis, Kingdom of God, DJG). Not sure about this.

2.7.4.1.2.3     Matt

1)      Matt uses ὅτι (because).

a)      Jesus speaks in parables because of the spiritual insensitivity of his hearers.

2)      Explanation for difference between Mark-Matt.

a)      Matt softens Marks difficult reading.

b)      Matts change is motivated to blame the Jews or to show why they were rejected.

c)      But not a contradiction between Mark and Matt.

i)       There is a strong predestinarian stance throughout, even in Matt 12:11 (To you it has been given to know , but to them it has not been given). Here, Matt gives the human reason.

ii)     Both authors balance divine sovereignty and human responsibility.

iii)   *Parables serve to confirm the state of peoples hearts, to further harden those whose hearts are hard, and to enlighten those with a desire to learn. Parables therefore do not simply provide information but challenge the reader.

2.7.4.1.2.4     Luke

1)      Luke: keep ἵνα but removes μήποτε clause, softening Marks view.

 

2.7.4.1.3     Why Jesus taught in parables

1)      To conceal

a)      His audience was hostile to him.

i)       The Sadducees saw him as a threat to the temple system.

ii)     The Pharisees saw him as a threat to their self-righteousness (Luke 18:914; Matt 21:1336) and their religious leadership and their oral traditions (Mark 7:13).

b)      By speaking in parables, Jesus made it difficult for his enemies to find charges against him. The parables therefore concealed his message to those outside, but Jesus privately explained them to his followers.

c)      But in Mark 4:1012, Jesus spoke in parables so that they would fail to understand in order that they would be unable to repent and be forgiven. It is clear that at times, the parables are far from self-evident illustrations.

d)      Other sayings which argue that the message of Jesus was intentionally concealed

i)       Matt 11:2527

ii)     Understanding and faith are a divine gift.

2)      To reveal and illustrate his message to his followers and outsiders.

a)      The parable of the Good Samaritan is an unforgettable illustration of what it means to be a loving neighbor.

b)      Outsiders understood the point Jesus was seeking to illustrate

i)       Mark 12:12

3)      To disarm his listeners

a)      Jesus sought to penetrate the hostility and hardness of his listeners.

i)       2 Sam 12:14.

ii)     Story of 2 moneylenders told to Simon the Pharisee (Luke 7:3650)

2.7.4.1.4     Parables and mystery

1)      What is the relationship of Pauls mystery language and parables.

a)      This teaching about mystery indicates that God hides his plan of salvation from those who do not know him. While it remains hidden to others, God does, however, make his plan of salvation known to his people (Mystery, in New Dictionary of Biblical Theology).

 

 

 

 

2.7.5        Interpretation of the Parable of the Sower (4:13-20) [124]

1)      Emphasis

a)      The preaching of the word elicits different responses. This may be a reflection of the experience of Jesus with his different audiences. At the same time, it is a call to the hearers to listen and respond to the message. Marks readers should take heed that they are the good soil and respond with faithful endurance (Stein).

i)       Tone is hortatory and prescriptive, fits the call to hear (4:3, 9).

b)      Focus is on the ultimate harvest at the end. Despite events to the contrary, a bountiful harvest will result from preaching the word.

 

1)      Pattern of private explanation to disciples (7:1723; 8:1621; 10:1012; 13:337 for pronouncements; 9:2829; 11:2125 for deeds).

2)      Failure of disciples (4:13).

a)      4:13 is not found in Matt-Luke.

b)      In contrast to Mark, Matt presents a more favorable impression of the disciplesthey are able to understand. See Matt 13:5152, M material (134)

c)      How will you understand all the parables?

i)       Does not imply that this parable is the key for understanding all other parables. Such as those who say that if this parable applies the allegorical method, then you should also use the allegorical method for other parables.

ii)     Rather, this verse means If you cannot understand this parable, how will you ever understand the other parables (that are more difficult)? (Stein)

d)      Function is not to denigrate the disciples, but to have them serve as examples whose failure to understand demonstrate what true discipleship involves.

3)      Interpretation (4:1420)

a)      Seed = word = Jesus teaching given in Galilee beginning with the gospel in 1:15.

b)      Awkward:

i)       People are identified with the soil in 4:15, but then later with the seed (οἱ σπειρόμενοι/ οἱ σπαρέντες) [4:16, 18, 20]. Treat the σπειρόμενοι as substantival.

ii)     People are identified with the soil throughout (Stein). Treat the σπειρόμενοι as adjectival.

(1)   4:15 These are the οἱ παρὰ τὴν ὁδόν (the besides-the-path people) who are sown (σπειρόμενοι).

(2)   4:16 These are the οἱ ἐπὶ τὰ πετρώδη (the upon-the-rocky soil people) who are sown (σπειρόμενοι).

(3)   4:18 Others are the οἱ εἰς τὰς ἀκάνθας (the in-the-thorny soil people) who are sown (σπειρόμενοι).

(4)   4:20 These are the οἱ ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν τὴν καλὴν (good ground people) who are sown (οἱ ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν τὴν καλὴν).

c)      3 kinds of unfruitful soil

i)       Path: no positive response due to enticement of evil (personified by Satan who snatches away the word)

ii)     Rocks: superficial interest, lacking foundational roots to withstand external pressures (heat of the sun) from social or religious environment (θλίψεως ἢ διωγμοῦ διὰ τὸν λόγον; 4:17).

iii)   Thorns: superficial interest that falls short of rigorous demands of true discipleship. Falls away due to internal priorities (αἱ μέριμναι τοῦ αἰῶνος, ἡ ἀπάτη τοῦ πλούτου, αἱ περὶ τὰ λοιπὰ ἐπιθυμίαι; 4:19).

d)      Fruitful soil: proper response to Gods word in obedience and perseverance.

i)       Fruit: Accepting the message and living it, probably involves faithfulness to Jesus and his teaching.

(1)   Note Matt theme of understanding: hears the word and understands it.

4)      Possible context in light of different responses so far, although not spelt out.

i)       Scribes and Pharisees opposition: 1st soil

ii)     Crowds superficial amazement: 2nd and 3rd soil

iii)   Disciples commitment: 4th soil.

2.7.6        2 short parables on Revelation and Response {2 Parables on receptivity} (4:2125) [125]

1)      These parables are // in Luke but scattered at various places in Matt.

2)      Function:

a)      Warning for outsiders to listen carefully

i)       Parable of the lamp: What is hidden is meant to be manifest, and the way to understand it is by listening correctly.

ii)     Parable of the measure: If we do not listen carefully, even what they have will be taken away.

iii)   As clearly as a lamp on a stand (4:2123) and as surely as the planted seed grows (4:2629), Jesus proclamation of the kingdom of God in parables will reveal the state of the hearers hearts and their destiny. If they do not respond, even what they have will be taken away (4:2425) (CNTUOT, 154)

b)      Function if addressed to insiders

i)       They are to publicize what they hear about the kingdom

ii)     They are to listen carefully to what they hear and not ignore it.

2.7.6.1       Parable of the lamp (4:2123)

1)      Parable (4:21)

a)      Bushel and bed = places where the lamp cannot be seen.

b)      Lamp =

i)       *Jesus, due to the personal verb ἔρχεται (Cranfield, Lane, Edwards) || parabolic revelation, particularly the secret of the kingdom of God, the knowledge which separates insides/outsiders (France) || word of God || *coming of the kingdom of God (Stein)

2)      Meaning (4:22)

a)      There is nothing hid except to be made manifest: What is hidden now will one day be revealed.

i)       Hiddenness serves the purpose of openness. Jesus is hidden in order to be manifested. Concealment intends disclosure.

(1)   The kingdom of God is like an embroidery: on 1 side is a mass of knots, while the other is a finished pattern. How do you detect in the ordinary threads of life the emerging pattern of the kingdom of God? Only by hearing (Edwards).

b)      Hidden; secret kingdom of God and Jesus role in it which is hidden.

c)      Contrast between a time of secrecy and open manifestation.

i)       Time for hiddenness, secrecy = present time in Jesus ministry

ii)     Time for open manifestation = resurrection with proclamation by disciples || *Parousia.

3)      Exhortation (4:23). How you hear is critical.

a)      *Warning. Take heed how you hear. This is an appeal for spiritual perception. There will be an unveiling in the future at the Parousia where Jesus identity will be revealed clearly.

b)      Not a warning to heed but encouragement that God will make the lamp manifest to all (Stein).

i)       Reminds readers that Jesus (the Lamp) and the kingdom of God although temporarily hidden, they are now being made manifest through his death and resurrection and in the proclamation of the early church. Moreover, Mark also reminds his readers that this hiddenness served a divine purpose in that the hiddenness led to the blindness of those outside led to death and resurrection of Jesus. The hiddenness of the kingdom of God led some to crucify the Son, and all of this was ultimately under a divine plan.

c)      Clarification of 4:1012. True intent of the kingdom in Jesus is not to conceal but to reveal. There is nothing hidden in the parables that will not be made manifest to his disciples in private explanation (Gundry).

2.7.6.2       Parable of the measure (4:2425)

1)      Function:

a)      Shows effect of teaching in parables, i.e. confirms the hearts of the listeners.

b)      Encourage proper hearing because careful hearing will be rewarded. What you get out of the parables depend on what you put in. Computer term: GIGO (Garbage In Garbage Out).

2)      Exhortation (4:24). Mark has Take heed what (τί) you hear; Luke has Take heed how (πῶς) you hear. Marks meaning is similar to Lukes, although awkward. The whole discourse centers on the difference between effective and ineffective hearing. The same parable is heard by both outsiders and insiders. The difference is not what you hear but how you hear them.

a)      In Mark, the effect is Consider carefully (βλέπετε) what you are now hearing. Do not dismiss it lightly. In essence, it is not what you are hearing but the attitude you are hearing that it is the issue (Lau).

3)      Lex talionis (law of retribution) = principle of reciprocity. We will receive what we do.

4)      Even what he has will be taken away: Those that have the privilege of being Gods people in the covenant, the knowledge that they have will be taken away. Similar to Rom 11 where those in Israel who have rejected Christ will be removed from the olive Tree.

2.7.7        2 more Parables of Seed (4:2632) [126, 128]

1)      Function

a)      Assurance

i)       These 2 parables complement the previous 2 by noting that despite the hiddenness of the kingdom of God, growth is certain. Although the kingdom may be insignificant in the beginning, it will be immense in the end. Mark assures his readers that God is in control.

b)      Warning

i)       Further develops the idea of time of secrecy || time of revelation, showing the paradox of the present unrecognized status of the kingdom and its future consummation. Warns against underestimating the significance of proclaiming the kingdom of God.

ii)     Against dismissing Jesus

(1)   Also warns against thinking that God is not at work in a significant way in Jesus, which is seen when the villagers of Nazareth do not believe that the local carpenters boy was capable of doing what he was doing (6:16). To dismiss Jesus message is a serious mistake because this is the seed that God has planted in whose eschatological shade the nations (birds of the air) will find rest.

(2)   This should be read in light of the Markan narrative where there is an increasing alignment of various authorities against Jesus: the Pharisees, the Herodians, the scribes from Jerusalem, and even his family.

 

1)      Parable of seed growing secretly (4:2639) [126]

a)      Only present in Mark. Matt has parable of the tares, which develops a different point.

b)      Similitude. Probably not an allegory where the farmer represents Jesus, the disciples, or God, and there is no need to find some consistent theological explanation for the farmers behavior.

c)      Harvest may imply a time of judgment and blessing.

d)      Thrust:

i)       In the story, the man does not contribute anything to the seeds growth apart from the initial sowing: no description of the typical farming activities (plowing, tilling. ) coupled with not knowing how the seed grows and the seed grows automatically.

ii)     Disciples need not worry about how the kingdom of God will come about (he knows not how; 4:27). The kingdom may be in a state of hiddenness, but the primary task of the disciples is to sow the seed. The kingdom will come in Gods way, Gods timing, and not by human effort or according to human logic.

2)      Parable of the mustard seed (4:3032) [128]

a)      Thrust:

i)       Present insignificance || future greatness. Emphasis is not on future greatness since all Jews affirm that the kingdom of God at the end of time would be great. Rather, what is emphasized is present insignificance and smallness. Rome is oblivious, and the Jewish leaders are blinded. They do not perceive that the wedding has begun with disreputable characters.

ii)     Birds of the air: may allude to Ezek 17:23 (of the renewed Davidic kingdom); 31:6 (of Assyria and Pharaoh); Dan 4:12, 21 (of Nebuchadnezzar) which shows the wide scope of the kingdom of God, to which many nations (Gentiles) will seek shelter.

b)      Caution: Dont read into this parable an evolutionary progress stemming from a Hegelian philosophy resulting in liberal theology. Such notions were destroyed by WW1, WW2, Rather, the contrast is between the beginning and end, without description of the progress.

c)      Smallest of all the seeds on earth:[19] The mustard seed is not the smallest seed if we understand seed in a scientific sense. However, if we understand seed to be that which people planted in the ground to grow crops, it is the smallest seed.[20] Moreover, we should not discount the hyperbolic use of language in those days.

2.7.8        Editorial Comment Parables and Explanation (4:3334) [130]

1)      Distinction between outsiders and insiders.

a)      Outsiders are given parables as they were able to hear:

i)       Parables enlighten or obscure depending on ones ability to hear. How you hear determines whether youre an insider or outsider. As an outsider perceives and wants to find out more, he moves from outsider to insider.

b)      Insiders are given explanations (to his own disciples he explained everything).

i)       An insider is one who is around Jesus and has fellowship with him. In this situation, fuller understanding is possible.

2)      Inclusio:

a)      By means of such miracles he spoke the word to them (4:33) || And he taught them many things in parables (4:2). demonstrates unity of 4:134.

b)      This is a collection of Jesus parables and not a chronological description of his parabolic teaching on a particular day.

3)      Imperfect tense Jesus customary habit of speaking in parables.

4)      He did not speak to them without parables

a)      Hyperbole emphasize enigmatic nature of Jesus teaching.

b)      Jesus teaching was not limited to parables (1:15; 3:28; 6:1011; 8:3438; 9:3350; 10:1819, 2431, 4245; 12:1344; 13:537, etc.).
