2.8         Further revelation of Jesus unique authority (4:355:43) {JesusLord of Nature, Demons, Disease, and Death} [13638]

1)      There are 10 miracles in 4:358:26. Achtemeier notes that they are from a pre-Markan miracle catenae, and they can be divided into 2 balanced groups. All 5 stories in the 2nd catena take place outside Galilee, Mark shows the ministry of Jesus for the benefit of the surrounding Gentile population.[21] [But Gerasene demoniac is also outside Galilee?]

 

Catena 1

Catena 2

Stilling of the Storm (4:3541)

Jesus walks on the sea (6:4551)

Gerasene demoniac (5:1-20)

Blind man of Bethsaida (8:2226)

Women with a hemorrhage (5:2534)

Syrophoenician woman (7:24b30)

Jairus daughter (5:2123, 3543)

Deaf-mute (7:3237)

Feeding the 5,000

Feeding the 4,000 (8:110)

 

1)      These 4 parabolic deeds follow after the 4 parables, that raise even more emphatically the question of Jesus identity. Each is accompanied by amazement and fear in response to Gods powerful presence in Jesus (NIVSB).

2)      Function: 4 miracle stories that shows Jesus increasing authority over nature, demonic forces, disease, and death.

a)      Corresponding to the four parables (4:134), the following four amazing parable-deeds further identify Jesus with Yahweh-Warrior, who inaugurates Israels Isaianic new exodus (CNTUOT).

b)      Stakes are raised with the first nature-miracle resulting in the astonishment of the disciples Who is this? Even the wind and waves obey him!

c)      If these 4 miracles are linked, then perhaps the question Who then is this? needs to be asked at the end of each of the 4 miracles miracle.

3)      These 4 miracle stories are linked together in a geographical sequence centering on the lake.

a)      Jesus crosses from the west side of the lake to the other side (Stilling of the storm)

b)      Gerasene demoniac

c)      Jesus returns to Capernaum. Jesus walks παρὰ τὴν θάλασσαν (5:21) and is met by Jairus, and on the way heals another woman.

4)      Placement of miracle story after teaching is not surprising: Jesus announces the kingdom of God in his teaching and demonstrates its presence by actions.

2.8.1        Miracle #1: Authority over wind and water (4:3541) [136]

1)      Function:

a)      Christology: Emphasize Jesus greatness. He has authority over nature. Together with 6:4552 (the other lake miracle), these 2 miracles cast Jesus in a more supernatural light.

i)       OT Background: Control of the forces of nature is an attribute of God

(1)   Job 38:811; Pss 65:58; 89:89; 107:23-32.

ii)     Both of them conclude with the disciples inability to comprehend the events (4:4041; 6:52). This raises the christological question Who is this? much higher.

b)      Discipleship: Minor theme is on the failure of the disciples.

2)      Redactional studies: Bornkamm.

a)      Mark considers it a simple miracle.

b)      Matt views this as a paradigm for discipleship. See 8990. Follows after testing the 2 would be disciples (8:1822), and the verb ἀκολουθέω (which is unnecessary in the narrative) in 8:23 (which echoes the ἀκολύθει μοι in 8:22). Shows the glory and danger of discipleship.

i)       Mark: Disciples accusatory tone, Do you not care if we perish || Have you no faith

ii)     Matt: Disciple wake Jesus, Save, Lord, we are perishing || O men of little faith

(1)   Bornkammm suggests that Jesus credits the disciples with faith and after the miracle, the disciples no longer disbelieve at all.

c)      Critique

i)       France cautions that the story in Matt is still primarily a miracle story that shows the ἐξουσία of Jesus ministry. In this, Matt is in agreement with Mark. Its a matter of emphasis.

ii)     Matt softens the negative force of Marks wording, but this is not irreconcilable. We have different perspective of the disciples wavering response, but both Matt and Mark probably had the same purpose in mind: those who felt inadequate in their faith could grow in their Christian lives, just as the 12 did despite a poor beginning.

3)      Other interpretations

a)      Marcus associates this story with the Jonah story. But there are not enough similarities.

b)      Allegorical interpretation:

i)       Bornkamm: Storm is the trial of life, boat is the church. For him, church is a haven of faith. Story is to encourage the church (boat) to remain faithful during persecution (storm) as it awaits the delayed second coming of Jesus (Jesus sleeping).

 

1)      Setting (4:3537)

a)      Geography: Surrounded by mountains.

i)       Given the topography of the Sea of Galilee, a storm could descend quickly onto the sea and without notice. The Sea of Galilee is 700 ft below sea level and is surrounded by hills with deep ravines which act like funnels that draw the cold wind down to the sea. The hills on the east side are steep. Cool air which rushes down the ravines collide with the warm air above the lake, creating an instant storm.

ii)     1st century fishing boat found in 1986 in Ginosar.

(1)   L: 9 meters; W: 2.5 m ; D: 1.25 m. 4 rowers, capacity of 15 people.

iii)   Look at topographical maps.

b)      Other boats were with him Jesus popularity.

2)      Terror and rebuke by the disciples (4:38)

a)      He was in the stern, asleep on the cushion:

i)       Jesus sleep could be due to fatigue or the serenity of omnipotence.

ii)     The Ginosar boat also had a raised section on one end. Jesus probably slept under the elevated stern platform.

b)      Teacher, do you not care? Only in Mark.

i)       Disciples do not understand Jesus identity and significance. They are therefore afraid and angry. Shows their self-centeredness. Begins failure of discipleship motif, although some think that it begins with 4:13.

c)      Teacher: For Marks use of διδάσκω/διδάσκαλος.[22]

3)      Miracle and aftermath (4:3941)

a)      Rebuke of the wind (4:39): Use of ἐπετίμησεν and Σιώπα, πεφίμωσο // 1:25 (ἐπετίμησεν, φιμώθητι). Some suggest that Mark sees this calming of the storm as an exorcism, but thats a stretch. The command just indicates that the winds are to cease what they are currently doing.

i)       Jesus does what only God can do (Gen 8:1; Job 26:1112; Pss. 18:15; 65:7; 74:1315; 104:49; 106:9; 107:2430; Isa 50:2; 51:910; Nah 1:34) (Stein).

b)      Rebuke of the disciples (4:40)

i)       Continues from 4:13 and develops further (7:18; 8:17ff, 23, 32f; 9:1819, 3337; 10:1316, 3545; 14:39, 2731, 3242, 5354, 6672).

ii)     What they lack is not understanding but πίστις.

c)      Response of the disciples (4:41)

i)       Great fear = awe (RSV), unlike the fear of 6:50 (ghost). When Jesus rebukes them above, he uses δειλός (cowardly) rather than φοβέομαι.

ii)     Who is this?:

(1)   Readers already know the answer (1:1-13), but disciples are still struggling to come to grips with the identity of Jesus.

(2)   Not another example of disciples failure to understand but a positive confession of Jesus greatness (Stein).

2.8.2        Miracle #2: Authority over demonic power: Gerasene demoniac (5:120) [137]

1)      Christology

a)      Shows ἐξουσία of Jesus; authority over demons.

i)       Most spectacular exorcism: location in Gentile area, description of the demoniac, naming of demons, destruction of pigs.

(1)   Brings to a climax Jesus authority over the demons, even though there are later reports of exorcisms.

(2)   Mark more expansive (330 words) || Matt (135 words).

b)      Identity of Jesus. The previous pericope concludes, Who then is this? This pericope provides some answers:

i)       Jesus is the Son of the Most High God (υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ τοῦ ὑψίστου; 5:7).

(1)   Do not think a full blown Nicene Christology. But rather, there exists a unique relationship between Jesus and God such that what Jesus has done is what God the Lord has done. See 5:1920 where Jesus tells the man to proclaim what the Lord (i.e. God) has done for him, but he instead went and proclaimed what Jesus has done for him.

(2)   Demons affirm Jesus is the Holy One of God (1:24), the Son of God (3:11), the Son of the Most high God (5:7). Possible growing intensity.

ii)     Jesus is the mighty Lord and conqueror of demons.

c)      New exodus motif:

i)       If there are allusions to the original exodus, then its possible that the drowning of the pigs (demonic hosts) // drowning of Israels enemy, Egypt.

2)      Missiological

a)      The kingdom of God and the Messiah is for both Jews and Greeks.

3)      Location:

a)      Mark-Luke: Gerasenes; Matt: Gadarenes.

b)      Variants: *Gerasa: Hills of the Transjordan (35 miles SE from the Lake) || Gadara: city is 6 miles SE from the Lake; but the southeastern shore (area nearest to both Gadara and Gerasa) offer no cliffs || Gergesa (eastern shore) proposed by Origen = modern Kursi; topographically fits the description but has least textual support.

i)       Most believe that the actual location is the village now called Kursi.

ii)     Both Gerasa and Gadara are cities of the Decapolis.

iii)   Gadara: Josephus remarks that Gadara had villages on the lake and probably included Gerasa; Gadara was the regional capital.

iv)   *Resolution: Marks Gerasa is probably a loose term, including the city and the surrounding region.

(1)   Just as I tell friends (esp. international friends) that I live in Chicago, even though I dont live in Chicago but Deerfield.

c)      Gentile area, given presence of pigs shows extension of Jesus ministry into the predominantly Gentile region of the Decapolis.

 

1)      Setting (5:1-5)

a)      Cutting with stones: suicide attempt || demon worship.

b)      Stress is on the pitiful condition.

i)       Mark shows that demon possession destroys the divine image in man (Lane).

c)      Mark-Luke (1 demoniac) || Matt (2 demoniacs).

i)       Probably there were 2. Matt records the bare facts; Mark-Luke focus on only the more prominent demoniac. Not likely that Matt introduces extra person to make up the legal minimum number for witnesses.

ii)     Nolland suggests that Matts doubling is to indicate that the incidents were not one-offs but part of a larger pattern and further suggests that this probably has some relationship to the importance in Jewish law of 2 witnesses (Nolland, NIGTC).

2)      Interchange and exorcism (5:613)

a)      προσκυνέω: not worship, but reluctant acknowledgment of a superior.

b)      Cry of the demon

i)       Son of the Most High God:

(1)   Recognition of Jesus identity. Possibly, as in 1:24, its also an attempt to control Jesus by uttering his name. Evidence in magical papyri that to know and declare the name of a spirit was to exercise control over them.[23] I dont think its likely.

(2)   Highest christological title in Mark.

(a)   Denotes divine Sonship, not Messiah (Osborne). {Not clear}

ii)     I adjure (ὁρκίζω) you: Normally associated with exorcists (cf. Acts 19:13). This could be an attempt to reverse the normal encounter and preempt Jesus use of the oath formula (France). But its better to show here the demons pleading, not negotiating, with Jesus.

iii)   For he had said to him : Suggests possibility that Jesus success in healing (8:2226) and exorcism, while never in doubt, was not always immediate (France).

c)      Jesus command

i)       What is your name? Shows Jesus mastery over the demon.

ii)     Legion: an army of demons. Legion comprises 6000 men and 120 horses. But focus here is not on the actual number of troops; just a lot of them Jesus superiority. Theres no allusion to Rome or the Roman occupation.

d)      Demons request

i)       Send them out of the country = send them into the abyss (i.e. Hades) (Luke).

ii)     Send us: Show total submission to Jesus authority.

iii)   Pigs: unclean animals, therefore fitting habitation for unclean spirits.

3)      Request granted (5:1013)

a)      Reasons for allowing demons to enter swine (Lane)

i)       Jesus allows demons to continue their destructive work (but not on man) since Satan is not yet finally defeated.

ii)     To show their ultimate destructive purpose (in drowning of pigs).

b)      Ethical dilemma (loss of animal life; economic loss): Man is worth more than animals.

4)      Result (5:1420)

a)      Proof of exorcism:

i)       Destruction of pigs.

ii)     Primary is the contrasting change in the man (clothed, right frame of mind).

b)      Cause of fear: juxtaposition of δαιμονιζόμενον || ἱματισμένον καὶ σωφρονοῦντα.

c)      Told what had happened to the swine. Possible rejection by the people because of

i)       economic reasons, but no indication that they owned the swine || *fear; they see the presence of God but like seed that falls on bad soil, they do not perceive and understand.

d)      Request to be with Jesus

i)       That he might be with him (ἵνα μετ αὐτοῦ ᾖ.): Similar to 3:14 (ἵνα ὦσιν μετ αὐτοῦ καὶ ἵνα ἀποστέλλῃ αὐτοὺς κηρύσσειν). Request for discipleship.

ii)     Jesus sends him on his mission: Example of discipleship

(1)   Tell them how much the Lord (i.e. God; see // in Luke 8:39) has done for you (ὅσα ὁ κύριός σοι πεποίηκεν). He attributes agency to Jesus, telling what Jesus has done (ὅσα ἐποίησεν αὐτῷ ὁ Ἰησοῦς).

(2)   His obedience (καὶ ἀπῆλθεν καὶ ἤρξατο κηρύσσειν fulfilling Christs purpose of discipleship in 3:14 ἵνα ἀποστέλλῃ αὐτοὺς κηρύσσειν).

(3)   Result: all men marveled

(4)   No secrecy: No objection to Gentiles hearing about his miracles because no risk of inconvenient popular enthusiasm (cf. 1:452:2) or false political messianic expectations.

iii)   Irony: Model of discipleship is the exorcised demoniac, not those who have followed Jesus.

iv)   He is one of the little people who exemplify true discipleship, while disciples fail (Rhoads & Mitchie).

2.8.3        Miracle # 3-4: Authority over disease and death (5:2143) [138]

1)      Sermon notes: Carson on Mark 5:2143.

2)      Example of intercalation.

a)      Not the best example of Marks intercalation technique as all 3 synoptists tell the story the same way.

b)      Markan sandwich: Like a sandwich, you describe it by the middle. What distinguishes a ham sandwich from an egg sandwich is the stuff in the middle, not the bread. So, the middle story of the hemorrhaging woman defines these 2 stories, and the middle of this middle is the question, Who touched me?

i)       I think that not only is the framing story to be interpreted by the inside, its also possible for the reverse (double check).

c)      Purpose:

i)       Healing of the hemorrhaging woman anticipates the greater healing.

ii)     Shows contrast (hemorrhaging woman [bottom of honor scale] || Jairus daughter [top of honor scale]). Jesus interrupts the healing of someone at the top to attend to someone at the bottom of the honor scale.

iii)   Provides a time lapse during which the girl died, in much the same way that the death of John the Baptist provides a time lapse for the mission of the disciples (Stein).

d)      Similarities between the 2 stories.

i)       Both have someone (Jairus, hemorrhaging woman) falling at Jesus feet.

ii)     Both are women in a hopeless situation

iii)   Both are stories of a female restored by Jesus touch

iv)   Both women are addressed by Jesus as daughter or some diminutive: θυγάτηρ for the woman || κοράσιον for the little girl).

v)      Both are identified by the number 12.

vi)   Both accounts have scoffers laughing at what Jesus is doing: disciples You see the crowd pressing ; the crowds weeping.

vii) Both have Jesus coming into contact with someone unclean: hemorrhaging woman || dead child. But in both case, its not Jesus who becomes unclean, but Jesus who makes the unclean clean.

(1)   I wonder if this can also be read symbolic of Jesus taking away the defilement of Israel (Lau). Double check.

3)      Connection with previous story: uncleanness.

a)      Unclean spirits; unclean animals || uncleanness of menstrual disorder, uncleanness of a corpse. But in both cases here, there is physical touch (5:27, 41). Also love hermeneutic, the love of Christ overcomes all such taboos.

4)      Mark is expansive.

5)      Primary emphasis: The 2 healings here continue Marks christological teaching showing the authority and greatness of Jesus. Jesus ἐξουσία reaches new heights: raising the dead. The question that is raised in the first miracle, Who then is this? is answered by the demons in the 2nd miracle, and is confirmed by the 3rd and 4th miracle here.

6)      Secondary emphasis: Importance of faith. Disciples are criticized for their lack of faith (4:40); the demoniac shows it by coming to Jesus and worshipping (5:6); the women is commended for it (5:34); and Jairus is urged not to lose it (5:36) (Stein).

a)      Faith is based on the authority of Jesus over nature, demons, illnesses, and death. He is worthy of faith.

b)      Woman as a paradigm of discipleship

i)       ὄπισεν: Mark 5:27 When she heard about Jesus, she came up behind him (ὄπισεν) // ὀπίσω language of discipleship (1:17, 20; 8:34).

ii)     disease: μάστιξ // closely tied to μαστιγόω of Jesus.

iii)   blood: Only 2 people in Mark whose blood is mentioned: this woman and Jesus (14:24).

iv)   suffer (πάσχω): Only 2 people in Mark who suffer: this woman and Jesus.

 

1)      Jairus request (5:2124)

a)      Jesus just crossed from the east to the west side of the Galilee.

b)      Synagogue ruler: lay ruler in charge of the building and worship services. But one of just one of the elders who constitute the governing body of the synagogue.

i)       Responsible for maintaining the building and the scrolls, and making sure that there were readers. Known for their piety. Widely respected in the community, and well to do.

c)      Fell at his feet: Prominent man in Capernaum in deference to someone who recently arrived. He is desperate. Any parent knows this mans desperation.

i)       Some measure of faith. He expects Jesus to do something. Jesus interrupts his public ministry for this private urgent appeal.

d)      At the point of death: Note the sense of urgency. Matt (has just died). Matt condenses this story, leaving out the section of the messenger and stating the condition that Jesus finds the girl when he arrives.

2)      Woman with the hemorrhage (5:2534)

a)      Jesus is interrupted despite the sense of urgency above. You can imagine the anxiety rising in Jairus. Besides this woman had this problem for 12 years; surely, she could wait an hour.

b)      Flow of blood for 12 years: menstrual disorder.

i)       Economic distress (spent all her $); physical distress (suffered much under many physicians); but also social and religious isolation, viewed virtually as a leper. Seen by her surreptitious approach to Jesus.

c)      Touch:

i)       We dont know what was in her mind. Its not stated. It could be superstition; it could be sophisticated, knowing that Jesus is so much the representative of God that just as the altar (Exod 29:1921) was so holy that if you touched the altar, you also became holy. So if she touched Jesus, then somehow what is of Jesus would also rub off on her.

(1)   Measure of desperation (as with Jairus); measure of faith (as with Jairus).

ii)     Popular belief that clothing of a holy man can impart healing powers (cf. Peters shadow, Acts 5:15 || Pauls clothing, Acts 19:12 || Jesus cloak, Mark 6:56)

iii)   Mark stresses that its not physical touch but πίστις (5:34).

d)      Effects of healing (5:2931)

i)       For woman: Immediate healing

ii)     For Jesus: Who touched my garments: Shows Jesus supernatural insight.

(1)   Wrong to assume that Jesus doesnt know the answer. 5:32 suggests that Jesus already knows about her situation (although this could be Marks interpretation). Note the feminine in περιεβλέπετο ἰδεῖν τὴν τοῦτο ποιήσασαν. Moreover, there are also places in the Bible where God asks questions, e.g. Adam, where are you. The question is to force an answer from the person to whom the question is posed. God wants Adam to step forward and face the responsibility.

iii)   For disciples: You see the crowds Failure to understand (in line with Marks portrayal). They continue to see things from an earthly commonsense perspective.

(1)   Luke softens it; Matt omits it completely.

e)      Encounter (5:3234)

i)       Fear and trembling: Awe in divine presence.

ii)     Your faith has saved you:

(1)   Faith is the basis of healing. Faith is conviction in Jesus ἐξουσία rather than a theologically developed understanding of his identity (France).

(2)   Establishes what a true encounter with Jesus is like.

(a)   Establishes significance of the earlier question. She wants the miracle; he wants the personal encounter. Jesus could just have healed her and moved on; after all, he has something urgent to deal with. Jesus changes it from a power encounter to a personal encounter. She wants a miracle; he wants to confront her with respect to her faith.

(i)     Martin Buber distinguish I it relationship from I thou relationship. We cannot have an I it relationship with God. God is just the Genie or the power source for our blessings. Christ wants an I thou relationship. Thats why 1st commandment is to Love God with all your heart, mind, and soul.

(ii)  She could have faced severe punishment for being in this crowd as she is unclean.

(iii)                        Miracles are not an end to itself; they lead to a meeting. Discipleship is not getting ones needs met, but growing in the presence of Jesus, knowing him and following him on his terms.

(iv) If Jesus didnt say anything, she might be inclined to think of Jesus power in magical terms. But Jesus specifies that it is faith. She had faith. There were undoubtedly other sick people who pressed against him, but they were not healed. It was not just touch, as if it was just magic.

(3)   saved: Probably has a wider sense than just physical healing.

iii)   Go in peace: The true shalom that she wanted, physical healing and reintegration within society.

3)      Raising of Jairus daughter (5:3543)

a)      Scene (5:3536)

i)       Your daughter is dead: Signify hopeless situation.

ii)     Why trouble the teacher any longer: Continues theme of lack of human faith.

iii)   παρακούω: *ignoring || overhearing.

iv)   Only believe: The faith of the woman (who is at the bottom of the social ladder [gender, nameless, unclean]) is to be the model for Jairus (who is near the top of the social ladder [male, named, synagogue leader]).

(1)   Jairus has some faltering faith.

(2)   This is the challenge of all discipleship. We are to continue to trust in the midst of dire circumstances.

b)      Miracle (5:3742)

i)       3 disciples are to be with him at special revelatory moments (Transfiguration, 9:2; Mount of Olives, 13:3; Gethsemane, 14:33).

(1)   Reason: Provide authoritative witness (Lane) || *Insider/outsider theme (Edwards), but then, why only 3 disciples?

ii)     Points to Jesus own resurrection.

iii)   Weeping and wailing loudly.[24]

iv)   Talitha cum: Aramaic. Mark often has the Aramaic (3:17; 7:11; 10:46; 14:36).

(1)   Bultmann: Exorcism and magic spells frequently use foreign words (Source?)

(2)   Perhaps, Mark uses is to give a vivid description of the scene || to stress that it is Jesus words that heal.

v)      Child is not dead, but asleep. This is not a medical judgment. Its how Jesus speaks of death (see the incident with Lazarus even after his body is decaying); death is not final. Death may be the final enemy, but it doesnt have the last word.

vi)   They laughed at him: The outsiders hear the words of Jesus, but they dont understand and believe it.

vii) Not a resurrection (in the eschatological sense) but a resuscitation.

c)      Charge (5:43)

i)       Secrecy motif. But how can you keep this a secret? You need to bring the girl out sometime. Perhaps, not to let anyone know about it long enough till he leaves the area (Lau).

(1)   To damp down political messianic connotations.

4)      Summary

a)      You have 2 peoples of faith or 2 kinds of faith.

b)      Note contrast:

i)       Jairus: named, man of standing, appealing for another; approaches Jesus respectfully; desperate and has bold faith in Jesus

ii)     Women with hemorrhage: unnamed, outcast; appealing for herself; she sneaks up behind; desperate but frightened.

iii)   But at the end of the day, she has faith that Jesus commends. Jairus has faltering faith that must be propped up. The sandwich account helps us to understand faith more fully than if the 2 accounts were widely separated.

(1)   What does faith mean today?

(a)   Refers to a religion, e.g. There are many faiths.

(b)   Refers to religious personal preference abstracted without notions of truth. This use of faith is not once found in the Bible. In the Bible, validity of faith turns on the truthfulness of what is believed, on the object of faith. E.g. in 1 Cor 15:17, if the resurrection did not occur, then your faith is in vain. Vain not because of lack of sincerity, but it didnt occur.

(i)     In the Bible, faith is a God given ability to perceive certain things that are true and to trust our live in Him. The Bible never suggests for us to believe in that which we think is not true.

(ii)  Bible also gives us more information about faith. For e.g. Heb tells us that genuine faith perseveres.

(2)   Here, faith of the women is commended in comparison to Jairus. The women has no name, no standing, no security. She did not deign to approach Jesus, she comes to him frightened. There are some here who think that your pastor is a man of mature faith, but when you look at your own life. You ask, How can I really trust Christ? Or you may have doubt and insecurity.

(a)   The faith that is commended here is faith that is not only desperate but broken, not the faith of the strong, but the weak; not the faith of the respected, but the disgraced; not the faith of the bold, but the faith of the frightened. All of this is bound up with the object of faith. He came as the strong comes for the weak. He wants that we not only draw from his power, but as we cry to him, Lord, I believe, help my unbelief.

(b)   You may hear the voice, Who touched me? He asked this question because he wants an I-thou relationship. God, the creator of the universe, wants to have a relationship with those who are frightened and desperate.

2.9         Not everyone is impressed by Jesus (6:16) [139]

1)      Connection with the previous episode: Lack of faith (6:6) contrasts with the faith of the woman in 5:34.

2)      Primary emphasis: Continues theme of rejection in the midst of rising popularity. He has been rejected by the Pharisees and Herodians (3:6), family (3:21, 3134), scribes (3:22), city of Gerasa (5:17). Now, second time Jesus is rejected by his own; the first is by his family.

a)      Implied application: Rejection is part of Jesus ministry; it will probably be yours also.

3)      Secondary emphasis: Necessity of faith (πίστις), but seen from a negative side. Those lacking faith will not see healing and salvation.

 

1)      Scene (6:12a)

a)      Nazareth: 25 miles from Capernaum.

b)      Common for visiting rabbis to be invited to speak. The invitation to teach at a synagogue shows that Jesus is now significant.

2)      Peoples reaction (6:2b3).

a)      What is the wisdom: Observed from his teaching.

b)      What mighty works: Second hand hearing of miracles.

c)      Problem: Jesus is the local boy.

i)       The switch in tone between 6:2 and 6:3 is unexpected. No good explanation. Perhaps just show the fickle nature of the crowds, esp. seen again in the shouts between Hosannas of Palm Sunday and the cries to Crucify him on Good Friday.

ii)     Use of οὗτος is derogatory. He is a mere carpenter.

(1)   Only Mark describes Jesus as a carpenter.

iii)   Carpenter: As the eldest son, Jesus takes over the family business of τέκτων. He worked with both stone and wood.

iv)   Son of Mary: Veiled reference to the virgin birth || Hint that they knew that he was not actually the carpenters son || Joseph has already died, but Stein argues that in the Semitic culture, Jesus would still have been addressed as the son of Joseph even if he had died.

(1)   No good explanation.

(2)   The demons and the voice from heaven recognize Jesus as the Son of God, but the people of Nazareth recognize him only as the son of Mary.

v)      Crowds comments Jesus had a normal and ordinary childhood.

vi)   Where did this man get all this?: He was never apprenticed to a rabbi. Same issue today: quality of education = quality of the person.

3)      Jesus response (6:46)

a)      6:4 is a common proverb.

i)       He could do no miracles: Probably not an absolute could not or inability for Mark records other miracles in which the beneficiaries exhibited no faith (feeding of the 5,000; stilling of the storm; healing the demoniac). The could not refers to Jesus mission, in that he could not exercise power in those circumstances since the performance of miracles in the presence of unbelief would only result in hardening mens hearts against God (Lane).

b)      Wonder ἐθαύμαζεν: Shows seriousness of the peoples unbelief. While people marveled (θαυμάζω, 5:20; ἐκθαυμάζω, 12:17) at Jesus teaching and deeds, he marveled at their unbelief.

2.10     Jesus mission extended through the disciples (6:730) [14245]

1)      Stein puts 6:6b8:21 together and notices several themes:

a)      Christology: Authority over the sick, deafness, demons, nature (feeding of 5,000; 4,000; stilling the storm; walking on water). Although Jesus rejects the request to perform a sign, the miracles in Mark do attest that Jesus indeed is the Son of God.

b)      Food: Feeding of the 5,000 (6:3544); Feeding of the 4,000 (8:19); 6:52; clean and unclean (7:123); exorcism (7:2430); Syrophoenician woman about crumbs (7:2728); JBs martyrdom and the banquet (6:1429)

c)      Misunderstanding of the disciples deepens (6:3537, 52; 7:1718; 8:1421).

d)      Continued hostility of the Pharisees.

2)      Fulfills 2nd part of the purpose in selecting the 12 (ἵνα ἀποστέλλῃ αὐτοὺς κηρύσσειν, 3:14) and his objective to make them fishers of men (1:1620).

a)      But this section is not about disciples; rather, their mission raises the profile of Jesus.

3)      Rejected by an entire Jewish Galilean village, Jesus sends the 12 to the nation at large (CNTUOT). But there is no indication of the extent of the ministry of the 12.

4)      Intercalation: Missions of the 12 sandwiches the story of the death of John the Baptist.

a)      Jesus public ministry begins after John was put into prison (1:14). Antipas execution of Jesus predecessor the mission for the kingdom of God can expect a similar reception from the kingdoms of this world. Moreover, Jesus suggests that what they did to Elijah (9:1213) will also be done to him.

b)      Disciples mission // JB: Similar proclamation (ἐκήρυξαν ἵνα μετανοῶσιν, 6:12 || κηρύσσων βάπτισμα μετανοίας, 1:4).

i)       Hostile reaction seen in Nazareth (6:16) and expected in 6:11.

ii)     Ambassador of the kingdom of God is not only called to restoration and redemption but also to a conflict (France).

c)      Jesus sends (ἀποστέλλω; 6:7) his disciples to heal (with no bread); Herod sends (ἀποστέλλω; 6:17) someone to execute JB (at a banquet).

i)       Herod Antipas wanted to be king but was not given the title king by Augustus, but he locally styled himself as king. This comparison may show Jesus to be the true king.

5)      Thrust:

a)      Primary: Cost of discipleship. Intercalation draws together the themes of witness and martyrdom, and discipleship and death. Points to 8:34 If anyone would come after me, he must deny himself and take up his cross and follow me. JBs death prefigures Jesus death and any other who follow in Jesus footsteps.

i)       John the Baptist is a precursor for Jesus

(1)   After affirming that Jesus is to be identified with John the Baptist, Mark appends the story of the death of John the Baptist. Its significance is all the more notable because this is one the few places Mark uses the literary device of flashback.

(2)   Just as JB is the precursor of Jesus in preaching of repentance (1:4 || 1:15), so also in death. Just as JB did not die of political reasons (although Josephus, Ant. 18.5.2 notes that Jesus was executed because Herod feared him as a potential political revolutionary), so also not Jesus. Just as JB was put to death by a reluctant political ruler, so also Jesus. JBs burial // Jesus burial (disciples come and take the body; πτῶμα occurs only in 6:29; 15:45; body is laid (τίθημι) in a tomb (μνημεῖον) in 6:29; 15:46)

(3)   If the religious authorities understood JBs authority, they would also understand Jesus authority (11:2733). Thats why he says, I will ask you one question. Answer me, and I will tell you by what authority I am doing these things. Johns baptismwas it from heaven, or of human origin? (11:2930).

b)      Secondary: Focusing on 6:713.

i)       Discipleship: Those who go out to do Gods work (1) should not be encumbered with the goods of the world, taking only what is necessary and useful for the mission; (2) should expect opposition.

ii)     Disciples: Presents a positive appraisal of the disciples despite the overall negative picture we, despite our flaws, can be used by God for his purpose.

iii)   Christological: Jesus is the one who possesses authority and who can bestow this authority to his disciples. He does not need to pray to God to bestow such authority on them.

6)      Application

a)      Whats the significance of this passage to how we do missions?

b)      Should this be taken literally?

i)       In forming a theology of missions, you should construct it from all of Scripture rather than from just one single passage.

ii)     Teaches a posture of faith, trusting that God will provide. The simplest preparation is needed; they have to depend on the hospitality of others.

2.10.1    Mission of the 12 (6:713, 30) [142]

1)      Extension of Jesus ministry: It is only in the report that the disciples emulated the ministry of Jesus: teaching and healing (ὅσα ἐποιήσαν καὶ ὅσα ἐδίδαξαν, 6:30).

 

1)      Sending forth (6:7)

a)      Possibly sending out in pairs follows the demand for 2 witnesses (Deut 17:6; 19:15) [Osborne].

b)      Shaliach motive [Rengstorf, TDNT 1:424f]

c)      Authority over unclean spirits: Follows Marks theme of a cosmic conflict.

i)       No guarantee that it will be successful (9:18, 2829). That which was once a special mark of Jesus is now shared with his disciples.

2)      Aspects of the commission (6:89)

a)      Minimal provisions. Emphasis on mobility and travelling lightly, perhaps fulfilling Jesus desire to preach to the surrounding regions of Galilee (1:3839).

a)      Discrepancy: Mark (take sandals, staff); Matt 10:10 (no sandals, no staff); Luke 9:3 (no staff).

i)       Luke also has Send-72 (L material; 177): Luke 10:4 (no sandals).

(1)   Blomberg, Osborne: There were 2 commissions. Send-12 (allowed staff & sandals; so Mark). Send-72 (no sandals or staff). Matt combined Send-12 with Send-72 and took the most negative form (no sandals, no shoes). Luke edited Luke 9 (Send-12) so that there will be no contradiction with Luke 10 (Send-72).

ii)     Mark may see the mission as 2nd Exodus (Exod 12:11; Deut 29:45); Matt-Luke may see it as holy ground (need to remove sandals; Exod 3:5).

iii)   Matts take no staff nor sandals do not acquire a new staff and sandals but use the staff and sandals they already possess (Carson).

iv)   *Different ways of saying the same thing: the simplest preparation is needed. They should depend on the hospitality of others.

b)      Disallow all others.

i)       Money: χαλκόν, smallest copper coin; wallet (πήρα; beggars purse)a known mark of itinerant Cynic preachers.

ii)     Reliance on God and the hospitality of others.

3)      Hospitality (6:1011)

a)      If rejected, as Jesus was in Nazareth, the disciples must move on.

b)      Shake off the dust: impending judgment. It includes a refusal to be made unclean by contact. Rabbis shook off the dust from their feet when they left Gentile territory to avoid carrying defilement with them.

i)       As 9:37 implies, rejection of disciples rejection of Jesus judgment.

4)      Action (6:1213)

a)      That men should repent ἵνα μετανοῶσιν: echoes Jesus message 1:15 (μετανοεῖτε καὶ πιστεύετε ἐν τῷ εὐαγγελίῳ) which is a repetition of JBs message (1:4). Repent/repentance in Mark only occurs in these 3 passages: 1:4, 15; 6:12.

b)      Anointing with oil: Symbolizes Gods care || actual therapeutic purpose.

c)      Their success in 6:13 contrasts with what happened in Nazareth (6:5) and heightens the unbelief of Nazareth.

5)      Return (6:30)

a)      Disciples are now called apostles.

i)       Does not suggest members of a fixed group or designate an office.

ii)     After the proclamation of Jesus message, they are now considered apostles. The main significance of an apostle is the proclamation of the message.

iii)   Probably tied to the etymological root of ἀποστέλλω in 6:7 and 3:14, but do not fall into root fallacy. {Probably not true}

2.10.2    Reaction of Antipas (6:1416) [143]

1)      Josephus account of the execution of JB presents him as a possible leader of sedition on account of powerful preaching.

2)      This account shows popular responses to Jesusthey all fall within the category of prophet.

3)      King Herod (6:14): MattLuke are correct in calling Antiapas a tetrarch. But Antipas acted and was recognized for all practical purposes as king. His drive to be called king led to his exile in 39 CE. Note that even Matt, who calls Antipas tetrarch (14:1) also calls him king (14:9).

4)      How could Herod or the people think that Jesus is John the Baptist revived since they were contemporaries, and Judaism did not hold to an individual resurrection but a general resurrection at the last day? Probably it means (1) the spirit of John the Baptist rests on Jesus; (2) Herod was saying in exasperation, This is John the Baptist all over again (Hooker); (3) Herod probably understood it in Hellenistic categories (Osborne).

2.10.3    Digression: The death of John (6:1729) [144]

1)      Markan expansion to create a memorable and vivid description: Mark (249 words); Matt (136 words).

2)      The degenerate lavishness of Antipas banquet contrasts with the simple feast in the feeding of the 5,000.

3)      Luke: Luke moves his notice of John the Baptists imprisonment from its place in the middle of Jesus Galilean ministry (Mark 6:1429) to its beginning in order that it may form the natural conclusion of his section on JBs mission (Luke 3:120).

 

1)      Antipas.

a)      Married Herodias, wife of his brother Herod Philip 1 (not Herod Philip 2, the tetrach). Forbidden in Levitical law to marry the wife of your brother (Lev 18:16; 20:21), even if they are dead, unless in the case of Levirate marriage.

b)      Jewish law did not allow a woman to divorce her husband. Herodias probably took advantage of her Roman citizenship.

2)      Dinner party

a)      The girl who danced is probably Salome, daughter of Herodias.

i)       Antipas lust for her stepdaughter is the 2nd incestuous affair after his new wife Herodias.

ii)     The dance may not be a sensuous dance, but a childs performance.

b)      Antipas weak will to Salome corroborates his weak will when confronted with Herodias.

c)      Half of my kingdom: traditional hyperbole (Est 5:3, 6; 7:2; cf. 1 Kgs 13:8).

3)      Death of John the Baptist

a)      Death of John the Baptist alludes to the death of Jesus.

b)      Soldier of the guard (σπεκουλάτωρ): Latinisms. Latin speculator used of soldiers with a special commission, for instance, as bodyguards or when detailed to carry out an execution (France).

c)      Burial of Johns body (πτῶμα; 6:29) alludes to burial of Jesus own body (πτῶμα; 15:45). The word πτῶμα is nowhere else used in Mark.

2.11     Miracles around the lake: Who is Jesus? (6:3156) [146148]

1)      As in the previous catena of miracles, the means of Jesus gradual revelation is through his miracles. These miracles again focus on his ἐξουσία.

2)      Location: After the disappointment in the hill country of Nazareth, Jesus is back at the lake againthe place of his previous popularity.

2.11.1    Feeding of the 5,000 (6:3144) [146]

1)      Synoptic comparison

a)      In Matt-Mark, this simple meal comes after and contrasts with the lavish banquet of Antipas. This is a foretaste of the messianic banquet.

i)       Moreover, the failed kingship of Herod is contrasted with the kingdom that Jesus ushers in. Antipas wanted to be king, but he was not crowned king.

b)      Only miracle found in all 4 gospels. Duplicated in Matt and Mark with the feeding of the 4,000.

2)      Primary thrust: Christological.

a)      *Greatness of Jesus, authority over natural elements. Other OT feeding miracles such as Elijah with the jar of oil (1 Kgs 17:816) or Elisha feeding 100 with 20 loaves (2 Kgs 4:4244) pale in comparison. Recalls Gods provision of manna in the wilderness. FG specifically notes that it was not Moses but God that gave the fathers manna in the wilderness.

b)      Jesus as Israels shepherd, fulfillment of the coming shepherd in Ezek 34:23; Ps Sol. 17:3044. (Stein)

3)      Secondary thrust:

a)      Failure of disciples to understand (6:3637). Seen in subsequent chapters (7:18; 8:4, 1421, 3133; 9:57, 32; 14:3740). (Stein)

b)      The dawning of the kingdom of God. Feast messianic banquet. There is also evidence of the arrival of the kingdom as the lost sheep of Israel receive their shepherd who feeds them spiritually (via teaching) and physically.

4)      Purpose of this gathering of men may be to persuade (or force) Jesus to be the political messiah they wanted.

a)      In John 6:15, the people intended to come and make [Jesus] king by force.

 

1)      OT background:

a)      Manna in the wilderness; Elisha feeding 100 with 20 loaves (2 Kgs 4:4244) signify Gods provision in the messianic banquet.

2)      OT allusion (like sheep without a shepherd; Num 27:17)

a)      Num 27:17 context

i)       Deals with the succession of Moses since he is forbidden to enter the Promised Land. Joshua is chosen so that the people will not be like sheep without a shepherd.

b)      Judaism

i)       Shepherding is a common metaphor in the OT and later Jewish literature for both Gods and human leaders care for Israel.

ii)     David is also presented as the shepherd. Moreover, as he is the one who effectively concludes the conquest of the Promised Land, he may be considered as Moses true successor.

iii)   Metaphor is especially used in the exodus led by Yahweh and becomes a key image in Isaiahs new exodus, where the mighty Yahweh-warrior is presented as a tender shepherd gently escorting his flock home (40:11).

iv)   Twin motifs of Davids and Yahwehs exodus/new exodus shepherding are combined in Ps 78 and Exod 34.

v)      In sum, Israels understanding of Yahweh as the compassionate yet strong shepherd springs from the first exodus, when the Lord provided for them, performed mighty deeds on their behalf, gave them Torah, and led them through his servant Moses. Likewise in the new exodus, the compassionate Yahweh-Warrior will again shepherd his people through his new servant. Although in Num. 27 Joshua succeeds Moses to lead the people into their inheritance, it is Yahwehs servant David who eventually becomes Israels paradigmatic shepherdprobably because he effectively completes the conquest and begins the process of establishing Yahwehs dwelling on his holy mountain, Zionand is therefore the focus of Israels eschatological shepherd hope (CNTUOT).

c)      Mark

i)       If Mark intends a clear allusion to Num 27:17, Jesus (Greek for Joshua), a man who is filled with the Spirit (like Joshua), will lead Gods flock in a new conquest of casting out demons.

ii)     Mark also contrasts Jesus with the false shepherds.

iii)   In feeding the crowds and demonstrating his power over the sea, Jesus may be a new Moses-Joshua-David. But these comparisons pale alongside his Isaianic new-exodus Yahweh-Warrior activities where he calms the sea and then drowns Israels demonic enemy hosts (alludes back to Moses) before healing the unclean woman and raising a dead girl.

(1)   Possible that the drowning of the pigs (demonic hosts) // drowning of Israels enemy, Egypt.

iv)   At the same time, in light of the servant imagery at the baptism and Jesus recent rejection by his own (6:16a), the crowds coming from all the towns around, the desert hills, and the green grass are intriguingly suggestive of Isa. 49:9s new exodus imagery of Gods people from all over pasturing on the bare heights under the auspices of the Isaianic servant, who likewise had only recently experienced a lack of success (Isa. 49:4) and who is also Israels teacher (R. E. Watts 2000: 25256) (CNTUOT).

 

1)      Scene (6:3134)

a)      ὡς πρόβατα μὴ ἔχοντα ποιμένα: Sheep without a shepherd is prominent in wilderness motifs (Num 27:17; Ezek 34:56).

i)       Israel in the wilderness (Num 27:17).

ii)     Ahabs army after his death (1 Kgs 22:17) political army without a leader

iii)   *People of God when their leaders do not discharge their duties (Ezek 34:56).

(1)   Promise of a messiah shepherd like David (34:32) who will lead them so that they may live in the desert and sleep in the forests in safety (34:25).

b)      Lonely place Ἔρημός ἐστιν ὁ τόπος: wilderness (recalls 1:34, 1213). ἔρημος occurs 3x (6:31, 32, 35), showing its significance here.

i)       People going to him in the wilderness recalls 1:45; also Jesus great popularity.

ii)     With respect to the disciples, the wilderness continues the motif of testing. The 2 miracles of Mark 6 test the disciples, and they fail on both occasions.

iii)   With respect to Jesus, the wilderness signifies a place of rest. His purpose is to provide rest (6:31) and a secure place (6:34).

c)      He had compassion on them:

i)       Recall John 10 where Jesus is the Good Shepherd. The miracle then shows the shepherd feeding and providing rest for his flock.

2)      Feeding the 5,000 (6:35-44)

a)      Failure of the disciples

i)       Although Jesus is in charge, they remind him of his responsibilities (cf. 1:3637; 4:38; 10:13).

ii)     You give them something to eat: Disciples should serve as an extension of Jesus power and authority, but they understand the command as only what they are capable of doing.

iii)   Unconcern for the crowds: Shall we go and buy Why should we spend such a large sum of money for a group of strangers?

b)      Sit down (recline; ἀνακλῖναι and ἀνέπεσαν): These verbs are associated with the Greco-Roman style of reclining at table. While it was not a formal banquet and the food was basic, there is a hint or foreshadowing of the messianic banquet.

c)      Green grass:

i)       Transformation of wilderness to a place of refreshment (Lane).

ii)     Recall Ps 23:2.

d)      Non-eucharistic. The supposedly eucharistic verbs (λαβών, εὐλόγησεν, κατέκλασεν, ἐδίδου) are normal actions for the head of the family in a Jewish meal.

e)      Leftovers

i)       Despite the simplicity of the meal, there was an abundance of food. Suggests insignificant beginnings of the kingdom of God that will eventually become a significant force (Mark 4).

ii)     12 baskets: Due to the fact that there are 12 disciples, rather than some symbolism (France).

iii)   ??ἦραν κλάσματα δώδεκα κοφίνων πληρώματα καὶ ἀπὸ τῶν ἰχθύων (6:43). How do you understand this grammar?

f)       No mention of amazement people were not aware. Lack of any mention of crowds reaction stands in contrast to John 6:1415.

2.11.2    Walking on the water (6:4552) [147]

1)      Lukes Great Omission

a)      Luke omits Mark 6:458:26.

b)      Reason?

i)       Possibly not necessary to include this or the feeding of the 4,000 since Luke already has one lake miracle and the feeding of the 5,000.

ii)     Luke structures his Gospel along the lines of a geographical outline that covers only Jesus ministry in Galilee, Samaria and Perea, and Judea in that order. (Not sure about this but then Luke also has a travel narrative. Double check. Lukes travel narrative begins with Samaria in Luke 9).

(1)   This is attractive as it sees Luke as the mirror image of Acts. [Not so sure]

iii)   *Removed Marks discussion on purity and Jesus ministry to the Gentiles because he will address it definitively in Acts.

iv)   Luke wanted to add more non-Marcan material and he was constrained by the physical limitation of a scroll.

v)      See Luke Intro.docx

2)      Emphasis 1: Supernatural power of Jesus.

a)      Epiphany of Jesus divine nature. In addition to feeding the 5,000, this episode reminds readers that Jesus does what God does in the OT. For God walking on or through the sea in OT, see Job 9:8; Ps 77:19; Isa 43:16. Moreover, theres possibility of a divine I am in 6:50. Jesus transcends the categories of teacher, prophet, Messiah, a Son of God. He is the only Son of God and possesses some sort of divinity (Stein).

3)      Emphasis 2:[25] Failure of the disciples.

a)      // with 4:3541

i)       Similarities: Late crossing; storm or strong wind; disciples fear; calming of the storm by Jesus; supernatural power of Jesus; disciples reaction of fear or astonishment.

ii)     Differences: Disciples alone and Jesus walks to them on water; Jesus comes across as a mysterious and terrifying figure rather than a familiar figure; disciples are more bewildered than impressed.

iii)   Narrative retrospection: reinforce the fact that the disciples failed to understand his calming of the storm on the first boat scene.

b)      Disciples move from a mountaintop experience of the feeding of the 5,000 (with Jesus) to a terrifying experience (without Jesus). Both scenarios demonstrate the failure of the disciples.

c)      Provides hope for readers that our failures can be forgiven. Moreover, God can still use us for his work despite our weaknesses.

2.11.2.1   Failure of the disciples

1)      Redaction

a)      Mark ends with the radical failure of the disciples, saying for they had not understood about the loaves; their hearts were hardened. Mark centers on the radical failure, and looks back at what they failed to learn about what Jesus presence meant for them in light of the importance of the previous event (see for they had not understood about the loaves [6:52])

b)      Matt ends on a note of worship and spiritual insight, saying Then those who were in the boat worshiped him, saying, Truly you are the Son of God. (14:33).

i)       Matt emphasizes the Christological understanding that this event produced, an understanding that is nevertheless coupled with some incomprehension. Whatever Son of God means here (perhaps similar to Messiah), it is not full-orbed as when Peter later uses it in Matt 16:16 where Jesus reply suggests a new insight has been given by God ( for this was not revealed to you by man, but by my Father in heaven [16:17]).

2)      6:52 introduce an ominous note (they had not understood about the loaves; their hearts were hardened); perhaps introduced in 4:13 (Do you not understand this parable? How then will you understand all the parables); further developed in 8:1421 (they forgot to bring bread, Jesus cautions them, Take heed, beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and the leaven of Herod). They should have gradually understood a new perspective of the kingdom, since they have been given insight into it (4:1112). But 4:13 suggests that it is not perfect.

a)      This and 8:1721 are the 2 main significant sections which show the failure of the disciples. Both are related to the feeding miracles.

3)      They did not understand (συνίημι): The criteria that separated insiders and outsiders is now leveled against the disciples. It is repeated again in 8:17 (coupled with a hardened heart), 21.

4)      They did not understand about the loaves:

a)      Disciples should have moved beyond astonishment to an understanding of who Jesus is.

b)      If they had realized the implications of the feeding miracle regarding Jesus true nature, they would not be amazed. Hooker suggests that the 2 miracles are linked by the 2 main miracles of the Exodus: crossing of the sea and provision of manna. Seeing one should suggest the other.

c)      Show connection to exodus/new exodus motif.

5)      Their heart was hardened:

a)      Goes beyond misunderstanding to unbelief, see Mark 16:14 where unbelief and hardness of heart are tied together (τὴν ἀπιστίαν αὐτῶν καὶ σκληροκαρδίαν).

b)      Used only to describe disciples and Pharisees.

i)       Disciples: Do you have a hardened (πεπωρωμένην) heart (8:17); He reproached them for their unbelief and hardness of heart (σκληροκαρδίαν) (16:14).

ii)     Pharisees: Man with shriveled hand on the Sabbath, τῇ πωρώσει τῆς καρδίας, 3:5; Dispute about adultery, Πρὸς τὴν σκληροκαρδίαν ὑμῶν, 10:5;

c)      Recalls Pharaoh (Exod 7:3, 13, 22; 8:15).

6)      Implication for Marks theology of miracles: Miracles in themselves do not produce faith; in this instance, it leads to unbelief and hardness of hearts. The eyes of faith must be opened to see the significance and truth behind the event. Same theology as in FG, although FG notes that miracles/signs can lead to faith.

a)      Application: If only my daughter is healed, Ill believe.

i)       Faith based on signs is not encouraged, but it is better than nothing (John 10:38).

2.11.2.2   Exposition

1)      Immediately, he made (ἠνάγκασεν): Makes sense if we read John 6:1415 (Jesus, knowing that they intended to come and make him king by force, withdrew again to a mountain by himself).

2)      4th watch:[26] roughly 36 AM. If they started off when evening came they were at it for 10 hours.

3)      He meant to pass (παρέρχομαι) by them: *he was about to pass them, i.e. from perspective of the disciples (Cranfield, France) || he meant to manifest himself to them taking παρέρχομαι as a t.t. for divine epiphany (Stein).

4)      Mark notes 2x the connection between seeing him and their fear. Focuses on their human predicament, and prepares for 6:52.

5)      It is I: Probably not a case of the divine name of God (Exod 3:14; Deut 32:39; Isa 41:4; 43:10; 46:4; 51:12). Mark 6:52 makes clear that the disciples did not understand that Jesus revealed himself as God. However, Marks readers may have understood it as Jesus divine nature.

2.11.3    Many healings (6:5356) [148]

1)      Christology

a)      Jesus great power to heal

b)      Jesus popularity.

2)      Given the contrast against the disciples failure to perceive, miracles only engender temporary excitementthe eye of faith is needed.

3)      κράσπεδον: edge, fringe || tassel Jesus is a law-abiding Jew (Num 15:3839; Deut 22:12; Stein).

4)      Nevertheless, Jesus heals their physical needs.

2.12     A foretaste of confrontation in Jerusalem: The issue of purity (7:123) [150]

1)      From miracles and popular acclaim, we return to conflict situation (2:13:6) and teaching.

2)      *In what follows, Jesus begins ministry among non-Jews. Discussions about ritual purity here serve as a narrative hinge between Jewish and Gentile phases of Jesus ministry, to prepare for the following mission to the Gentiles.

3)      Themes:

a)      Christological:

i)       Jesus is Israels true teacher. He upholds Torah and yet transcends it.

(1)   Authority of the Son of God not only to invalidate Pharisaic traditions but also several OT stipulations. This authority should again raise the question Who is this man ? (4:41).

ii)     Extension of Jesus purity to others.

(1)   Scribes see marketplace was a source of impurity from which they must be purified.

(2)   But Marks Jesus, already declared to be the Holy One of God in Marks first mighty deed (1:24) and having cleansed lepers (1:4042), forgiven sins (2:112), restored the impure woman (5:2934), raised the unclean corpse (5:4142), and cast out unclean spirits (1:2327; 3:11; 5:213; 6:7), not only sees no threat but also recognizes an opportunity to extend purity to others (CNTUOT).

(3)   Note that sin, sickness, healing and forgiveness were very closely connected with wholeness and purity.

(4)   By extending purity to others, Jesus again shows himself to be the one that brings in the kingdom of God.

iii)   Ecclesiological

(1)   In so far as purity delimits the community, then the issue here is who has the authority to define what constitutes the boundaries of Israel. Here, it shows Jesus to be the center around whom Israel is being reconstituted, but also that the Jerusalem leadership is disqualified because of their hypocrisy.

b)      Conflict: First and public denunciation of the scribes by Jesus.

i)       While the Pharisees and scribes continue their accusation, Jesus assessment of them is harsher. They are hypocrites, and their traditions are invalid. Reminds readers that Jesus death was not for any crime that he committed, but due to the hostility of those who honor God with their lips.

ii)     Apart from Mark 1:23, this is the only other explicit reference to Isa. If it recalls Mark 1:23, then it affirms the Mal 3:1 warning about the unpreparedness of the Jerusalem leadership.

c)      Salvation history: Hints to a change in salvation history with the abrogation of clean and unclean distinctions in Judaism. This change is brought out forcefully in subsequent chapters. Implication for early Christian community: their present freedom concerning food regulations stems from Jesus himself.

d)      Failure of disciples to understand.

4)      Jesus and the Law (See Law in DJG)

a)      Jesus critiques the oral traditions (7:8).

b)      Does Jesus abrogate the ceremonial ritual laws (7:15, 19)?

i)       Yes.

(1)   Some say that Jesus makes a distinction between the so-called moral (honor parents) and ceremonial laws, because he upholds honoring parents (7:10), while abrogating laws about clean and unclean food. There may be hints of it especially on Jesus stress on the weightier matters of the Law (Matt 23:23). Nevertheless, the Judaism of Jesus days do not make that distinction.

ii)     *No

(1)   Its not clearly self-evident that Jesus abrogated the OT food regulations. He probably said, There is nothing outside a person that enters into him via defiled hands that defiles him (Stein).

(a)   Suggested in Matt 15:20, These are what defile a person; but eating with unwashed hands does not defile them.

(b)   The full implication of Jesus teaching was not immediately apparent to the disciples. Nevertheless, Mark subsequently indicates that Jesus was passing down a ruling: the kingdom of God had arrived and the food regulations of the OT had come to an end.

 

1)      Structure

a)      7:113

i)       7:18: Jesus attacks scribal tradition.

ii)     7:913: Jesus berates scribes for undermining authority of OT law.

b)      7:1423

i)       Jesus apparently undermines and critiques a fundamental principle of OT law.

1)      Boundary markers: Food laws, circumcision, Sabbath.

2)      Historical question

a)      Food laws and table fellowship is a major issue in 1st century Christianity? If Jesus made such a clear statement, why did it remain a debate for such a long time?

i)       Due to conservatism of all religious communities which resists change to fundamental traditional values (France).

(1)   Why didnt the Jerusalem council refer to Jesus saying? Why did Peter still struggle with unclean food in Acts 10.

(a)   Perhaps they had not yet processed the full ramifications of Jesus statement.

(b)   Perhaps, Jesus did not abrogate the OT food laws. Note that Marks statement Thus he declared all foods clean is an editorial statement, probably written during his time, i.e. about late 50s, after the Jerusalem council. Mark traces the churchs understanding of the abrogation of the food laws ultimately to Jesus.

(2)   If Luke used Mark, why did Luke leave out Thus he declared all foods clean?

(a)   Need to differentiate between the world of the text and the world behind the text. In Marks days, the issue should have already been resolved. Since the date of Jerusalem council is about 50 CE, and Mark is written in late 50s (or in the 60s).

(b)   Luke may have omitted it so that there wouldnt be any discrepancy with his account of Acts 10 and Acts 15.

ii)     Why didnt Paul use this Jesus tradition when he deals with food offered to idols in 1 Cor? Probably because he didnt know of this Jesus tradition (double check).

2.12.1    First interchange (7:18) [150] Jesus attacks scribal traditions

1)      Complaint (7:15)

a)      Jerusalem Scribes: first mentioned in 3:22; reinforcement of local opposition from the capital.

b)      That is, unwashed: explanatory note for Gentile readers. Moreover, 7:3 is to clarify Jewish purity rituals for his Gentile readers.

c)      Ritual

i)       Tradition of the elders: oral law. The issue here not with OT law, but with oral tradition.

(1)   b. Ber. 52b also affirms washing of hands for non-sacred food is not prescribed by the Torah (Soncino).

ii)     Before a basic meal, pious Jews would ceremonially wash their hands.

iii)   If they come back from the market place, they would probably immerse (βαπτίζω) the whole person (France).

iv)   Washing of cups and pots : broadens to general ritual purity rather than food laws.

v)      Common people (am ha-aretz) typically disregarded these rituals, and were considered sinners by the Pharisees.

d)      ἄλλα πολλά ἐστιν ἃ παρέλαβον κρατεῖν: infinitive is either exegetical or purpose

i)       NASB: There are many other things which they have received in order to observe.

2)      Response (7:68)

a)      Isa 29:13. Contrast between lip-worship and heart-worship scribal religion was emphasizing external correctness rather than fundamental attitudes towards God.

i)       Because this people draw near with their mouth and honor me with their lips, while their hearts are far from me, and their fear of me is a commandment of men learned by rote (RSV).

ii)OT context: Part of the woe oracles against Israel. The setting is Judahs participation in a rebel coalition with Egypt against Assyria. They reject Yahwehs wisdom, but yet still continue with their religious practices.

iii)Quotation is from LXX which is different. Some claim cannot come from Jesus. But this is based on the following 3 questionable assumptions: (1) Jesus could not have known and used the LXX; (2) the MT represents the Hebrew text known in Palestine at that time; and (3) the inclusion of μάτην and διδάσκοντες dramatically alter the meaning (France).

b)      Jesus charge against them (7:8): Hypocrisy.

i)       Contrast between OT law and their traditions: [ἀφέντες κρατεῖτε]; [ἐντολήν παράδοσιν]; [θεοῦ ἀνθρώπων]. True religion focuses on God, not on human activity. OT law cannot take 2nd place to oral tradition. Scribes, however, would argue that the oral law serves to put a fence around the Torah (m. Abot 1:1; 3:14).

ii)     By emphasizing external correctness, they are neglecting the commandment of God such as Deut 6:45.

iii)   Hypocrisy. The leaders professed devotion to God (expressed in ritual purity) is contrasted with their rejection of the sanctifying (purifying) new exodus work that God was accomplishing in Jesus before their very eyes (cleansing of leprosy, healing of the dead, casting of demons) (CNTUOT).

iv)   If Isa 29 describes the outcome or judgment of Isa 6 warning in the parables of Mark 4, then we have here an example of those whose soil/heart is hardened such that they cannot see or understand that Isaiahs long-awaited exodus has begun in Jesus (CNTUOT).

2.12.2    2nd counter-charge (7:913) [150] Jesus berates scribes for undermining OT authority

1)      Escalated argument in controversy: (let go ἀφίημι [7:8] set aside ἀθετέω [7:9] nullify ἀκυρόω [7:13]); (παράδοσις τῶν ἀνθρώπων more pointed with τὴν παράδοσιν ὑμῶν); (ἵνα law of God is now a hindrance to keeping oral law) (France).

2)      Jesus now gives a specific example where Pharisaic tradition nullifies the commandment of God.

3)      OT commandment:

a)      Choice of Moses critical since scribes trace oral law back to Moses (Deut 4:14). Jesus is using rabbinic argument of the weighty (Moses) versus the light (oral law) (Osborne).

b)      5th commandment (Exod 20:12; Deut 5:16).

i)       Context

(1)   The first 4 commandment shows how Israel is to relate to Yahweh, and forms the foundation for the final 6 which shows how people are to relate to one another and the world.

(2)   As Yahweh must be honored because he is the source of life, humans should also recognize the role of parents as Yahwehs proxies who give their children life.

c)      The addition of Exod 21:17 with the death penalty show the gravity of the situation.

i)       To curse (the antonym of brk bless) your parent is to curse God, who gave you life through them.

ii)     Jewish tradition (t. Seb. 3.6) also notes that one dishonors parents only when one has already dishonored God.

iii)   Failure to honor parents leads to not living long in the land, an idea which is linked with exile. Thus, the failure to honor parents would also threaten the new exodus that Jesus is ushering.

4)      Qorban (something offered, dedicated to God): Not clear how it works. Supposedly it allows a child to keep property from his parents (by dedicating it to God), but still being able to use it for his own purposes. The property belonged to God but used by the person.

a)      The mere utterance of the word (qorban) made the vow binding (France).

b)      Although this was not an explicit curse of ones parents, it amounted to the same thing because both effectively repudiated the parent-child relationship (CNTUOT).

5)      Result: They voided Torah. The verb ἀκυρόω is a legal term (to annul or repeal), and they declared that Gods law (i.e. ὁ λόγος τοῦ θεοῦ = ἡ ἐντολὴ τοῦ θεοῦ) is unlawful. Moreover, what is a capital offense in the law (7:10) is now not only permitted but mandated by Pharisaic tradition.

2.12.3    3rd counter-charge (7:1423) [150] Jesus apparently undermines and critiques a fundamental principle of OT law

1)      Discussion is now opened up to include the crowds.

2)      To the crowds (7:1415)

a)      True source of defilement is not external (ritual purity) but internal.

b)      In line with OT emphasis on the heart rather than on cultic ritual (Osborne).

c)      Listen to me: Recalls the Shema Hear, O Israel.

3)      To disciples (7:1723): εἰς οἶκον, ἀπὸ τοῦ ὄχλου.

a)      Failure to comprehend: emphasized in 6:52 and further developed in 8:1721; threatens to put disciples with the uncomprehending outsiders of 4:1112 (France).

b)      Food goes into the stomach (κοιλία) and out into the latrine without touching the heart (καρδία). Thus, food does not defile a person. Only the heart ( spiritual and intellectual processes, including the will) does that.

c)      Editorial comment: Thus he declared all foods clean (Not in Matthew).

i)       Early church traced the abrogation of Jewish food laws back to this saying (Osborne).

ii)     Took the Palestinian church a long time to recognize this. Seen in Peters vision at Joppa (Acts 10) and the Jerusalem decree (Acts 15).

iii)   Deliberate editorial comment that moves from the history of Jesus then to the situation of the reader now.[27]

iv)   See also Rom 14:14 (I am convinced, being fully persuaded in the Lord Jesus, that nothing is unclean in itself. But if anyone regards something as unclean, then for that person it is unclean), 14:20 (Do not destroy the work of God for the sake of food. All food is clean, but it is wrong for a person to eat anything that causes someone else to stumble.).

d)      Absence in Matt:

i)       In Matt, Jesus only criticizes the tradition of the Pharisees, and makes no radical reformation of the written Torah. For Matt, Jesus alone is the true interpreter of the law (Hagner).

e)      Absence in Luke: Luke removes it because he wants to emphasize Peters role and to negate any misunderstanding of this incident with Acts 10.

i)       Schnabel:

(1)   A possibility is that Jesus statement is not an overturning of the food laws, but his emphasis was on the priority of the heart over the external.

(2)   Shows limitations of the 2 source theory.

f)       Vice list: Mark has 12 items; Matt 6. Defilement is interpreted not in external, but in moral, categories. What defiles a person is in our nature.

2.13     The mission extended to neighboring peoples (7:248:10) [15153]

1)      Marks declared all foods clean new approach that makes it possible for Jew-Gentile integration. This perspective is reflected here in this narrative as Jesus moves outside Jewish territory and ministers to Gentiles.

2)      Evidence for Gentile focus

a)      Geographical movement: He arose and went away (from supposedly the Galilean location in 7:1) move north to Tyre and Sidon (7:24) moves south through Sidon through the region of the Decapolis (distinctively Gentile area to the east of the lake; 7:31) and remains there until the unidentifiable Dalmanutha (8:10), which is presumably Jewish territory as indicated by the presence of Pharisees (8:11).

b)      Other clues: woman was a Greek, a Syrophoenician || the use of σπυρίδες for baskets rather than the more Jewish κόφινοι in 6:43 || Matt emphasizes the Gentile setting of the healing of the deaf and mute by having the people glorify the God of Israel (Matt 15:31).

c)      Mark has placed Jesus in Gentile setting before, e.g. crowds from Idumea and Tyre and Sidon (3:8); Gerasene demoniac. But these are Gentile touches in an essentially Jewish story (France).

2.13.1    Syrophoenician (Canaanite) Gentile woman (7:24-30) [151]

1)      Emphasis:

a)      Salvation history

i)       Signals dramatic shift: coming of the kingdom of God to Gentiles. There is a new openness to Gentiles within the Kingdom in contrast to the Jewish attitude (represented in Jesus saying). This shift in salvation history is not an arbitrary decision of the church, but can be traced to Jesus.

b)      Christological: Jesus fame cannot be hidden. He did not seek notoriety (secrecy motif), but his fame rose anyway. This is made clear in 7:24 (And he entered a house, and would not have any one know it; yet he could not be hid).

c)      Discipleship

i)       Her faith contrasts with the Pharisees unbelief. Another example of the little people that exemplify true discipleship.

ii)     Contrast between disciples and Syrophoenician woman

(1)   Her understanding of a cryptic saying about food contrasts with the disciples failure to understand the parable about food (7:17).

(2)   Disciples failure to understand about bread (6:52) contrasts with the womans ability to understand and use the bread metaphor to her advantage.

d)      Matt: This episode has an important place for his universal mission motif (Osborne). << Not sure.

 

1)      Social status of the woman: low.

a)      Woman || Gentile || daughter has an unclean spirit.

b)      Josephus notes that the people of Tyre were notoriously our [the Jews] bitterest enemies (A. Ap. 1.13; A. J. 14.12.35; J.W. 2.18.5).

2)      Jesus response is in the form of a parable:

a)      He responds with an insulting Jewish epithet (Dog: unclean animal because they eat refuse) and states that kingdom benefits (i.e. bread) are only for Jews.

b)      Tone appears harsh. Misunderstanding arises because of failure to read it as a whole.

i)       May be similar approach to Jesus question regarding the woman with the flow of blood, Who touched me? Jesus seeks to initiate a faith encounter with the woman Jesus is using this to test her response, to draw out her faith. Matt makes it explicit in 15:28 when Jesus replies O woman, great is you faith!

c)      Let the children be satisfied first she is not excluded from Gods mercy, but there is a temporal priority for the Jews. This leads the woman to see Jesus response not as a rejection, but as a test.

i)       Edwards: Mark suggests the inclusion of Gentiles into the Kingdom by using a diminutive form of dog (κυνάριον). But diminutives have lost their force in the first century. Moreover, the presence of several diminutives in this pericope undercut their significance (θυγάτριον, δαιμόνιον, ψιχίον, παιδίον) [France].

d)      Woman does not deny her lower place but argues that dogs should also have their day, i.e. the mission of the Messiah of Israel must begin with Israel but cannot stop there.

i)       She demonstrates humility, and faith in Jesus mercy.

ii)     She affirms that Gods work in Jesus is so great that mere crumbs will be sufficient for her.

iii)   Early church followed this (first for the Jew, then for the Gentile; Rom 1:16).

e)      For this saying: For this word (of faith is implied). Indicates that her response secured her request.

i)       Israel may have priority but the grace of God is more than sufficient to meet the needs of Gentiles who make supplication.

2.13.2    Healing a deaf mute and many others in Decapolis (7:3137) [152]

1)      Location:

a)      Circuitous route in Mark. From Tyre Sidon regions of Decapolis Sea of Galilee. Shows Gentile mission in Mark. Matt only has summary statement of healing along the Sea of Galilee.

i)       Such a journey would be like going from Chicago to Indiana by going north through Wisconsin and then east and south through Michigan to Indiana (Collins, Mark).

b)      Its difficult to determine the location of this healing and the feeding of the 4,000.

i)       Western Sea of Galilee area (Stein) || *Decapolis (France).

2)      Emphasis

a)      Healing of the deaf mute coming of the kingdom of God. This is a healing loaded with eschatological significance. Fulfillment of Isa 35:56 Then the ears of the deaf [shall be] unstopped and the mute tongue shout for joy.

i)       First time healing of a deaf and mute are mentioned in Mark.

b)      Secret motif Christs greatness. The more zealously they proclaimed it: Shows that Jesus glory cannot be contained. When one is touched by Jesus, it is impossible to keep quiet (1:45; 5:20; 7:24, 36).

i)       If this is in the Decapolis, this miracle contrasts with previous healing incident (of the demoniac) in the Decapolis: Here, Jesus avoids public notice. In the healing of the Gerasene demoniac, Jesus instructs him to tell his own people what happened.

ii)     If this was in a Gentile setting, the secrecy motif focuses on refusing to treat Jesus as a Hellenistic wonder-worker (Osborne)

3)      Why spittle: The use of spittle in healing is well documented.

a)      We would be grossed out, putting finger into somebodys ear; using spit, touching somebodys tongue.

b)      Doriani suggests that since the person is deaf, Jesus cant talk to the person to challenge his faith, and that the use of this substitutes for the test of faith. Im not sure about it.

c)      Could this be an example of enculturation and accommodation, using practices that re familiar for Holy Man in that culture (Lau)?

4)      Sigh: Prayer-like gesture.

1)      Ephphatha, that is, Be opened. (7:34)

a)      The retention of the Aramaic term is not due to it being a secret incantation possessing magical power, but due to Marks conservative handling of the traditions

2.13.3    Feeding of 4,000 (8:110) [153]

1)      Geography: Western Sea of Galilee (Stein)[28] || *Gentile area (France).

a)      No geographical note until 8:10. In this feeding, theyre probably still in the Decapolis, on the eastern side of the lake. In 8:10, they go to Dalmanutha, which although it cannot be located with certainty, its probably Jewish territory on the Western shore, since Pharisees show up again. This incident continues Jesus ministry among Gentiles (France).

2)      Emphasis:

a)      Christology: Shows Jesus greatness and ability as the Son of God.

b)      πάλιν:

i)       Again If we take it that this miracle was performed in Gentile area, then Jesus does for the Gentiles what he has done for the Jews.

ii)     Again shows continual failure of the disciples to understand

iii)   Again greatness of Jesus.

3)      Continuation of bread motif.

a)      Syrophoenician woman: Gentiles are only given crumbs.

b)      Perhaps, its why Mark carefully records a different set of statistics.

i)       Fewer people: 4,000 people || 5,000 men.

ii)     More resources: 7 loaves || 5 loaves; few small fish || 2 fish

iii)   Less leftovers: 7 baskets || 12 baskets.

iv)   But 8:1921 suggests that the numbers are insignificant, without symbolic meaning.

 

1)      Authenticity

a)      Similarity with feeding of the 5,000: Hungry crowd; Jesus compassion; disciples incredulity at the idea of feeding such a crowd; the question How many loaves do you have?; command to sit on the crowd; giving thanks for the bread; crowds eating and being satisfied; record of the number in the crowd; leftovers.

b)      Differences: [5000Jesus compassion leads to his teaching them; 4000Jesus compassion leads to his feeding them]; [5000Crowds interrupt Jesus; 4000Jesus takes initiative].

c)      Probably authentic. If were the same tradition, oral transmission typically keep the same numbers but change scenery. Moreover, hard to imagine that the mid-first century church would allow Mark to put in 2 feeding incidents when only 1 occurred (France).

d)      Moreover, Mark specifically has Jesus reprimand the disciples immediately following for not learning from the feeding of the 5,000 and the 4,000 (8:1920).

 

1)      How can one feed these men with bread?:

a)      Implied answer, No human can. But just as God was able to feed Israel in the wilderness, so is the Son of God able to do the same in the desert (ἐπ ἐρημίας; 8:4).

i)       But one must be cautious and note that the allusion to the wilderness is uncertain. But emphasis on Jesus ability to work miracles is clear.

b)      Disciples incredulity shows their failure to learn from events they witness. Failure to comprehend is becoming an important theme, esp. in 8:1721 where Jesus rebukes them for not learning from past experiences.

c)      Marks remark that the crowds were ἐχορτάσθησαν (8:10) answers the disciples incredulous question χορτάσαι ἄρτων (8:8).

2)      Number 7 may signify perfection of Gods provision.

 

Feeding of the 5,000

Feeding of the 4,000

Last Supper

he blessed

εὐλόγησεν

having given thanks

εὐχαριστήσας

having blessed

εὐλογήσας

he broke

κατέκλασεν

he broke

ἔκλασεν

he broke

ἔκλασεν

he was giving

ἐδίδου

he was giving

ἐδίδου

he gave

ἔδωκεν

 

having blessed (the fish)

εὐλογήσας

having given thanks (the cup)

εὐχαριστήσας

 

1)      There are similarities, but I dont think that the feeding of the 5,000 or 4,000 is meant to be sacramental.

2.14     Summary so far: Both opponents and supporters still have a lot to learn (8:1121) [15455]

1)      This bridge passage moves Jesus away from Galilee end of first act.

2)      Contains 2 scenes which look back at the preceding chapters point to the re-education of the disciples as they go to Jerusalem.

2.14.1    Pharisees seek a sign: Jesus abandons the Pharisees (8:1113) [154]

1)      Jesus returns across the lake into Jewish area and is confronted by the Pharisees again.

2)      MattLuke: Has sign of Jonah, a Q tradition.

a)      Sign of Jonah: Jesus being buried and then resurrected.
