b)      There is a formal contradiction, but no contradiction in actual meaning. The Pharisees disbelief about Jesus later resurrection shows that this was not the sign that they were looking for. From their perspective, no sign except the sign of Jonah was effectively no sign at all.[29]

3)      Emphasis:

a)      Continued hostility against Jesus by the Pharisees.

i)       This is contrasted with the disciples blindness in the next pericope. Although slow to understand, the disciples are not hostile. They are teachable and they have not committed the unpardonable sin. Even though they may not understand the significance of Jesus miracles, they know that they are from God. On the other hand, the leaders see the same miracles and refuse to acknowledge them that they are from God. Rather, they attribute it to Satan (3:22).

b)      Jesus refusal to give a sign terminates his dialogue with the Pharisees and his public ministry in Galilee. Those who have not yet believed will not receive any further incentive to believe. The term ἀφεὶς αὐτούς shows his decision to disengage with the Pharisees (France). Stein, however, disagrees with this interpretation.

i)       The division between insiders and outsiders that is mentioned in Mark 4 is now acted out where Jesus turns away from the Pharisees, the spokespeople of this present generation, and goes off into a boat with his disciples.

ii)     ἡ γενεὰ αὕτη stands for outsiders. If they cannot understand what they have seen and heard so far, there is no further point in further dialogue.

c)      This generation echoes the wilderness generation of Israel who refused to believe in Gods power despite signs to the contrary.

 

1)      σημεῖον: In John, σημεῖον refers to miracles, esp. the theological significance of miracles. Here, Pharisees ask for absolute divine and supernatural authentication in spite of the miracles. The request for a sign is biblical (Exod 4:19, 2931; 7:811). However, Mark notes that their true motive is to test Jesus (πειράζοντες αὐτόν; 8:11).

a)      from heaven:

i)       they reject the heavenly source of Jesus miracles, seen already in Mark 3 where they accuse Jesus of casting out demons by Beelzebul.

ii)     from God.

b)      to test him:

i)       From the perspective of Pharisees, they want something more than a miracle, they want a heavenly sign.

ii)     From perspective of Mark, this is a temptation. The verb πειράζω alludes back to the temptation by Satan in 1:13, and shows this as a cosmic conflict. In Mark, the subject of this verb is either Satan (1:13) or the Pharisees (8:11; 10:2; 12:15), and the direct object is always Jesus.

(1)   Satan and the Pharisees are portrayed as one group tempting Jesus.

2)      The occurrence of ἡ γενεὰ αὕτη 2x that the desire for authentication is larger than the group of Pharisees.

a)      Used in OT to describe the evil generation of Noahs day and the generation of the wilderness sojourn.

3)      εἰ δοθήσεται τῇ γενεᾷ ταύτῃ σημεῖον.

a)      Semitic oath where the protasis lacks an explicit apodosis, and the unexpressed apodosis assumes a curse such as May God do X to me.

4)      Jesus rejection of their request shows that man cannot come to him via human categories; all must come to him through faith (Osborne).

5)      This marks the end of Jesus public ministry, and he now focuses on his group of disciples.

2.14.2    The leaven of the Pharisees: the disciples blindness (8:1421) [155]

1)      Emphasis 1: Disciples failure to grasp the significance of Jesus teaching and ministry.

a)      Summarizes the many passages on misunderstanding (4:13, 40; 6:37, 52; 7:18; 8:4) and prepares for more to come.

b)      Language of Isa 6:910 which is used to describe outsiders (Be ever hearing, but never understanding, be ever seeing, but never perceiving) is now applied to the disciples (ὀφθαλμοὺς ἔχοντες οὐ βλέπετε καὶ ὦτα ἔχοντες οὐκ ἀκούετε; 8:1718), despite the fact that they have been given the secret of the kingdom of God.

c)      συνίημι and καρδία πεπωρωμένη (8:17) is already used of the disciples in 6:52, and this again recalls Isa 6:910 in 4:12.

d)      Do you not yet understand: The use of οὔπω in 8:17, 21 their incomprehension is only temporary.

e)      Literary analysis: The conclusion of 4:18:21 with Jesus questioning the disciples suggest to some that what distinguishes disciples from the religious leaders is not because they understand but because:

i)       They ask the right questions. The disciples do not ask for signs but they ask Who then is this? (4:41). The disciples search for understandingunderstanding who Jesus is and thus what it means to follow him.

ii)     They still follow Jesus.

f)       Matt is softer. Omits hardened hearts and ends with then they understood that he did not tell them to beware . Matt emphasizes the understanding of the disciples.

i)       Matt does not idealize the disciples by noting their understanding. After all, he explicitly tells of their deficient faith (14:31; 16:8, 2223; 17:20). Rather, the theme of the disciples understanding accentuates Jesus teaching and his role as an effective teacher.

2)      Emphasis 2: Christological. Emphasis is not on the failure of the disciples but what they are dull about: namely that Jesus is the Son of God. The numbers 7 and 12 allude to the mighty working power of Jesus (Stein).

 

1)      OT Context (CNTUOT)

a)      Combination primarily of Jer 5:21, secondarily of Ezek 12:2, with clear echoes of Isa 6:910.

b)      Focusing in on Jer 5:21

i)       Jer 5:21 context: Hear this, you foolish and senseless people, who have eyes but do not see, who have ears but do not hear.

(1)   The context of our section consists of Gods complaint that his people, although professing loyalty (5:2), have hardened their faces like rock against his correction (5:3). His rebellious children have become like any other nation (5:9, 29 and therefore are consigned to judgment (5:79) at the hands of Babylon (5:1519).

(2)   At issue is the fear of Yahweh and the recognition of his authority. The evidence of Yahwehs authority stems from his control of the seas and his giving of rain (5:24), i.e. Israels bread.

ii)     NT context. As in Jer 5 which focuses on Yahwehs authority, the issue is also Jesus authority and identity.

 

1)      Beware the leaven:

a)      Yeast:

i)       Has negative connotations (forbidden in offerings [Lev. 2:11]; symbol of pride and sensual pleasure [Philo, QE 1.15; 2.14]; evil instinct [b. Ber. 17a]), and since it was avoided in the first exodus, presumably it ought also be so here.) (CNTUOT).

ii)     Main metaphorical force in NT is its powerful growth and influence (France). In Matt 16:12, it refers to the διδαχή of the Pharisees and Sadducees; in Luke 12:1, its the ὑπόκρισις of the Pharisees. Not clear what it specifically refers to here: external rigidity of the oral tradition || *unbelief in Jesus identity || refusal to recognize the truth. Overall, it means to be negatively influenced by the Pharisees.

2)      Metaphorical blindness and deafness: Framed by 2 miracles of literal perception; shows that Jesus can heal the spiritually blind and deaf.

a)      Metaphorical blindness here points to the next pericope where the healing of the blind man symbolize the enlightenment the disciples need.

b)      Deafness recalls the previous healing of the deaf and dumb man.

3)      Lesson of the 5,000 and the 4,000

a)      The lesson is not that they have a steady supply of bread, but that these miracles ought to show them who Jesus truly is.

3           Acts 2: On the way to Jerusalem (8:2210:52)

1)      France: This is the discipleship section. Geographically, it links the N and S phases of Jesus ministry. At the same time, it prepares the disciples for Jesus rejection and death in Jerusalem.

2)      Geography: Focus on Jesus movement from N to S, ending in his arrival in Jerusalem. Bridge between Galilee and Judea.

3)      Literary integrity

a)      Emphasis on disciples incomprehension.

i)       3 cycles: Passion prediction (8:31; 9:31; 10:3334) disciples incomprehension Jesus explanation and teaching on discipleship. The repetition adds clarity and force.

b)      Emphasis is on disciples re-education (see 9:3031; Jesus did not want anyone to know where they were because he was teaching his disciples). Only one miracle recordedexorcism (9:1429)apart from the framing of the 2 accounts of healing a blind man.

c)      Frequent use of ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ and similar language (8:27; 9:3334; 10:17, 32, 52) presents discipleship as a journey. In Acts, Christians refer to their movement as ἡ ὁδός.

d)      With Peters confession of his identity, Jesus repeatedly lays out what his mission in Jerusalem entails.

e)      Framed by 2 accounts of healing a blind man. The blind man symbolizes the blindness of the disciples.

i)       The concluding story of Bartimaeus shows what true discipleship is: Disciples are to see as he does and to follow on the way as he does.

3.1         1st healing of a blind man: Bethsaida (8:2226) [156]

1)      // to 7:3137 (healing of the deaf mute in Decapolis)

a)      Similarities: unique to Mark; outside Galilee; crowds ask for help but Jesus takes the patient away in private; specifically touch the affected organs; use saliva; command to silence.

b)      Both 7:3137 (healing deaf & dumb) and 8:2226 (healing blind) is a fulfillment of Isa 35:56. Function: Christological, shows who Jesus is.

i)       First healing of a blind man in Mark.

c)      If 8:2226 is also symbolic to show the gradual enlightenment of the disciples, and if these 2 episodes are //, perhaps 7:3137 symbolically show the enabling of the disciples to hear and speak Gods word properly.

2)      *This healing of the blind man // the healing of blind Bartimaeus (10:4552), forming the introduction and conclusion to this section.

a)      Significance? The concluding story of Bartimaues show what true discipleship is: Disciples are to see as he does and to follow on the way as he does.

3)      Emphasis: Curing of the disciples blindness.

a)      Recaps blindness motif in 8:18. The progressive healing of the blind man here shows the progressive restoration of the disciples spiritual sight in this act. For example, after Peter confesses Jesus messianic status, he is rebuked a few verses later for understanding Jesus mission from a human perspective. Peter sees, but not clearly.

i)       Disciples understanding // healing in 2 stages.

(1)   Stage 1: Jesus earthly ministry (disciples do not comprehend) || Stage 2: Post Easter (they see everything clearly).

(2)   Stage 1: Teaching ministry of Jesus (Mark 18) || Stage 2: Passion prediction (Mark 810), proper understanding of the Messiah must be coupled with the cross.

(3)   *Disciples understanding of Jesus as the Messiah requires a second touch. Stage 1: Peters understanding of Jesus as the Messiah is flawed || Stage 2: Jesus explains that the Messiah must suffer.

ii)     Stein refutes this interpretation, arguing that nowhere in 8:2216:8 do the disciples gain clarity. Thus, nowhere in Mark is there a 2 stage healing. Evidence for the clarity of the disciples comes only from knowledge of the post-Easter experience of the disciples. Stein, therefore, prefers to treat this as a simple miracle demonstrating the greatness of Jesus. The presence of a 2 stage healing is due to the historical reality.

 

1)      Location: Bethsaida is NE of lake.

2)      2 stage healing.

a)      After applying spittle, the man only see blurry images.

b)      After the laying of hands, He looked intently and was restored, and saw everything clearly (8:25): 3 // expressions that show full and complete healing.

3)      Why 2 stage?

a)      Historical.

b)      *Theological: shows the gradually recovery of spiritual sight in the disciples. Even when the narrative climaxes in Jerusalem, the disciples will still be characterized by confusion (France).

i)       Did the disciples ever gain full sight?

(1)   Osborne suggests that there is full understanding at the Transfiguration (9:9). Im not sure on this.

3.2         Learning to recognize Jesus (8:279:13)

3.2.1        Peters confession: Jesus is the Messiah (8:2730) [158]

3.2.1.1       Mark

1)      This is the turning point in Marks narrative, where the increasing tension of the question regarding Jesus identity culminates in his identification as the Messiah. No one (except the demons perhaps) recognizes Jesus as Messiah from 1:1 to 8:31. The disciples have so far only called Jesus διδάσκαλε. So, the first part of Mark (Mark 18) points to this fact, emphasizing the teaching ministry of Jesus.

2)      From this point, the plot moves to the fulfillment of the messianic mission in the cross, predicted in 8:31; 9:31; 10:3334.

a)      This turning point is also seen geographically. From this northerly point in Caesarea Philippi, Jesus moves south towards Jerusalem.

3)      Emphasis: Christological.

a)      Jesus is the Messiah.

4)      After the use of ὁ Χριστός, the title is no longer mentioned against until 14:61-62 when the high priest asks, Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed One?

 

1)      City: Caesarea Philippi. 25 miles north of the lake. At the foot of Mt. Hermon. Former city of Paneas or Panion, name derived from the local worship of Pan. Renamed Caesarea by Herod Philip 2 in honor of Augustus. Essentially a Hellenistic and pagan city.

2)      Who do you say that I am?

a)      One of the prophets:

i)       If its true that prophecy had ceased with Malachi, then seeing Jesus as one of the prophets indicates that God is working in history again. France, however, questions where the idea of the cessation of prophecy during the Second Tempe period is widely held.

ii)     People do not acknowledge his messianic role.

3)      Messianic secret:

a)      This is the only place where the call for secrecy is tied to his identity as the Messiah. Reason for secrecy: due to the political climate and popular enthusiasm, messianic language can be misunderstood.

b)      In contrast, Jesus speaks about the sufferings of the Son of Man plainly (παρρησίᾳ; 8:32). This is the true meaning of the messianic secret.

4)      Messiah

a)      In OT or LXX, Messiah is not a t. t. for a coming deliverer. But in intertestamental period, eschatological hope was gradually tied up with the Messiah. Vermes, Jew, 134, writes, If in the inter-Testamental period a man claimed, or was proclaimed, to be the Messiah, his listeners would as a matter of course have assumed that he was referring to the Davidic Redeemer and would have expected to find before them a person endowed with the combined talents of soldierly prowess, righteousness and holiness.

b)      See also Pss. Sol. 17:21.

5)      Notes from Mark Theology.docx

a)      Some speculate that Jesus rejected the messianic title as applied to himself altogether with the rebuke Get behind me, Satan!

b)      This is wrong and it assumes that messiah carries a monolithic meaning. But the diversity of messianic speculation suggests that Jesus may have rejected one form of messianic understanding for his particular own understanding.

c)      Jesus rebuke is not a rejection of the term Christ altogether. Rather, 8:3033 shows that there is a certain reserve towards that term, and that Christ achieves its proper meaning as a title for Jesus only in light of his suffering. Thus, the passage indicates that Jesus is the Christ, a messiah that cannot be dissociated from the central mission of the cross.

d)      Moreover, situate the term Christ within the overall narrative. Up to this point, others have asked about Jesus (1:27; 2:7; 4:41; 6:23) or offered identifications of him (1:24; 3:22; 5:7; 6:1416). Here, Jesus poses the question directly and makes explicit the question that is simmering throughout the narrative. In the overall narrative, 8:2730 is a turning point in the story. It gathers up the questions preceding this passage and suggests how his identity will be manifest in the following chapters.

3.2.1.2       Matt 16:1320

1)      You are the Christ, the son of the living God:

a)      Luke: Christ of God. Both are interpretive options of the original.

2)      not revealed to you by flesh and blood, but by my Father in heaven:

a)      Even though this was revealed by the Father, it still falls short. On our side of the cross and resurrection, to confess Jesus as the Messiah means to confess him as Messiah crucified. But the context here shows that this is not what the apostles understood before the cross and resurrection. Thus, Luke can report the resurrected Messiah as not only opening the minds of his followers so they could understand the Scriptures (Luke 24:4445) but also berating them for not understanding (24:2526). This is a moral culpability (Carson, Justification and Variegated Nomism 2, 432 n.115).

b)      The significance of Jesus was not self-evident to people who knew him. Flesh and blood, that is human understanding, could not reveal to Peter that Jesus was the Christ. Only God could reveal that fact. No one is able to understand Christ without Gods Word and the Holy Spirit. Even the disciples needed the outpouring of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost before they finally grasped the meaning of Christs coming. In other words, historical facts dont interpret themselves (Goldsworthy, According to Plan).

3)      Simon Barjona: Peters name is probably bar yohanan son of Johanan. Jonah is a shortened form of the Aramaic. In John 1:42 and 21:5, Peter is called son of John, probably a Greek transliteration of the name. Davies & Allison suggest that Matt changes the name son of John to son of Jonah to elevate Peter as a prophet. I think that it is speculative.

4)      On this rock:

a)      Jesus

b)      Peters faith statement: some protestant scholars adopt this view so as to avoid Catholic interpretation.

c)      *Peter as the representative of the disciples since πέτρος and πέτρα are synonyms (Gundry, Carson, France).

d)      Peter as the representative first bishop of the church. Catholics read apostolic succession into this story, but this is not a first century concept.

5)      Gates of Hades (πύλαι ᾅδου): Hades is the realm of the dead.

a)      Hades is generally the place of the dead, not the place of torment for the wicked dead (which is hell). Resurrection is understood as Gods eschatological act of bringing the dead from Hades back to life (ABD).

i)       The idea that eternal punishment of the wicked already begins in Hades begins to be found occasionally in the Jewish literature of the NT period.

ii)     In Luke 16:1931 (Jesus story of the rich man and Lazarus), it appears that only the rich man go to Hades where he is tormented in fire while Lazarus goes to Abrahams bosom in paradise.

b)      Metaphor for death (France, Keener, Hagner). Imagery is that death (or the powers of death) will not swallow up the new community; it will not be destroyed.

i)       In OT, gates of death is the place where dead people go (Job 38:17; Pss 9:13; 107:18); gates of Sheol is used the same way in Isa 38:10. In NT, Hades is equivalent to Sheol (cf. Matt 11:23).

ii)     Gates of Hades keep the dead imprisoned in its realm, and only God can open them (Wis 16:13). Here, it appears to be the power of Hades to hold the dead in death. A related idea is the keys of Hades which Christ possesses (Rev 1:18).

c)      Gates of Hell: probably wrong translation, but ESV, NLT still use Hell. NIV consistently translate γέενα (Gehenna) as hell, since it is the place of punishment in the next life.

i)       Imagery of the church victoriously attacking the fortress of the devil is probably not correct.

ii)     Jesus probably didnt stand at the temple of Pan and point to this supposed Gates of Hell, the cave that served as the doorway to the underworld.

6)      Keys of the kingdom:

a)      Peter (representing the disciples) will control admission into the kingdom. By his proclamation of the gospel, Peter will either open or shut the kingdom to many as people respond to or reject the gospel (Carson, Hagner).

b)      Chief rabbi where keys = teaching authority (Davies/Allison); Peter stands over against the Pharisees whose teaching is rejected. Jesus hands on his own authority for the future to his disciples.

7)      ἔσται δεδεμένον, ἔσται λελυμένον: Future periphrastic. Shows expectation of the state of being bound or loosed without temporal implication. Peter achieves this binding and loosing by preaching the gospel. Whatever he binds, will be in the state of being bound as long as he adheres to the divinely disclosed gospel.

a)      The statement about binding and loosing is made to all the 12. (where?)

b)      Binding and loosing refers to the allowance and disallowance of certain conduct, based on an interpretation of Torah, and thus it concerns the issue of whether or not one is in proper relationship to the will of God. Jesus is the true interpreter of Torah. His disciples will pass on that interpretation and extend it The authority spoken of, then, is in effect that of being able to declare whether a person becomes fully a part of the community of salvation or not, no longer simply on the basis of obedience to Torah but on the basis of response or lack of response to the good news of the kingdom (Hagner).

8)      Function

a)      The church is in effect now the true Israel established by Jesus. The kingdom has been taken from its old leaders and given to a new people who will produce the appropriate harvest (Matt 21:43).[30]

3.2.2        1st Passion prediction: The Messiah (and his followers) must suffer (8:319:1) [15960]

1)      Emphasis: Christological

a)      Jesus predicted his suffering his death was not a tragedy but the plan of God; it is a divine necessity (δεῖ; 8:31).

i)       The tone is not gloomy; rather, it is freely accepted and purposeful.

ii)     Suffering is necessary for the resurrection and can be freely proclaimed (παρρησίᾳ; 8:32).

b)      Messiahship and suffering are intertwined.

i)       The Son of Man who will be rejected and killed is the same one who will come with power with the Fathers glory. Death is the means to glory.

ii)     Isaiahs new-exodus redemption comes only through the messianic Son of Mans taking upon himself the laws curse. Having already embodied the law in doing good and giving life by healing on the Sabbath (3:16; Deut. 30:15), Jesus now, in embodying the laws exilic judgment, will through his vindication bring life and healing to all (CNTUOT).

c)      Eternal destiny of one depends on his relationship to Jesus. Becoming a disciple of Jesus is necessary to save ones life.

2)      Emphasis: Discipleship

a)      False discipleship: defined as operating from an earthly rather than a heavenly perspective.

b)      True discipleship:

i)       Call to perseverance, to renew ones commitment to Jesus, especially for those who are suffering shame and are tempted to return to the world. Know that the Son of Man will be the ultimate judge one day.

ii)     Being a disciple does not depend on ones socio-economic or religious background. It depends on the will and commitment (θέλω; 8:3435) to follow Christ. Not just confessing Jesus as Christ and Lord but on active and obedient discipleship (Matt 7:2123).

 

1)      Background motif of the suffering is probably Isa 53:410 (CNTUOT).

a)      If so, then Jesus linkage of the Messiah with the suffering servant is unexpected, as was the consequent notion that Israels peace would come through his bearing the wounds and sickness of Israels exilic judgment.

b)      The Targum was right to see the Messiah in Isa 53, but it did not understand that he was present in all of it, including the suffering.

c)      Regarding the suffering motif in Isa 53 .. although a few late Jewish texts attribute nonvicarious sickness or suffering to the Messiah (Ruth Rabbah, b. Sanhedrin), the majority apply it to Israel (LXX, Sipre Deuteronomy, Targum, Numbers Rabbah) or the righteous (Sipre Numbers, S. Eli. Rab. [27]25) who are either oppressed by the wicked (Wisdom; 4Q541) or disciplined by God (CNTUOT).

 

3.2.2.1       Jesus foretells his passion (8:3133) [159]

1)      The Son of Man must suffer:

a)      Shifts to using Son of Man language.

i)       Reasons:

(1)   What he is going to say differs from perceived notions of the Messiah.

(a)   But do note that Messiah and Son of Man are also functionally equivalent. This is seen in 1 Enoch.

(b)   What is new or unexpected in Jewish understanding of the Messiah is the suffering and rejection of the Messiah. 4 Ezra allows for the death of the Messiah, but it was to be a natural death after a 400 year reign, belonging to the passing away of all temporal things and part of the transition to the new age. Josephus gives us portraits of so-called messiahs who died violent deaths, but their deaths indicated the falsehood of their messianic claims (Collins, Mark).

(2)   Make the tight connection between suffering and glory. So, Son of Man is used here for suffering, but also used later in 8:37 to refer to his coming in the glory of his Father with the holy angels.

b)      Basis for the divine necessity (δεῖ) is not laid out here. In 9:12; 14:21, 29, it is traced to what is written, i.e. Scripture (e.g. messianic suffering in Pss 22; 69; rejection of a messianic figure in Zech 914; most important, the suffering servant in Isa 53). Death of Jesus is foretold in Scripture; its not the result of political machinations.

c)      Rejected: Picks up language of LXX Ps 117[118]:22 (the stone the builders rejected).

d)      Elders, chief priests, scribes: the 3 groups that make up the Sanhedrin, representing the most powerful Jewish political and religious group. Josephus notes that there was disagreement and rivalry between these different parties, but their opposition towards Jesus unifies them.

2)      After 3 days rise again: Used in all 3 passion predictions (8:31; 9:31; 10:34). Matt-Luke consistently use on the 3rd day (although Matt 27:6364 takes over the Markan formula).

a)      After 3 days: Jewish usage day after tomorrow (France).

i)       Jewish usage: Cf. Josephus, Ant. 7.280 with 281; 8.214 with 218: in each case an event promised μετὰ τρεῖς ἡμέρας is expected to occur τῇ τρίτῃ τῶν ἡμερῶν.

ii)     Matt 12:40 has 3 days and 3 nights following LXX Jon 2:1. Again, this phrase need mean no more than the day after tomorrow/before yesterday (France, Mark, 337 n.56). May be to show how Jesus death and resurrection is the sign of Jonah to an unbelieving generation.

(1)   Rather than viewing this as a total of 72 hours, or 3 full days, it is best to see it as a common expression in that day in which any part of a day or year could be referred to as all that day or year.[31] So, in 1 Sam 30:1112, David finds an Egyptian who had not eaten bread or drunk water for 3 days and 3 nights. He adds, Today is the 3rd day (literal Hebrew rendering of 13c, hayyom sheloshah). See also Est 4:16 (Go, gather together all the Jews who are in Susa, and fast for me. Do not eat or drink for three days, night or day) with 5:1 (On the third day Esther put on her royal robes and stood in the inner court of the palace, in front of the kings hall.).

iii)   After 3 days: on the 4th day, but the reference is taken from the day of his rejection, rather than from the day of his death.[32]

iv)   After 3 days: Remember that in the Talmud, one is really dead only after 3 days. See notes on Lazarus.

b)      Stein: After 3 days, on the 3rd day, and after 3 days and 3 nights are all ways of describing a Fri afternoon death, a Sat stay in the tomb, and a Sun morning resurrection.

3)      Peters rebuke:

a)      Continuation of messianic misunderstanding.

b)      Rebuke: Peter rebukes (ἐπιτιμᾶν) Jesus, and Jesus rebukes (ἐπετίμησεν) Peter. Verb is used earlier of Jesus rebuking the demons (1:25; 3:12; 9:25). Shows seriousness of the situation.

c)      But turning and seeing his disciples (8:33) suggests that the disciples too shared similar concerns (France).

d)      Get behind me Satan:

i)       Does not imply that Peter is possessed by Satan, but that Peter was tempting Jesus like Satans representative.

e)      The things of men: One might expect the things of Satan given the earlier reference to Satan. But this shows that the fallen worlds values reflect Satans values.

3.2.2.2       True discipleship and suffering (8:349:1) [160]

1)      Invitation to discipleship (8:34)

a)      Called the multitude with his disciples: Discipleship applies not just to the 12, but to any who wants to follow Jesus. The indefinite pronouns (εἴ τις [8:34]; ὃς ἐάν [8:35, 38]) shows that this is a basic condition of discipleship.

b)      ὀπίσω μου and ἀκολουθέω: marks of discipleship. Here, it is to join Jesus on the way to his execution. In 8:2210:52, ἀκολουθέω is frequently used as a technical term for discipleship.

c)      3 requirements of discipleship:

i)       Deny oneself: Not the denial of something to oneself (such as chocolate on Lent), but the denial of self itself. Denial of ones own identity and ambition, a refusal to be guided by self-interest and self-determination; a reckless abandon to the will of God (Lane).

ii)     Taking ones cross:

(1)   Pictures the condemned person carrying his beam to the place of execution.

(2)   Also a curse to the Jews (Gal 3:13 = Deut 21:23).

(3)   It cannot be domesticated to mean that one should only endure hardship; its referent is literal death and martyrdom. However, the primary meaning is probably metaphorical as Luke notes that we are to die daily (Luke 9:23), and expands on the earlier idea that we are to deny oneself even to the point of death.

(4)   The cross is Romes ultimate symbol of degradation, and its use here directly repudiates Israels nationalistic messianic hope and 1st century Greco-Roman conceptions of power and status (CNTUOT).

iii)   Follow me: Not defined, but probably includes keeping Jesus teachings.

2)      1st reason for accepting the invitation of 8:34 (8:35)

a)      Double meaning

i)       Save: Used first negatively in not denying oneself; then positively in attaining eternal salvation.

ii)     Lose: Used first negatively in not attaining eternal life; then positively of denying oneself.

(1)   Losing ones life in the positive sense: Loss of reputation, privilege, comfort, and finances is legitimate if the more radical sense of losing ones physical life is not removed.

iii)   Life is first used to describe human existence that does not deny personal goals, and then to describe ones real being that continues to exist after death.

b)      My sake (Jesus) and the gospel (message concerning Jesus)

i)       And the Gospel: Only in Mark, not in Matt-Luke.

(1)   Probably an editorial insertion by Mark. Mark sees the person of Jesus (me) and the message concerning Jesus (gospel) as intimately related. Marks addition helps the reader understand what loyalty to the person of Jesus involves (BECNT).

(2)   If this was spoken by Jesus, then this understanding of the gospel would be different from that preached by Jesus in 1:1415.

c)      Application: Irony: Those who lose their lives by this crucifixion thereby find their lives: they discover that they belong to God and they can never find themselves, be fulfilled, never realize their potential, unless they abandon self-interest and abandon themselves to God (Carson, How Long, 75).

3)      Explanation of 8:35 (8:3637)

a)      Reason for willing to lose ones life: surpassing worth of eternal life.

b)      To gain the whole world: Height of human achievement.

4)      2nd reason for accepting invitation (8:38)

a)      Ashamed of me: Preference for the whole world, for the adulterous and sinful generation idolatry; denying Jesus in times of persecution rather than confessing him.

b)      Failure to give absolute allegiance in the present to Jesus and his announcement of Gods kingdom will result in eschatological ruin (cf. shame in Ps. 119:6; Isa. 1:24) when the Son of Man comes in the glory of the Father with his holy messengers/angels (CNTUOT).

i)       In light of the previous passion prediction and teaching about the necessity of taking ones cross, participation in the messianic Son of Mans eschatological vindication requires unashamedly identifying with him and his gospel as the suffering Messiah, and over against the powerful and self-sufficient, following his footsteps through cross-bearing self-renunciation and utter trust in God (CNTUOT).

c)      Referent of the Son of Man coming in glory:

i)       *Parousia when the Son of Man comes as the eschatological judge in the final judgment. Apocalyptic imagery adds to the gravity of Jesus judgment.

ii)     Coming to the throne of God. 2 theaters: earthly (this adulterous and sinful generation) and heavenly (glorious). The coming of the Son of Man refers not to the Parousia, but to his coming to the throne of God to receive sovereignty over all the nations. The heavenly scene is that of God seated on the throne and the enthronement of the Son of Man. The Son of Man who is the victim of the human judicial system will be seen to be the ultimate authority. It is before this heavenly court that the Son of Man will be ashamed of those who are ashamed of him in the earthly court (France).

d)      Use of Dan 7:13 in Mark

i)       Even though Jesus stuns his followers with the declaration that the Son of Man will suffer, he also notes that he will be vindicated.

5)      There are some standing here who will not taste death before they see that the kingdom of God has come (ἐληλυθυῖαν) with power (9:1):

a)      Kingdom of God has come with power:

i)       Death and resurrection (Edwards)

ii)     Exorcisms (Evans).

iii)   *The transfiguration as a proleptic preview and preliminary fulfillment of the coming of the kingdom. Does not fully refer to the transfiguration, although the transfiguration is a partial and proleptic fulfillment of Jesus words (Stein).

(1)   Barth: Transfiguration is proleptic of death/resurrection which is proleptic of the Parousia.

iv)   *Experience the realized dimension of the kingdoms arrival: events that show the kingdom with powerdeath, resurrection, ascension, Pentecost, explosive growth of the church.

v)      *Perceive that the kingdom of God has already come. Its not that they will see the coming of the kingdom of God but they will recognize that the kingdom has already come; note the perfect RAPAFS ἐληλυθυῖαν. The kingdom has already drawn near in 1:15 and is implied in the conflict with the kingdom of Satan (3:2327). But the kingdom is a mysteryit is like a mustard seed that has insignificant beginnings but whose growth will one day be recognized by all. Jesus words disciples will one day recognize that the kingdom of God has already come with power (France).

3.2.3        Transfiguration: Jesus revealed again as the Son of God (9:213) [16162]

1)      Some take this as the fulfillment of partial fulfillment of Jesus promise

a)      After 6 days: specific temporal connection with 9:1, suggesting that one should interpret the other.

b)      Events described here are from disciples rather than Jesus perspective, thus fulfilling Jesus promise that there are some standing here before they see.

c)      The otherworldly character of the scene points to the kingdom of God. Disciples recognize the eschatological significance.

2)      Emphasis:

a)      Christological:

i)       Confirmation of Jesus unique identity as the Son of God.

(1)   Aural pronouncement, // with that given at Jesus baptism, provides the most direct testimony of Jesus identity as the Son of God. Slight progression. At Jesus baptism, it was apparently to Jesus alone; here, it includes his disciples. Moreover, it is given just after the affirmation of Jesus identity as the Messiah and the Passion prediction.

(2)   His visible transfiguration shows that hes more than a human teacher. The glory presented here contrasts with his predicted humiliation and rejection in 8:31.

(3)   Only Jesus is transfigured, not Elijah or Moses.

(4)   *Divine reconfirmation despite the fact that Jesus the Messiah was going to suffer, a course of action that people did not expect.

ii)     Purpose of transfiguration. Association with Elijah and Moses messianic role.

iii)   Coming after 8:38, transfiguration reassures readers that Jesus will indeed come back one day as the Son of Man to judge the world. Moreover, it also serves to confirm 9:1 that some have a proleptic vision of the coming Son of Man in his glory. Readers can be assured that Christ will return to consummate the kingdom.

iv)   Confirms the necessity of Jesus passion and death.

(1)   Listen to him is a rebuke to Peter that he has to listen to Jesus passion prediction in 8:3031 and understand Jesus death to be a divine must (δεῖ).

(2)   Moreover, Jesus reinforces his passion again in 9:9, thus reminding that Jesus glory cannot be separated from his death and resurrection.

b)      Salvation-historical

i)       Clarifies that Elijah has already come in the form of John the Baptist, preceding the death and resurrection of the Son of Man.

3)      Link with Peters confession and functions as a divine rebuke of Peter.

a)      This is my beloved Son

i)       Voice from heaven corroborates Peters confession. Although Son of God is used here and Messiah in Peters confession, Mark understands them to be complementary as Jesus is the Christ, the Son of God (1:1).

b)      Listen to him

i)       Rebuke to Peter that he should listen to Jesus passion prediction in 8:3031.

 

1)      OT //: Moses experience in Sinai (Exod 24).

a)      Similarities

i)       Mountain setting (Exod 24:1215)

ii)     He took 3 named companions (Aaron, Nadab and Abihu) + 70 elders.

iii)   After 6 days, Moses went into the cloud on the 7th (24:16).

iv)   Moses shining face and Jesus dazzling clothes

v)      Disciples fearful response (Exod 34:30)

vi)   Voice from the overshadowing cloud on the 7th day (Exod 24:16)

vii) Subsequent descent to encounter an unfaithful generation (Mark 9:19; Deut 32:20)

viii)           Peters odd remark about building tents σκηνή (recalls shekinah).

b)      If Mark is describing a new exodus, then this is its new Sinai.

i)       Some similarities to show this as a new Sinai experience with Jesus as the new Moses. But although Mark may be aware of this New Moses typology, he did not exploit it.

c)      Ps 2:7 in Mark

i)       Since the disciples were not present at Jesus baptism, this is their first and only experience of the divine affirmation.

ii)     Ps 2 is Gods confirmation of Peters confession (8:29). Moreover, it also affirms that Jesus is the glorious Son of Man (8:31, 38).

iii)   By its placement, Ps 2 is also connected with Isa 53.

(1)   This means that the traditional hopes that had attached to Ps. 2 of a restored Jerusalem in which a victorious king-messiah drives out the unclean and purifies the temple (Pss. Sol. 17; 4Q174; cf. Tg. Ps. 2:6) must undergo radical transformation. These things Jesus will do, even to becoming the keystone of a new temple (Ps. 118:22 in Mark 12:10), but his wielding a rod of iron and shattering the nations like pots (Ps. 2:9) will come through the power of redeeming death and resurrection (CNTUOT).

3.2.3.1       Transfiguration (9:210) [161]

1)      Geography: Traditional site is Mt Tabor.

2)      Transfiguration

a)      Jesus is transfigured, his clothes also become bright white. Mark only mentions clothes; Matt-Luke also stress his radiant face.

b)      Glistening (στίλβοντα) white radiant robes of God himself (Dan 7:9). Here, they show Jesus glory.

c)      As no fuller on earth could bleach them: supernatural, no natural explanation for what the disciples saw.

d)      Meaning

i)       The pre-incarnate glory of the Son of God was revealed in his humanity.

ii)     *A proleptic glimpse of the glory of the Son of Man in his coming glory, given Matt 16:28 and 2 Pet 1:1618. This then functions as the fulfillment of 9:1.

3)      Elijah and Moses

a)      Not likely that they represent the law and the prophets.

b)      Contrasts and alludes to Jesus victory over death. Both Elijah and Moses are presented in some Jewish thought as the deathless ones. Elijah was translated to heaven; Moses because of his unknown location of his grave (Deut 34:56). But here, Jesus is the one who died and was raised again.

c)      Both men spoke with God on Sinai/Horeb (1 Kings 19).

d)      Both Moses and Elijah appear together in just one place (Mal 4:45), both are to be obeyed in preparation for the long-awaited new exodus, the great and terrible day of the Lord. Moses recalls the beginning of Israels story when he prepared for Yahwehs coming in glory upon his tabernacle. Elijah anticipates its consummation by preparing for Yahwehs glorious return and permanent resident in his temple. The opinion that Elijah and Moses represents the law and the prophets may be correct, in that Elijah functions as the representative prophet that calls the people back to the law of Moses (CNTUOT).

i)       Lau

(1)   Moses: Initiates Gods covenant with the people. Brings about the 1st Exodus

(2)   Elijah: Attempts to restore Gods covenant with the people. Prepares for the new exodus (forerunner that prepares for the return of Yahweh)

(a)   Elijah needed to hear Gods gentle whisper

(b)   Here, we are commanded to listen to him

(3)   Jesus: Brings about the new covenant. Brings about the New Exodus

(a)   In 3G, they talk to Jesus about his upcoming exodus.

e)      Represent the coming of the messianic age. Reappearance of Elijah represents the coming of the day of the Lord. Moses a prophet like Moses (Deut 18:1519) who would come in the end-time.

4)      Peters request (9:56)

a)      Failure to recognize Jesus uniqueness:

i)       Rabbi: Inadequate answer when Jesus has just been revealed to be more than a mere human teacher. Peters fault is that he does not put Jesus on a different plan than Elijah or Moses.

(1)   In Mark, rabbi is only used by disciples (9:5; 11:21; 14:45), emphasizing the master-pupil relationship. The address of Jesus by Judas as a rabbi in14:45 emphasizes the master-pupil relationship and thus heightens the drama of betrayal. He is called rabboni by Bartimaeus, but that may be more of a term of respect (10:51). Both Jesus disciples and outsiders call Jesus teacher (9:17; 10:17, 20; 12:14, 19, 32).

(2)   In Matt, disciples call Jesus Lord; only outsiders and Judas address Jesus as rabbi or teacher.

ii)     Stein also notes that Peters failure is not to prolong the experience but he failed to recognize Jesus uniqueness and superiority over Moses and Elijah.

b)      Failure to embrace suffering:

i)       His desire to erect tents suggests that he wants to enjoy the benefits of the new eschatological age, forgetting that suffering and death must precede glory (Lane). Moreover, this present glory is only temporary as 9:8 shows.

ii)     Peters decision to build booths may allude to the Festival of the Tabernacles or Booths, a celebration filled with allusions to Gods final intervention in history.

c)      Failure to comprehend: He did not know (ᾔδει) what to say; absent in Matt 17:4, but present in Luke 9:33.

i)       Point is not so much about Peters acumen, but that it is not possible prior to Jesus death and resurrection to truly understand who Jesus is.

5)      Heavenly portents (9:7)

a)      Cloud: Theophanic motif in OT. But here, probably points to Sinai narrative where the shekinah cloud overshadows the mountain and God speaks from the cloud (Exod 19:9; 24:16; 24:1825:1; 34:5).

b)      Voice: Bat qol (daughter of a voice קול בת) was a term used by 1st century rabbis for the echo of Gods voice which was given in some situations following the cessation of prophecy. It was however considered an inferior substitute for the direct communication of prophecy. Here, this is not a bat qol, but direct communication from God. Together, with the glory of the shekinah cloud, we have Gods communication in 2 ways.

c)      This is my beloved son: Echoes language of divine sonship in Ps 2:7 and 2 Sam 7:14.

d)      Listen to him:

i)       Echoes Deut 18:15 in that the prophet like Moses is to be accorded the same authority as Moses himself.

ii)     Rebuke to Peter for not accepting Jesus passion teaching in 8:3031.

iii)   Moreover, its related to the rebuke of the disciples in 8:18, and with the injunction to listen in the parable of the Sower.

e)      Importance in the early church. 2 Pet 1:1619. Confirms the prophetic word.

6)      Secrecy motif: In contrast to other commands for secrecy, here a time limit it set. Wrede used this verse (9:9) to explain why the early Church did not realize Jesus messianic office until after the resurrection.

a)      This transfiguration vision would also have fueled messianic expectations. Only reveal it after his death and his resurrection. The revelation of the kingdom of God in Jesus could not be rightly perceived until after his death and resurrection.

b)      This is illustrated in the next verse where his disciples did not understand the necessity of his dying and resurrection. (Osborne) << but Im not sure of this.

7)      Failure to understand: Questioning (συζητοῦντες) what the rising from the dead meant.

a)      Only present in Mark.

b)      Reason for the incomprehension: They probably understood resurrection that was corporate and tied to the eschatological age. For resurrection to be tied to a single person and a particular event in history would be incomprehensible.

3.2.3.2       Coming of Elijah (9:1113) [162]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Eschatologically, Jesus identification of John with Malachis promised Elijah confirms that this is the great and terrible day of the Lord, and that Jesus himself is necessarily identified with Yahwehs personal presence (CNTUOT).

b)      Ecclesiologically, in rejecting John and Jesus, official Israel rejects Yahweh and choose the covenantal curses (CNTUOT).

 

1)      Question

a)      ὅτι: interrogative use (BDF 300.2), Markan feature.

b)      Relationship of this question with preceding verses is unclear. Having just seen Elijah and puzzling over his reference to being raised from the dead, the disciples ask the question.

i)       If Jesus death and resurrection are associated with the coming of the kingdom of God in power (9:1, 28), why then has Elijah not arrived? Since disciples state Why do the scribes say, they may be alluding to the scribes objection to Jesus claim that the kingdom of God has drawn near (1:1415) (Stein).

ii)     Having just seen Elijah, they presumably assumed that the eschatological reconciliation of Israel had already begun. How is it then, that Jesus can still speak of his resurrection, and thereby his rejection and death? Does not Elijah restore all things (CNTUOT).

c)      Reappearance of Elijah arrival of the great and dreadful day of the Lord (Mal 4:56). Probably also Sir 48:10 since disciples say, Why do the scribes say

2)      Reply

a)      *Jesus agrees with the scribes that Elijah does indeed come first to restore all things. He then replies with his own question: given that Elijah was indeed to restore all things, how can it be written that the Son of Man should suffer many things and be treated contemptibly [exoudenēthē] (9:12)? (CNTUOT).

i)       Jesus probably asks, If Elijah has indeed come to restore all things, why it is that the Son of Man should suffer and be rejected? After all, in restoring all things, Elijah should have prepared the hearts of the minds to receive the Son of Man. Answer. Elijah did come, but the people rejected him. (Lau).

ii)     Jesus highlights the tension between the scribal expectation of reconciliation (Mal 4:56) and the suffering Messianic servant of Isa 53. Since Scripture affirms that the messianic Servant must be rejected, it also presupposes the same for Elijah, since they could not reject Jesus without first rejecting Elijah. Thus, Mal 4:46 should not be read as a blanket promise of restoration (as the scribes and disciples seem to have thought), but as a final warning. See especially Mal 4:6 (Otherwise, I will come and strike the land with a curse) (CNTUOT).

iii)   Jesus then confirms that the suffering of the Son of Man that Elijah has already arrived, and they have done to him everything as they wished, just as it is written about him.

b)      Hard to understand 9:12b, probably should be read as a rhetorical question emphasizing the necessity of his death.

i)       9:12b hints that Elijahs return to restore all things is tied to the suffering of the Son of Man. Both are eschatological events of the end times. The scribes are correct. But their error is not recognizing the arrival of Elijah. Jesus states that the suffering of the Son of Man Elijah has already arrived.

ii)     Although John the Baptist is not here specifically indicated to be Elijah, Matt 13:17 explicitly states that the disciples understood that he was speaking to them about John the Baptist.

iii)      The mission of Elijah has met with rejection and death, a foreshadowing of the same treatment that will befall the Son of Man. Mark does not explicitly identity Elijah = John the Baptist, but his readers would have picked it up since he links Jesus with Elijah and John the Baptist (6:1415; 8:28).

c)      Martyrdom of Elijah is not explicitly foretold in Scripture (as it is written of him; 9:13).

i)       It is from a typological reading of 1 Kgs 1719, 21.

ii)     It is written not in direct prophecy, but that it is presupposed by the Isaianic predictions of the suffering servant (CNTUOT).

3)      Matt 17:13 Then the disciples understood show Matthean theme of understanding (13:23, 51; 14:33; 16:12).

4)      In summary, the promise of Elijahs return does not refute the claims of Jesus (as the scribes would want to believe), but rather supports them.

3.3         Jesus heals a boy possessed by a spirit: Success and failure in exorcism (9:1429) [163]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Reeducation of the disciples:

i)       Failure of the disciples: Failure to fulfill the commission to cast out demons given to the 12 in 3:15, 6:7.

ii)     Lesson on discipleship and faith, stemming from the failure of the disciples. Emphasis here is not on the impression the healing makes on the crowds, but on the lesson this experience teaches the disciples.

(1)   Cannot rely on past experiences be on automatic pilot; need for continual dependence on God.

b)      Christological: Emphasizes Jesus ἐξουσιά over all demons, confirms Jesus sonship established at the Transfiguration.

i)       Crowds are amazed at his presence; crowds only see him (9:15), rather than Peter, James, and John.

2)      Mark is expansive. Mark (272 words); Luke (144); Matt (110).

3)      Symptoms appear to be that of epilepsy, but better to take it with Mark as demon possession.

 

1)      Scene (1415)

a)      Crowds: Do not play a major part in this story, only heightens the drama and embarrassment of the disciples.

b)      Great crowd .. all the crowd: shows Jesus popularity.

c)      Conflict narrative: Scribes arguing (συζητοῦντας).

d)      Crowds were greatly amazed (ἐξεθαμβήθησαν) when they saw him: Usually in response to a miracle, here shows the powerful impression that Jesus presence creates.

i)       Possible allusion to the Moses story whose face shone after coming down from the mountain.

2)      Situation (9:1619)

a)      They were not able (9:18): The use of οὐκ ἴσχυσαν rather than οὐκ ἠδυνήθησαν heightens inability of disciples. Note the use of ἰσχύω in another exorcism narrative (no one was strong enough to subdue him; 5:4) disciples were not strong enough; they were too weak in a power struggle.

b)      And he said to them: Not clear who the antecedent of them is. It can refer to the disciples, but their faithlessness is symptomatic of the entire generation.

3)      Miracle (9:2027)

a)      It has often cast him to destroy him (ἵνα ἀπολέσῃ αὐτόν): shows destructive intent and nature of demons. Purpose of demonic possession: to distort and destroy the image of God in man (Lane).

b)      If you can: Shows importance of faith for receiving divine power.

i)       Doubt of the father: If the disciples couldnt, how did he know whether the Master could? Here its the faith of the father in question, not the faith of the exorcist (although the faith of the disciples has been shown to be lacking in the words O faithless generation).

c)      All things are possible to him who believes:

i)       Hyperbole. Needs to be balanced with theodicy and prayer that is in line with Gods will. Cannot be taken to mean that you do not have faith if something that you pray doesnt turn out.

ii)     All things here emphasizes the unlimited power of God and his unquestionable authority over all demonic powers.

d)      I believe, help my unbelief (9:24):

i)       Paradoxical reply is indicative of many sincere believers. Belief and unbelief are part of us. But Mark shows that God is able to use this faith, no matter how limited (faith like a mustard seed), certain, or paradoxical.

4)      Question (9:2829)

a)      This kind cannot be driven out by anything but prayer [and fasting]:

i)       Fasting: TC. Although Jesus rules out fasting as obligatory while he is still with them, this reading suggests that fasting (as in Matt 6:1618) is permitted or encouraged as a spiritual discipline in preparation for spiritual conflict.

ii)     This kind (τοῦτο τὸ γένος): Suggests that there are different categories of demons. But this is not taught anywhere else in NT. Perhaps this kind does not suggest a special class of demons, but that demons as a class can never be overcome by human strength. They have forgotten their dependence on Jesus ἐξουσία that was the basis of their earlier successes. Perhaps they have become self-dependent based on their earlier successes (6:13, 30) and must now learn that all spiritual conflict requires dependence on Gods power that is reflected in the posture of prayer. Prayer seen as turning from self-centeredness to a dependence on God in faith. Their public humiliation is a wakeup call to relearn the fundamental principle of the kingdom of God (France).

iii)   Prayer trust in God. Once again, the disciples fail because of their incomprehension, of thinking the things not of God but of humans.

 

1)      Literary

a)      Why this healing miracle here?

i)       The failure of the disciples to cast out the deaf-mute spirit is possibly related to their own idolatrous blind and deaf condition (8:1718) (CNTUOT).

3.4         More lessons about the way of the cross (9:3050)

1)      2nd cycle of Passion prediction disciples incomprehension teaching on discipleship.

 

 

1st

2nd

3rd

Passion prediction

8:31

9:31

10:3334

Disciples incomprehension

8:32

9:3234

10:3541

Failure of inner circle

Peter

John

James & John

Teaching on discipleship

8:3438

9:3550

10:4245

 

3.4.1        2nd Passion prediction followed by incomprehension (9:3032) [164]

1)      Emphasis:

a)      Reeducation of disciples

i)       No miracles, nor public activity. And he would not have any one know it; for he was teaching his disciples (9:3031).

ii)     Imperfect tense ἐδίδασκεν customary, showing the continual theme of teaching at this stage.

b)      Christological: Assuming that Mark wrote to Gentile readers, hes assuring them again that Jesus death is not a tragedy. Rather, Jesus, as the Son of God, knew of his impending death and that it was divinely ordained (note divine passive of παραδίδοται; 9:31) to secure the redemption of humanity (10:45).

 

1)      Geography: Begins at the foot of Mount of Transfiguration (location unknown) and he now passes through Galilee.

2)      Delivered into the hands: παραδίδοται (future present), recalls fate of John the Baptist (1:14) and points to his future betrayal by Judas.

a)      παραδίδωμι is also used in Isa 53:6, 12 (CNTUOT).

3)      Son of Man will be delivered into the hands of men (ἀνθρώπων): the divine figure given into human power || the sovereign of all humanity (re. Dan 7:14) given to human power.

4)      They did not understand the saying:

a)      Probably not cognitive understanding, but acceptance of what Jesus was saying (Stein).

b)      Mark emphasizes disciples incomprehension. Mattnot present. Luke adds and it was concealed from them that they should not perceive it, mitigating the failure of the disciples.

3.4.2        Teaching on discipleship (9:3350) [16668]

1)      Comprise 3 episodes that teaches about true discipleship: true greatness [166]; the strange exorcist [167]; warnings concerning temptation [168]

2)      Emphasis

a)      Discipleship:

i)       Failure 1: While Jesus eyes are fixed on martyrdom, they are jockeying for personal greatness. Contrast between the Son of Man who faces death willingly and gives his life for others and the disciples who only care about their own status. After 2nd and 3rd passion prediction, disciples show concern only for themselves

(1)   Principle of the kingdom of God found in the inversion of the worlds values. Preeminent status in the kingdom is characterized by those who are lowly (last of all) and who serve (servant of all). Exemplified by Christ in 10:45.

ii)     Failure 2: Discrimination against others that are not part of your group. Principle of the kingdom of God: warning against forming sectarianism or to think that you have an inside track to the kingdom of God.

(1)   Illustration: David Adeney: Which mission organization to join? Focus should be on Gods work rather than the agency.

iii)   Failure 3: Causing Christian to stumble, obstacles in ones own life that cause stumbling.

iv)   Reward: Welcoming God (9:37), reward (9:41), (eternal) life = kingdom of God (9:43, 45).

b)      Christological:

i)       Shaliach motif (9:37), which is more prominent in John.

ii)     Like 8:3438, human destiny depends on how one receives Jesus.

3.4.2.1       True greatness: Radical lesson on status (9:3337) [166]

1)      Geography: Capernaum. Hard to see how Jesus could not be recognized here. But emphasis here is not on public ministry but on a private teaching ἐν τῇ οἰκίᾳ.

2)      Dispute (9:33-34)

a)      What were you discussing/arguing on the way: Not asking for info, but to open a debate about something which they were ashamed.

b)      Who was the greatest: Triggered by selection of Peter, James, and John to go up the mountain for the transfiguration. Those who stayed behind may be upset, further aggravated by their humiliation at the failed exorcism. Moreover, if they understood a little about Jesus prediction of his death, they may be asking themselves about plans of succession.

3)      Jesus resolution (9:35)

a)      Sat down and called the 12: Sat down position for teaching, now made more formal with the calling of the 12.

4)      Illustration: Child (9:3637). Acted parable illustration 9:35 (Lane).

a)      Aramaic uses the same word for child and servant.

b)      Reference to a child is not because he is a paradigm for humility, but because of his status = lowest in the social structure, under the authority and care of others, does not have the right to decide matters for itself, no honor or status.

c)      To become like a child (Matt 18:13) accept the lowest place. Not present here, but later in 10:15.

d)      Whoever receives one such child in my name receives me:

i)       Greatness in Gods kingdom does not depend on how one is received, but how one receives the lowliest (CNTUOT).

ii)     Receiving one child:

(1)   Call to invert ones value system by giving importance to those that are not important. The verb δέχομαι, a general term for receiving someone such as a guest, here probably means treating them as significant. You can see Jesus calling a child, who was in the background scene, and pushing him or her into the foreground, in their midst of them (ἐν μέσῳ αὐτῶν; 9:36).

(2)   The 1st century world did not idealize childhood, nor romanticized as examples of innocence and purity. In Judaism, they were not yet people of the covenant, and were expected to serve those that were first.

(a)   The negligible value of children is suggested by a comment of R. Dosa ben Harkinas in the Mishnah: Morning sleep and midday wine and childrens talk and sitting in the meeting-houses of ignorant people put a man out of the world (m. Avot 3:11). Moreover, girls under the age of twelve could be sold as slaves by their fathers (m. Ket. 3:8). (Edwards)

iii)   In my name: modifies child (a child who comes in my name = Christian) || *the one receiving (i.e. doing as what Christ himself would do)

iv)   Child: literal | metaphorical for a believer | *both (a literal child who believers in Jesus)

(1)   Reasons: (1) The parallels to 9:37 all involve receiving/rejecting believers; (2) 9:42 delimits the little ones to believers

(2)   When a Christian receives (serves) a socially unimportant person in the believing community such as a child (i.e., when he has become servant of all), he receives (serves) Jesus, and receiving (serving) Jesus means to receive (serve) the one who sent him.

(a)   Possible Shaliach motif: receive Christian receive Christ receive God.

5)      Application

a)      Importance of childrens ministry

b)      Importance of ministry to the handicapped

3.4.2.2       Strange exorcist: Warning against cliquishness (9:3841) [167]

1)      Follows smoothly from 9:3337. Call to receive someone you typically reject is illustrated by the call to receive this strange exorcist. The link is further strengthened by the use of in my name (or its variants) 3x in this pericope, the same reason for receiving the child in my name in 9:37.

2)      Why did the disciples find it distressing? Exorcism has so far been the prerogative of Jesus, and he has given them this authority. This would then be a blow to their significance and status. Moreover, to see an outsider succeeding where they failed miserably would add to the injury (France).

a)      Irony: Disciples telling the man to stop what they were unable to do (9:1719) (Gundry).

 

1)      Johns objection (9:38)

a)      His hostility to outsiders possibly explains Sons of Thunder (3:17).

b)      Reason: Because he was not following us (not Jesus, but us). John was not looking for authentic discipleship of Jesus but participation in an authorized group. The us portrays the 12 as having an exclusive claim and link with Jesus, and other peoples association with Jesus must be mediated through them.

2)      Jesus response (9:3941): 3 γάρ clauses

a)      1st γάρ: The fact that he can work miracles in Jesus name shows that he cannot be against them.

b)      2nd γάρ: The one that is not against us is for us.

c)      3rd γάρ: Whoever gives you a drink of water (i.e., basic courtesy) because you bear the name of Christ will not lose his reward that you will not lose your reward if you show courtesy to other Christian worker (such as this exorcist).

i)       ἐν ὀνόματι ὅτι = on the claim, on the basis that (BDF 397.3)

ii)     you are of Christ: Why Χρίστος and not Son of Man? Probably because Jesus knows that after his death, it is the title Christ which will serve as the test of allegiance. See 1 Cor 1:12 I am of Paul, I of Apollos, I of Cephas, I of Christ.

(1)   Or could you say that this is a change in the early tradition when Jesus may have said on account of me (Lau)?

3)      Parallels: Paul in Phil 1, where he does not mind others preaching the gospel even those that do it out of spite to him.

4)      Application:

a)      How far do we take this tolerance? Reject those who are truly Gods enemies and rejoice with those who serve God who are not within our circle.

3.4.2.3       Warnings concerning temptation: Further sayings on discipleship (9:4250) [168]

1)      9:42 fits more naturally with 9:37. Thematically, it fits with the larger theme of discipleship.

 

1)      Warning against tripping another persons discipleship.

a)      Little ones who believe in me: disciple

b)      Great millstone: lit. a donkey-pulled millstone; shows the severity.

c)      How one might cause a believer to stumble is not outlined here.

2)      Warning against temptation.

a)      The offending body parts are seen to be gangrenous. It is better to amputate that than to lose ones life. Idea is extended to spiritual realm.

b)      Contrasts: [enter life maimed || go to hell] (9:43); [enter life lame || thrown into hell] (9:45); [enter the kingdom of God with 1 eye || thrown into hell] (9:47)

i)       enter into life = enter the kingdom of God. This is further brought out in Mark 10 where the terms enter the kingdom of God (10:25) = saved (σωθῆναι; 10:25) = eternal life (10:30).

ii)     hell = gehenna, origin is possibly in the Valley of Hinnom (Heb. ge-hinnom) where the fire of Jerusalems rubbish dump burns continuously. In OT, it was associated with child sacrifice to Molech and Baal.

c)      Cut it off:

i)       Literal (Gundry).

ii)     *Metaphorical: Amputation shows the seriousness of the situation. How we handle the temptation to sin leads to eternal life or hell. Seriousness also emphasized by 3x repetition using hand, foot, eye.

d)      Application: Shows the need to have clear preaching that lays out the consequences of ones actions such as Edwards Sinners in the hands of an angry God.

 

1)      OT background of where their worm does not die, and the fire is not quenched (Isa 66:24)

a)      Isa context

i)       Isa 6566 employs the lawsuit language of Deuteronomy, and draws out the strong contrast between Yahwehs blessing on the humble and contrite offspring of the servant of Isa 4055, and his fiery judgment on the arrogant rebels, with their elitist pseudo-holiness, who refuse his summons, neglect Torah, and seek to control their own destinies (CNTUOT).

b)      Mark context

i)       The Pharisees with their false purity and who in fact reject Torah have rejected Gods call very much like the rebels of Isa 6566.

ii)     Nevertheless, there are differences. Jesus addresses his newly reconstructed community rather than Israel; the object of abuse is not the Torah or the temple, but rather one of the little ones who believe in Jesus.

3.4.2.3.1     Salted/Salt (9:4950)

1)      These sayings were probably independent sayings.

2)      Everyone will be salted with fire (9:49): Enigmatic. Possibly purified by fire.

a)      Temple sacrifices such as grain (Lev 2:13) and burnt offering (Ezek 43:24) are to be sprinkled with salt, symbolizing a pure sacrifice. Salt is seen as a purifying agent. Disciples are viewed as a sacrifice to God and discipleship is a purifying process. Fire that purifies probably refers to trials (Num 31:23; Mark 8:34-37; Matt 5:10-12; 1 Pet 1:7; 4:12) (Osborne, Stein).

i)       But CNTUOT notes that salt in Lev 2:13 apparently does not signify purification. Rather, the salt just indicates that it is a most holy offering. Thus, Jesus declares that even the least disciple is Gods most holy sacrifice, and each one will be salted by fire (purifying ordeal of cross-bearing discipleship | fiery sanctifying presence of the Holy Spirit).

b)      France: To be salted with fire evokes imagery of temple sacrifice believers service to God is like a burnt offering that is complete and irrevocable. One who follows Jesus must be totally dedicated to Gods service, and there is the danger that it will be costly.

c)      Referent for the fire:

i)       metaphor for purifying suffering (Lane, Frane)

ii)     testing fire that will purify genuine disciples and consume apostates (Gundry)

iii)   purifying eschatological fire of Mal 3:2-3 over against Gehennas consuming fire (Evans)

iv)   Holy Spirit (suggested by CNTUOT)

3)      Tasteless salt (9:50a).

a)      Metaphor shifts from salt as an agent of purification to salt as a metaphor of discipleship (Stein). Salt is the quality that prevents food from spoiling. Here, the disciple must maintain their life changing quality in the world. This thought is made explicit in Matt where it states You are the salt of the earth.

i)       NaCl doesnt lose taste. But salt in those days is not pure NaCl and the salt could leach out leaving other minerals such as gypsum. But if salt has lost its taste, it is worthless. See Davies and Allison, 1988 on Pliny N.H. 31.82.

ii)     Another perspective is that Jesus is referring to the inconceivable situation of real salt losing its taste. In other words, no disciple could be a nominal disciple and still remain a true disciple.

4)      Have salt in yourselves (9:50b)

a)      Metaphor shifts to a more specific example. Disciples are called to have salt in themselves, the true essence of discipleship in that having salt in yourselves = consists of (epexegetical καί) or results in (consequential καί) peace within the community (France). Such characteristics would encompass not seeking status (9:3338) and inclusivism (9:3840), resulting in peace within the community.

b)      Note that peace within the community forms an inclusio with 9:34 where the disciples were arguing with one another (πρὸς ἀλλήλους διελέχθησαν).

3.5         Counter-cultural values of the kingdom of God (10:1-31) [251255]

1)      From 10:29, Jesus engages in discussion with outsiders. But from 10:10 onwards, the disciples again become the focus of attention.

2)      Emphasis

a)      Values of the kingdom of God. ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ prominent here (10:14, 15,23, 24, 25), more so than any other part of the gospel.

i)       Contrast between the values espoused by disciples and the principles of the kingdom of God. Shows how far they have to learn before the kingdom of God can be established in them (France).

3)      Structure

a)      Divorce (10:112)

b)      Letting the children come to Jesus (10:1316)

c)      Rich Young Man (10:1731)

3.5.1        Marriage and divorce (10:112) [25152]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christology: Jesus authoritative teaching of Scripture and his declaration of the will of God should ask the question, Who then is this man?

b)      Discipleship in the area of marriage. Disciples cannot live their lives based on what God has conceded due to human sinfulness (10:5), but on Gods intended plan of monogamy and fidelity (Stein).

 

1)      Geography: Movement from Galilee (Capernaum), down to the region of Judea, and into the east beyond the Jordan, i.e. Perea.

2)      Jewish views of divorce

a)      Women were not allowed to divorce, only men.

b)      The possibility of divorce was not debated. What was debated were the legitimate grounds for the divorce.

i)       General agreement on matters such as infertility, unfaithfulness, and neglect (material and emotional; cf Exod 21:1011). (CNTUOT).

ii)     Major issue surrounded the interpretation of Deut 24:14 something indecent about her

(1)   Typically, it means shameful exposure or nakedness. In this context, the precise meaning is not clear and may denote a physical deficiency such as the inability to bear children (Craigie).

(2)   Sir 25:26 If she does not accept your control, divorce her and send her away;

(3)   Josephus At this time I divorced my wife, not liking her behavior (Life 246);

(4)   Hillel: lenienta spoiled meal

(5)   R. Akiba if he found another fairer than she (m. Git. 9.10).

(6)   Shammai: stringentunchastity (m. Git. 9.10). But this is a marginal view. Hillel was almost universally accepted.

(7)   Emphasis lies not on the grounds for divorce, but that (given the tradition of its occurrence), a legal document of divorce is to be formally provided to the wifealmost certainly to provide the wife with protection and a formal status, and to give her the freedom to remarry without charge of adultery. The specific illegality of remarriage to the former husband (Deut 24:4) presupposes the legality of a different remarriage.[33]

c)      All divorce was with a view towards remarriage. The question that is raised today regarding divorce without remarriage was not addressed.

3)      Jesus and the Law (See Law in DJG)

a)      Jesus questions the Mosaic provision for divorce in Deut 24:14, and some debate whether Jesus abrogates the Mosiac law at this point.

i)       Stein says no: 10:1012 is not a contradiction of the law, but a revelation of the laws true purpose.

 

1)      Gen 1:27/5:2; 2:24

a)      Only humans are designated male and female both genders are included in the image of God, and both are essential to articulate fully our humanity.

b)      In 2:24,

i)       Man is a social being, and that he needs a woman to complete him.

ii)     Marriage is the sole appropriate expression of this reality.

iii)   Since honoring parents is next to honoring God, for a man to leave and cling (which is covenantal language) stresses the supreme sanctity of marriage. Thus, this is not descriptive but constitutes a divine decree.

 

1)      Attempt to trap Jesus (10:12)

a)      Purpose of the trap (πειράζω).

i)       To jeopardize him with Antipas whose marriage to Herodias was a scandal. Note that Jesus is now in Perea, in Antipas control. Moreover, John the Baptists death was also due to his criticism of Antipas marriage.

(1)   Antipas was tetrarch of Galilee and Perea; Philip was tetrarch of Galanitis, Trachonitis, Batanea, and Paneas

ii)     To marginalize Jesus further, perhaps they knew that his views was extreme (France).

2)      Jesus answer (10:39)

a)      Mosaic command (10:35)

i)       Mosaic regulation in 10:24 (Deut 24:14) does not permit divorce but regulates it, providing protection for the wife to marry another man. The certificate given to a divorced wife reads, You are free to marry any man (m. Git. 9.3).

ii)     Note the switch from command in Jesus question to allowed in their response. Instead of citing the Laws command and intention as Jesus does in 10:69 (they could also quote Mal 2:16), the Pharisees show their wrong focus in centering on what God allows (although he disapproves of it).

b)      Jesus response (10:69)

i)       Temporal priority of Gods provision in Gen 1:27; 2:24. First principles have precedence over subsequent formulations, formulations which are given in light of human weakness. The formulation was meant to limit the problem of divorce, not serve as a license for this practice.

ii)     God created man and woman to be married, becoming one flesh: something permanent and indivisible. Emphasized by no longer two (οὐκέτι εἰσίν δύο).

iii)   Interpretation (10:9): Note the contrasts between [God || man], [join together || put asunder].

(1)   Implication: True disciples will return from the formulations of man to true principles of God.

3)      Private teaching (10:1012)

a)      Continues incomprehension motif, because the disciples immediately ask Jesus.

b)      Jesus goes beyond Jewish assumptions by stating that a husband could commit adultery against his wife that a wife had rights over her husbands behavior and vice versa. In Jewish world, a man could commit adultery against the husband of the woman concerned, or a woman could commit adultery against her own husband. So, for the comment that a husband can commit adultery against his wife is remarkable development for equality (France).

c)      And if she divorces her husband and marries another, she commits adultery: Jesus recognizes the right of a wife to divorce (only in Mark).

i)       Contextualization on Marks part for a Gentile audience in the Roman world, where Mark brings out the true intent of Jesus.

ii)     Historically goes back to Jesus. Although generally Jewish women could not divorce their husbands, there were exceptions (Sir 23:2223). One famous case is where Herodias divorced Herod Philip 1 in order to marry Herod Antipas. So, its possible that just as John the Baptist spoke against such a divorce and union, so did Jesus.

 

1)      1 Cor 7

a)      Paul allows for divorce in the case of desertion by an unbelieving partner (1 Cor 7:1215).

2)      Matthews except for πορνεία

a)      Not found in Mark 10:11; Luke 16:18, 1 Cor 7:11.

b)      Many think that this is a Matthean addition to suit the sitz im leben of the Matthean church.

c)      Probably Mark and Luke assumed the exception.

i)       The debate pitted Hillel versus Shammai, but both agreed on Matthews exception, so any contemporary Jew would have inserted that exception mentally even if it was not present.

d)      See Osbornes notes on Matt 5:32.

i)       πορνεία (general sexual promiscuity) nullifies the martial contract and frees the innocent party to remarry.

e)      Biblio[34]

3)      Matt 19:11-12

a)      eunuch who were born this way. Those born with a physical disorder of sex development.

i)       Nashville statement:

(1)   WE AFFIRM that those born with a physical disorder of sex development are created in the image of God and have dignity and worth equal to all other image-bearers. They are acknowledged by our Lord Jesus in his words about eunuchs who were born that way from their mother's womb. With all others they are welcome as faithful followers of Jesus Christ and should embrace their biological sex insofar as it may be known.

(2)   WE DENY that ambiguities related to a persons biological sex render one incapable of living a fruitful life in joyful obedience to Christ.

4)      Application

a)      Allowances for divorce: sexual immorality and desertion by an unbelieving spouse.

i)       If Jesus declaration in 10:9 is taken to mean no divorce under any circumstances, then he will be at odds not only with Moses, but also with God who divorced Israel (N. Kingdom) in Jer 3:8. The fact that Jesus says nothing about non no fault divorce probably presupposes Exod 21:10-11.

ii)     But even in these situations, following Yahwehs example, divorce is not mandatory, and reconciliation and forgiveness are much preferred.

b)      Physically abusive situation: Should immediately have separation while seeking counseling.

i)       Is this a ground for divorce? Difficult issue, because is the abusive husband then functioning as an unbeliever, and this would then fall in line with 1 Cor 7.

ii)     Osborne says that he might be open to it.

c)      Continued emotional abuse: should probably also separate

d)      Husband addicted to internet porn:

i)       Is this also grounds for divorce? Probably not.

3.5.2        Children (10:1316) [253]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Discipleship: Shows what is involved in becoming a disciple.

i)       Necessity of receiving Gods offer of the kingdom in humility and simple faith.

(1)   Jesus promises the Kingdom to those whose faith resembles the empty hand of a beggar (Schweizer)

ii)     Necessity to see children as Jesus sees them. Disciples failed because they were arrogant and had too much self-importance. Disciples need humility.

(1)   Application: Stress importance of those who are socially insignificant (e.g. children, handicapped) and the need to cater to their spiritual welfare.

b)      Failure of the disciples to learn from 9:3638 where Jesus used the example of receiving a child (person with low status) as principle of the kingdom.

 

1)      Disciples failure (10:13)

a)      They were bringing: parents. Their anonymity focuses on their status. They and their children are not special. The conative imperfect προσέφερον shows their unsuccessful attempt.
