b)      Why hinder the children? Children were thought to be less important than adults || disciples thought they had exclusive access to Jesus.

2)      Jesus rebuke (10:1416)

a)      For to such (τῶν τοιούτων) belongs the kingdom of God: The for to such suggests a group which children represent = people who have no status.

b)      Whoever does not receive the kingdom of God like a child shall not enter it:

i)       ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ = ζωὴ αἰώνιος (following pericope; 10:17)

ii)     Receive the kingdom:

(1)   Become a disciple

(2)   Willingly embrace the radical values of the kingdom that Jesus is trying to inculcate.

iii)   Like a child ὡς παιδίον:

(1)   *παιδίον NNS: Receiving the kingdom like a child receives it = to recognize ones utter dependence on God, to receive it as one who has no claims to it (Edwards) and without questioning, to trust God and receive the kingdom (Best, Disciples, 9496).

(2)   παιδίον ANS: Receive kingdom as one receives a child. Idea is to receive the kingdom as Jesus welcomes the child.

c)      Receive enter: One receives the kingdom now but enters into the kingdom in the future.

3.5.3        Rich young ruler: Affluence (10:1727) [254]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Soteriological: What must I do to inherit eternal life?

i)       True discipleship will result in eternal life. Discipleship is not what one does after one becomes a believer; a disciple is a believer.

b)      Discipleship:

i)       Nature: true discipleship demands self-denial, a radical orientation of ones life, priorities, and values. Placing anything ahead of Jesus will result in eternal loss; following Jesus will result in reward and blessing not only in the future, but also in the present.

ii)     Wealth: Critique of conventional human values. In Jewish society, wealth Gods blessings.

(1)   This is the major discussion in Mark on possession. Luke has a more developed theology of possession.

(2)   Wealth is a potential barrier to the kingdom of God (10:22).

(3)   Application: Is this the call to renunciation specific for that man alone or should it be generalized?

(a)   Those who left everything to follow Jesus (10:28) appeared to have kept the use of some possession: Peters house in Capernaum (1:28); boat and tackle (John 21:3); Levis party (2:15).

(b)   From Jesus sayings in other places, this does not appear to be a general statement (Luke 8:13; 19:110; Acts 5:34; 28:3031). It is best understood as a particular teaching, directed to this particular situation, indicating for the rich man what repentance (1:15) would entail for him (Stein).

(c)   Issues: Wealth is relative

(d)   Conclusion: Wealth is a form of Gods blessing, but it is also a source of temptation. Nature and degree of renunciation of wealth needs to be worked out individually and according to ones culture, but we cannot lose sight that wealth is a potential impediment to Gods work.

iii)   Connection with the previous section:

(1)   Status: child (low status) enters the kingdom and the rich young ruler (high status) cannot.

(2)   Faith: Contrasts between the child who accepts Gods kingdom in humility and simple faith, and one who trusts in his own riches or who is enslaved to wealth.

c)      Disciples incomprehension:

i)       Leads to a pronouncement on the fundamental different perspective between humans and God.

2)      Jesus and the Law (See Law in DJG)

a)      Does Jesus view obedience to the Law as a means of salvation?

i)       Yes.

(1)   Jesus believed that true keeping of the law in the way that God intended would result in eternal life. See also the // in Luke 10:2528. Loving God with all of ones heart, mind, and soul, involves trusting upon Gods grace. It involves trusting in the sacrificial death of Jesus (10:45), even as OT believers trusted in Gods grace provided during the Day of Atonement (Stein).

(2)   Salvation involves keeping the OT law. The disjuncture between the law and grace present in Romans and Galatians is not found here. Truly keeping the commandments does not result in merit for salvation is ultimately a gift of Gods grace (10:27) (Stein).

(3)   But we still have to ask whether Jesus considered it possible that one can fulfill it adequately to achieve that end. Jesus own understanding of the implications of these OT commands must also be found in Matt 5:2128. The narrative notes that even after the young man has fulfilled all the requirements of the law, he is still short of entering the kingdom of God.

ii)     *Jesus did not address the issue whether the law is possible as a means of salvation.

(1)   Rather, he was citing the OT command to initiate a discussion with the young man. The climax of the narrative is follow me.

(2)   Whatever the role of the law, the nexus of righteousness is no longer Torah, but rather Jesus. Not only does Jesus do what Yahweh does, but also his words are the authoritative revelation of Gods will, and obeying them is now the path to eternal life of Israels long-awaited eschatological redemption. Following Jesus, not obedience to the Law, is now the door to the kingdom of God (CNTUOT).

3)      Resources:

a)      Blomberg, Neither Poverty nor Riches.

 

1)      Event (10:1722)

a)      Setting out on his journey (εἰς ὁδόν): Markan // to Lukes journey narrative, depicting the road to Jerusalem and the cross.

b)      Man is not introduced. Matt (young); Luke (ruler).

c)      Potential disciple seeking out a rabbi (different model than Jesus calling his disciples).

d)      From my youth: From 12 years old, when a child enters manhood and is responsible for his actions (Osborne).

e)      Why do you call me good?:

i)       *Jesus is pointing to the source of goodness (i.e. God), or making a comparison to the goodness of God, rather than making an ontological statement.

(1)   Jesus objects that the sense of perfect can be applied to any human being. Jesus is getting the person to focus attention on Gods goodness, without implying that he is not good, since there is no one that is ultimately good except God.

ii)     Matts rephrasing Why do you ask me about what is good?: Deflects the suggestion that Jesus is asserting that he is not good. In a culture that emphasizes good works as central to righteousness, Matt still captures the point of the young mans question.

f)       All these things I have kept:

i)       This person is the archetype of Jewish righteousness; he has kept the Torah faithfully

(1)   Jesus nowhere questions his Torah observance (for the possibility of such observance, see Phil 3:6; b. Yoma 38b; b. abb. 55a; Gen. Rab. 22:6) (CNTUOT).

(2)   His subsequent abundant blessing as seen in his wealth.

(3)   Jesus love for him.

g)      You lack one thing; go, sell what you have, and give to the poor, and you will have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me.

i)       In light of the inaugurated kingdom, everything about Torah observance is realigned. In order to gain eternal life, (CNTUOT)

(1)   all his wealth, which was both a reward and a sign of his righteousness, must be relinquished to the poor

(2)   his obedience must now center not on Torah, but on the person and teaching of Jesus, who embodies that Torah (Mark 3:16; 9:7; cf. 10:2830), and who binds Israel to Yahweh.

(3)   So here, Jesus upholds the Torah, only to place his person and authority above it.

ii)     True emphasis is not just on renunciation of possessions, but a total change in his lifestylecommitted followers of Christ. Note Marks favorite discipleship term: ἀκολούθει (10:21). Mark emphasizes the renunciation of all earthly relationships and a radical commitment to follow Christ.

iii)   The word order of follow me after treasure in heaven suggests that discipleship is a reward in the kingdom and not merely one of the requirements. It is also Gods gifts and not mans response alone (Osborne).

h)      He went away sorrowful; for he had great possession: Sin of idolatry. He placed riches before God.

2)      Teaching (10:2331)

a)      How hard it will be for those who have riches: Possessions are not an advantage but is an obstacle to entering the kingdom of God.

i)       Wealth breeds self-sufficiency and hinders us from trusting in God.

ii)     Jesus comment about the rich man is not a challenge to enter into some deeper level of commitment or spirituality. Rather, it describes the fundamental requirements about being a believerentering the kingdom of God.

b)      TC: How hard it is [for those who trust in riches] to enter the kingdom (10:24): Echoes 10:23. The addition of trust in the textual variant points to the issuewealth engenders self-reliance and trust in money rather than in God.

c)      Eye of a needle:

i)       Proverbial and hyperbolic way of saying something is impossible. Camel = largest animal in Palestine; eye of a needle = smallest hole possible.

ii)     This stringent tone was modified to make it remotely possible by preachers: Eye of needle = small gate within the larger double gate of the city wall. Thus, the only way for a camel to go through the gate is when it strips off its load, so a rich man should do the same. But no shred of evidence for this idea.

d)      Exceedingly astonished: In their culture, wealth was a symbol of Gods blessing (e.g. Job 1:10; 42:10; Ps 128:18; Isa 3:10), and gives them greater ability to do good works. So if the rich cant be saved, who can?

i)       Failure of disciples to understand. They still see things from an earthly, rather than a heavenly, perspective.

e)      With men it is impossible: Overall, salvation is Gods gift and prerogative.

i)       What is the gift that God provides? 2 views: *Salvation is Gods gift, Gods prerogative; one cannot earn salvation; // to Pauline justification by faith || Prevenient grace is Gods gift; one cannot respond to Gods invitation of salvation.

ii)     Sums up emphasis on discipleship so far: to turn away from self-reliance to an utter dependence on God, who alone is sufficient (Osborne).

3.5.4        Losses and Gains (10:2831) [255]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christology:

i)       Ones eternal destiny is dependent on ones relationship to Jesusfor my sake and for the gospel (10:29). Thus, Jesus can make the claim that ones relationship to him takes precedence over familial relationships.

 

1)      Peters question (10:28)

a)      Matt makes explicit whats implicit in Mark We have left all whats in it for us?

i)       The question sounds self-centered and pragmatic, but Jesus graciously answers the question that all of us would also want answered.

ii)     We have left all: The home of Peter and Andrew was still available to them; the boat of 3:9; 4:1, 36 may have belonged to Peter or to one of the other fishermen-disciples. Probably not a disposal of all possessions and relationships, but a setting aside of them for the duration of their ministry (France).

2)      Jesus response (10:2931)

a)      God will repay (10:2930)

i)       Not a commendation of poverty for its own sake, but the renunciation of family ties and possessions as a result of discipleshipfor my sake and for the gospel.

ii)     This age 100x

(1)   New family reflects 3:31-35, the new community of the kingdom.

(2)   With persecutions: blessings will be mixed with trials.

(a)   Although this can be read as a Markan redaction to comfort his readers in the midst of a Neronian persecution, its probable that it goes back to Jesus as warnings were part of Jesus message (8:3438; 10:3839; 13:913).

(3)   Its doubtful whether the blessings are material. In light of this pericope, it probably implies that God would provide spiritual blessings for material sacrifice (Osborne).

(4)   App: Do we experience this? Is there joy in ministry? Do we say How good it is to serve the Lord?

iii)   Age to come

(1)   Eternal life: Inclusion with 10:17. Jesus returns to the question of the rich young ruler. Eternal life can only be obtained through discipleship.

b)      Reversal of roles (10:31)

i)       Emphasis is more on discipleship rather than on riches, and Jesus here overturns the values of the world. Those who follow Jesus and make themselves last in worldly terms will ultimately be first.

3.6         Following Jesus in the Way of the Cross (10:3245) [26263]

3.6.1        3rd Passion Prediction (10:3234) [262]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Death of Jesus is part of the sovereign plan of God. This is especially necessary in a Gentile context where crucifixion was connected with shame.

b)      Christological:

i)       Jesus possesses a clear precise knowledge of the future.

ii)     Obedience of the Son, emphasized by amazement of the disciples.

 

1)      Setting (10:32)

a)      Use of ὁδός resumes the journey motif. First mention of the destination, going up to Jerusalem.

b)      They were amazed: Probably at the resoluteness of Jesus intent to go to Jerusalem as he walks ahead of them, given all that was foretold.

i)       The reason for the fear of the followers is evident when we remember the earlier trips to Jerusalem reported in FG.

ii)     The use of προάγω also points to its use in 14:28; 16:7 where it speaks of Jesus going before the disciples to Galilee after his resurrection.

2)      Prophecy (10:3334)

a)      He began to tell them what was to happen to him (τὰ μέλλοντα αὐτῷ συμβαίνειν): similar to δεῖ, indicating a future certainty.

b)      More detailed than the 1st 2, providing an outline of the 6 stages of the passion: delivered to the chief priest and scribes; condemned to death; delivered to the Gentiles; mocked, spat, scourged; killed; resurrected.

i)       Language of mocked, spat upon, and beaten recalls Isa 50:6. Presents Jesus as the Isaianic servant.

c)      Remarkably follows what occurred in Mark 15:1520. Such prophecy is viable for an omnipotent God.

3.6.2        The Sons of Zebedee: Greatness in Service (10:3545) [263]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Failure of the disciples:

i)       They could not accept the notion of a suffering Messiah, and they are filled with self-ambition.

b)      Discipleship

i)       Disciples are to share in self-sacrifice.

ii)     Greatness in the kingdom is not lording over others but serving others.

 

1)      Ambitious request (10:3537)

a)      All that they heard and picked up about Jesus Passion prediction was the glorious Son of Man (Dan 7:14) inaugurating the eschatological age (8:37).

b)      In this journey to Jerusalem, they see themselves as Princes following King Jesus as he approaches the royal city. Their understanding of Jesus as king is noted by the use of δόξα (10:37). Like Peter, they are correct about Jesus as the Messiah, but they are wrong regarding his messianic taskthat suffering precedes glory.

c)      Matt 20:20 has the Mother making a request for her sons; but Jesus responds to the 2 disciples. Mark probably eliminated the intermediary of the message because the conversation ultimately is between Jesus and the 2 disciples.

i)       From the various gospel accounts of the women at the cross; Salome = Mother of James and John, the sons of Zebedee = Marys sister. See notes on John.docx

(1)   John, the beloved disciple, is the cousin of Jesus; Johns mother, Jesus aunt, is now making the request.

2)      Jesus reply (10:3840)

a)      You dont know what you are asking: Amplifies incomprehension of the disciples.

b)      Cup: Metaphor of suffering, esp. of wrath from God.

i)       Some OT prophets use the picture of a drink that makes the recipient totally intoxicated (an undesirable condition) a poison that kills.

ii)     Judgment, punishment of the wicked (Ps 75:8; Jer 25:1529; 49:12; Ezek 23:3134; Hab 2:16) || suffering of Gods people (Isa 51:1723).

iii)   Suffering. cf. Mark 14:36 Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.

c)      Baptism: metaphor of submersion is used to denote a calamity in ones life (Ps 42:7; Job 22:11) or divine judgment (Osborne).

d)      Applied to James and John (10:3940)

i)       Shaliach motif: solidarity of the one who is sent with the sender.

ii)     Their request cannot be granted even if they fulfilled these conditions cup and baptism are not true conditions but is just a way to show that their understanding of δόξα and the means to achieve it is wrong. Glory cannot even be earned by utmost suffering; it is Gods prerogative to give to those for whom it has been prepared.

3)      Further indignation and teaching (10:41-45)

a)      10 were indignant: Since Jesus instruction is to them (supposedly the 12), the indignation of the 10 is not annoyance at the ambition of James and John, but that they got in first and tried to get an unfair advantage in securing high positions (France).

b)      Reference to Gentile rulers is because absolute power was maintained in their hands rather than in the Jewish leaders.

c)      Those who are supposed to rule: Does not question the reality of their rule; rather, it means those who are reputed to rule (BDAG 2aβ), i.e. those whose rule are publicly acknowledged.

d)      It shall not be so among you: The values within the kingdom of God are reversed from the world. Secular leadership teaches us that rulers should be good and fair, but Jesus understanding of leadership is more radical, and remarks that it is to be characterized by service.

i)       Model (καὶ γάρ) of status reversal is the Son of Man. He whose destiny was to be served διακονηθῆναι (Dan 7:14 LXX καὶ ἐδόθη αὐτῷ ἐξουσία, καὶ πάντα τὰ ἔθνη τῆς γῆς κατὰ γένη καὶ πᾶσα δόξα αὐτῷ λατρεύουσα; Thdt καὶ πάντες οἱ λαοί, φυλαί, γλῶσσαι αὐτῷ δουλεύσουσιν) will now serve διακονῆσαι.

ii)     Servant leadership does not one does not have authority since Jesus said All authority in heaven and on earth has been given me (Matt 28:18). Rather, it means that one uses ones position for the good of others.

e)      Ransom for many λύτρον ἀντὶ πολλῶν:

i)       ἀντί: *instead of (i.e. as a substitute for) substitutionary atonement || for the sake of Jesus death brings about the ransom for many but does not describe how that ransom is accomplished.

ii)     λύτρον: usually a payment to secure release.

iii)   Concluding example to the discussion in 10:42-44.

iv)   OT context (Isa 53:1012), make his life an offering for sin

(1)   See discussion in CNTUOT.

(2)   How is the servant an offering (ʾāām אָשָׁם)?

(a)   Offering was used in ritual purification of the leper, reintegrating him into the community from which he had been exiled.

(b)   Offering was also used in violation of Yahwehs holiness by breaking oath or in idolatry. In these cases, the individual had to bring an ʾāām and express remorse.

(3)   In Isa 52, Yahweh declared that Israel will not be redeemed with money, but he would bare his arm and bring about an unprecedented act of mercy. Here, Yahweh accepts the suffering servants offering for Israels sins.

4)      Application

a)      Disciples are not called to imitate his ransom for many but the spirit of service and self-sacrifice (France).

b)      Pattern for Christian leaders is commonly understood to be a CEO of a corporation. Here, Jesus presents the model of a servant leader.

5)      Authenticity of 10:45. Heavily debated in critical circles. See Stein.

3.7         2nd healing of a blind man (10:4652) [264]

1)      Emphasis:

a)      Discipleship

i)       Necessity of persevering faith and the resultant opening of blind eyes.

(1)   Contrasts with the rich your ruler. The blind beggar is on the opposite spectrum of the social scale. But he is the one who will follow Jesus ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ with his sight restored while the rich ruler goes away blind (France). Bartimaeus discards his cloak, his supposedly lone possession, but the Rich Young Ruler is not able to discard his riches.

ii)     The 2 healings of the blind man frame Act 2 (8:2210:52), which is the main discipleship section, and these 2 incidents symbolically show the blindness of the disciples (6:52; 8:1718, 21).

iii)   Contains elements of a call story, esp. the prominent note that he followed Jesus in the way. Thus, this story serves as a conclusion to 8:2210:52, the requirements of discipleship.

(1)   Emphasized by ἀκολουθέω and ἡ ὁδός.

(a)   Possibly also seen in the 3x use of φωνέω (8:49) and in Bartimaeus discarding of his cloak, his only possession (8:50). But note that it is προσκαλέω in the call of the 12 (3:13)

b)      Christological:

i)       Healing shows Jesus authority.

(1)   Heightened by the fact that it is brought about by Jesus word alone and that it is immediate.

ii)     Presence of great crowds shows Jesus popularity.

iii)   His identity as the Son of David, the promised royal Messiah (cf. Ps. Sol. 17:21). The one who came not to be served but to serve and give his life as a ransom for many, including Bartimaeus.

(1)   Connects with Jesus entrance into Jerusalem as Israels Messiah since the title that Bartimaeus uses, Son of David, ties in easily with the kingdom of our Father David (11:10).

(2)   Prepares reader also for his messianic judgment on the cultic practice of the temple and the exercise of his messianic authority in 11:2712:44.

(3)   Although Mark understands Jesus as the Son of David, Marks Christology also argues that this understanding is inadequate. Jesus is this and much more.

 

1)      Bridge passage: From journey phase into Jerusalem phase. Here, we have Jericho, the last town before the traveler reaches the surrounding area of Jerusalem.

2)      Just as Jesus teaching on ritual purity (7:123) is illustrated by his ministry to the unclean (7:248:10), here Jesus teaching on the reversal of earthly values within the kingdom (children, rich young ruler, greatness in the kingdom) is illustrated by this little one who is the least likely disciple according to worldly standards. Bartimaeus then becomes a paradigm of discipleship. Disciples are to see as Bartimaeus does, and to follow on the way.

3)      Marks last healing story. He is the only patient that is named; the others were simply cases. His naming (and that of his father) they were well known in the disciples group (France).

4)      Jesus lineage: Some argue that by the time of Jesus, it was no longer possible to trace ones lineage back to David. But this is probably not correct. Josephus was able to produce his genealogy, Paul notes that hes a descendant of Benjamin, pre-Pauline tradition notes that Jesus lineage goes back to David (Rom 1:3).

 

1)      Setting (10:46)

a)      Mark: Leaving Jericho

b)      Matt: Leaving Jericho, 2 blind men.

c)      Luke: Drawing near to Jericho

d)      Resolution: None is certain.

i)       There were 2 Jerichos. The original city is 17 miles NE of Jerusalem and had deteriorated over the centuries. The city in Jesus time was enlarged by Herod the Great and was 6 miles NT from where Jordan enters the Dead Sea (Edwards).

(1)   Jesus could be leaving (Matt-Mark) the old and entering (Luke) the new (Morris). But its not clear that the old Jericho was inhabited during this time.

ii)     Calvin: On his way into the city, Jesus did not respond to the petitions. However, he healed them on his way out.

iii)   Osborne: It was in the process of going in and going out that Jesus healed.

iv)   Blomberg:[35] Probably Luke was abbreviating Mark, leaving out Marks reference to the departure from Jericho (but including Marks reference to Jesus entering Jericho), and then Matt-Mark-Luke all describe Jesus healing Bartimaeus on the way out.

(1)   Luke 19:1(he entered Jericho and was passing through) seems to refute Blombergs hypothesis. However, Blomberg suggests that Luke 19:1(Καὶ εἰσελθὼν διήρχετο τὴν Ἰεριχώ) need not be consequent after 18:43. Rather Luke seems to have relocated this passage topically so that it can form the middle of a climactic sequence of 3 passages about Jesus upending traditional Jewish expectation (healing the blind [who were often thought to be sinful and thus punished by their incapacity], fraternizing with a tax collector [who had betrayed his nation in the eyes of the Pharisees by working for Rome] and telling a parable about the destruction of a noblemans servants and enemies who clearly stood for the Jewish leaders.

v)      Literary: Marshall and Bock. Luke places the story before Jericho to accommodate the following story of Zaccheus which he wants to place as a climax. But this breaks inerrancy, and would not be different from Gundrys midrash.

vi)   Harmonization

2)      Persistent faith (10:4748): One of the little people.

a)      Son of David: Found only here in Mark (apart from Jesus in 12:3537). Messianic. As Jesus approaches Jerusalem, public begins to perceive the messianic aspect of his ministry, and the messianic language is proclaimed on everybodys lips in the next pericope (Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David; 11:10).

b)      Many rebuked him: Crowds are like the disciples rebuking those with no status. Moreover, it highlights the persistent faith of Bartimaeus.

3)      Jesus initiative and healing (10:4952)

a)      Jesus initiative to care for the insignificant stands in contrast to the disciples and the crowds.

b)      What do you want?: Intended to draw out the faith, as noted in Your faith has made you well (10:52).

c)      Rabboni: My rabbi. Only disciples call Jesus Rabbi in Mark (9:5; 11:21; 14:45), perhaps elevating Bartimaeus status here.

d)      Followed (ἠκολούθει) him on the way (ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ): Presence of ἀκολουθέω and ὁδός indicates discipleship (Stein, France, Evans; contra Kingsbury).

4           Act 3: Jerusalem (11:116:8)

1)      Structure

a)      Arranged by events

i)       Public confrontation (Mark 1112)

ii)     Olivet discourse (Mark 13)

iii)   Passion narrative and resurrection account (Mark 1416).

b)      Arranged in 7 days (Narrative time slows down).

i)       Day 1 Sun (10:4611:1)

ii)     Day 2 Mon (11:1219)

iii)   Day 3 Tue (11:2026)

iv)   Day 4 Wed (11:2713:37)

v)      Day 5 Thu (14:116)

vi)   Day 6 Fri (14:1715:41)

vii) Day 7 Sat (15:4247)

viii)           Day 8 Sun (16:18)

ix)   Caveat:

(1)   Its possible that some of this material such as the controversy stories and the eschatological teachings are grouped topically together (Stein).

(2)   Its possible that these events recorded here took place over as long as several months. This, however, cannot be proven. But there are hints: (Edwards)

(a)   The description of Jesus entry into Jerusalem seems to fall more in line with the Feast of Tabernacles (waying branches of palm, willow, myrtle, or citrus, and shouting Hosanna [m. Suk. 3.39]) than with the Passover.

(b)   Every day I was with you, teaching in the temple courts (14:49) suggests a longer time.

(c)   FG presents a more reasonable time frame of Jesus passion. In FG, Jesus was in Jerusalem for the Feast of Dedication (which occurred in mid-Dec), after which he retired across the Jordan into Perea (10:40; 11;54). Thus, FG places Jesus in Judea and Jerusalem at least 4 months or longer before his crucifixion.

(3)   Possible reasons for Mark to put it into the sequence of a week (Edwards)

(a)   A 1 week passion narrative served catechetical and liturgical purposes by putting the passino narrative into a block of material that could be read and celebrated during Easter Week.

(b)   More importantly, the material in the passion narrative is oriented around the focal point of the temple, and has been gathered and presented in order to show that Jesus supersedes the temple as the locus Dei. All the materials in Mark 11-13 is either set in the temple or directly related to it. Like the prophets, Jesus pronounces judgment on Zion. Jesus is not a reformer of the temple, for neither his teachings nor ministry institutes a program of change and improvement. He is rather the fulfillment and replacement, for his death on the crossand not the templeis the perfect atonement for sin. At Golgotha, the temple curtain is torn asunder and Jesus is confessed as the Son of God the object of saving faith.

4.1         Throwing down the gauntlet (11:125) [269, 27175]

1)      Jesus makes sure that his arrival into Jerusalem is noticed by 2 events: royal procession outside the city walls and the demonstration in the temple. Both actions show Jesus unique authority and antagonize the Jewish authorities further. With these 2 events introducing the final act, Mark signals that this act is the final decisive confrontation. France therefore considers these 2 events as Jesus public acts which directly challenge the authority of the religious authorities. In essence, Jesus throws down the gauntlet and forces them to respond.

4.1.1        Triumphal Entry: Royal Procession (11:111) [269, 271]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christological

i)       Jesus is the Son of David who comes to bring the messianic kingdom of David. The act that Jesus performs has messianic overtones. Yet, Marks readers will know that the messianic kingdom that Jesus brings is different from the expectations of most of the Jewish people (Ps. Sol. 1718).

ii)     Significance:

(1)   Nowhere do we hear of Jesus riding an animal.

(2)   He did not ride an animal because he was tired; having walked from Jericho to this point, the remaining journey is less than 2 miles and all downhill. Moreover, pilgrims do not ride into Jerusalem, they walked. The special nature of the cold (unridden), emphasize its unique function. Jesus intends to enter into Jerusalem as the King of Israel.

2)      Issue

a)      Triumphal entry?

i)       No (Edwards, Stein)

(1)   This passage is traditionally called a triumphal entry. Its appropriate for Matt, John, and Luke. Matt records that the whole city was stirred (21:10); Luke reports that the city was so electrified that the stones were ready to cry out (19:40). Marks account is noteworthy for what does not happen. Like the seed in the parable that receives the word with joy but lasts only for a short time, the crowd disperses mysteriously as it has gathered. The most expressed messianic symbol in Jesus entrythe riding of a colt in allusion to the humble Messiah of Zech 9:9is either short lived in the minds of the crowd or missed altogether. Jesus enters the temple alone, and having sized it up, leaves for Bethany. This is the first of Marks clues that the temple is not the habitation of Gods Son. Jesus is indeed the Messiah, but he is veiled and organized. Even when he stands at the center of Israels faith, he stands alone.

(2)   The whole scene comes to nothing (see esp. 11:11 where Jesus goes into the temple and looks around). Note that 11:11 has no parallel in Matt and Luke.

ii)     *Yes (France?, Lau)

(1)   Historically, the other gospel accounts appear to present it as a triumphal entry where the crowds understood and welcomed Jesus as the Messiah.

(2)   Jesus came in such a way that he could be construed as a royal, though not as a military challenger to the elite or to Rome.

(a)   Matt 21:9 Hosanna to the Son of David

(b)   Luke 19:38 Blessed is the king who comes in the name of the Lord.

3)      What happened

a)      Jesus intentionally arranged for a colt as a conscious messianic act in fulfillment of Zech 9:9.

b)      Mark understands the event to be a messianic act. Whatever the original crowds understanding of the acclamation Hosanna! Blessed is the one coming in the name of the Lord! Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David! Mark wants his readers to interpret this as addressed to Jesus, the Son of David. (Stein)

c)      Did the crowds and disciples understand it messianically?

i)       No (Stein)

(1)   Reasons:

(a)   Lack of any Roman opposition and of any mention of this event (although there was questions about his messiahship) at Jesus trial (14:5515:5) indicates this.

(b)   John states that the disciples did not understand what was taking place until after the resurrection (12:16).

(2)   The crowds welcomed Jesus as a famous religious figure without understanding it to be an overt messianic act. The lack of any Roman opposition or mention in the trial suggests this. Even FG which has Jesus addressed as the King of Israel (12:13; which may be an interpretive gloss by John) notes that the disciples did not understand what was taking place until later (Stein)

(3)   For Mark, the event was therefore messianic, yet hidden from people. The authorities and crowds saw it as a warm welcome of a famous religious leader. It was only later that the messianic significance was understood (Stein)

(4)   The messianic significance was later emphasized in Matt and John.

ii)     Yes (France)

(1)   Reasons:

(a)   Shouts of the coming kingdom of David (11:10).

(b)   Jesus action places the Galilean preacher firmly in contention for the title King of the Jews and that title will be at the center of his Roman trial. For the Jewish leaders, it would not have the same connotation as for the Roman governor, and Son of David had an honored place in their messianic ideology.

 

1)      Who are the crowds?

a)      They drew near to Jerusalem: Location is still outside Jerusalem.

b)      The ones who went before and the ones who followed: Most probably these are the pilgrims who are accompanying him and his disciples to the festival. They are probably Jesus Galilean supporters welcoming the arrival of the Galilean Messiah rather than the skeptical Jerusalemites (France).

i)       Matt 21:1011 makes this explicit, When Jesus entered Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred and asked, Who is this? The crowds answered, This is Jesus, the prophet from Nazareth in Galilee.

ii)     invalidates typical understanding of a fickle crowd which would shout Hosanna one day and Crucify him a few days later.

 

1)      Day: Sunday

2)      Setting and preparation (11:17)

a)      Mt. of Olives.

i)       Unnecessary mention, possibly because of its messianic significance (Zech 14:4; Ezek 43:29[36]). Mt. of Olives is the place of Gods final revelation and judgment, and associated with the coming of the Messiah (Ezek 11:23; 43:15).

ii)     The rabbis and Josephus (Ant. 20.169) associated it with the coming of the Messiah.

b)      Instructions indicate that Jesus probably knew the owner. This is possible if read in light of John where Jesus has made multiple trips to Jerusalem. This incident may then be a deliberately organized act which enhances the symbolism of his actions, and Jesus intended to view it as a fulfillment of Zech 9:9.

c)      The Lord needs it: Password to finish the transaction. Lord here probably refers to God. The password asserts that the donkey is for Gods service and is a bold statement by Jesus himself regarding the significance of his arrival (France).

d)      Riding on a colt

i)       Some evidence that pilgrims were to walk to Jerusalem if they were able. His riding on a colt would then surely be noticed.

ii)     Messianic overtones.

(1)   Return of the king

(2)   Zech 9:910 Rejoice greatly, O daughter Zion! Shout aloud, O daughter Jerusalem! Lo, your king comes to you; triumphant and victorious is he, humble and riding on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.

(a)   Colt on which no one has ever sat: alludes to the πῶλον νέον in Zech 9:9.

(b)   An unbroken beast of burden was regarded as sacred (Num 19:2; Deut 21:3), making it appropriate for a king, since according to the Mishnah (m. Sanh. 2.5), no one else may ride a kings horse.

(3)   Gen 49:1011 He ties his foal (πῶλον) to the vine.

(a)   You will find a colt tied

(4)   Moreover, this comes straight after Bartimaeus unchecked use of Son of David.

(5)   Commandering of a beast of burden was the perogative of a king in ancient times.

iii)   Donkey

(1)   not a horse (or in a chariot, as a Roman celebrating a triumph would)

(a)   Jesus invokes the prophetic imagery of a king coming in peace rather than as a victorious warlord.

(i)     Some suggest that Jesus did indeed come as a victorious warlord who has conquered death by raising Lazarus and will again do so decisively with his own death and resurrection.

(2)   not a mule (ἡμίονος; that recalls the narrative about the succession of Solomon to the throne of David; 1 Kgs1:33)

(3)   2x function: royal messianic theme coupled with humility, thus emphasizing the servant leadership of 10:4145.

(a)   evokes the royal tradition of Gen 49:11 that is open to messianic reading

(b)   humility of the triumphant king (Zech 9:910)

(i)     By using a donkey, Jesus expresses his willingness to become the king of Israel but in more humble terms than the prevailing nationalism of that day.

(4)   Does not suggest lowliness and meekness, but was a vehicle fit for a king (Zech 9:9). Matt 21:5 describes Jesus coming humbly as a king, but that is due to his character and not because he is riding on a donkey.

(a)   I dont agree with this. The donkey is clearly a vehicle fit for a king, but it also indicates humility.

iv)   For discussion of Zech 9:910, see notes in John.docx

3)      Entry (11:810)

a)      Spread their garments: symbolic of a royal reception, similar to the reception of Jehu in 2 Kgs 9:13.

b)      Laying of branches.

i)       Branches are specified to be palm branches only in John.

(1)   They were a national (perhaps nationalistic) symbol. When Simon the Maccabee drove the Syrian forces out, he was feted with music and the waving of palm branches (1 Macc 13:51). Apocalyptic visions of the end utilize palm branches (Testament of Napthali 5). Palms appear on the coins struck by the insurgents during the Jewish wars against Rome.

(2)   These palm branches could have signified nationalist hope that a messianic liberator was arriving on the scene.

(3)   Palm branches were commonly used to celebrate victory. Presents Jesus as one who has conquered his enemies.

c)      Hosanna! Blessed is the one who comes in the name of the Lord :

i)       Refers not to the Messiah but to pilgrims entering the temple sanctuary, meaning that the pilgrim is blessed in Gods name (Edwards).

ii)     Ps 118:2526

(1)   Again highlight Jesus entrance into Jersualem as the arrival of the Davidic deliverer

(2)   Ps 118 is a royal song of thanksgiving for military victory that was later incorporated into a processional liturgy. Psalm celebrates the kings vice-regency within the context of Yahwehs ultimately kingly reign.

(3)   OT context

(a)   Recall how he was threatened on all sides and employing the exodus imagery of Yahwehs mighty right hand, the king rejoices in the Lords intervention on his behalf (118:1418)

(b)   Surrounded by glad victory songs from the righteous (118:1516), he approaches the temple and requests entrance from the gatekeepers (118:19) who readily admit him (118:20).

(c)   Inside the temple, his thanksgiving (118:21) is joined by the congregation (118:2225) with the change from 1S to 1P.

(i)     118:22 with its reference to the stone that the builders rejected [that] has become the cornerstone is alluded to repeatedly in the NT.

(ii)  The king is the Davidic representative, and Davids rule is seen as revived in the person of the actual king. Thus, the day of the Lord (118:24) is the day of Gods deliverance and exaltation of the Davidic king from the builders who rejected him.

(d)   Priests blessing

(i)     The priests respond by blessing the king who comes in the Lords name (118:26)

1.      The phrase he who comes became a messianic designation (cf. Matt 11:3; Luke 19:38).

(ii)  The priests blessing on the festive congregation.

(e)   If Ps 2 celebrates the promise given to the Davidic king in the face of the threatening nations, then Ps 118 is its realization.

(4)   Judaism

(a)   Ps 118 was sung during Passover, which reflects the exodus.

(i)     Some, such as Wright, say that the psalm took on eschatological significance in the postexilic period as people anticipated a new exodus at which Yahweh would deliver his people through his Messiah.

(b)   Ps 118 with its focus on the temple became a communal anticipation of Israels eschatological redemption under a royal Davidide.

(c)   Ps 118 was well known in Second Temple Judaism because of its association with the Feast of Tabernacles, and as the final psalm of the Hallel sung annually at the Passover.

(d)   Later rabbinic commentary interpreted this psalm messianically

(e)   Hosanna: Comes from the Save us now in Ps 118:25, but changes into a cultic shout of praise. An example today would be the statement Praise the Lord which is not understood to be a command, but a statement of thanksgiving.

(5)   Mark

(a)   Jesus exorcism and healings testify to the victorious inauguration of Isaiahs new exodus.

(b)   Ps 118 is applicable to the victorious Davidic messianic Son of God who comes in joyful procession to the temple.

(c)   Irony:

(i)     Unlike Ps 118, Jerusalems response is divided. The temple authorities and the Jerusalem leadership do not welcome Jesus, nor does any blessing come from the house of the Lord (cf. Ps 118:26b). Jesus is Israels unwelcome messianic king.

(ii)  Nevertheless, in keeping with Ps 118, Jesus enters the temple, surveys it in preparation for his action the new day

(6)   John

(a)   Textual matter: [καὶ] ὁ βασιλεὺς τοῦ Ἰσραήλ

(i)     This phrase may be an interpretive gloss by the evangelist (epexegetical καί) defining the one who comes in the name of the Lord.

(ii)  Emphasis is in line with Johns emphasis on Jesus royalty.

(b)   In the narrative, Jesus signs prove that he is the Messiah and Son of God. It is he who now enters the holy city in messianic fashion as the paradigmatic Sent One of God.

d)      Blessed is the kingdom of our father David that is coming:

i)       Lacks any clear Jewish parallel.

ii)     This reference to the coming kingdom is certainly eschatological, but it is not necessarily messianic as son of David.

iii)   The summary effect of the quotation in vv. 910 is thus not overtly messianic. Indeed, had the crowd intended the acclamations of vv. 910 to refer to a specific messianic fulfillment in Jesus we should be surprised that Jesus was not promptly arrested by Roman authorities (see Acts 5:37; 21:38), or that charges to that effect were not raised at his trial (14:5558). There are of course subtle messianic undertones in Jesus riding a colt into Jerusalem as the gentle and peaceable Messiah of Zechariah 9, but it is doubtful whether the crowd or authorities grasped their full significance. Like that of countless other Passover pilgrims to Jerusalem, Jesus entry was apparently regarded by the masses as a pilgrimage rather than as a messianic triumph. (Edwards)

4)      First visit to the temple (11:11) [271]

a)      Day: Sunday

b)      Some think that this is a pointless note. But it gives Jesus the opportunity to check out the scene and to plan the next days action. Thus, what happens on the next day (Monday) is not a spontaneous act but a planned public demonstration to highlight the arrival of the kingdom of God.

c)      Anti-climatic visit to the temple and ending of the day supports the suggestion that Jesus entry into Jerusalem was not understood to be messianic by the people (Stein).

i)       Edwards: Marks account

d)      The ἱερόν was the whole complex of building and courtyards that covered the temple mount. It is not the ναός or sacred building that contained the Holy of Holies. Note that ἱερόν is not used metaphorically; but ναός is used of the body of Christ (John 2:21) and believers (1 Cor 3:1617; 2 Cor 6:16; Eph 2:21). The location where the traders set up their stalls would be the huge outer court, or the Court of the Gentiles.

e)      Returns to Bethany probably because there were not enough accommodations in Jerusalem because of the crowds.

4.1.2        The barren temple and the withered tree (11:1225) [27275]

1)      Narrative sequence (France)

a)      First visit to the temple (11:11)

i)       Cursing of the fig tree (11:1214)

b)      Jesus takes action in the temple (11:1519)

i)       The fig tree is found to be dead (11:2025)

c)      Jesus returns to the temple (11:27)

2)      Intercalation

a)      The fig tree is a parabolic act serving as an interpretive commentary on the temple: while it seemed healthy, it was fruitless.

3)      Matthew

a)      Cleansing of the temple (21:1217)

b)      Cursing of the fig tree (21:1822)

 

1)      Temple incident

a)      Heart of religious and national identity. The rededication of the temple was the high point of Macabbean victory.

b)      One factor which united his enemies against Jesus and led to his death was his perceived opposition towards the temple.

 

1)      Emphasis

a)      Divine judgment upon the aristocratic priesthood (Evans)

i)       Judgment is not upon the people or the lower-ranking priests. The cursing of the fruitless fig tress does not symbolize the end of the Jewish people but the end of the corrupt temple establishment.

(1)   This is made clear by the insertion of the story of the temple action into the fig tree story. So also the parable of the vineyard where Jesus alters and retells the vineyard parable of Isa 5:17 to shift the blame away from the Jewish people to the caretakers of the vineyard: the ruling priests. The ruling priests rightly recognize that Jesus has told the parable against them.

(2)   But Evans also says that Jesus probably said something that threatened the destruction of the temple (cf. John 2:19).

(3)   Theres clearly divine judgment upon the aristocratic priesthood, but there is also judgment on the temple, Jerusalem, and the nation. See notes on Parable of the Vineyard [Lau]

b)      Divine judgment on Israel:

i)       Cleansing of the temple: prophetic act regarding the forthcoming judgment of the temple and Jerusalem. This judgment theme is developed further in subsequent chapters: the parable of the vineyard (12:112) privileged position of Israel will be taken away and given to others; coming destruction of Jerusalem in Mark 13; tearing of the temple veil (15:38) (Stein).

c)      Christological:

i)       Jesus authority. He cast out the traders in the temple and no one stops him; he curses the fig tree and it withers completely from the root up. In the quote of Isa 56:7 My house, the my perhaps does not refer to God, but Jesus himself (Stein).

(1)   His statements regarding the judgment of the temple are not merely prophecies, but something he will do (We heard him saying, I will destroy [14:58]; You who are going to destroy the temple [15:29]). Unlike the prophets who proclaimed Gods judgment, Jesus proclaims his own judgment (France). However, take note that 14:57 records that it is a false testimony since in 13:2, Jesus did not portray himself as the destroyer. But its possible that Jesus may have said something similar (Stein, 681).

(2)   I think that its more likely that Jesus didnt say that he will be the agent that destroys the temple. Even in Mark 13:2, where Jesus predicts that not one stone will be left on another stone, the καταλυθῇ should be construed as a divine passive.

d)      Prayer: Need for wholehearted faith (not doubting) and forgiveness of others.

e)      Eschatologically and christologically, in Jesus Israels long-awaited Davidic messiah and Lord of the temple has unexpectedly come. But, ecclesiologically, because of its corruption and failure to be a light to the nations (cf. Rom. 2:24), the temple would be destroyed and replaced by a new one, as we will see in the next appeal to Ps. 118 (CNTUOT).

 

1)      Cursing of the fig tree (11:1214) [272]

a)      Day: Monday

b)      Jesus cursing appears to be vengeful reaction to his disappointment in not finding any fruit. To make matters worse, Mark states that it was not the season for figs.

i)       Marks comment He found nothing on it because it was not the season of figs Jesus action should be understood symbolically.

(1)   The explanatory comment for the reader that Jesus action is not about a fig tree at all. Moreover, the fig tree is commonly used in judgment statements against Israel, Judah, Nineveh, and the nations in general (Stein). In 13:28, Jesus uses a fig tree to signify the coming destruction of Jerusalem and the temple.

(2)   The term kairos is not the botanical term for the growing season but the religious term found in 1:1415 denoting the time of the kingdom of God. Moreover, the tenants do not produce the fruits of the vineyard at harvest time (12:2; lit, in season). The barren fig tree represents the barrenness of temple Judaism that is unprepared to accept Jesus messianic reign (NIVAC).

ii)     Actions are symbolic: A tree that is full of leaves during the Passover season (when it is not the time to bear fruits) is making a promise that it cannot fulfill; so, too, is Israel (France).

iii)   Horticulturally understandable: Although it was not the time for ripe figs (Greek συκῆ; Heb. teenim; May/June), small green figs (Heb. paggim; Song 2:13) were available and eaten by natives Jesus expected to find something. The leaves of the fig trees develop after this. 11:13 could be paraphrased: It was, of course, not the season for figs, but it was for paggim (Edwards).

(1)   In fall, the fig trees develop buds that remain undeveloped until early spring, when they swell into green knops, or paggim. The leaves of the fig tree develop after this (Pliny, N.H. 16.49). The knops, which are edible even if not palatable, develop into the earlier harvest of figs (Song 2:13; Isa 28:4; Jer 24:4; Hos 9:10; Mic 7:1) that take place at the end of June (Stein).

c)      Interpretation

i)       Fig tree represents Israel and is judged by the Messiah to have failed in producing the appropriate fruit, despite its appearance and religious activity (symbolized by the leaves).

ii)     Just as Mic 7:1 speaks of God looking for fruit but not finding any, so also Jesus looks for fruit in his initial visit to the temple but found none. His verdict on the fig tree is a verdict against a barren temple. While it looked healthy, it was dead inside.

2)      Cleansing of the temple (11:1519) [27374]

a)      The sacrifice animals were originally sold on the Mount of Olives, and it was only in recent years that they were allowed to set up shop at the Court of Gentiles (France).

b)      Jesus was not protesting against the trade nor against dishonest or exploitative practices. Rather, he was protesting that the trade was held at the wrong place; trade was not the intent of the temple courts (France).

c)      And he would not allow anyone to carry anything through the temple: Only in Mark. Refusal to allow anyone to use the temple as a thoroughfare. Rationale: improper use of the temple.

d)      Jesus response:

i)       My house shall be called a house of prayer for all the nations?

(1)   Isa 56:7

(a)   OT context:

(i)     A series of promises regarding the new eschatological age where worship of God in the temple would be opened to foreigners.

(ii)  Also alludes to Solomons understanding of the temple as a place also for gentiles (1 Kgs 8:4143).

(b)   Judaism

(i)     Even though some proselytes are included in some traditions, the emphasis is firmly on Israels blessings.

(2)   Function:

(a)   *Expansion of temple for all nations. Only Mark adds for all the nations.

(i)     Jesus declares that the temple has not lived up to the legacy of Isa 56. He condemns the narrow exclusivism of Jews. This then signals for the arrival of the Greek who wants to see Jesus in FG. Might also fit in with the Gentile readers of Mark. Jesus actions then contrasts with common expectations that the Messiah would drive out the Gentiles from Jerusalem and the temple.

(ii)  Judaism considered the temple firmly as Israels house of prayer, and thus the no entry on pain of death warning on the temples soreg ensured that the court primarily signified separation, not inclusion (CNTUOT).

(iii)                        Demonstration of Messianic prerogatives. There was an intimate link between Israels king and Israels temple since David. The Messiah was supposed to rebuilt and/or cleanse the temple (DJGSE, Messiah).

(b)   Indictment against improper use of the temple.

(i)     Marks emphasis is not specifically targeted towards Gentiles, but fulfilling of Isaiahs eschatological role of the temple as a sacred place.

ii)     But you have made it a den of robbers (σπήλαιον λῃστῶν):

(1)   Jer 7:11, esp. 7:911

(a)   7:9 Will you steal and murder, commit adultery and perjury, burn incense to Baal and follow other gods you have not known, 10 and then come and stand before me in this house, which bears my Name, and say, "We are safe"--safe to do all these detestable things? 11 Has this house, which bears my Name, become a den of robbers to you?

(b)   OT context:

(i)     Yahweh declares that if his people want him to dwell among them, they must amend their ways and act justly. They cannot steal, shed innocent blood, commit adultery, oppress the widow (crimes that directly reflect the Decalogue), and then flee to the temple like robbers to their cave thinking that they escape judgment simply because they think that the temple will protect them. On the contrary, Yahweh will come and judge the land.

(c)   Mark

(i)     Relationship to Isa 56: Jesus pins the failure of the temple to live up to the legacy of Isa 56 on the ruling priests (Lau).

(ii)  Function: Indictment against Israels leaders (aristocratic priesthood; not against the people and the lower-ranking priests) who have rejected the summons to do justice and righteousness. In terms of Jer 7, Israels leaders in Mark have also rejected the summons to do justice and righteousness. Apart from the possibility of their unscrupulous business practice (profiteering in the sale of sacrifices and the exchanging of $), of which nothing is said about it in Mark, breaches of the Decalogue have Markan counterparts. Israels leaders have

1.      stolen from their parents (7:1012)

2.      conspired to shed innocent blood (3:6; 11:18)

3.      committed adultery via their lax divorce laws

4.      sworn falsely by professing a love of God and yet avoiding his most important command (7:69)

5.      idolaters who are blind and deaf (3:29; 4:12; 7:67)

6.      oppress widows (12:4144)

(iii)                        As in Jeremiah, Jerusalems authorities are also guilty of the same sin of their lack of respect for Gods house.

1.      Jesus allusion of Jer is not to say that the Jews in his days are comparable to Jeremiahs contemporaries but that they are guilty of the same sin of their lack of respect for Gods house. {I think that its better to say that the emphasis here is not on their practices, but on their lack of respect for the temple}

(iv) Note that Jeremiah goes on to predict the destruction of the temple (7:1215), and Jesus will make the same prediction (Mark 13:2)

(2)   λῃστής: *robber, highwayman, bandit (BDAG 1) || revolutionary, insurrectionist, guerilla (BDAG 2).

(a)   France notes that λῃστής at Jesus time probably meant only robber or bandit and that it came to be known as insurrectionist at the time of Josephus.

(b)   If λῃστής means insurrectionist,

(i)     the Zealot and nationalistic connotations of λῃστής may be deliberately placed against the internationalist agenda of πᾶσιν τοῖς ἔθνεσιν.

(ii)  Moreover, Israels leaders are insurrectionist against the rule of Yahweh

e)      Historical: Since there was no interference and it was not mentioned in the trial, not a massive attempt to stop the entire activity of buying and selling but a symbolic act.

3)      Fig tree is dead (11:2025) [275]

a)      Matt: Death of tree is instantaneous. Perhaps Matt collapses an original more extended event.

b)      Day: Tuesday

c)      The fig tree which you cursed: Not a divine passive (an action performed by God), but an act of judgment by Jesus, the Son of God.

d)      Fig tree withered to its roots: Symbolic prediction of the destruction of the temple.

e)      Discourse on prayer (11:2225):

i)       Whoever says to this mountain: Hyperbolic language which encourages and emphasizes the importance of faith.

ii)     Whatever you ask in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours:

(1)   πιστεύετε ὅτι ἐλάβετε, καὶ ἔσται ὑμῖν. Alternate translation, Believe that you will receive it, and it will be yours. From the context, the aorist may be understood as referring to a future time (see Carson notes in Aspect).

(2)   Should not imply that all unanswered prayers is a result of inadequate faith. The will of God also needs to be factored in (e.g. Jesus prayer in Gethsemane).

(3)   Similar to Jas 1:6. See discussion there. But over there, my notes that you should not doubt the character of God. But here, it appears to be doubting the request itself (Lau).

iii)   Forgive: Another condition for effective prayer is not only faith but also forgiveness. Principles for effective prayer in the kingdom of God: corporate harmony and forgiveness.

iv)   Function

(1)   Appears to be a different subject.

(a)   Stein: Not originally connected with the cursing of the fig tree, but was connected later by word association.

(b)   Jesus offers those who put their faith in God the opportunity likewise to become participants in Gods redemptive, mountain-removing activity (Evans).

(2)   *Destruction of the temple and the formation of a new community

(a)   France: Suggests that the destruction and condemnation of the Jerusalem temple leads to its replacement by the praying community. Communal aspect of prayer underscored by the 2P verbs (11:22, 2425), and also the need to forgive one another in 11:25. Prayer is presented in communal rather than individual categories.

(b)   Mountain represents Zion and the temple (CNTUOT)

(i)     In the language of Isa 40:35, it is this mountain that resists the way of the Lord that needs to be leveled and cast, like the demonized pigs, into the sea as the glory of the Lord is vindicated and revealed.

v)      Look at Keller, Prayer, 229.

4.2         Confrontation with the Jerusalem establishment (11:2713:2)

1)      Shows Jesus in confrontation with a wide group of influential people in Jerusalem. Jesus does not back down, exudes a dominating presence, speaks the last word. Further elaborates the messianic claims in 11:125: Jesus authority is linked with John the Baptist; he situates himself in the stream of Gods prophetic messengers, portraying himself as the most important, the son of the owner of the vineyard; this then raises the question whether the messianic title Son of David is adequate for him (France).

2)      Jesus departure of the temple in 13:1, never to return, is the climax of the confrontation. Moreover, declaration of the destruction of the temple alludes to Jeremiahs temple sermon.

3)      Structure (needs more work).

a)      11:2733 introduces the parable of the vineyard.

b)      12:112, the parable of the vineyard emphasizes the lack of fruit and impending judgment symbolized in Jesus cursing of the fig tree.

c)      Following controversy stories show the lack of fruit.

4.2.1        By what authority? (11:2733) [276]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christology

i)       Jesus authority: Note the 4x repetition of the question (ἐν ποίᾳ ἐξουσίᾳ). The Galilean narrative speaks constantly of the ἐξουσία of Jesus. The actions of Jesus in Jerusalem so far are a challenge to the authority of the religious authorities. Consequently, they confront him.

ii)     Jesus does not explicitly state his messianic identity. That is left for the more formal setting in 14:62. However, he states his claim in actions and elusive language: by means of a parable, reference to a Psalm regarding the stone which the builders rejected, and a question about whose Son the Christ is.

iii)   Nevertheless, this episode develops the identity of Jesus. By comparing his ἐξουσία with that of John the Baptist, he makes 2 claims: Just as John the Baptists authority is ἐξ οὐρανοῦ (i.e. from God), so also is his. Moreover, if they accepted Johns testimony, then they should accept him as the stronger one whose mission supersedes that of John the Baptist (1:78).

(1)   JB is the precursor to Jesus in message of repentance (1:4 || 1:15) and also in fate. Here, failure to understand the significance of JB results in failure to understand Jesus.

iv)   Shows Jesus dominating presence. He is not intimidated by the religious leaders, but he instead embarrasses them.

b)      Opposition

i)       If John was Malachis Elijah, then not only have they rejected his preparatory call to repentance and are therefore under Yahwehs curse, but also, in rejecting Jesus, they have opposed the Lords Messiah and the Lord of the temple himself (CNTUOT).

 

1)      Question (11:2728)

a)      Chief priests, scribes, elders: The 3 groups which make up the Sanhedrin official delegation from the Sanhedrin. Sanhedrin is led by the high priest, and consists of 71 members comprising chief priests, scribes, and elders. They have authority over all religious matters, and some political matters; their authority derived from the Roman Emperor, contra Jesus.

2)      Dialogue (11:2930)

a)      Question about the Baptist:

i)       Johns baptism: Baptism is the distinctive feature of Johns ministry his entire ministry. Moreover, John preaches a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins it bypasses the temple and its rites. If Johns baptism is from God temple is redundant (Garland).

b)      Dilemma: If the Pharisees said that Johns ministry was from God, then it would also imply that Jesus ministry is from God since JB spoke of the stronger one that is coming after me.

4.2.2        Parable of the vineyard (12:112) [278]

1)      This parable develops the confrontation between Jesus and the authorities.

2)      Matthew: This parable is the middle of a 3 part parables in which each has the message of reversal: tax collectors and prostitutes entering the kingdom before religious authorities (21:31-32); kingdom of God given to those who will produce its fruit (21:43) in contrast to the original tenants; those in the streets (ordinary people) replaced by the first-invited guest (22:10).

3)      Emphasis:

a)      Where are the people of God to be found?

i)       In speaking this parable against the religious authorities (Mark 12:12), Jesus remarks that the religious authorities will be punished and that the people of God will now find their fulfillment in him (France).

b)      Christological

i)       The beloved son (υἱὸς ἀγαπητός): The only other occurrences of this term are in 1:11 and 9:7 where the voice from heaven declares Jesus to be his beloved son. Moreover, the killing of the son and casting him out the death of the Son. The Scriptural reference of Ps 118 demonstrates Jesus vindication through resurrection.

(1)   This parable identifies Jesus as unique and different from the OT prophets.

(2)   The quotation at the end emphasizes the vindication of the son. The entire parable may therefore not be so much about wicked tenants but about the rejected son.

(3)   Affirms again the divine necessity of Jesus death. As 12:11 remarks, this was the Lords doing and it is marvelous in the eyes of those who have faith and understanding.

ii)     If the parable is authentic and goes back to Jesus, then this parable affirms the messianic self-consciousness of Jesus.

c)      Judgment: Like 11:1519 (cleansing of the temple) and 13:137, there is judgment not only on the leaders but also on the nation, Jerusalem, and the temple. Like the OT, prophetic judgment against the leaders also falls on the nation as well. The kingdom of God is now no longer the exclusive purview of Israel, but is given to the church.

4)      Allusion to Isa 5:17

a)      A man planted a vineyard :

i)       Recalls Isa 5:17: vineyard (5:1); planted (5:2); put a fence around it (5:2 LXX); I have dug out a pit for a wine vat (5:2); What shall I do (5:5 // Mark 12:9).

ii)     Jesus is talking about the Jewish people.

b)      Difference. In Isa, it is the vineyard that failed; here, it is the tenants. In Isa, the vineyard is to be abandoned; here, vineyard is entrusted to new tenants with hope of a new beginning after judgment on the old regime.

5)      Allegorical elements of the parable

a)      man = God; vineyard = Israel/kingdom of God; tenants = leaders of Israel (chief priests, scribes, elders); servants = prophets; beloved son = Jesus, the Son of God; killing of the son = crucifixion.

 

1)      Situation (12:1)

a)      He began to speak to them: αὐτοῖς refers to the Sanhedrin delegation (chief priests, scribes, and elders; 11:27).

b)      in parables: to speak parabolically.

2)      Sending the servants (12:25)

a)      Common payment for tenancy was to of the crop.

b)      Description of ill-treatment is incremental: beat him and sent him away empty-handed wound in the head and treat shamefully killed.

c)      Alludes to the traditions of the martyrdoms of the prophets: Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel, Micah and Amos in the Lives of the Prophets. Most recently, it will be John the Baptist.

3)      Sending the son (12:68)

a)      Beloved Son: Alludes to 1:11, 9:7 to Jesus. The Sanhedrin was not there at that time, but the readers know that this is a reference to Jesus. Nevertheless, without using the Son of God title directly on himself, Jesus use of the beloved son in this parable gives sufficient reason for the Sanhedrin to ask him in 14:6 Σὺ εἶ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ εὐλογητοῦ;

b)      Matt-Luke has throw him out of the vineyard, then kill him. Perhaps this is done to suit the story of Christ better and may demonstrate Marks more primitive narrative.

4)      Q&A (12:9)

a)      What will the κύριος of the vineyard do?: Probably better Lord rather than owner. Just as the Lord of Hosts (Isa 5:57) pronounce judgment, so also the Lord will pronounce judgment.

b)      Destroy (ἀπολέσει) the tenants: In Isa 5, it is the vineyard that is at fault. Here, it is the tenants, perhaps suggesting that it is the leaders, not the people, who are guilty. Note that ἀπόλλυμι echoes 3:6, 11:18 where it is used against Jesus. By the use here, Jesus implies that the tables are overturned.

c)      Give the vineyard to others: Marks readers would probably understand this to be the churchcomprising Jews and Gentiles. Matt makes it clear (the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a nation producing the fruits of it; 21:43).

5)      OT support (12:1011)

a)      Emphasis: Rejected by men but vindicated by God.

b)      κεφαλὴν γωνίας: cornerstone or keystone at the top of an arch.

c)      12:11 is not in the other NT stone passages.

d)      Ps 118:2223

i)       OT and Jewish context

(1)   Ps 118 is a royal song of thanksgiving for military victory that was later incorporated into a processional liturgy.

(2)   The stone was typically interpreted as David.

(3)   Several Jewish tradition also anticipated the Messiahs rebuilding of the temple (Zech 6:12).

(a)   In Tg. Zech 4:7, the top stone is understood as the Messiah, probably due to a messianic interpretation of Ps 118. In Tg. Zech. 6:1213a, it is the Messiah who rebuild s the temple.

(b)   But I dont find this link convincing.

ii)     Use in Mark (CNTUOT)

(1)   Builders rejection of the stone reflects the temple authorities rejection of Jesus.

(a)   Rejection: ἀποδοκιμάζω occurs only here and in the first passion prediction of 8:31.

(2)   Note the // between son (bēn) and stone (ʾeben).

(3)   Following on traditions surrounding Ps 118 (and Isa 56) that anticipates the rebuilding of the temple, the messianic restoration of the temple is fulfilled in Jesus as the newly reconstituted Israel is gathered around him.

(a)   See also 1 Pet 2:47, which cites Ps 118, where Jesus is the foundation of a spiritual temple in which spiritual sacrifices are offered.

iii)   Function

(1)   Jesus is the Davidic messiah, emphasizing the motif of vindication in the face of rejection.

(2)   Jesus is the basis of the reconstituted vineyard of Israel, which is also the eschatological temple. (CNTUOT). But I dont think that this is strong.

6)      Result (12:12)

a)      Leaders understand the meaning of the parable.

4.2.3        Roman Poll Tax (12:1317) [280]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christology: Shows Jesus greatness and authority as a teacher.

b)      This controversy story also demonstrates the lack of fruit found in the temple.

c)      Principles of living in the kingdom of God: How members of the kingdom of God are to live as members of the kingdom of Caesar (Stein).

 

1)      Attempt to trap Jesus (12:1315a)

d)      Poll tax or direct tax (κῆνσος): Carried out by means of Quiriniuss census when Judea became a Roman province in 6 CE. This led to a revolt by Judas of Galilee that year.

e)      The question that the Pharisees and Herodians asked is a political one. But it was also a theological issue as Judas of Galilee considered this issue to be a matter of allegiance to God or to Rome.

f)       It was a trap. Yes Jesus would alienate the general populace and brand him as pro-Roman; No Jesus would be seen as a rebel and the Roman authorities would not tolerate such acts of rebellion.

2)      Jesus answer (12:15b17)

a)      Jesus asked for a denarius, a silver coin used to pay the Roman poll tax. The Tiberius Caesar denarius carries a portrait of Tiberius with the words TI[BERIUS] CAESAR DIVI AUG[USTI] F[ILIUS] AUGUSTUS Son of the Divine Augustus while the opposite side reads PONTIF[EX] MAXIM[US] High Priest. This was religiously offensive. Jews were able to avoid idolatry by using copper coins which was locally minted. By asking his questioners to show him a denarius, Jesus tricked them. He did not have a denarius, but his questioners were able to produce one, thereby showing their guilt (France).

b)      Render to Caesar :

i)       Jesus was presented with an either-or question. He challenged their assumptions, arguing that the dichotomy between loyalty to Caesar and loyalty to God is a false dichotomy. It was an answer that neither a zealot nor a pro-Roman would have given.

ii)     Because Jesus doesnt answer the question directly. There can be 2 ways to intererpret Jesus response.

(1)   Jesus response provides the basis for Rom 13:17 and 1 Pet 2:1317. He appears to remark that in normal situations, the loyalties of Caesar and God are compatible. But at times, Caesar also demands things that legitimately belong to God, e.g. Rev 18:1ff. In such cases, the church must remember the first commandment to love God with all their heart, mind, and soul.

(2)   Jesus undercuts the authority of Caesar. Ultimately, everything belongs to God. Thus, we should give God everything.

iii)   Render (ἀποδίδωμι): Give back, returning something that already belongs to the receiver.

c)      They were amazed: Shows that Jesus succeeded in escaping this trap. Even his enemies are amazed at his wisdom.

4.2.4        Question about the Resurrection (12:1827) [281]

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christological:

i)       Shows the great wisdom of Jesus and his teaching authority (Is not this why you are wrong You are wrong [12:24, 27]). See also Matts statement at the end And when the crowd heard it, they were astonished at his teaching (22:23) or Lukes Teacher you have spoken well. For they no longer dared to ask him any questions (20:3940).

b)      Provides hope of resurrection for those who are dead. This will be especially important for Marks readers who are undergoing persecution.

i)       Jesus teaching on resurrection will be later verified by his own resurrection.

 

1)      The previous question by the Pharisees and Herodians was both political and theological; here, it is primarily theological, although it has political implications for dividing the dominant parties within Jerusalem.

a)      Sadducees:

i)       Denotes a theological view that is shared among the aristocrats of Jewish society, rather than a formal party. It was adopted by most of the priestly family within the Sanhedrin. They rejected the oral tradition and held to the Pentateuch.

(1)   This view may be erroneous, and may be confused with the Samaritans (Lau).

ii)     Theres progressive understanding of an afterlife in the Bible. Initially, Sheol is little more than the grave or a form of shadowy existence. But by Dan 12, resurrection of both the just and unjust is articulated. This is carried further from the 2nd century B.C.E. onwards primarily in the apocalyptic works and in the traditions of the martyrs of the Maccabean period. The Pharisees who were open to new religious ideas accepted it; the Sadducees could not find support for it in the Pentateuch and therefore rejected it. Sadducees believed that Sheol was the final resting place. Any form of resurrection took place through the reputation of your name or through your children. The NT then more clearly articulates the nature and occupants of heaven and hell.

iii)   Read up more about Resurrection: See Brown, DNTT 3.26175; Nickelsburg, Resurrection.

2)      Another test: They presumably knew that Jesus shared the Pharisaic belief on the issue of resurrection (Luke 14:14; 16:1931; 23:43). They therefore constructed a case that would show the absurd outcome if someone held to the view of resurrection.

 

1)      Question (12:1823)

a)      Example may be drawn from Tob 3:8. However, levirate principle does not play a part in that example, just cycles of remarriage and widowhood.

b)      Levirate law (Deut 25:56) was important for those who did not believe in resurrection as it enabled the survival of the dead brother.

i)       If a man dies childless, then his brother was bound by duty to marry the widow and continue the family line.

ii)     The Sadducees believe that since it was commanded that the brother should marry the childless woman, this case refutes the doctrine of life after death and the doctrine of the resurrection.

iii)   This contrived nature shows that this question is not meant to seek wisdom or enlightenment, but is meant to embarrass Jesus.

2)      Jesus answer (12:2427)

a)      2 errorsignorance of Scripture and the power of God.

i)       Ignorant of the power of God

(1)   Resurrection life is not mere continuation of the present life.

(a)   There are no marriages in heaven issue of marriage is irrelevant in the matter of resurrection.

(b)   Like angels in heaven: Not that they become angels, but that they are like angels, i.e. eternal beings, not needing procreation.

(i)     Note also that Sadducees do not believe in angels (Acts 23:810).

ii)     Ignorant of Scripture

(1)   God stresses the reality of resurrection by speaking of his present lordship over Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. I am (ἐγώ) the God of :

(2)   Allusion to Exod 3:6.

(a)   OT context

(i)     Larger narrative of Moses commissioning in 3:14:17. What is central here is Gods self-identificationthe God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacobas the one who is faithful to his covenant with the fathers. Because of his covenantal faithfulness, God has heard his peoples outcry, baring his mighty arm, to deliver them from bondage and set him in a bountiful land (3:78).

(ii)  The ensuing exchange between Yahweh and Moses shows Yahwehs utterly sovereign control over every aspect of human existence and even existence itself.

(b)   Mark

(i)     Appeal to Torah: To make a compelling case to the Sadducees.

(ii)  Not based on the tense of the verb: There is no verb either in the OT or in Mark (contrast Matt who follows the LXX as ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ θεός . ). Argument is probably not grammatical, since an argument based on the tense of an implied verb will probably not be valid.

(iii)                        Based on the character of God:

1.      *The argument is based on the character of the covenantal God whom Moses encountered. As the great I AM, he is the living God, the ever-present helper and delvierer of his people. If such a God chooses to be identified by the names of his long-dead servants Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, with whom his covenant was made, and whome he committed himself to protect, they cannot simply be dead and forgotten: οὐκ ἔστιν θεὸς νεκρῶν ἀλλὰ ζώντων. The basis for Jesus argument, far from being merely the tense of a verb, is in the fundamental theological understanding of Yahweh, the living God, and of the implications of his establishing an everlasting covenant with his mortal worshippers. (NIGTC)

a.       If he identifies himself as the God of the long-dead Patriarchs, it implies that they are not dead. By identifying himself as the God of the long-dead Patriachs God establishes an everlasting covenant with mortals Gods promise and his relationship with the patriarchs are not broken by death.

i.        OT evidence that Gods promise with the patriarchs are not broken by death. Everlasting covenant: After the Golden Calf, Moses reminds God of his covenant with Abraham and Isaac: I wil make your descendants as numerous as the stars (Exod 32:13). Then God relented of his anger (Lau).

b.      Since God exercises his matchless power in order to keep his covenantal promises, it is inconceivable that those whom he establishes an everlasting covenant would not participate in the life that he offers as the sovereign one over human existence itself. Here, because God is characterized by life, so will be all of those who put their trust in him.

2.      God is the covenant protector and redeemer of his people. Resurrection is the logical outcome of the covenant idea, for God could not protect his people from various forms of physical calamity and hand them over to the final destruction of death. God could not let his people die and be faithful to his promise of establishing an everlasting covenant (Lane).

4.2.5        The greatest commandment (12:2834) [282]

1)      [Carson] Issues

a)      What does it mean to love God with your mind? To us, love and cerebral dont fit together.

b)      Why is this the 1st commandment?

c)      How is the 1st commandment related to the 2nd?

2)      Matt-Luke sees this as another conflict story. They include [ἐκ]πειράζω, and also do not include the comment made by the scribe, You are right (καλῶς), Teacher.

3)      Levels of importance in Jewish law

a)      According to scribal traditions, there are 613 commandments in the Pentateuch. Rabbis considered some as heavy and others as light, and there was a natural desire for a summarizing principle.

i)       In b. Sab. 31a, a famous question was put to Shammai and Hillel Teach me the whole torah while I am standing on one leg. Hillel responded, Do not do to your neighbor what is hateful to you; this is the whole Torah: the rest is commentary. This is similar to Jesus statement in Matt 7:12 So in everything, do to others what you would have them do to you, for this sums up the Law and the Prophet.

 

1)      Question (12:28)

a)      Acknowledgement that some laws are more important than others. In any complex legal system, one law must take precedent; this was debated in those days. Its not a question just to trap Jesus. Jesus himself acknowledges the importance of some laws over others. See Matt 23:23; John 7:23 (circumcision law is more important than Sabbath law).

b)      Apart from this verse, Jesus elsewhere criticizes the Pharisees for tithing mint and dill while ignoring the weightier matters of the law: justice, mercy, and faith (Matt 23:23). One should of course do those that are important without ignoring the others; but the thrust here is to find out which commandment is most fundamental and from which other commandments arise.

2)      Answer (12:2931)
