a)      Jesus goes behind discussions about heavy and light to the whole principle that undergirds the Torah.

b)      Jesus explicitly links, as far as we know for the first time, 2 texts (Deut 6:4-5 & Lev 19:18).[37]

c)      Great Shema (hear): Only Mark includes the Shema, and the 2 love commandments draw out the implication of the Shema. Since there is only 1 God, man must love him totally, and his lordship forms the basis for loving God with the 4 alls: all your heart, all your soul, all your mind, all your strength.

i)       [Carson] Command to love God is preceded by the oneness of God. Why? In pagan world, gods occupy certain domain. You ask Neptune if youre going to cross the sea. This you cant give all your allegiance to 1 god. But if theres only 1 god that governs all domains, then he demands all our affection and loyalty.

ii)     καρδία (center of ones thinking and affection), ψυχή (source of ones desire and feeling), and διάνοια (thinking and understanding), ἰσχύς (ones energy and power). Hard to differentiate clearly between καρδία, ψυχή, and διάνοια (France); but the cumulative effect is to love God totally with all of ones energy and being.

(1)   [Carson] Love cannot be just reduced to mere volition to seek the other good even though you hate the other person. In 1 Cor 13, If I give my body to be burned but do not have love On the other hand, it cannot be reduced to mere emotion, because biblical heart is more comprehensive.

(2)   [Carson] OT context: Love for God is bound up with fearing God, obeying God, and passing on in obedience and instruction for covenantal faithfulness to the next generation (Deut 6:13, 68, 1315, 20). This is a God centeredness that embraces all of life, not just something you do on Sunday.

(a)   This goes against the thought that we are loving God with our minds if we are doing intellectual work roughly within the kingdom domain. This is a rising sentiment, as in Mark Noll, The Scandal of the Evangelical Mind, The scandal of the evangelical mind is that there isnt one. This sentiment presupposes that you are obeying this command provided youre engaged in intellectual work, e.g. studying Coptic to improve your text criticism. This is wrong since there are those who enjoy great pleasure from just sheer intellectual work, such as the study of worms. Our danger is that we think our work is more noble because it is in the domain of God.

(b)   Loving God does include intellectual work, but beware of idolatry by just fixating on the word mind.

(c)   1st commandment is anti-idolatry. The primary responsibility of any created being is to acknowledge our creator.

d)      2 dimensions of mans response (12:3031)

i)       Vertical dimension: loving God (1st part of the Decalogue).

ii)     Horizontal dimension: loving man (2nd part of the Decalogue). This is the 2nd commandment one cannot fulfill the horizontal without the vertical, love of God is the basis for love of other people.

(1)   Neighbor: In OT context, it denotes a fellow member of the covenant community and Lev 19:34 extends it to include the resident alien (France).

(a)   Luke 10 extends the meaning of neighbor in the Parable of the Good Samaritan.

(2)   [Carson] OT Context: Full of commands regarding social relationships.

(a)   Note how I am the LORD is tagged on as justification for this command and other commands in Lev 19. This clause ties the 1st commandment with the 2nd commandment. The cardinal offense is not first and foremost horizontal, but defying God. Every social offense is a breaking of the 1st command of loving God. It is to dethrone God. See Ps 51 where David said that he only sinned against God.

(i)     One of the ways we convince the world of the value of Christianity is to show its moral value in helping society. That is true. But the Bible sees the fundamental sin as idolatry.

(ii)  So even a private sin like pornography is a sin committed in defiance of God.

e)      Function of OT citations

i)       Coming at the end of Jesus public ministry, this episode also serves as something of a climax.

ii)     Jesus summarizes the heart of the Torah by which he lived, and which he exhorts his disciples to follow.

3)      Scribes response (12:3233)

a)      Whats amazing is that the scribe agrees with Jesus and also adds that the 2 commandments are more important that all whole burnt offerings and sacrifices.

b)      Common rabbinic view was expressed by Simon the Just (ca 200 BCE): the world rest on three things: the law, the sacrificial worship, and expressions of love. But the prophets often stress the necessity of ethics over sacrifices, and this scribe may have picked up on this.

c)      Absent in Matt-Luke: Reasons

i)       Redundant to repeat Deut 6:45 and Lev 19:18

ii)     To follow the normal pattern of a pronouncement story in which Jesus pronouncement occurs at the end of the story.

4)      Jesus response (12:34)

a)      Not far that he should grasp the final truth, which would certainly be christological (Osborne).

b)      [Carson] Not far does not that if you try harder along these lines, you can get in. Its not that the key to entering the kingdom of God is to obey these commandments adequately. Jesus is saying that entrance into the KOG is bound up with these 2 commands. Thats why in 1 John, John makes the test of love for brothers as important as the test of truth. See 1 John 2:9; 4:1921.You cannot be saved by grace and hate your neighbor or make yourself God. Entrance into the KOG is bound up with having a firm understanding of a God centered universe.

i)       In the story line of the gospel, 10:45 already says that Jesus says that he came to give his life as a ransom for many. Moreover, Marks gospel is rushing towards the cross and the resurrection (Khler: passion narrative with an extended introduction). The way one enters the kingdom is by Jesus Christ. He gives the rite of the new covenant: this cup is the blood of the covenant which is poured out for many. The way to come to the new covenant is by Jesus, by recognizing that all the sins that we commit is a breaking of these 2 commandments, and that they can only be satisfied by Jesus.

ii)     These 2 commandments prepare us for the kingdom, both in the present and in the future. Many of the OT commands will not be in force in the new heaven and earth, e.g. sacrificial lambs, murder (with resurrection bodies?). Moreover, our hearts will be so turned towards God. But in the new heaven and the new earth, these 2 commands will still be enforced and obeyed. In some way, the church is to be, as far as possible, this side of heaven and earth, a foretaste of the new heaven and earth.

c)      In Luke 10:28, Jesus responds, Do this and you will live.

i)       Knowledge of what God requires is not enough; such knowledge must be put into practice.

ii)     Explanation:

(1)   Jesus assumes that a person who loves God will respond to what he requires and teaches. No one can know the Father except by way of the Son (Luke 10:22). Thus, the response to Jesus is a part of the love for God. The issue is not really pre-evangelistic, in that the lawyer needed Jesus because he could not keep the law. Rather, the issue of love is key to evangelism. To love God is to be devoted to the teaching and person of Jesus. One may see Gods love in Jesus. Anyone who loves God will respond to his message, and, as a result, to fellow humans (Bock).

 

1)      Emphasis

a)      Theological:

i)       Important monotheistic formulation for Marks Gentile readers who probably came from a polytheistic background: God and Abraham and the Lord Jesus Christ cannot be placed alongside other gods.

b)      Ethical: Emphasis on ethics rather than sacrifice. This has significance for Marks readers as the temple with its sacrificial system would be destroyed in70 CE. Moreover, Jesus also remarks that the temple should be called a house of prayer (not sacrifice) for all nations (11:17). Finally, see also the emphasis on the community of prayer after the action of the fig tree which symbolizes judgment on the temple.

c)      Christological: Jesus authority as the teacher of Israel.

i)       Jesus authority to capture the heart of the Torah.

ii)     After this incident, Mark records that no one dared to ask him any question. Jesus emerges clearly as the winner, and he presses his advantage with denouncements of the scribes and other religious authorities.

d)      Soteriology:

i)       Repeats emphasis in the story of the rich young ruler. In response to the question, What must I do to inherit eternal life (10:17), Jesus responds first with commands that speak of loving your neighbor as yourself (10:19), and then with the command to sell all that he has and follow Jesus (10:21), which Marks readers would have understood to be the first command, loving God with your entire being such that there is no room for idolatry of any form.

e)      Indictment against the Jewish leaders.

i)       Sets up what is necessary for living in the kingdom of God. By setting up these 2 standards, they also form the standard by which Jesus later judges the scribes in 12:3840.

4.2.6        Question about Davids Son: Status of the Messiah (12:3537) [283]

1)      Jesus raises an academic question about the Messiah but does not present clues that he is the Messiah. However, the reader is aware of Jesus messianic identity, and it should be apparent within the narrative context that those who had witnessed Jesus entry into Jerusalem would have seen the relevance of this question to his identity and status. However, the academic nature of the question that it cant be used against him.

2)      Function

a)      Jesus goes on the offensive and challenges the adequacy of the scribes conception of the Messiah. Readers know that Jesus is the Son of God since the baptism. As the story nears its climax, Jesus shows the inadequacy of the scribes messianic expectations. Jesus cannot be merely Davids messianic son.

b)      *In his confrontation with the scribes in Mark 1112, Mark reveals further the identity of Jesus and the judgment of the religious authorities

i)       Triumphal entry: Jesus is the messianic Son of David.

ii)     Jesus clears the temple: Jesus is one who can exercise messianic judgment over the religious authorities.

iii)   Authority of Jesus questioned: Just as JB, he is one who has authority from heaven; moreover, according to JB, he is superior.

iv)   Parable of the tenants: He is the beloved Son who is superior to the prior prophets.

v)      Here: He is more than the Son of David; he is one who also sits at the right hand of God. Matt 22:42 asks: Whose son is he? If he is not the Son of David, the implication then is that he is the Son of God.

(1)   But what does it mean to be the Son of God when Jesus earlier (in the episode with the scribe) already affirms that there is one God (and one power in heaven)?

 

1)      Jesus question (12:35)

a)      Second step after 11:111 in overturning the messianic secret. But the use of the 3rd person still makes it enigmatic (Osborne).

b)      Jewish references that understand the Messiah as the Son of David.

i)       Messiah is a branch of David (Jer 23:56; 33:1516).

ii)     Messiah is a branch from Jesses stump (Isa 11:1ff; Ezek 34:2324; 37:2428).

iii)   See also Ps. Sol. 17:21, the coming king who will rule over Israel is called the Son of David.

2)      Explanation (12:3637a)

a)      Ps 110:1 MT The LORD (God; Yahweh) said to my Lord (Davids Lord = Messiah; Adonai) Messiah is Davids Lord.

b)      OT context

i)       Ps 110 is a new interpretation of Ps 2 and amplifies several core ideas: See CNTUOT

(1)   More explicit than Ps 2:7 use of son, the king here sits at Yahwehs right hand and implies the highest possible authority and honor short of usurpation.

(2)   Ps 2, nations take counsel against the Lords anointed; Ps 110:2, they surround him.

(3)   Ps 2:8 has Yahweh inviting the king to ask for the nations as his inheritance; Ps 110:1, 56 has the king sitting while Yahweh fights for him.

(4)   Ps 2s warning to the nations to submit is ignored; in Ps 110:56, you have Yahwehs judgment on behalf of the king.

(5)   Ps 110:4 designates the king as a priest after Melchizedek

ii)     Another construal

(1)   The event is Solomons enthronement as recorded in 3 Kgdms 1. Note also that David recognized the superiority of his newly enthroned son by doing obeisance on his bed (3 Kgdms 1:4647).

(2)   Ps 110 would be The LORD [Yhwh] says to my lord [Solomon]: Sit at my right hand.

(3)   This is the only instance in the history of Israel that a son ascends the throne and is crowned king while his father is still alive.

c)      Judaism

i)       Rarely used because of the staggering claim concerning sharing Gods throne.

ii)     Royal-priestly combination lies in the attempts of the Hasmonean king to legitimize their fusing kingly and priestly roles.

iii)   Other sources interpret this psalm eschatologically with regard to a messianic/son of man figure.

d)      Most OT scholars do not believe it to be written by David nor does it speak of the Messiah. Rather, they consider it a typical royal psalm by an anonymous psalmist who sees The Lord (God) calling my Lord (i.e. the psalmists king) to sit at his right hand in triumph at the time of his enthronement. If theres any link with David, it is David who is the king that is enthroned.

i)       Nevertheless, this Psalm is ascribed to David, and there is a significant strand in Jewish interpretation which identifies the κύριος which God addresses to be the messiah (France).

e)      Mark

i)       Christological

(1)   Jesus questions whether the Scribes are justified in calling the Messiah merely the Son of David when David himself calls him Lord. The real question is What does it mean for the Messiah to be Davids Lord?

(2)   Moreover, given the use of Ps 2 in Jesus baptism and transfiguration, and the connection between Ps 110 and Ps 2, the question also arises, What does it mean for Jesus to be Gods son?

(3)   Marks Jesus has already identified himself with the exalted figures of Dan 7 and Isa 5253, both texts linked in the tradition to Ps 110. But Marks Jesus also transcends these intertetamental heavenly figures.

(a)   Marks new-exodus beginning points not so much to a messianic figure, but to the presence of God himself.

(b)   Jesus exercises divine prerogatives in forgiving sin, walking on the sea, and commanding healing rather than requesting them. Jesus also responds to the scribe by noting that the Lord our God, the Lord is one (12:27)? What does it mean then for Marks Jesus to immediately draw attention to Davids calling the Messiah Lord?

(c)   Jesus actions and teaching of the Torah in the temple display his ultimate authority over the purity of Israels worship. If so, the Ps 110 citation then implies not only Jesus priestly authority, but also an authority, by virtue of its Melchizedek character, to supersede that of the present temple authorities.

ii)     Judgment:

(1)   The addition of Yahwehs promise to make his enemies his footstool (until I put your enemies under your feet) Jesus enemies are Gods enemies, and they are destined for destruction.

(a)   Reinforces the point of the parable of the Wicked Tenants: those from the house of the Lord who refuse to bless Jesus but rather plot his death will be shattered and placed under the feet of Yahweh.

(2)   Just as Ps 110 is a heightening of Ps 2, the judgment motif in Mark is coming to its zenith.

iii)   Summary:

(1)   Jesus is more than Davids messianic son, he is also Davids exalted Lord, the Son of God, who uniquely sits at Gods right hand.

(2)   Moreover, God will see to it that he rules in the midst of his enemies, shattering kings and their supposed safe-houses (the temple; Mark 13; Jer 7:11 in Mark 11:17b)

3)      Result (12:37b)

a)      Great throng heard him gladly:

 

1)      Emphasis

a)      Christological:

i)       Purpose: The discussion questions the validity of the title Son of David as applied to the Messiah. But why?

(1)   Negatively. Does not reject the Son of David title. Son of David is clearly a valid title for Jesus in the early church. But perhaps the title encouraged too much of a political and nationalistic understanding of Jesus mission (France).

(2)   *Positively: Son of David, by itself, is perhaps inadequate to understand Jesus identity. Jesus is more than Davids son; Jesus is Davids lord. Matt brings this out better What do you think of the Christ? Whose son is he? The implication is that if Son of David is inadequate, then the proper answer should be Son of God. Mark probably presupposes this answer (France).

(a)   In previous discussions, Jesus is presented to be greater than the prophets (8:2729; 12:112); here, he is greater than David. Specifically, the Messiah is superior to David; he is to be understood as Davids lord rather than his son.

(b)   Jesus redfines meaning of messiahship.

(i)     Citation of Ps 110 specifies both priestly function of Messiah (note reference to Melchizedek in Ps 110:4) and intimates exaltation of Messiah to share in Gods throne (cf. title Lord in 110:1). Both themes of priestly Messiah and exalted Messiah were current in 2nd Temple Judaism (DJG, Messiah).

ii)     Probably shows messianic self-consciousness of Jesus. What Jesus meant by the question is what Mark also intended. He who heard the heavenly voice at the baptism (You are my beloved son) and who believed that he would one day sit at the right hand of power (14:62) understood himself to be more than the Son of David.

iii)   Mark presents Jesus as a suffering Messiah. But Jesus messiaship is also heavenly and eternal, not just earthly and temporally limited. Thus, Mark raises the question how the Messiah can be Davids son if David called him Lord. As the hidden Son of Man on earth, Jesus suffered and died like David. But after his resurrection, he was installed as a heavenly Messiah, more like that Son of Man in the Similitudes of Enoch than like David (Collins, Mark).

4.2.7        Denunciation of the Scribes (12:3840) [284]

1)      This small episode in Mark // Matts extensive woes in Matt 23.

2)      Ambitions of the scribes (12:38b39)

a)      Long robes: The robes were distinguished garments of eminent men.

b)      Greetings in the marketplace: Shows the growing status of scribes. For example, people were to greet them in the marketplace.

c)      Best seats in the synagogue: Seats at the front that faced the congregation.

d)      Places of honor at banquets:

3)      Excesses (12:40a)

a)      Devour widows houses.

i)       Defrauding of widows is particularly despicable since they are vulnerable; taking financial advantage of widows.

b)      Out of pretense make long prayers: Hypocrisymaking long prayers in order to catch the attention of others.

4)      Result (12:40b)

a)      Greater condemnation.

 

1)      Emphasis

a)      Discipleship: Scribes are portrayed as ostentatious, exploitative, and hypocritical, all of which a believer is not to be.

i)       Warning to beware of scribes because they failed to observe the 2 great commandments of 12:3031. Wanting honor for themselves failure to love and honor God; devouring widows houses failure to love others as themselves.

b)      Judgment motif

4.2.8        Widows mite (12:4144) [286]

1)      Location: Court of the Women outside the treasury. There were 13 trumpet chests (so called because of their shape) to receive various offerings (France).

2)      Setting (12:4142)

a)      Gifts of the wealthy were inconsequential to themselves; the widow gave all she had.

i)       The copper coin (λεπτόν) is the smallest denomination of currency in use. Its worth less than 1/100 of a denarius (France). It was half a Roman quadrans or Jewish peruta (ABD).

ii)     Roman κοδράντης: smallest Roman coin, of an as (1/16 of a denarius). Use of κοδράντης suggests Mark is written to the church in Rome.

3)      Teaching (12:4344)

a)      According to the worlds standard, the amount of $ matters. No one names a building or a room in a building after the widow because of the 2 copper coins she contributed.

b)      Jesus explains why the widows gift is greater. She gave out of her poverty. She only had 2 copper coins, and she gave not one but both of them, thereby manifesting her total love for God.

c)      No gift is insignificant to God when given in love and devotion. The size of the gift does not matter to God so much as the attitude of the giver.

 

1)      Emphasis

a)      Discipleship:

i)       Jesus honors a woman whose devotion would not have been appreciated by his male disciples (France). See also another episode in 14:8 where another woman anoints Jesus. Both demonstrate reckless devotion. Discipleship demands a total surrender of the self.

(1)   Contrasts with the rich young ruler; she gave all that she had. She embodies what Jesus requires of disciples: loving God with all of ones heart, mind, soul, and strength (12:30).

(2)   *Contrasts with the ostentatiousness, rapaciousness of the scribes who are just only mentioned as one who devours widows houses (12:40). Note that widow only occurs in 12:40, 42, and 43.

ii)     Jesus repudiates a value scale which attributes greater worth to the amount of the gift rather than the dedication of the giver.

4.3         Eschatological discourse: Explanatory discourse: The end of the old order (13:137)

1)      *Concludes 11:113:37. The failure of Israel and its leadership to fulfill its mission; its lack of fruit; hostility to Gods anointed these all lead to their judgment and destruction. This then brings to a climax the judgment motif that begins with Jesus cleansing of the temple, cursing of the fig tree, and the warning in the parable of the vineyard. After this in Mark 1416 is the passion, crucifixion, and resurrection.

a)      The hostility between the Jerusalem authorities and Jesus reaches the climax, and Jesus explicitly predicts the destruction of the temple. Jerusalem and the temple which is the locus of its authority will lose its place within Gods economy, and the kingdom of God will find a new focus (France).

2)      Same basic pattern: Pronouncement followed by a request for its explanation. The prediction concerning the temple triggers the disciples question for clarity which Jesus then uses to explain the significance of the narrative events so far.

3)      Interpretation: Need to differentiate the meaning of Jesus for this audience and that of Mark for his readers.

a)      For Jesus and his audience

i)       Jesus message is a prediction about the future judgment of Jerusalem and the temple. They were to wait for the sign of the desolating sacrilege, and then flee Judea and Jerusalem to seek safety.

b)      For Mark and his readers

i)       Although they do not reside in Jerusalem, they need to watch lest they be led astray. They should prepare themselves for persecution.

ii)     Salvation history: Coming destruction of Jerusalem. Judgment on the temple was due to its failure to produce fruit in line with its calling. It shows Gods sovereign control of history take heart because Our God reigns!

iii)   Christological:

(1)   Jesus awareness of the situation.

(2)   Jesus is in some way bringing about the destruction. Seen in his symbolic act of cleansing the temple, telling of the parable of the vineyard. This is recognized by the public (14:58, 15:29). As for 14:58, Mark records that it was false testimony (14:57), but it could be false in that Jesus never formally stated that he would destroy the temple.

 

1)      Genre

a)      France: Not an apocalypse.

i)       Lacks major apocalyptic motifs: attribution of ancient prophetic figure, heavenly journey, heavenly vision, angelic mediator, symbolism of numbers and animals, systematization of world history into past, present, and future; review of human history.

ii)     Some apocalyptic elements: focus on future, impending judgment, call to faithfulness.

2)      Debate and issues

a)      In the disciples question of 13:4, what does these things (ταῦτα) and all these things (ταῦτα πάντα) point to? Do they refer to the same things?

i)       Most agree that they refer to the complex of events surrounding the destruction of Jerusalem.

ii)     ταῦτα πάντα (All these things):

(1)   // to ταῦτα (Lane, Stein, France).

(2)   Looks beyond ταῦτα to the end of the age (Edwards, Osborne).

b)      What does 13:2427 (Coming/Going of the Son of Man) point to?

i)       The end of the world and to the parousia.

ii)     Destruction of Jerusalem (France, Wright).

(1)   Coming of the Son of Man language does not Parousia, but the vindication and enthronement of the Son of Man as he exercises supreme authority. It therefore shows a change in government: the authority inherent in the temple is replaced by the Son of Man. This removes the difficulty of 13:30.

(2)   France, contrast Wright: But there are still indications of the Parousia in 13:3237.

c)      How do we understand 13:2930, esp. 13:30 This generation will certainly not pass away until all these things have happened.

4.3.1        Understanding time frame of Mark 13

Look at chart in document Mark 13.docx

4.3.2        Prediction of destruction of the temple (13:12) [287]

1)      Prediction of the temple as a factor in Jesus death

a)      See Sanders, Jesus and Judaism, 7176, that it was Jesus attitude towards that temple that united the people against him.

b)      Predicting the destruction of the temple is dangerous. Josephus records that after Jesus, another Jesus, son of Hananiah, was put on trial for threats against the city and its temple (War 6.300309) (France).

2)      After symbolically predicting the fate of the temple in the cursing of the fig tree, Jesus explicitly predicts it here.

3)      Function:

a)      While 13:12 is the setting for the question of 13:34 and provokes the discourse of 13:5-37, it also functions as no less as a conclusion to Jesus earlier confrontation with the Jerusalem establishment (France).

i)       Jesus symbolically cleanses the temple, trumps the religious leaders who made it apostate, leaves the temple, and predicts its destruction that the old structures of Gods relationship with his people is to be replaced.

4)      This prediction is probably a different saying than the one alluded to in 14:58, 15:29, since 13:2 is directed to his disciples and in private.

5)      Historical setting

a)      Wenham suggests that a version of Jesus sermon forms the basis for the 3 synoptic accounts.[38] All 3 synoptic accounts preserve traces of the original discourse. The Synoptists did not invent such a discourse by pulling together isolated sayings from unconnected contexts in Jesus life.

4.3.3        Discourse 13:337 [288-94]

4.3.3.1       Disciples question (13:34) [288]

1)      Time frame: Destruction of temple and Jersualem

2)      Tell us when will this (ταῦτα) be and what will be the sign when these things (ταῦτα πάντα) : ταῦτα refers to destruction of the temple.

a)      2 questions: when and what are the accompanying signs.

i)       When (πότε):

(1)   Answered by ὅταν (13:14), ἐν ἐκείναις ταῖς ἡμέραις (13:24), καὶ τότε (13:26), καὶ τότε (13:27), and finally summed up in that it will take place within this generation (13:30).

ii)     What (σημεῖον): Not clear.

(1)   Abomination of desolation.

(2)   Budding of the fig tree summer is near events are right at the door.

b)      Debate:

i)       Both questions relate to the destruction of the temple (France, Stein, Lane)

ii)     1st question = destruction of temple; 2nd question = also refers to the destruction of the temple but συντελεῖσθαι foreshadows the end time (Edwards, Osborne)

3)      Mount of Olives:

a)      Messianic significance as in 11:1

b)      *Place where Gods glory stopped after leaving the temple in Ezek 11:23 || Jesus stopping here after leaving the temple and declaring its destruction.

4)      κατέναντι τοῦ ἱεροῦ: opposite the temple and overlooking it (Mount of Olives is 300 ft above temple); may also suggest over against the temple (France).

5)      All these things to be accomplished (συντελεῖσθαι):

a)      Mark probably just refers only to the destruction of the temple.

b)      Nevertheless, the destruction of the temple proleptically hints at the end of the age, which is picked up by Matt. Matt expands it to the end of the parousia and to the end of the age.

4.3.3.2       Signs, birth pangs, persecution (13:513) [28889]

1)      Time frame: Destruction of temple and Jerusalem

4.3.3.2.1     Despite worrisome signs, the end is not yet (13:58) [288]

1)      Emphasis:

a)      Do not be misled by premature indications.

2)      Time frame: Destruction of temple and Jersualem

a)      The turbulent period between Jesus ministry and the destruction of the temple proved fertile ground for ψευδόχριστοι καὶ ψευδοπροφῆται (13:22).

 

1)      Take heed (βλέπετε): Repeated in 13:9, 22, 23; coupled with be alert ἀγρυπνεῖτε (13:33) and be watchful γρηγορεῖτε (13:35, 37) attitude of watchfulness and discernment.

2)      Come in my name: Claiming to act on Jesus authority || *claiming to be the Messiah

a)      Saying, I am he (ἐγώ εἰμι): We dont know of anyone else claiming divine status, so the ἐγώ εἰμι probably does not allude to the divine name from Exod 3:14. Here, it probably flushes the meaning of coming in my name. These people are not so much acting in Jesus authority as usurping his rightful place as that of the Messiah. Matt 24:5 makes it explicit by stating I am the Christ.

b)      For false messianic leaders before 66 CE: See Josephus, Ant. 20.9799 (Theudas), 102 (sons of Judas of Galilee), 16972 (the Egyptian), 16768, 88 (various unnamed impostors).

i)       Lead many astray:

(1)   Theudas led 400 astray (Acts 5:36)

(2)   The Egyptian led 4,000 astray (Acts 21:38). Josephus, War 2.61 states 30,000.

3)      Wars and rumors of war: Wars include

a)      Rome and Parthia 36 CE

b)      Antipas and the Nabatean king Aretas (3637 CE).

4)      The end (τὸ τέλος) is not yet:

a)      *Events of 70 CE (Stein).

b)      Parousia of 13:2427, 3237 (Osborne).

i)       Difficulty of this view: Setting of 13:5ff refers to the destruction of the temple/Jerusalem. Some also take 13:1420 as referring to events of 6670 CE, not the Parousia.

ii)     But if this refers to the destruction of the temple, how can it be that if Mark was written in late 60s, the destruction of the temple/Jerusalem can be said to be not yet?

(1)   Perhaps its Mark recording what Jesus said (Lau).

5)      Beginning of the birth pangs (ὠδίνων): Note that this is just the preliminary suffering, not the imminent end.

a)      *Birth pangs for the events of 70 CE (Stein, France).

i)       No indication that birth pangs is a t.t. for the end of the age. Usage of this term to refer to the suffering of the Messiah is found in later Rabbinic sources. Rather, the birth pangs are a metaphor for great suffering in various contexts (France, Gundry, Stein).

b)      Birth pangs for the end of the age.

4.3.3.2.2     Prospect of persecution (13:913) [289]

1)      Time frame: Destruction of temple and Jersualem

2)      In the midst of their waiting, disciples are called to faithfulness. The warning is not given so that believes can escape persecution, but in order to prepare them to endure it faithfully.

3)      Jewish Christians will be brought before local councils (probably not the Sanhedrin in Jerusalem) and beaten in synagogues. All believers would be susceptible to trials before Jewish and Gentile authorities.

a)      Predict Jesus sufferings, disciples in Acts

4)      To bear testimony before them: Their suffering will be part of the Christian witness. αὐτοῖς can be dative of advantage (a witness to them) or disadvantage (a witness against them).

5)      Gospel must first be (πρῶτον δεῖ) preached to all nations:

a)      Gospel:

i)       For Marks readers, gospel would include not only Jesus message that the kingdom of God has drawn near but also the message about Jesus himself. The gospel that Jesus preached (1:1415) is gradually becoming the good news about Jesus (1:1).

b)      First: The text is not clear as to what is to follow.

i)       First before the destruction of Jerusalem and its temple (France, Stein).

(1)   cf. Matt 24:14 And this gospel of the kingdom will be preached in the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come.

ii)     First before the Parousia (Evans, Osborne).

iii)   First before you are arrestsed.

c)      All nations:

i)       Not all people groups. Its misused by missionaries who argue that Christ cannot return until the gospel is preached to all people groups (Osborne).

ii)     Nations of the Roman Empire. This was begun in Jesus ministry to Gentiles; hinted at in 11:17 (My house will be called a house of prayer for all nations); confirmed by the confession of the Roman centurion. It was fulfilled in Paul. Paul writes that the gospel had been made known to all nations (Rom 16:26; Col 1:6, 23).

(1)   The temple (and the central role that Israel plays in Gods plan) will not be destroyed until the gospel has gone out to the Gentiles. And the new temple will then comprise the elect from all over the world (13:27).

6)      Say whatever is given you in that hour: Promise is given to disciples on trial, not lazy preachers.

7)      Brother will deliver up brother to death : Recalls Mic 7:6. Familial hostility against those who decided to become believers.

8)      Hated by all for my names sake: Hated by all for their association with Jesus.

9)      He who endures to the end (εἰς τέλος) will be saved:

a)      Note that τέλος has no article and it probably means right through without any specific end in mind (France); end of their lives (Stein). Save is used in the spiritual sense. This promise does not concern the end time but is a general call for endurance and assurance that those who persevere will be vindicated.

4.3.3.3       Beginning of the end: Desolating Sacrilege and False Prophets (13:1423) [29091]

1)      Time frame:

a)      *Destruction of temple and Jerusalem (Most)

b)      Great tribulation before the Parousia (Edwards, Osborne, Evans, Garland)

2)      Issues: Difficult passage.

a)      Period spans from the appearance of the desolating sacrilege (13:14) to the destruction of the city by Rome with the destruction of the temple. However, there is no agreement what the desolating sacrilege refers to.

i)       τὸ βδέλυγμα τῆς ἐρημώσεως (LXX Dan 12:11); βδέλυγμα ἐρημώσεως (Thdt Dan 12:11; LXX Dan 11:31); βδέλυγμα ἠφανισμένον (Thdt 11:31). See also Dan 9:27. In all these cases, it refers to the cessation of regular burnt offering and the desecration of the temple sanctuary.

(1)   Abomination of desolation in Judaism:

(a)   Refers to the action of the little horn (8:9), Antiochus Epiphanes, who in 167 BCE threw truth to the ground in destroying Torah scrolls (8:12), abolished the daily sacrifice, and established an abomination of desolation (cf. 1 Macc 1:54; 6:7; 2 Macc 6:15).

(i)     It is probably similar to the profanation of the temple mentioned in Dan (in Daniel, it probably refers to the desecration of the temple by Antiochus Epiphanes in 167 BCE. This is confirmed in 1 Macc 1:54, 59 which represents the installation of the altar of Zeus over the altar of burnt offering).

(b)   Actual referent is debated: image | altar for pagan sacrifice | sacrifices themselves | sacred stones

(c)   Exegetical issue:

(i)     Dan 8:12. Does this desolation occur in or because of rebellion. Most read this as in (an act) of rebellion (i.e. Antiochus). But note also that 1 Macc 1:1543, 2 Macc 7:18, 32 note Israels idolatrous culpability.

(ii)  Other prophetic texts such as Jeremiah and Ezekiel see Israels idolatrous abominations as polluting Yahwehs temple (see CNTUOT).

(2)   Referent in Mark

(a)   Atrocities committed by Zealots under John of Gischala and Eleazar son of Simon in 6768 CE (J.W. 4.3.68; 4.3.9) (Stein; Witherington).

(b)   Antichrist, the man of lawlessness 2 Thess 2:34 (Edwards, Evans)

(i)     Using sensus plenior. Although Mark and Jesus may be referring to the destruction of Jerusalem, there is a deeper reference to the Parousia.

(c)   Series of events: CNTUOT

(i)     Its difficult to be overly precise. As with all prophetic language, the concern is the significance of the event, not an exact description. Thus, it could refer to a series or related, idolatrous events involving several persons and actions that effectively amount to Daniels abomination.

(ii)  In Mark, it is the rebellion of Israels leadership that culminates in Jesus final announcement of the destruction of the temple. Not surprisingly, Jesus cites Jeremiahs Temple Sermon, which explicitly links the sanctuarys desolation (Jer 7:3234; cf. Mark 13:1719) with Israels abomination. This time, it is not Antiochus, but Israels insurrectionist leaders who make war on Gods people and kill the Son of God, and whose actions are likened to the little horns abominations. Thus, the abominations which Jesus warns probably begins with the abuses and rebellion that he saw in his own days, and which culminates in the Zealots takeover of the temple.

(iii)                        If Jesus is the cornerstone of Gods temple, then to crucify him is the supreme act of temple profanation. The tearing of the veil at Jesus death is then a prophetic sign that the temple is effectively dead.

ii)     set up ἑστηκότα: RAP AMS. Even though βδέλυγμα is neuter, Marks use of a masculine should be a construction ad sensum (France), referring to the person responsible for the abomination of desolation.

3)      Let the reader understand (13:14): Probably indicates that the saying about the desolating sacrilege is cryptic.

a)      Mark is written for public church reading and this is a note to the church reader to explain an obscure item.[39]

4)      Flee to the mountains: Recalls what Matthias did when he declared his opposition to Antiochus new policy (2 Macc 5:27).

5)      Pray that this will not take place in winter:

a)      Suggests authenticity because temple was captured in August and destroyed in September.

6)      In those days:

a)      Not t.t. for the last days (Stein).

b)      t.t. for the last days (Edwards).

7)      Such tribulation as has not been from the beginning of creation:

a)      Hyperbolic language for unparalleled suffering, not to be taken literally (France, Stein).

b)      Universal judgment of the eschaton (Osborne).

8)      For the sake of the elect:

a)      If 13:1423 refers to 70 CE: Elect = Jewish Christians.

b)      If 13:1423 refers to the Parousia: Elect = Christian community as a remnant within Israel, recalls prophetic remnant theology (judgment on Gods people and the escape of the remnant or elect).

4.3.3.4       Coming/Going of the Son of Man (13:2427) [292]

1)      Time frame:

a)      *Parousia (Lane, Witherington, Stein, Edwards, Osborne, Evans, Garland)

b)      Destruction of temple and Jerusalem (Frane, Wright)

2)      Emphasis

a)      Assures readers that despite persecution and chaos, they need not fear. The Son of Man will come one day and gather his elect from the ends of the earth.

b)      Theophany of the Son of Man who comes in clouds with great power and glory. This stands in contrast to the OT where God is the subject of the theophany (Stein).

c)      Jesus foreknowledge reveals that he is a great prophet.

 

1)      In those days:

a)      Commonly used to describe a theophany or divine intervention in history for judgment or restoration. Probably not a t.t. with a consistent eschatological meaning (Stein).

b)      Refers to the preceding events associated with the destruction of Jerusalem (Stein).

2)      After that tribulation:

a)      tribulation associated with the destruction of Jerusalem in 13:1423 (Stein).

3)      Sun will be darkened powers in the heavens will be shaken:

a)      Same language in the prophetic literature (Ezek 32:7; Joel 2:10, 31; 3:15; Amos 8:9). Such cosmic language symbolizes political changes within world history with overtones of Gods judgment. What is different is that this language was used by the prophets primarily against Gentile nations that were threatening Israel. Now, however, it is used against Jerusalem. Of course, such language was also used against Israel in Amos 8:9 or Joel 2:10 (locus plague in Judah).

b)      Coming day of the Lord (Isa 13:10; 34:4).

i)       See CNTUOT.

c)      Key issue: What is the referent?

i)       *Events associated with the coming of the Son of Man at the Parousia

ii)     Metaphorical descriptions of the coming of the Son of Man in the destruction of Jerusalem.

(1)   Destruction of Jerusalem and the temple. More than describing the demise of the city, the cosmic language is consistent with the widely held Jewish belief that the temple stood at the center of creation, which originated from Zion. Moreover, as early as Amos, cosmic chaos was seen to be the consequent of Israels failure to obey Torah (CNTUOT).

4)      And then they will see the Son of man coming in clouds with great power and glory:

a)      Destruction of Jerusalem and the vindication and exaltation of the Son of Man (N. T. Wright, France).

i)       Enthronement of the Son of Man to receive everlasting dominion (France)

(1)   Dan 7:13 In my vision at night I looked, and there before me was one like a son of man, coming with the clouds of heaven. He approached the Ancient of Days and was led into his presence. The reference to Dan 7:13 involves the Son of Man going to, not coming from God.

(2)   coming is from the perspective of heaven

b)      *Parousia (Cranfield, Evans, Edwards, Osborne, Stein)

i)       Watts tries to combine both views. He sees this as a Parousia, Jesus second one, but only to Jerusalem, not to the rest of the world. His second coming results in the destruction of the recalcitrant city. The coming of the Son of Man fulfills Gods promise to rescue his people (Zech 2:6; Deut 30:4). But for Mark, the new exodus has already begun, but here, it expands to include those outside the land of Israel who are yet to hear the good news of Yahwehs return to Zion.

5)      Gathering of the elect:

a)      Allusion: Zech 2:6 and Deut 30:4

i)       Zech 2:6

ii)     Deut

b)      Formation of the church (France).

i)       Echoes OT predictions of Jewish exiles gathered back from the ends of the earth. But theres an ironic reversal, instead of extracting Jewish exiles from their places of captivity, this gathering is the inclusion of all peoples from all nations. The elect is now the elect of the Son of Man who are drawn from people of all nations. This then is the fulfillment of 13:10 where the gospel is preached to all nations.

c)      *Rapture of the saints (Osborne, Stein).

4.3.3.5       Lesson of the fig tree (13:2831) [293]

1)      Time frame:

a)      Destruction of temple and Jerusalem (all)

2)      Emphasis

a)      Recognition of Jerusalems destruction through parabolic analogy.

i)       These things will take place within this generation.

b)      Christology: Jesus authoritative pronouncement is seen in Truly, Heaven and earth will pass away but my words will not pass away.

i)       Echoes Isa 40:78. The reliability of Jesus words is no less than Gods words.

(1)   Heaven and earth will pass away:

(a)   Not a prediction of a future passing away of heaven and earth; rather, it just highlights the permanence of Jesus words (France).

(b)   Prediction of a future passing away of heaven and earth (2 Pet 3:7; Rev 20:11; 21:1; Stein).

3)      When you see these things (ταῦτα) taking place This generation will not pass away before all these things (ταῦτα πάντα) take place (13:2930):

a)      // these things (ταῦτα) all these things (ταῦτα πάντα) in 13:4 these things refers to things preceding the destruction of Jerusalem (such as abomination of desolation) rather than the Parousia.

b)      It is near (ἐγγύς ἐστιν) (13:29): probably not he is near (RSV, ESV); rather,

i)       Destruction of Jerusalem and the temple.

ii)     Destruction of temple as harbinger of parousia (Osborne).

c)      This answers the disciples question of the σημεῖον they were looking for (13:4). The sign would be the desolating sacrilege. Just as the budding of the fig tress summer was near, seeing the desolating sacrilege Jerusalems destruction is imminent.

4)      This generation:

a)      If you take it to refer to end time, how do you understand this generation?

i)       Fall of Jerusalem is a paradigm for the end of the world. So, you have multiple fulfillments (Osborne; Edwards).

4.3.3.6       An unknown day and hour: be ready (13:3237) [294]

1)      Time frame:

a)      *Parousia (Most)

b)      Destruction of the temple and Jersualem (Wright)

2)      Emphasis

a)      Need for watchfulness. The unknown day of the parousia demands constant alertness. Even though they are not to misconstrue normal events as indicating the time of Jerusalems destruction, they are still to be alert regarding the return of the Son of Man.

3)      Shift in topic (France)

a)      περὶ δέ signals a change of subject (same as in 1 Cor).

b)      Moreover, the note of uncertainty concerning the day or hour contrasts with the strong affirmation of Truly, I say to you

4)      Why doesnt the Son know the time? Hard to know.

a)      Emphasis in Mark is not to teach a Christological truth.

b)      Perhaps, his understanding of Son of God does not include the full divinity of later incarnational theology.

c)      Perhaps, he would have felt comfortable with later kenotic theology.

d)      From systematic theology, see notes on sof-proposed-revision-article-4.docx in North Sub Doctrine Class under the secction Hypostatic Union.

5)      Parable (13:3436)

a)      Return of the lord of the house (ὁ κύριος τῆς οἰκίας) = return of the Son of Man.

b)      The doorkeeper is to watch for the masters return.

i)       Return at night is unusual since travel during the night is not common. But it suggests that extra caution is needed when there is the natural propensity for laxness.

c)      Division of 24 hours in 4 quarters/watches (evening, midnight, cockcrow, morning) is Roman Gentile audience. Jewish system had only 3 watches.

i)       Christian is never off duty.

6)      How does Wright interpret this passage?

 

1)      Pastoral

a)      The overall thrust of this passage calls for watchfulness.

b)      How would you answer those who say that the call for watchfulness that you really need to discern every single sign and read every jot and tiddle?

i)       Nature of apocalyptic literature is not to be precise, but to set the scene.

4.4         Setting the scene for the passion (14:111) [305307]

1)      Martin Khler: Mark is a passion narrative with an extended introduction.

a)      From Mark Intro.docx

i)       Overly simplistic, but it is a reminder that the cross of Christ is central, and the action rushes towards the cross.

ii)     In the last 3 chapters, narrative time slows down. We now have a day-by-day and hour-by-hour account of the last week.

iii)   Narration from Jesus entry into Jerusalem until the end occupies 1/3 of the gospel.

2)      Emphasis

a)      Contrast between insiders and outsiders. Those who are thought to be insiders within Gods kingdom (i.e. the Jerusalem religious authorities) reject the kingdom of God and seek to kill Jesus. On the other hand, those who are outsiders (a leper and an unnamed woman) reveal by their actions that they are in the kingdom of God (Stein). Moreover, the location of Bethany is outside Jerusalem (Edwards).

b)      *Sandwich: The womans actions (14:39) are sandwiched between that of the religious authorities & Judas (14:12, 1011), heightening the contrast between them.

i)       Thread of death runs through: authorities plot to arrest Jesus and kill him || woman prepares Jesus body for burial || Judas agrees to betray Jesus

ii)     Her love || Judas treachery

iii)   For her faith, she sacrifices $ || Judas sacrifices his faith for $.

iv)   She becomes an example of what it means to follow Jesus wholeheartedly.

c)      Christology

i)       Jesus places himself above caring for the poor (=loving your neighbor as yourself). We can understand this statement if it was from God, but not from a mere mortal. Again, this raises the question, What kind of man is this?

3)      Double sandwich (France). But I think that its better just to see this as 1 sandwich of the anointing of Jesus between the attempts to kill Jesus.

a)      The Passover hints at the impending sacrificial death of Jesus.

b)      14:1a Passover is coming

i)       14:1b2 Chief priests plot the removal of Jesus

(1)   14:39 A woman anoints Jesus in advance for his burial

ii)     14:1011 Judas provides the answer for the chief priests

c)      14:12 Preparing the Passover

4.4.1        Jesus death is premeditated: Passover and the priests (14:12) [305]

1)      Passover

a)      Lambs are slaughtered on the afternoon of Nisan 14.

b)      Passover meal is held after sunset, i.e. on the next day Nisan 15.

c)      Feast of the unleavened bread follows on directly from the Passover and lasts for 7 days Nisan 1521 (Num 28:1516).

2)      Population of Jerusalem is typically about 30,000. During the feast, it can go up to 180,000 (Jeremias). Given the large crowds, riots can easily happen. Thus, Jewish authorities would be glad if Judas offered to hand Jesus over privately.

3)      After 2 days: This date can be fluid, since Mark uses after 3 days to refer to the time from: Late Fri afternoon (Day 1) Fri 6 PM Sat 6 PM (Day 2) Sat 6 PM Sun morning (Day 3). (Stein)

a)      *Interpreted inclusively, i.e. the day after 13 Nisan (Tue 6 PM Wed 6 PM).

b)      Interpreted exclusively, i.e. 12 Nisan (Mon 6 PM Tue 6 PM).

c)      Collins suggests that Mark departed from Jewish calculation of days from sunset to sunset and substituted the reckoning of days from sunrise to sunrise to make the account intelligible to a wider audience.

4.4.2        Anointing of Jesus (14:39) [306]

1)      Matt 26:613 || Mark 14:39 || John 12:18; Luke 7:3650 is sufficiently different.

2)      Luke is different: Set in Galilee; host is a Pharisee; woman is a sinner; objection is her immorality rather than her extravagance.

3)      Comparison with John 12:18

a)      Similarities:

i)       location is Bethany.

ii)     pure nard

iii)   reaction: perfume should be sold and given to the poor

iv)   300 denari.

v)      dedication of love by the woman serves as a foil to the treachery of the Jewish leaders and the greed of Judas.

b)      Differences

i)       John: Placed on Sat (before triumphal entry) || Mark: Placed after triumphal entry

ii)     John: Owner of the house is not stated, but Lazarus is the host || Mark: House belongs to Simon the leper.

iii)   John: tied to the raising of Lazarus || Mark: not tied to Lazarus

iv)   John: anoint Jesus' feet followed by wiping Jesus' feet with the woman's hair || Mark: anoint Jesus' head

c)      Conclusion: Lukes account is sufficiently distinct that it is a different. As for Matt-Mark & John

i)       2 separate incidents that had their details mixed.

ii)     *1 incident:

(1)   Evangelists (Mark-Matt) typically order their accounts topically, rather than chronologically. FG offers a far more precise chronological structure than any of the Synoptic Gospels.[40] By putting this story here, FG contrasts 2 responses to the raising of Lazarus: devotion of Mary serves as a foil to the decision of the leaders to kill Jesus.

(a)   Marks arrangement is to sandwich this messianic anointing with the plot by Jewish authorities and Judas visit to them.[41]

(b)   FG is probably more historical. It may be better to anoint Jesus as Messiah in Bethany before riding into Jerusalem the next day. (But this sounds like a literary argument).

(c)   However, do note that FG reduces the messianic significance of this event by having the woman anoint Jesus feet rather than head.

(2)   If the jar was full, it would have been too much to pour just on the head.

(3)   In Matt and Mark, the perfume was poured on his body in anticipation of his burial, more than just the head.

(4)   Matt and Mark refer to head to show that Jesus is being honored, anointed as a king. John could have done the same. But by referring to Jesus feet, emphasis is placed on the self-perceived unworthiness of the woman. She thus serves as a foil to the authorities who want to kill Jesus, and as a foil to the disciples, who needs to be taught to wash one anothers feet in the next chapter.

(5)   Why her hair? Not sure. This would have appeared scandalous, but probably shows her humility.

(1)   Different names (Lazarus and Simon the Leper). Some speculate that Simon the Leper was the father of Lazarus and the sisters.

4)      Significance of the action

a)      The anointing of the Messiah, comparable to the anointing of kings in the Hebrew Bible.

i)       Cons

(1)   It would be surprising that the Messiah would be anointed by a woman, but she might have been seen in the role of a prophet like Samuel. If so, this is ironic. A woman, not a priest or a prophet, anoints Jesus in the home of a leper. She might have done this in the hope that it is time for God to intervene in the affairs of Israel with this king.

(2)   Anointing the head in the context of feasts was a common custom at feasts.

(3)   Messianic significance is not explicit in Marks text.

(4)   Mark interprets the event in terms of death and burial rather than messianic commissioning.

ii)     Pros

(1)   Story placed in the Markan sandwich of plot by Jewish authority to kill Jesus (14:12) and Judas visit to the chief priests in order to offer to betray Jesus (14:1011).

(a)   Contrasts devotion and faith of the unnamed women || treachery and faithlessness of the named disciple Judas.

(i)     Again, its the little people that demonstrate true discipleship.

(b)   Perhaps Judas reported this anointing which may have led the Jewish authorities to speculate that Jesus and his disciples are planning an imminent messianic uprising.

 

1)      Description of the anointing (14:3)

a)      Since lepers were barred from society, his hosting of the dinner he had been healed of his leprosy, possibly by Jesus himself.

b)      Breaking of alabaster jar: Not because that was the only way to pour out the perfume, but total outpouring of the perfume.

2)      Rebuke by some (14:45)

a)      Why was the ointment thus wasted?

b)      Given to the poor: Passover was especially a time in which the poor were to be remembered.

c)      Matt 26:8 notes that it was the disciples; John 12:4 puts it as Judas Iscariot. Marks some do not protect the disciples but places emphasis on the objection.

3)      Jesus defense of the woman (14:68)

a)      She has done a good thing.

i)       Their concern was that the ointment could have been put to more good had it been sold. But Jesus calls it a beautiful deed (καλὸν ἔργον). The superiority of the womans action is precisely because of the occasion, that Jesus will not always be there to receive it.

(1)   In rabbinic logic, almsgiving was considered to be less praiseworthy than burying the dead because the former was done to the living (and could be done anytime), while burying the dead had to be done when the need arose. (t. Pea 4:9; b. Sukk. 49b In 3 aspects are acts of loving kindness greater than act of charity an act of charity is done only for the living. An act of loving kindness may be done either for the living or for the dead). The womans action was commendable because it was done to one who was as good as dead.

(2)   After Jesus death, where were the complaining followers when he needed to be buried? Unlike the disciples of JB, who claimed his body after execution, the disciples of Jesus are missing in action. According to Mark, Jesus was hurriedly buried by a stranger with no mention of any anointing for the corpse. This anointing before his death will suffice. The later attempt by other women to anoint the body after Jesus burial is not realized because he receives a greater anointing from God (NIVAC).

b)      Its unlikely that the women knew or understood Jesus imminent death. Mark, however, states that her act did serve this purpose.

4)      Memorializing of what the woman did (14:9)

a)      But if memorialized, why is her name not mentioned? Protective anonymity, because she has done a politically subversive act in anointing Jesus as a messiah.

b)      Mentioned in FG because she has presumably died.

 

4.4.3        The priests and Judas (14:1011) [307]

1)      We have no clear indication why Judas betrayed Jesus.

2)      Judas betrayal contrasts with the love and devotion of the unnamed woman. The unnamed woman gives up $ for Jesus, but Judas gives up Jesus for $.

a)      Coins paid to Judas (Matt 26:15) were probably silver shekels of Tyre or Antiochia. 30 shekels = 120 denarii (laborers salary for 4 months).

 

Application

1)      How much is too much devotion to Jesus? (NIVAC)

a)      The disciples seem to suggest: A little oil, even expensive perfume, is fine; but to break open a whole jar seems too extravagant.

b)      Itll be helpful to compare this with the widow and her two copper coins (12:4144). In 12:44 They all gave out of their wealth; but she, out of her poverty, put in everythingall she had to live on.

c)      Both women stand in contrast to men: the widow is an antithesis to the teachers of the law, who plunder widows houses, and the rich who only give out of their abundance. This anonymous women is the opposite of Judas who betrays Jesus for $ and those tightfisted bystanders who mouth pious clichs about giving to the poor but take no action.

2)      Caring for the poor

a)      Does the statement The poor you will always have with you downplay almsgiving?

i)       Jesus is not implying that nothing could be done to eliminate poverty. The text underscores the need for total devotion to Jesus. But if we respond to Jesus properly, we will take care of the poor.

ii)     Jesus statement of Deut 15:11 There will always be poor people in the land may also be seen as a rebuke. For Deut 15:4 says However, there need be no poor people among you, for in the land the LORD your God is giving you to possess as your inheritance, he will richly bless you, 5 if only you fully obey the LORD your God and are careful to follow all these commands I am giving you today. Thus, if Gods people were obedient to God, there would be no poor.

b)      How do we show lavish giving to Christ?

i)       Majestic buildings? Lavish pageantry?

ii)     At times, one should instead give this money to missions or to help the poor.

3)      Insider-outsider

a)      It is not those that are ostensibly evil, but the religious authorities and one of Jesus intimates that played a central part in Jesus death. As the church looks for threats from without, it mustnt ignore threats from within who believe they may be acting in the best interests of Gods cause on earth.

b)      Its a tragic mistake for those in power to believe that they are in control; its also a mistake for us to think that our sacrificial devotion is wasteful or insignificant? Who knows how God will use it?

c)      Why did Judas betray Jesus?

i)       No reason is given. FG identifies Judas as a thief. Other scholars think that Judas was a zealot and wanted to precipitate actions that would force Jesus to set kingdom events in motion.

ii)     But Mark provides no reason. If so, then the implication is that every disciple is potentially another Judas. Attempts to find the reasons why Judas did what he did is a diversion that prevents us from looking at our own potential betrayal.

4.5         Last Supper and Jesus prediction of denial of the disciples (14:1231)

1)      Sandwich

a)      Judas betrayal (14:1011, 1821)

i)       Last supper (14:22-25)

b)      Denial of the disciples (14:2631)

2)      Look at Was the Last Supper a Passover Meal.docx

4.5.1        Last Supper (14:1225) [308, 310, 311]

1)      Emphasis (Stein).

a)      Soteriological understanding of Jesus death.

i)       Ransom for many.

b)      Eschatology

i)       Now (This is the blood of the new covenant; 14:24) and not yet (I will not drink; 14:25).

(1)   Jesus inaugurates the new covenant (14:24) that comes with the kingdom of God, and he in some way also consummates the kingdom (14:25).

c)      We can trust that Jesus gave his life as a ransom for many, and that we will one day eat and drink in the kingdom of God.

d)      Sovereignty of God and human responsibility.

i)       Son of Man goes as it is written of him death of Jesus is divinely ordained.

ii)     Woe to that man better for that man human responsibility.

 

1)      Preparation for the Passover (14:1217) [308]

a)      1st day of unleavened bread, when they sacrificed the Passover lamb

i)       Technically, Passover lamb was typically sacrificed on Nisan 14, and the 1st day of Unleavened bread is Nisan 15, the day that the Passover was eaten. But since the festival was one entire complex, it was also common to call Nisan 14 as the beginning of the Feast of Unleavened Bread (See Josephus J.W. 2.1.3; Ant. 14.2.1; 17.9.3; 18.2.2; 20.5.3; Stein).

b)      Instructions // those given in securing the colt.

i)       Jesus probably prearranged the accommodations. For example, it was uncommon for a man to carry a jar of water since it was a chore that women did a prearranged signal. Why this secrecy? Judas had already agreed to betray Jesus (see sequence in Matt 26; Mark 14). So this prearranged signal was done so that Judas would not even know about the location. Jesus did not want to be arrested before he shared the Passover meal.[42]

ii)     May be intended to show that Jesus knows everything in advance and has total control of the situation.

2)      Prediction of betrayal (14:1821) [310]

a)      Prediction and woe (14:1821)

i)       One who is eating with me: Allude to Ps 41:9, recalls the righteous sufferer.

ii)     In Matt 26:25, Jesus answers Judas question Is it I? in the affirmative. This was probably said privately and not overheard by the others (Jesus was sitting between Judas and John), given the lack of response from the other disciples.

iii)   Woe pronounced by Jesus: compatibilism, divine sovereignty (the Son of Man goes as it is written of him) and human responsibility.

3)      Words of institution (14:2225) [311]

a)      Breaking of bread (14:22)

i)       Take, this is my body: As the broken bread was shared, they may have begun to realize that they were participating in the significance of his death.

ii)     Stein suggests that the breaking of the bread does not refer to Jesus body being broken since no bones of Jesus were broken. Breaking the bread was just part of the process of distributing breading during the meal.

iii)   Luke has cup-bread; Matt-Mark has bread-cup. But note that the Passover ritual Jews today even celebrate has 4 cups. This suggests that Luke is referring to an earlier cup that Matt-Mark omit.

iv)   Jesus uses an article of food so common that the disciples can never again recline at a meal, take bread, bless it, and break it, without thinking of the last night with Jesus. The disciples can never eat another meal without thinking about what Jesus did for them on the cross (NIVAC)

(1)   Disciples failed to understand about bread throughout Jesus ministry

(a)   6:3637, Jesus told them to give the crowds something to eat. Their response, That would take more than half a years wages! Are we to go and spend that much on bread and give it to them to eat? But Jesus will supply the bread.

(i)     Later that night, they crossed the sea and Jesus came to them walking on the sea. They were terrified for they had not understood about the loaves; their hearts were hardened (6:52).

(b)   8:4, second feeding incident in Gentile territory. Disciples asked, But where in this remote place can anyone get enough bread to feed them?

(i)     8:1618.

(2)   Bread is a symbol of Jesus mission, and the disciples do not understand.

b)      Blessing of cup (14:23-24)

i)       14:23 suggests a common cup (France) oneness.

ii)     My blood of the covenant:

(1)   My blood

(a)   This would have been scandalous for Jews. Gen 9:4 forbade the consumption of blood. See also Acts 15:20, 29. The law forbade drinking of blood because it was the life and because it had been ordained of God as a means of atonement. Any animal killed for human consumption had to be drained of all blood before being eaten. Some Jewish scholars claim that these words would have been impossible on the lips of a Jew (NIVAC).

(2)   Echoes Exod 24:8.

(a)   OT context (CNTUOT):

(i)     Confirmation of the covenant. The people agree to abide by all of Yahwehs words (24:3, 7). Moses next sets up 12 witness pillars and offers sacrifices, probably signifying atonement and the resulting well-being. Moses dashes half of the sacrificial blood upon the altar of the presence (24:6) and, after reading from the book of the covenant (24:7), dashes the other half upon the people (24:8), thus eternally binding Israel to Yahweh.

(ii)  This covenant is Yahwehs initiative and Yahwehs presence stands at the center. Thus, following the covenant ratification meal on the mountain (24:911) and the giving of the tables, the remaining 1/3 of the book largely concerns preparations for the tabernacle whereby God can dwell among his people (25:131:17; 35:140:38).

(b)   Judaism:

(i)     Possibly also echoes LXX Zech 9:11 where God promises to redeem his people from exile because of the blood of my covenant with you.

(c)   Mark: See below

(3)   Note too that this meal cements covenantal loyalty.

iii)   τὸ ἐκχυννόμενον ὑπὲρ πολλῶν picks up the vicarious language already present in 10:45, and recalls language of the final section of the prophecy of Isa 53:1112, where the redemptive significance is strong.

(1)   Mark (ὑπὲρ πολλῶν) is synonymous with Matt (περὶ πολλῶν).

(2)   Pouring out of blood is the language of sacrifice (Exod 24:6).

(3)   Does blood have reference to the blood of the original Passover lamb (Lau)

(a)   *Perhaps: Shedding of the blood of the Passover lamb commemorated the Exodus event since the death of the lamb was part of the means by which God redeemed Israel out of Egypt so as to form them into a covenant people.

(b)   No: Notes on 1 Pet 1:19. Does not refer to Passover. ἀμνοῦ ἀμώμου is not used in the original description of the Passover lang (but how about Exod 12:5?); blood of the paschal lamb was not the means by which Israel was redeemed from Egypt, it was the power of God

(4)   Marks use of Exod 24:8, Isa 53:1112 (CNTUOT):

(a)   Jesus makes himself the focus of Israels great memorial meal, shifting the focus from the past to his future death.

(b)   Jesus combines Passover (Exodus) with Exod 24 (Confirmation of covenant). Passover was not an end in itself. It pointed to the Exod 24 covenant. By combining the two, Jesus references the founding moments of Israel, and reconfigures it around himself, in the context of a new exodus and a newly reconstituted Israel.

(c)   Ignoring the deaths of all the righteous martyrs before him, Jesus claims that his death alone is efficacious in bearing Israels punishment (Isa 53:56)

(d)   Similarities

(i)     God initiates the 1st covenant || Jesus initiates the new covenant.

(ii)  Representatives of Israel celebrated the 1st covenant with a meal in the presence of God || The 12, representing restored Israel, celebrate a meal with Jesus

(iii)                        1st covenant was sealed by a blood sacrifice || new covenant is sealed by a sacrifice and shed blood

(e)   Exod 24:8 implied Torah obedience (24:7). But obedience is not mentioned in Mark. Nevertheless, the story of Mark suggests that obedience can now only be fulfilled in relation to Jesus.

(f)    Theologically, the people of God now find their vocational identity as his kingdom of priest in loyalty to Jesus, the messianic Son.

c)      Significance of bread and wine

i)       The bread and the cup are 2 ways of expressing the total giving of Jesus for the sake of the many.

ii)     They all drank from the one cup. Drinking the cup of someone meant entering into a communion relationship with that person, to the point that one shared that persons destiny, good or evil (Ps 16:45).

(1)   Jesus asked James and John if they were able to drink the cup that he would drink and then assured them that they would (10:3839).

iii)   *Blood sealed or inaugurated a covenant (Exod 24).

d)      Promise (14:25)

i)       No more: Farewell banquet, linking his death to the consummation of Gods kingdom.

ii)     I drink it new: Use of new.

(1)   Adverbial: I will drink it anew (Gundry)

(2)   Adjectival:

(a)   New wine (France), expectation of messianic banquet when God makes things new. Moreover, new wine prosperity and good living (Gen 27:28; Deut 33:28; Joel 3:18; Zech 9:17). Furthermore, new also signifies what God does in his ultimate salvation (France).

iii)   Each NT account of the Lords Supper contains a positive statement of the future (Mark 14:25; Matt 26:29; Luke 22:16; 1 Cor 11:26). Celebration of the Lords Supper looks back as well as forward, with joyous anticipation of the day when believers will partake of the messianic banquet.

iv)   Kingdom of God. Previous references envisage the arrival of the kingdom of God with the ministry of Jesus. Here, it is future. As noted in 4:3032, the development of the kingdom of God is a gradual process.

4.5.1.1       Description of meal

1)      Description of meal. See Lane.

a)      Pronouncement of blessing, first of festival then of the wine.

b)      Drink 1st cup of wine.

c)      Food brought in, consisting of unleavened bread, bitter herbs, greens, stewed fruit and roast lamb.

d)      Son asks why this night is distinguished from all other nights.

e)      Head of the family responds by recalling biblical account of redemption from Egypt. This leads to praise of God and anticipation of future redemption.

f)       Drink 2nd cup of wine.

g)      Head of family takes bread and pronounce blessing over it. Break bread and hand it to those at the table who eat it with bitter herbs and stewed fruit.

h)      Followed by the meal proper, beginning with eating the roasted lamb.

i)       Drink 3rd cup with a prayer of thanksgiving and singing the 2nd part of the Hallel.

j)       4th cup of wine concludes the Passover.

 

1)      See Mishnah (m. Pesahim x.19), about 200 CE. From Stanton, The Gospels and Jesus

2)      The Preliminary Course

a)      Blessing (Kiddush) spoken over the first cup of wine.

b)      Dish of green herbs, bitter herbs and fruit sauce

c)      Serving of the meal and mixing of the second cup of wine.

3)      The Passover Liturgy

a)      The Passover narrative (haggadah, based on Exod 12) was recited by the head of the household, in response to the youngest sons question, Why is this night different from all other nights?

b)      Drinking the second cup of wine

c)      Singing of Ps 113

4)      The Main Meal

a)      Grace spoken over the unleavened bread, bitter herbs (Exod 12:8)

b)      Meal of lamb, unleavened bread, bitter herbs

c)      Grace over the third cup of wine

5)      Conclusion

a)      Singing of Ps 11418 (the great hallel)

b)      Praise over the fourth cup of wine.

 

Implication (NIVAC)

1)      The annual ritual to have a Passover seder the Thu evening of Holy Week

a)      Garland thinks that it is misguided and misunderstands the thrust of Marks presentation of the Lords Supper.

b)      Marks recounting of the meal ignores Passover elements. There is no mention of the paschal lamb, the stewed fruit, the bitter herbs, the unleavened bread, or deliverance from Egypt. The Lords Supper was not celebrated in the early church as an annual ritual, but each Lords Day. Because the Passover of Israel is fulfilled in Jesus, the disciples will never need a ritual lamb again.

c)      For Christians to celebrate Passover subtly undermines the significance of Christs death and the meaning he attached to this meal.

d)      I dont think that this need to be the case, if we remind ourselves of what Christ achieved in the Passover (Lau).

Passover

Lords Supper

In the old age of law

In the new age of the kingdom

The great festival meal celebrating the birth of Gods people.

The new celebratory meal of the birth of Gods people.

Participants associated themselves with deliverance and the old covenant

Participants associate themselves with redemption and the new covenant

Looks back to the Exodus and forward to Gods salvation

Looks back to the cross, which brings salvation, and forward to the final realization of Gods kingdom

 

1)      Remembering the Lords Supper

a)      Remembering is not just recall, but to let the significance of that event control the will and affect our present reality.

i)       Past (the event) Present (what is the significance of that even in our lives) Future (we anticipate the day when we drink it new again).

b)      Significance

i)       We remember that God has established the beginning of the new covenant with God

ii)     We experience Jesus death for us and the power of our sins

iii)   We proclaim the Lords death until he returns (1 Cor 11:26).

iv)   A reminder that we live with eternitys values, and not with the values of the world.

c)      Not a magical ritual.

i)       Did Judas partake of the bread and cup? Theres no evidence that he didnt. If so, it had no salvific effect. The bread and the cup must be internalized. The new covenant must be written on the hearts of Gods people.

d)      Examination

i)       The first Lords Supper was filled with tension, sweaty palms, lumps in their throat. Disciples were challenged to examine themselves. In the same way, Mark presents a warning to the readers to examine themselves in the same way that the first disciples did. Perhaps, we should ask ourselves, Surely, not I?

ii)     Instead of looking at watches and wondering about dinner or lunch, we should examine our own lives whether we have betrayed Jesus in the previous week or in the next. Each should contemplate his own life and confess all the ways we have betrayed the Lord and acknowledge such weaknesses. If the disciples could betray Jesus, all of us have the potential to do so. This self-examination is also called for in Paul (1 Cor 11:2729). We are worthy of the Lords Supper when we recognize how unworthy we are; we feel its power when we recognize that Jesus accepts us despite our unworthiness.

iii)   Warning against egocentricity? Disciples all asked whether it is I? Did they care about the rest? None of them expressed any concern that Jesus will be betrayed; none express any concern for the traitor?

(1)   Drinking from one cup.

(2)   Jesus gives his life for others. The disciples show that they care only about themselves. The Lords Supper is a time when we can heal our broken relationships.

e)      The Lords Supper as a rite, and as a meal

i)       Viewing the Lords Supper only as a rite can lead to abuse as to who can officiate it, who may participate.

ii)     Its better to celebrate the Lords Supper in the context of a meal (NIVAC)

(1)   Problems with it being tied to a mealsee 1 Cor 11.

2)      Contextualization

a)      Should we substitute the elements with crackers and soda?

b)      Should we substitute the elements with grape juice?

4.5.2        Prediction of the disciples failure (14:2631) [315]

1)      Prediction and fulfillment (France)

a)      A: Prediction of betrayal by one disciple (14:1821)

i)       Passover (14:22-24)

b)      B: Prediction of desertion by all the 12 (14:2628)

c)      C: Prediction of denial by Peter (14:2931)

i)       Prayer in Gethsemane (14:3242)

d)      A: Fulfillment of predicted betrayal by Judas (14:4349)

e)      B: Fulfillment of predicted desertion by the 12

i)       Sanhedrin trial (14:5365)

f)       C: Fulfillment of predicted denial by Peter.

2)      Emphasis

a)      Failure of the disciples.

i)       Promise of restoration (14:28). Provides comfort for those who have failed the Lord that they will receive forgiveness and restoration.

b)      Control of events by Jesus.

i)       His predictions show that the events are according to divine purpose. The events are not to be interpreted as a victory for the evil forces but as part of the divine plan as written in Scripture.

 

1)      Zech 13:79 (CNTUOT)

a)      OT Context:

i)       Yahweh will strike my shepherd, scattering the flock. Only a remnant of the land will survive, but after being refined by Yahweh, they will call on him and he will reconstitute the covenant with them.

ii)     Difficulty: Who is the shepherd? Why is he struck? When?

(1)   Worthless shepherd | Enigmatic but presumably righteous future leader | Messianic Davidic figure whose suffering leads to Israels final restoration.

iii)   Zech is not clear. We must admit that we know only that the shepherd is a strong leader, that his being struck probably happens after the return when the nation is afflicted with corrupt leadership (chaps. 1112), and that it results in the scattering of the flock with a view to producing a purified remnant that is truly dependent on Yahweh and so facilitates the eschatological renewal of the covenant (CNTUOT).

b)      Mark: Zechariah foresaw that a postexilic Israel led by corrupt shepherds would require drastic action if Jerusalem and Gods people were to attain their calling. Marks Jesus saw it unfolding in his death.

i)       I will strike divine necessity

ii)     Sheep scattered disciples will be forced to admit that they are like the little ones (Zech 13:7b; cf. Mark 9:4248) who will stumble.

iii)   But as in Zech, Gods purpose will stand. But in a surprising twist, this shepherd will be resurrected to go ahead of his purified remnant.

iv)   Ecclesiologically: the remnant is not national Israel but Israel gathered around and in covenant with him.

v)      Christologically, the shepherd is Jesus, although the identity is not clear in the Torah.

vi)   Last Supper scene has many allusions to Zech 914 (NIVAC)

(1)   Blood of the covenant (Mark 14:24/Zech 9:11)

(2)   that day, the kingdom of God (Mark 14:25/Zech 14:4, 9)

(3)   Mount of Olives (Mark 14:25/Zech 14:4)

(4)   Resurrection and restoration of the sheep (Mark 14:28/Zech 13:89)

(5)   This suggests that Jesus last night on earth is the eschatological testing spoken by Zech. Gods shepherd will be struck and his people will be tested to the breaking point. The use of I will strike the shepherd shows divine initiative. What happens is not a travesty of justice outside Gods sovereign control. The blow lays on him the iniquity of us all. Some will perish, but the remnant will be refined, purified, and restored. Jesus will re-gather them.

vii) Function

(1)   Jesus sees his own suffering and subsequent vindication in terms of judgment and restoration (scattering and regathering of Israel). What happens to Jesus is a microcosm of what will happen to his disciples and to Israel. The times before the end was the messianic woes. These woes are to fall upon Gods people as a precursor to the final manifestation of KOG.
