ii)     Nothing unusual to end with γάρ, and several examples of this is found in Greek literature.

iii)   Ending of 16:8 fits well with the motif of astonishment and fear found through this gospel (Lane).

iv)   Longer ending has vocabulary different from that found in the rest of Mark.

v)      Mary Magdalene is identified as the one from whom Jesus had cast out 7 demons (cf. Luke 8:2), although she was already introduced in 15:40, 47; 16:1 without any such description.

b)      Purpose

i)       Resolution of the crisis occurs outside of the gospel narrative. Jesus promise of the re-gathering of the disciples are promised and fulfilled (outside the narrative). Earliest readers did not fret, Oh those foolish women who never told the good news. Now, no one will ever know what happened!

(1)   In the same way, Jesus promise of the Spirits presence in the midst of persecution (13:913) and of his return are to be trusted for they too will be fulfilled (Green, Cambridge Companion to the Gospels, 155).

ii)     *Marks open-ended story leaves it for the reader to work out the implications for themselves. The ending therefore functions like one of Jesus own parable, where the hearer is forced to go on thinking (Best).

(1)   Forces us to ask whether we will go to Galilee and meet him there.

(2)   The issue is then not what those first women did, but what we will do now that we have been informed of the news? Will we flee in fear and become silent? Will we obediently follow Jesus to Galilee and tell others about him? The ending leaves readers with unfinished business to proclaim the gospel. Who will tell the story? Will we join in the continuation of the story?

iii)   *Challenges reader to become the perfect disciple and fulfill what the disciples and women failed to do (Tolbert)

(1)   Forces us to admit of our own fear and silence.

 

Application

1)      Christians after the resurrection must still live with ambiguity

a)      In the present, we still have to believe in Jesus resurrection based on hearsay evidence. We only have eyewitness reports to confirm the resurrection, no scientific proof. How will we know for sure what they say is true? Like the first readers of this gospel, we have only the reports from the eyewitness to confirm the resurrection. Only at the end of time when Christ returns will all ambiguity be eliminated.

2)      The last scene where the narrative speaks of Jesus speaks and acting directly is on the cross, rather than on his resurrection. Surely, this mas was the Son of God comes when Jesus dies on the cross, not at the empty tomb.

a)      While the resurrection is important, we cannot neglect the suffering of the cross. Nonetheless, many Jews died, but only one was resurrected; many so-called Messiahs died, but only one was resurrected.

3)      The fulfillment of this promise to go to Galilee (fulfilled outside the text) suggests that Jesus other promises will come true as well.

a)      John the Baptist prophesied that the one coming after him would baptize with the Holy Spirit (1:8). Mark does not narrate the fulfillment of this prophecy, but the readers know it has come true because they experienced this baptism for themselves.

b)      Jesus promised Peter and Andrew that he would make them fishers of men (1:15).

c)      Jesus promised Peter that those who made sacrifices to follow him will receive a 100x more and in the age to come, eternal life (10:2930).

d)      He promised that the gospel will be preached to all the nations before the end comes (13:10).

e)      He promised that the womans extravagant anointing of him for his burial will be remembered wherever the gospel is preached (14:9).

f)       He assured his disciples that he will drink from the fruit of the vine anew in the kingdom of God (14:25)

g)      He promised the high priest and his council that they would see the Son of Man sitting at the right hand of the Mighty One and coming on the clouds of heaven (14:62)

4)      Failure of the disciples

a)      All of Jesus followers, male and female, falter. If the disciples could not come to terms with his death, the woman could not come to terms with his resurrected life.

b)      At this time when Mark was written, Mark and his readers probably held Peter and the disciples as saintly witnesses. But Marks portrayal of the failure of the disciples shows us that witness to Jesus does not come from our own impetus or strength. Mark is offering a story of hope based on the initial failure of the most famous followers of Jesus and a second chance of them. Mark may have in mind readers who failed initially or become discouraged by the thought of the cross. At the same time, he is issuing a warning against the danger of falling way from faith and being overconfident.

c)      Discipleship is established by Gods call and can only be sustained by Gods power and mercy.

5           Notes

1)      For Jewish interpretation of Dan 7, see France, Jesus and the OT, 17983, 18588.


[1] Guelich takes it that as has been written (1:2) should go with beginning Thus, Mark opens by stating that the beginning occurs as has been written. Since Isaiahs promise underlies the coming of the Messiah, then 1:115 represents the beginning of the gospel about God, as has been written by the prophet Isaiah.

[2] See http://craigaevans.com/Priene%20art.pdf.

[3] For the Greek text of the whole inscription, see W. Dittenberger, ed., Orientis Graecae Inscriptiones Selectae (2 vols., Leipzig: S. Hirzel, 1903-5; repr. Hildesheim: Olms, 1960) 2.48-60 [ = OGIS 458]. See also L. R. Taylor, The Divinity of the Roman Emperor (APAMS 1; New York: Arno, 1931; repr. Chico: Scholars Press, 1975) 273; V. Ehrenberg and A. H. M. Jones, Documents Illustrating the Reigns of Augustus and Tiberius (2nd ed., Oxford: Clarendon, 1955) 82. For discussion of this famous inscription, see A. Deissmann, Light from the Ancient East (New York: Harper & Row, 1927) 366; G. Pfohl (ed.), Griechische Inschriften als Zeugnisse des privaten und ffentlichen Lebens (Munich: Heimeran, 1966; rev. ed., 1980), 134-35; H. Koester, Ancient Christian Gospels: Their History and Development (Philadelphia: Trinity Press International, 1990), 3-4.

[4] See Green, Cambridge of the Gospels, 145.

[5] ἔννυχος: pert. to the period between sunset and sunrise, at night *in the early morning, when it was still quite dark (BDAG).

[6] For Jewish reverence of the Sabbath, see E. P. Sanders, Jewish Law from Jesus to the Mishnah (1990): 623.

[7] When midrash was applied to legal material, it was called halakah; when applied to other material, it was called haggadah. Halachic midrash established the grounds of righteousness before God; hagaddic midrash created the ethos for Jewish life.

[8] There are alternate readings in various manuscripts, but these are not likely to be original: D W {271} it sys and a few others omit ἐπὶ ᾿Αβιαθὰρ ἀρχιερέως, no doubt in conformity to the parallels in Matt 12:4 and Luke 6:4; {A C Θ Π Σ Φ 074 13 and many others} add τοῦ before ἀρχιερέως, giving the meaning in the days of Abiathar the high priest, suggesting a more general time frame. Neither reading has significant external support and both most likely are motivated by the difficulty of the original reading (NET).

[9] It is possible that what is currently understood to be the most natural reading of the text is in fact not correct. (a) There are very few biblical parallels to this grammatical construction (ἐπί + genitive proper noun, followed by an anarthrous common noun), so it is possible that an extensive search for this construction in nonbiblical literature would prove that the meaning does involve a wide time frame. If this is so, in the days of Abiathar the high priest would be a viable option. (b) It is also possible that this phrasing serves as a loose way to cite a scripture passage. There is a parallel to this construction in Mark 12:26: Have you not read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the bush? Here the final phrase is simply ἐπὶ τοῦ βάτου, but the obvious function of the phrase is to point to a specific passage within the larger section of scripture. (cf NET notes).

[10] When life is in danger, and whenever there is doubt whether life is in danger this overrides the Sabbath (m. Yoma 8.6; cf. b. Yoma 85a).

[11] Diminutive, but his frequent use of diminutives no particular force.

[12] ἐξῆλθον should not be a technical term for outsiders, since its also used for Jesus.

[13] Stein, however, argues that while Matt typically portrays the mountain as places of divine revelation, this is not so in Mark. Moreover, he also notes that the portrayal of Jesus as the new Moses, where his going up the mountain (Matt 5:12) // Moses going up the mountains, should not be read back into Mark.

[14] Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 100.

[15] But note that the RSV and NRSV translate it as when his family heard it, they went out to seize him, for people were saying, He is beside himself.

[16] There are only 2 major teachings of Jesus in Mark. Here, in 4:134, and in 13:337.

[17] The word ὅ can mean a certain part of the collective seed, i.e. some seed || a seed. Most likely it is part of the collective seed. (1) Matt uses the plural seeds throughout; (2) Hard to imagine a sower sowing total of 6 seeds; (3) Hard to imagine the birds coming together to eat 1 seed; (4) the interpretation in 4:1320 understands ὅ and ἄλλο as involving more than a single seed (Stein).

[18] Manifestations of the kingdom of God in Christ: Lepers are cleansed (1:4045); paralytics are raised (2:12); withered hands are restored (3:16); demoniacs are delivered (1:3234); prince of demons has met his master (3;2227); fasting gives way to feasting (2:1822); sinners and tax collectors are offered forgiveness (2:1317). See Stein.

[19] Comparative μικρότερον used as a superlative.

[20] Rabbinic writings consider it the smallest perceptible object (y. Ber. 5.8d, 3b; b. Ber. 31a; Lev. Rab. 31.9; m. Nid. 5.2; see also O. Michel, TDNT, 3:810n. 1).

[21] P. J. Achtemeier, JBL 89 (1970): 26591; JBL 91 (1972): 198221.

[22] See France, GP 1:10312.

[23] J. M. Hull, Magic, 67, 69.

[24] Jairus leadership position much weeping and wailing. Professional mourners would often be hired; flute players might be present and m. Ketubi 4.4: Even the poorest in Israel should hire no less than two flutes and one wailing woman [in such circumstances] (Stein).

[25] France considers failure of the disciples to be primary; Stein hints that Christological is primary.

[26] Jews reckon time according to 3 watches, Rome divided the night into 4 watches Mark written for Roman audience (Stein). Probably night time was from 6pm-6am. Thus, the 4th watch is just before dawn (3am-6am) [Lau].

[27] Barnett, Jesus and the Logic of History, 156. Mark tends to make a distinction between then (when Jesus was alive) and now, but its the asides that he uses to bridge the gap between then and now. Its the same situation as Mark 13:14 Let the reader understand.

[28] Not on the eastern side of the Sea of Galilee. 3 reasons: (1) Dalmanutha is probably on the western side given the presence of Pharisees; (2) no mention of crossing to the other side; (3) the subsequent journey from Dalmanutha to the other side (8:13) ends at Bethsaida (8:22), on the eastern side of the Sea of Galilee.

[29] Blomberg, Historical Reliability, 174.

[30] Marshall, New Testament Theology, 106.

[31] Walter Kaiser, Recovering the Unity of the Bible, 40.

[32] Norman Walker, After Three Days, NovT 4 (1960): 261-62.

[33] NIGTC, 1 Corinthians, 541.

[34] Craig Keener, And Marries Another: Divorce and Remarriage in the Teaching of the New Testament (Peabody: Hendrickson, 1991); and David Instone-Brewer, Divorce and Remarriage in the Bible: The Social and Literary Context (Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 2002).

[35] Blomberg, Historical Reliability, 170.

[36] The mountain east of Jerusalem is the Mount of Olives, see Ezek 11:23.

[37] However, Craig Evans, NT Use of the OT, New Dictionary of Biblical Theology, suggests, There is probably an allusion to the two commandments in combination in the Testaments of the Twelve Patriarchs: Each of you speaks the truth clearly to his neighbour ... Throughout all your life love the Lord and one another with a true heart (Testament of Dan 5:23); Love the Lord and the neighbour (Testament of Issachar 7:6); they are also linked by Philo: Among the great number of particular propositions and principles, two, as it were, stand as pre-eminent topics: one of duty toward God in piety and holiness, one of duty toward people in generosity and justice (On Special Laws 2.15 63).

[38] David Wenham, Rediscovery of Jesus Eschatological Discourse; Blomberg, Historical Reliability, 183.

[39] Barnett, Is the New Testament Reliable, 78.

[40] Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 227.

[41] Bauckahm, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 196.

[42] Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 189.

[43] Rhoads, 128, suggest that it was at the first instance of failure in Gethsemane that Jesus reverts to calling Peter Simon. But why here, because Peter has failed before, not least after Peters confession.

[44] Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses, 188.

[45] J. C. Vanderkam, From Joshua to Caiaphas: High Priests after the Exile (Minneapolis, Fortress, 2004), 478.

[46] Possibly Lucan emphasis that Jesus is a prophet.

[47] Darrell L. Bock, Blasphemy and Exaltation in Judaism: The Charges against Jesus in Mark 14:5365 (WUNT 2/105; Tbingen: Mohr-Siebeck, 1998).

[48] Some factors for consideration. The Romans made one concessionthat of being able to put to death any gentile who entered from the Court of the Gentiles into the inner court. The execution of James was an anomaly. This incident took place when the Roman governor/procurator was not in Judea. When the new Roman governor heard about it, he immediately removed the high priest responsible for this illegal act from the office of high priest (Josephus, Ant. 20.9.1).

[49] See Liv.Pro. Habakkuk 12 (And concerning the end of the Temple he predicted, By a western nation it will happen. At that time, he said, the curtain of the Dabeir [the Holy of Holies] will be torn into small pieces, and the capitals of the two pillars will be taken away and no one will know where they are; and they will be carried away by angels into the wilderness); and 2 Bar. 6:68 (And I saw him [the angel] descend into the Holy of Holies, and take from thence the veil, and the holy ark, and the mercy-seat, and the two tables, and the holy raiment of the priests, and the altar of incense, and the forty-eight precious stones, wherewith the priest was adorned and all the holy vessels of the tabernacle. And he spake to the earth with a loud voice: Earth, earth, earth, hear the word of the mighty God, And receive what I commit to thee, And guard them until the last times, So that, when thou art ordered, thou mayst restore them, So that strangers may not get possession of them).

[50] Bauckham, Jesus and the Eyewitnesses,125. See also Hengel, Saint Peter, 42.
